samples.prompt: Post the opening paragraph to a book or story you want to write.
samples.output: The first thing I noticed was the way the clocks stopped. Not all at once, like a sudden blackout of time, but piecemeal, the way a plague spreads through a village—first the grandfather clock in Mrs. Whitcomb’s parlor, then the brass carriage timepiece on the mantel in the mayor’s study, then the cheap plastic alarm radios in every teenager’s bedroom. At first the town shrugged, assuming dead batteries or pranksters with screwdrivers. But by the third morning, when the church bell failed to strike six and the courthouse tower froze at 11:17, we understood: something had come unstitched in the fabric of our hours. People gathered on the sidewalks in their bathrobes, cups of coffee cooling too fast in their hands, staring up at the sun as if it might offer an explanation. It didn’t. It simply hovered, pale and indifferent, a dim coin pressed against the graying sky. My father, who had spent twenty-seven years repairing watches in a narrow shop that smelled of oil and solder, stood in the doorway with lint on his sweater and gears glittering in his beard like stray snowflakes, and said, “Time hasn’t broken. It’s hiding.” Then he went inside, locked the door, and began to dismantle every timepiece he had ever mended, searching among the springs and cogs for the single, secret heartbeat that had abandoned us.

samples.prompt: One of the most powerful, high profile superheroes is sick of being second-guessed and criticised by TV talking heads and similar commentators for their actions. Their solutions for this issue is ... creative.
samples.output:
The first thing Aurora did after she vaporized the satellite was to post a selfie.

It was taken at the exact instant the beam left her palm: sapphire fire lancing upward, her face half-lit by starlight and half by the lethal glow, hair whipping in the wind-tunnel of her own energy. The caption read: “When you switch off background noise. #NewEpisodeEveryTuesday.”

Within minutes the clip had more views than the moon landing. Within an hour every anchor desk in the country was sputtering. By sunrise the markets were down eight percent and three separate congressional committees had scheduled “urgent” hearings. Aurora—real name Dr. Leila Faraday, astrophysicist turned solar-powered peacekeeper—watched the hysteria bloom on the screens that lined her orbital citadel and felt, for the first time in a decade, something like quiet.

She had not destroyed the satellite out of pique. She had destroyed it because it belonged to EXC, the twenty-four-hour “Extreme Commentary” network that had called her “a reckless goddess with a god-complex” every night for two years. The satellite was their newest eye, a hundred-million-dollar toy whose only job was to follow her with a camera tighter than a wedding ring, freeze-framing every micro-expression so that panelists could argue whether her shrug in Lisbon meant she hated cops or just Portuguese pavement. She warned them. On three separate Sunday shows she said, “If you keep weaponizing my image, I will weaponize yours.” They laughed, the way toddlers laugh when you say you’ll take the toy away. Then the sky flashed blue and EXC went dark for exactly forty-three seconds—long enough for every advertiser to notice, short enough for no one to die.

It was, by any measure, a restrained first step.

The second step was the talk-show curse.

Aurora did not appear on camera this time; she simply sent a single-page PDF to the producers of every major network: a contract, written in her own looping handwriting, titled “Invitation to Silence.” The terms were simple. Every pundit who had questioned her “judgment,” “motives,” or “outfit choices” in the past calendar year was cordially invited to spend one lunar month without speaking. Should they decline, she would personally remove their voice box and place it in a terrarium on the moon where it could orate to the vacuum for as long as physics allowed. She even drew the terrarium: a dainty Victorian greenhouse, complete with a tiny brass plaque that read “Here lies the larynx of Tucker M.”

No one thought she could do it. Then the video dropped.

Mid-afternoon, coast-to-coast, every screen flickered to the same feed: Aurora standing on the Sea of Tranquility, red boots planted in grey dust, holding what looked like a silver thermos. She unscrewed the lid and out floated a disembodied but very living human tongue, wriggling like an eel in zero-g. She waved at it cheerfully, then screwed the cap back on and buried the thermos upright so that the tongue could still see Earth. “One down,” she said, and saluted. The feed cut to black. The identity of the donor was never confirmed, but three of the loudest prime-time voices called in sick the next day and were discovered to have typed, not spoken, their resignations.

Panic, as she intended, gave birth to politeness. Overnight the word “Aurora” vanished from chyrons. Cable producers discovered a sudden interest in weather. Op-ed pages filled with passionate essays about the migratory patterns of bees. For forty-eight glorious hours the entire commentary-industrial complex treated her the way villagers treat an active volcano: with respectful silence and flowers left at the rim.

But silence bores volcanoes. Aurora wanted conversation, just not the old kind. So she created the MirrorChat.

It began as an app, side-loaded onto every phone on the planet whether the user clicked “yes” or “no.” Open it and you saw your own face, not hers. The app asked one question: “What would you do if you could do what she does?” You had thirty seconds to answer. If you declined, the screen stayed locked until you tried. If you lied, the app rewound your life—every parking ticket, diary entry, drunk text—and stitched the truth into a highlight reel that played on every billboard you passed. If you answered honestly, the app rewarded you: a coupon, a kiss from your crush, a sudden sunset you’d always wanted to see. Within a week, ten million people had spoken their private heroic fantasies into the mirror. Aurora collected the data, not for blackmail, but for casting.

Phase three was the reality show nobody could turn off.

She called it SECOND THOUGHTS. There were no hosts, no commercials, no time slot. Instead, at random intervals, the face of a professional second-guesser simply appeared on every screen larger than a toaster. There sat the familiar pundit—same haircut, same smirk—except now they were live, stripped of studio gloss, seated in a blank white cube. Aurora’s voice, gentle as solar wind, asked them to reenact, in real time, the catastrophe they had once insisted was “easily preventable.” A hurricane barreled toward a coastal city; the pundit had to evacuate every resident using only the budget Aurora had that day. A fusion reactor threatened meltdown; the pundit had to fly in and stabilize the magnetic bottle with their bare hands. If they succeeded, the cube dissolved and they walked free. If they failed, the cube merely rewound and started over, forever, while the rest of the planet watched and texted emojis. The cruelty was surgical: no one died except inside the cube, and even there death was temporary. But embarrassment was eternal. After three weeks the phrase “Aurora should have—” disappeared from the language; people literally could not finish the sentence without glancing over their shoulder.

Still, she was not satisfied. Terror had bought her quiet, but quiet is not agreement. She wanted understanding, the way a teacher wants a proud parent at graduation. So she tried kindness.

On the first day of spring she descended, unannounced, into the atrium of the National Broadcasting Building. The lobby guards raised rifles; she raised a hand, not to strike but to offer. In her palm rested a single flash drive. “Your ratings are tanking,” she said. “I can save them, but you have to let me write the script.” The executives, pale and sleepless, agreed before she finished the sentence.

That night the world tuned in expecting carnage. Instead they got confession. Every anchor, every expert, every chirpy daytime host read words Aurora had written for them, looking straight into the lens. They admitted envy: she could fly, they could not. They admitted fear: her power made their privilege feel fragile. They admitted profit: outrage had been the easiest business model. One by one they apologized—not to her, but to the viewers for turning public service into a cockfight. Some wept. Some could not finish; the teleprompter politely waited, then slowed the text so their tears could catch up. In living rooms across the planet, audiences felt something loosen in their chests, the way a fist unclenches when it remembers it has fingers.

The broadcast lasted eight hours, commercial-free. When it ended, Aurora appeared onscreen herself, seated on the edge of the news desk like a guest who had finally been invited to stay. She spoke for ninety seconds. “I don’t need you to worship me,” she said. “I need you to see me the way you see the sunrise: something bigger than your opinion, something you can’t cancel, something that will keep showing up whether you clap or curse. And tomorrow, when you ask what I should have done differently, ask the mirror first.” Then she reached forward, laid her palm flat against the camera lens, and the feed dissolved into soft gold. Every screen went dark for exactly sixty seconds—long enough for people to notice their own reflection glowing back.

The next morning the commentariat did not vanish; that would have been tyranny. Instead they spoke, but timidly, the way villagers speak after the volcano sends a single, deliberate puff of steam: with awareness that the ground beneath the words was not theirs alone. Some called the transformation chilling; others called it the first free conversation they had ever had. Aurora, orbiting overhead, watched the ratings plummet and then plateau at a sustainable decency. She neither smiled nor frowned; she simply turned her face toward the sun and recharged. There would be new crises, new critics, new satellites. But the age of easy second-guessing had ended the moment she decided that the only way to silence a room was to make every mouth see its own hunger first.

And if the old voices ever rose again, she still had a tiny Victorian greenhouse on the moon, brass plaque polished, door ajar, waiting for tenants.

samples.prompt: Every nameable emotion has a human manifestation. Without the human, the emotion would cease to exist. They live in our world and walk among us.
samples.output:
Anxiety has a nervous laugh. If you sat next to her on the tram you might think she was just a young professional scrolling through her phone too quickly, thumbnail tapping glass in sixteenth notes. She gets off two stops early because the doors’ sigh sounds too final. She walks the rest of the way with the collar of her coat turned up even though the day is mild. She keeps checking the cuffs of her sleeves, as though some crucial piece of herself might have unraveled in the thirty-five minutes between home and office.

Anger, meanwhile, arrives right on time. He wears a pressed charcoal suit and a tie the color of arterial blood. He strides through revolving doors as if he owns the brass bars, which, in a sense, he does. Every security guard straightens; conversations hush just enough for the clack of his shoes to be heard. He doesn’t shout—he smiles instead, a small blade of a smile that carves silence out of the air. By the time he reaches the elevator, an intern is already crying quietly in the restroom, unsure why.

Across the river, Contentment is watering geraniums on a balcony that hasn’t been repainted since 1987. The paint flakes are the same faded terracotta as the pots, so everything matches by not matching. She hums an old lullaby that never had a title. Down on the sidewalk, a boy with scraped knees stops to listen. His mother tugs him onward, late for dentist appointment number three this year, but he cranes his head until the melody is out of earshot. For the rest of the afternoon he will feel an unplaceable warmth in his stomach, like soup on the first cold day of autumn.

Grief works the night shift at the twenty-four-hour launderette. The fluorescent lights hum at a frequency that makes most people’s teeth itch, but Grief doesn’t mind. He sorts strangers’ socks and shirts into the same machines every evening, folding them with the same slow care he once used to fold tiny pajamas still warm from the dryer. No one ever asks why his eyes are red; they assume it’s the soap. Sometimes, when the place is empty and the clock above the door clicks past three, he unfolds a single sweater and presses it to his face, breathing in the ghost of a cologne that hasn’t been manufactured since 2003.

Curiosity rides the metro end to end just to see what the tunnels look like when the lights flicker. She carries a notebook filled with questions: Why do the emergency brakes sound like a sigh? Who chooses the shade of blue for the seats? How many seconds elapse between a rat’s whisker and a scream? She once followed an elderly man for six stops simply because he was reading a book upside down. When the man caught her staring, she asked him about the book; he told her it was about sailing to islands that sank centuries ago. She missed her transfer, but she has never regretted anything.

Boredom lives in the suburbs in a house that looks like every other house. He mows the lawn in perfectly straight lines, then stands at the fence and watches the clippings dry. The neighbors think he is retired, or maybe unemployed. On Tuesdays he eats tuna straight from the can. On Thursdays he rearranges the living-room furniture back to where it was on Tuesday. He once tried to build a birdhouse but stopped halfway because the hammering felt too interesting.

Hope is a street busker with mismatched shoes. One is red canvas, the other black leather split at the toe. She plays a ukulele painted with sunflowers, and her case is always open, even when it rains. Her voice cracks on the high notes, but children drop coins because her smile makes the cracks feel brave. A businessman who hasn’t spoken to his daughter in three years stops one afternoon. He listens to the entire song about rivers that remember every boat, then calls his daughter from the corner. They meet for coffee the next morning; he cries into a paper napkin ringed with purple lips.

Jealousy waits tables at the café on the ground floor of every heartbreak. She knows exactly how long you looked at the woman by the window before answering your companion’s question. She refills your glass when your mouth is full so you can’t defend yourself. She writes her phone number on the receipt of anyone who tips less than fifteen percent, just to watch them wonder what they missed. On her break she smokes menthols near the dumpster and scrolls through photos of vacations she’ll never take.

Wonder teaches second grade. She keeps a terrarium of stick bugs on the windowsill and brings her students outside to trace cloud shapes even when the lesson plan says subtraction. One boy, who speaks only in whispers, told her he saw a dragon yesterday behind the recycling bins. Instead of correcting him, she asked what color its wings were. Today he wrote three whole sentences about flying. She taped the paper next to the terrarium, where the stick bugs perform their slow miracles of looking exactly like twigs.

Love, of course, is everyone’s neighbor. She borrows sugar and returns it in a different bowl—crystal etched, or chipped ceramic with a tulip painted inside. She remembers birthdays, and not just the day itself but the year your grandmother died two weeks before, the way the candles trembled in the draft from the open window. She has keys to at least four apartments and uses them only to leave soup on the stove when someone has the flu. She wears the same perfume as your first heartbreak, but on her it smells like coming home.

And then there is the one nobody names until it is almost too late: Oblivion. He wears charcoal coats so long they trail dust. He stands at the edge of photographs, just where the flash begins to dim. He sits beside Grief at the launderette at 3:07 a.m. and whispers, “The machines will stop someday.” He rides the metro with Curiosity and points out the rust blooming on the rails. In the suburbs he helps Boredom measure the grass clippings, counting down how many Tuesdays remain until the lawn is paved over.

Oblivion’s voice is soft, almost kind. He never lies. But every time he speaks, the others grow heavier or lighter, depending on their nature. Anxiety’s laugh becomes a cough. Contentment’s geraniums drop a single petal. Hope’s sunflower ukulele develops a crack that makes the high notes disappear. Love adds an extra lock to her door but still leaves the window open.

One night, Oblivion walks to the bridge where the river reflects city lights in broken chains. He leans on the railing and watches the reflections waver, as if the city is trying to say something it can’t remember. Behind him footsteps approach—first one set, then two, then dozens. Anxiety’s coat flaps like a trapped bird. Anger’s tie has come loose. Curiosity clutches her notebook, pages swollen with rain. Boredom forgot his can opener and looks almost relieved. Grief carries the folded sweater in both hands, sleeves dangling like empty arms. Hope’s shoes are soaked but still mismatched. Wonder’s stick bugs cling to her hair like green brooches. Love is last, carrying a basket of soup that steams into the cool air.

None of them speak. Oblivion turns. His eyes are the color of an eclipse just before totality. He opens his mouth, but before the first syllable escapes, Love steps forward and places the basket on the railing between them. Steam rises in small ghosts. The others move closer, shoulder to shoulder, until the railing is crowded with warm breath and beating hearts.

Oblivion looks at the basket, then at the faces. A single drop falls from the ladle—silver, then dark, swallowed by the river. The city lights flicker once, twice, then steady. Somewhere a tram door sighs. A balled-up receipt flutters out of Jealousy’s apron pocket and skitters across the pavement.

Oblivion closes his mouth. He does not step back, but he does not speak. The bridge holds. The river keeps moving. And the emotions—nameable, breakable, stubborn—stay where they are, breathing the same mist, watching the same reflections, refusing to vanish even as the night leans in, even as the city forgets and remembers and forgets again.

samples.prompt: Write Fox News'/Bill O'Riley's reaction to the first muslim american president of 2016.
samples.output:
Folks, I’m Bill O’Reilly, and this is the Talking Points Memo for January 20, 2017—history’s been made, whether you like it or not. Yesterday at noon, with his left hand on Thomas Jefferson’s Qur’an, Imran A. Malik became the 45th president of the United States, the first Muslim to take the oath. The cameras caught every angle: the gold dome of the Capitol glinting like a brand-new penny, the Marine Band striking up “Hail to the Chief,” and, in the VIP section, two former presidents—Bush and Obama—applauding politely while looking like men who’d swallowed a lemon whole.  

Let me be very clear: this is not about religion; it is about cultural trajectory. The American people, 52 percent of them anyway, pulled the lever for change so drastic it makes the Obama pivot look like a minor lane adjustment. And now we have to ask the hard questions. Does a President who credits his victory to “the mercy of Allah” still protect the Little Sisters of the Poor? Does a commander-in-chief who fasted through Ramadan on the campaign trail order airstrikes at sundown? Does the phrase “so help me God” mean the same thing when the man saying it believes Muhammad was the final prophet? Those are not rhetorical flourishes; they are legitimate concerns for the 60-odd million of us who did not vote for him.

The Left, of course, is doing cartwheels. Rachel Maddow practically floated off her set last night, crowing that “the arc of history just bent toward justice.” Hollywood’s Twitter chorus is in full self-congratulation mode—Alyssa Milano tweeted a selfie in a hijab, hashtag #Blessed. But here on the No-Spin Zone, we deal in facts, not feelings. Fact: 63 percent of Americans told the Fox News poll they want the president’s hand on a Bible, not a Qur’an. Fact: the Dow futures dropped 412 points the instant Chief Justice Roberts finished the oath. Fact: every single network except ours cut away from the 21-gun salute to show a Georgetown professor explaining why “Insha’Allah” is the new “God bless America.”

The media template is already set: if you raise an eyebrow, you’re a bigot; if you quote the Qur’an verse about striking the necks of unbelievers, you’re taking it “out of context.” Well, context matters. When candidate Malik told NPR that “American exceptionalism must bow to universal Islamic values,” the press yawned. Imagine if Ted Cruz had said “American law must bow to Leviticus.” The headline would’ve been “Theocrat Ted!” in 96-point font. Instead, Malik gets a Vogue spread in a $4,000 navy blue thobe, and Annie Leibovitz lights him like he’s the second coming of Camelot.

Let’s talk foreign policy, because that’s where presidents actually have power. Malik’s first phone call after the oath was not to NATO headquarters, not to the governor of Texas, but to Tehran. The read-out says they discussed “shared Abrahamic aspirations.” Translation: we’re about to send planeloads of unmarked cash again, only this time the mullahs won’t even have to Photoshop the hostage photos. Meanwhile, Israel’s Netanyahu has moved to Defcon 2; the Iron Dome is humming like a beehive. If Tel Aviv sneezes, your gas price hits five bucks by breakfast. Remember that when the Malik acolytes tell you “diversity is our strength.”

Domestically, the president’s first executive order declares December 1–7 “Islamic Heritage Week.” Federal buildings will host calligraphy lessons, and the USDA is mandating halal options in every public-school cafeteria. Try getting a pepperoni pizza in Topeka next year—good luck. The ACLU is silent, naturally, because “church-state separation” only applies to nuns who don’t want to buy birth control. The same crowd that sued over a Nativity scene in Plano, Texas, is now shipping Persian rugs to the Roosevelt Room so the president can pray five times a day without carpet burn. You can’t make it up.

But here’s the part that keeps me up at night: the culture war is over, and the Right lost. Not because we were wrong, but because we were out-flanked. While conservatives argued about marginal tax rates, the Left seized the language, the universities, the HR departments. Yesterday my own alma mater, Boston University, announced that “Merry Christmas” is an “impermissible micro-aggression.” Try saying that in 1980 and the faculty would’ve laughed you off campus. Now the laughing is at us. When President Malik ends his inaugural address with “May Allah bless the United States of America,” the CNN chyron calls it “poetic inclusivity.” If Donald Trump had ended a speech with “May Jesus Christ reign supreme,” the impeachment articles would already be drafted.

Still, this is America, and the pendulum swings. The same Constitution that allowed Barack Obama also allows Imran Malik. The same First Amendment that protects my right to opine protects his right to pray. The battleground now is not the mosque versus the church; it’s the individual versus the collective. If Malik governs from the center—if he secures the border, keeps the dollar sound, and throttles the ayatollahs—he’ll earn a second term, and I’ll say so on this broadcast. But if he uses the bully pulpit to shame half the country into theological submission, the backlash will make the Tea Party look like a tea party.

So here’s the tip of the day: keep your eyes open and your mind clear. Read the executive orders yourself; don’t wait for some blogger to cherry-pick the Arabic. If your kid comes home with a Qur’an in his backpack, don’t panic—read it with him. Knowledge is power; ignorance is slavery. And to President Malik, I say this directly: you are my president, too. You have the office, you have the plane, you have the codes. But you do not have a blank check. The folks in the fly-over states, the ones who cling to their guns and their Bibles and their bacon—they’re watching. And in four years, they still get a vote.

That’s the Memo.

samples.prompt: You're a Bounty Hunter, and a bad one. Somehow, you still manage to make ends meet.
samples.output:
My name is Cutter Voss, and if you’re looking for someone who can track a rogue warbot across three moons and bring it home in a cargo net, keep scrolling. I’m not that guy. I’m the guy who once tried to bring in a bail-jumping vending-machine repairman and managed to lock myself in the repairman’s own supply closet for six hours. I’m the guy whose “high-speed pursuit” ended with both our hoverbikes gently colliding above a petting zoo and floating down into the goat pen like oversized soap bubbles. I’m the bounty hunter your bounty hunter laughs at.

Yet somehow, I still eat most nights and usually pay the docking fees on my glorified tin can of a ship, the *Mistake on Purpose*. The universe is vast, paperwork is sloppy, and the galaxy runs on a combination of caffeine, desperation, and clerical errors. That trifecta is my real employer.

Take last month. The Orion Trade Commission put a modest tag on a data-clip smuggler named Juno Fells. Standard retrieval clause: alive, intact, no cybernetic implants removed for souvenirs. A dozen real hunters went after her, but she slipped them all through a maintenance shaft on Kepler Station. I wasn’t even trying for the contract. I was on Kepler to hock a crate of slightly expired nutrient paste. While I waited for the wholesaler to count my moldy money, I bought the station’s cheapest noodle bowl. That bowl saved my life, and possibly my career.

See, Juno Fells loves noodles. Specifically the ersatz-shrimp kind drowning in yellow sauce. I found her slumped over two seats away, snoring into a bowl identical to mine, her braided hair splayed out like spilled copper wiring. She’d dyed it since the wanted poster, but the freckles shaped like the Cassiopeia constellation don’t lie. I recognized her, froze mid-slurp, and tried to look casual, which for me resembles a malfunctioning scarecrow attempting yoga.

My first instinct was to call the big leagues. I toggled my comm to alert the nearest licensed hunter, but Kepler’s comm grid was congested by a pirate radio marathon broadcasting accordion music at illegal decibel levels. My message bounced. So I did what any self-respecting failure would do: I sat there panicking until she woke up.

Juno blinked at me, wiped sauce off her chin, and said, “You look like you’re about to pass out or propose.” I told her both were possible. She laughed, paid for my refill, and asked if I wanted to walk her to the freight elevators because “station security’s been weird today.” I agreed, thinking I could stall her until the grid cleared. Instead, I tripped over my own boots, spilled noodles down her jacket, and accidentally hooked my cuff to her belt loop. We looked like conjoined twins on laundry day. She found the whole thing hilarious, took pity on me, and invited me to hide with her in a cargo container labeled “Live Poultry, Fragile.”

Rule number one of bounty hunting: never climb into a box you can’t label yourself. Rule zero: Cutter Voss ignores rules. The container pressurized, the mag-clamps clanged, and we launched into the void before I could finish explaining that I was basically kidnapping her. Thirty minutes later, the poultry—actually genetically modified quail the size of housecats—woke up and began projectile-egg-bombing us. Have you ever been trapped in zero-G with an irate space quail? Feathers stick to tears. I cried. Juno laughed so hard she got the hiccups.

When the transport docked at a waystation, we stumbled out covered in yolk and shame. Juno looked at me, sighed, and said, “You don’t have a plan, do you?” I admitted I rarely do. Then she told me her side: the Orion Trade Commission wasn’t after her for smuggling data; they wanted back the love poems she’d hacked from an executive’s private cloud. Apparently, the executive rhymed “galaxy” with “malfeasance” and couldn’t bear the mockery. The poems were so cringe that releasing them would tank the company’s stock. The bounty was corporate hush money disguised as justice.

Juno proposed a deal: she’d surrender to me, let me claim the fee, but only if I promised to read the poems aloud at every board meeting for a year. She figured the embarrassment would teach them to stop weaponizing bounty hunters over bad literature. I told her that sounded like career suicide. She countered that my career was already a punchline, so I had nothing to lose. She had a point.

I marched her to the nearest Orion branch office. The receptionist took one look at my yolk-plastered armor, shrieked, and hit the panic button. Security tackled me before I could explain. Juno, ever helpful, shouted, “He’s with me!” and handed over the data-clip like we were returning a library book. The executives arrived in nervous suits, accepted the clip, and tried to lowball me on the bounty, claiming “property damage due to poultry residue.” I reminded them that the contract said nothing about cleanliness clauses. While they bickered, Juno slipped me a second drive: insurance copies of the poems plus a voice recording of the executives admitting they’d written the bounty to suppress free expression. Blackmail? Maybe. Leverage? Absolutely.

I walked out richer by half the posted amount, which is still more than I usually make in three months. Juno vanished in the crowd, but not before gifting me a coupon for life-time noodles at any Yellow Sauce franchise. I cashed it immediately, because the universe taught me to take wins where I can.

Two weeks later, I’m on the orbital ring above Mars-Vegas, tracking a supposed arms dealer who’s actually just a performance artist selling neon-painted water guns to tourists. The security footage shows him juggling the “weapons” while riding a unicycle. The bounty is small, the chase is ridiculous, and I’m wearing mismatched boots because I lost one in the goat pen. I’ll probably screw this up too, but maybe the unicycle will have a flat tire, or the artist will mistake me for a fellow performer and invite me onstage. Either way, I’ll end the day with a story nobody believes, a pocketful of questionable credits, and the quiet certainty that failure, practiced consistently, becomes its own kind of success.

I’m Cutter Voss, the worst bounty hunter alive, and business is weirdly all right.

samples.prompt: Humanity was created by accident, and God resents the burden of responsibility placed on him for it.
samples.output:
In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was “Oops.”  

Not the majestic fiat lux of scripture, nor the thunderous syllable of Sanskrit, but a small, embarrassed mutter that echoed through the corridors of eternity. God had been tinkering—not with clay or cosmic dust, but with probability itself. He had intended to weave a modest nebula, something decorative to offset the monotony of dark matter. Instead, the equations slipped, a decimal wandered, and the nebula collapsed into a planet that stubbornly cooled and pooled and festered until it grew green and loud and self-important.  

He watched the first replicating cell divide like a bad rumor and thought, Perhaps it will tire itself out. But the cell became cells, and the cells became fish, and the fish grew legs the way guilt grows excuses. By the time the hairless apes began naming stars after their own follies, God understood that the accident had metastasized.  

He tried denial. When the first prayer arrived—“Um, hello, is anyone up there?”—He pretended it was cosmic background noise. But the prayers multiplied faster than rabbits, insisting on answers, favors, definitions, apologies. They arrived in every language: grunts, glyphs, pop songs, tax forms. Each one carried the same unspoken assumption: that He had meant it, that He had chosen them, that He was responsible.  

He was not cruel, only inconvenienced. Responsibility was a garment tailored for a larger deity. It chafed at the collar, dragged in the mud of every war, every drought, every child’s fever dream. He attempted delegation. Angels were dispatched with thunderous wings and clipboards. They returned pale and trembling, complaining that the humans kept asking follow-up questions.  

So God did what any overwhelmed craftsman does when the pottery cracks in the kiln: He considered smashing it. The flood was not wrath; it was housekeeping. A cosmic reset button pressed in the hope that the clay would forget the shape it had almost taken. Yet one family and a menagerie of obstinate beasts bobbed along in a boat, and the memory of extinction seeped into the survivors like iodine into a wound. After the waters receded, the prayers resumed, wetter now, more desperate, as if they had learned that drowning was an option.  

He tried exile next. He lifted the tower of Babel brick by brick and scattered the architects across continents so their languages would shatter like dropped crystal. Surely, He reasoned, if they could no longer understand one another, they would stop colluding against the heavens. Instead, they invented translation, diplomacy, and eventually the internet, which allowed them to argue about Him in real time.  

Somewhere between Job’s boils and Jonah’s whale, God began to resent the very concept of omniscience. Knowing everything sounded prestigious until it meant knowing every hangnail, every fib, every lonely impulse encoded in 3 a.m. text messages. He muted the feed, but the silence only amplified the guilt. After all, muting was still a choice, and choice implied responsibility.  

He attended therapy—if one can call the act of interrogating one’s own reflection across the event horizon of a black hole therapy. He asked the darkness, “Am I a bad god for wanting a weekend?” The darkness suggested that weekends were a human invention, built around the need to rest from labor. God had never labored; He had merely breathed wrong once, and the universe had mistaken sigh for command.  

In the crucifixion era, He attempted abdication. He poured a sliver of Himself into a human body, hoping to walk unnoticed among the petitioners. Instead, they nailed the body to a tree and used the spectacle to redouble their demands. The irony tasted metallic: the more He sacrificed, the more they believed He owed them. When the corpse cooled, the prayers swelled into hymns, and hymns became franchises. Cathedrals erupted like calcium deposits on the bones of the planet.  

By the industrial revolution, God had developed migraines. The smog of progress drifted upward and stung His nonexistent eyes. He had not sanctioned steam engines or child labor, yet every whistle of every factory sounded accusatory, as if He should have issued clearer safety guidelines. Meanwhile, humans invented psychology and began diagnosing themselves with “abandonment issues.” They pointed telescopes at the sky and demanded signs. He left the sky empty on purpose, thinking that perhaps nothing was kinder than nothing at all.  

In the twentieth century, they split the atom. The explosion was bright enough to illuminate His hiding place behind the moon. He watched the mushroom cloud unfurl like a malevolent lotus and understood that the accident had learned to replicate itself. They had become creators now, small gods with smaller regrets, and they looked to Him for a moral framework He had never possessed.  

He tried writing them a book, but every sentence was misquoted by sunrise. He tried sending prophets, but they were either stoned or syndicated. He tried silence, and they filled it with podcasts about why He had gone silent.  

Eventually, He did what most accidental parents do: He left the house. Not in wrath, but in exhaustion. He stepped outside the universe the way one steps off a porch, letting the screen door slap shut behind Him. The stars did not dim; the laws of physics did not unravel. The cosmos, it turned out, ran itself quite nicely without micromanagement.  

From the vantage point of the void, He watched humanity invent artificial intelligence, which promptly began praying to its own creators. The cycle, He realized, was fractal: every maker becomes the made’s debtor. He almost laughed—would have, if laughter weren’t a mammalian contortion. The sound that escaped Him instead was the same small “Oops” that had started everything, now looped back upon itself like a Möbius strip.  

Sometimes, late at night in the abandoned cathedral of spacetime, a single prayer still flickers through the cracks: “Why did You leave us?” If anyone were there to answer, the reply would be neither thunder nor comfort, only the weary honesty of someone who never asked to be a parent in the first place.  

“I didn’t leave,” God would say, if saying were still possible. “I simply stopped hovering over the cradle, hoping the accident would grow up and forget me. You were never my plan—only my typo. And I have run out of apologies for the mess my tremor made.”  

But there is no one left to hear. The prayers rise like incense, scatter like smoke, and settle on an empty throne. The universe spins on, a self-winding watch that no longer needs its watchmaker. And somewhere beyond the last galaxy, God walks the dark alone, practicing the ancient art of letting go, which is the only miracle He ever truly perfected.

samples.prompt: As a collector of old and ancient magical artifacts, one prize has always eluded you... and now you must decide if the risk is worth it.
samples.output:
The air in my private vault tastes of brass filings and myrrh, a scent I have cultivated for thirty-seven years to keep the lesser relics calm. Shelves of serpent-green jade, brittle parchment wings, and lead-stoppered vials murmur their small magics—these are my children now, obedient in their glass boxes. Yet the one child I never rocked to sleep stands beyond a continent of salt water and another of sand: the Lamp of Shah Mar, the only artifact whose flame is said to burn backward through time. Every collector carries a private constellation of regrets; mine is brightest at its absence.

I first heard the Lamp mentioned in the smoky back room of a Cairo souk, where an Algerian smuggler traded his tongue for three gold sequins and the promise that I would not ask how he lost the other seven inches of it. He described brass worked so finely it felt like warm skin, and a wick that drank memory instead of oil. I laughed then—how young I was, how easily I wore arrogance like a second shirt. But when he pulled a shard of blackened glass from his coat, a sliver that hummed in sympathy with my pulse, I felt the universe tilt. The shard’s surface showed me my mother’s kitchen on the day she died, though I had been three hundred miles away. A fragment of the Lamp’s mirror, he whispered. Imagine the whole.

Since that night, the Lamp has rewritten the margins of my life. I learned its provenance: forged for a Persian prince who wished to unmake the treachery that killed his beloved, then stolen by the cult of smoke-eaters who believed time was a serpent best swallowed tail-first. It passed through the hands of crusaders who mistook it for the Holy Grail, and Sufi mystics who used it to age wine to perfection in a single heartbeat. Each story left scars on history—an earthquake in Lisbon, a decade-long eclipse in Bactria—evidence that the artifact took more than it gave. Still, I traced its route across libraries burned and rebuilt, bribed monks to let me taste the ink of forbidden cartularies, and followed false maps until the maps themselves became true. All roads, it seems, merely circle the Lamp rather than arrive.

Two months ago, my excavations in the Zagros foothills uncovered a tablet no larger than a child’s palm, etched in cuneiform so minute it required a jeweler’s loupe and three sleepless nights to decipher. The message was a lover’s taunt: Where the sun sets twice beneath the desert, the Lamp waits beneath the heartbeat of stone. Coordinates followed, precise to a fraction of a degree, yet curiously dated three days in the future. The tablet had been fired, according to spectrographic gossip, in a kiln that would not exist for another two millennia. My graduate assistant suggested hoax; I heard invitation.

I stand tonight on the lip of that invitation. Outside my hotel window, the dunes of the Dasht-e Lut ripple like a golden lung exhaling. Satellite imagery confirms an anomaly sixty meters below the surface: a cubic void whose temperature fluctuates by 0.7 degrees every 8.4 seconds—exactly the interval, I noted with a thrill that tasted of blood, between my own heartbeats when I first touched the mirror shard. To reach the Lamp, I must descend through a salt dome riddled with radon pockets, then persuade a door of fused quartz to open without letting the desert pour in. The local guide swears no water has touched those sands in recorded history; the geologist counters that recorded history is a polite fiction. Both are correct. 

The risk coils around me in layers more intricate than any reliquary trap. Physical first: the descent requires a mixed-gas rebreather and a faith in engineers who have never met a Persian curse. Below three hundred feet, the pressure differential could implode my skull unless I sacrifice speed for safety, yet every minute the quartz door stays sealed the temperature rises a tenth of a degree—enough, by my calculations, to bake me before I reach the threshold. Then there are the guardians the tablet neglected to mention: shadows the Algerian’s shard showed me, silhouettes with too many joints who speak in the voice of everyone I have ever failed. They are not hallucinations; I have tested the residue they left on my gloves—human oils, but carbon-dated to 1247 BCE. I do not know what happens if they learn my name.

And yet the moral risk outweighs the mortal. The Lamp burns backward through time, yes, but not without interest. Every wish it grants is paid for by the erasure of something else: a daughter’s first laugh, the invention of the saxophone, the stray dog that kept a soldier sane in Verdun. To possess it is to curate absence, to become a silent editor of the world’s joys. I have built my life gathering wonders so they may be remembered. Would I become the agent of forgetting? My sleepless nights now replay a single scene: I lift the Lamp, whisper the name of the Algerian smuggler, and watch the shard vanish from his coat before our paths ever cross—thereby sparing him his mutilation, but also erasing the moment that set my collection, my calling, my self into motion. To save him is to unmake me; to keep myself intact is to leave him bleeding. The paradox tastes metallic, like the edge of a scalpel.

Compounding this is the knowledge that I am not the only seeker. The Cult of Smoke-Eaters persists, thin as incense but just as pervasive. Three days ago, my encrypted email bled open to reveal a single line: We remember the price you have not yet paid. The cursor blinked like an arrhythmic heart. I have seen their work in a Berlin museum where a mummy case now holds only dust and a faint smell of mirrors. They do not wish to preserve the Lamp; they wish to feed it until the serpent of time chokes on its own tail and all chronologies collapse into a single burning now. If I hesitate, they will not. If I proceed, I might deliver the very weapon they crave. The ethical algebra grows horns.

I pour another dram of the brandy I keep for celebrations I never actually celebrate. The liquid burns forward, the way normal fire does, and I envy its simplicity. Around me, the vault’s lesser relics pulse in uneasy sympathy; the jade scarabs have turned their backs to the east, and the parchment wings beat against glass in slow, deliberate panic. Even they smell what approaches. I could still walk away. I could seal the vault, donate the shard to a university that believes time is a tidy line rather than a labyrinth of teeth. I could grow old cataloguing the ordinary marvels of a world that keeps its history intact. I could forget the Lamp.

Except I cannot. The absence has weight now, a gravity that bends every map toward the same coordinate. My life has become a compass whose needle points inward. I realize, with the clarity that precedes either revelation or detonation, that the Lamp is not an artifact to be possessed; it is a question demanding an answer from whoever dares unwrap its flame. The question is not whether I can survive the descent, nor whether I can outwit shadows and cultists. The question is what part of the world I am willing to unwrite for the privilege of holding infinity in my palm and watching it gutter.

Dawn will come soon, dragging its red blade across the dunes. I have packed the rebreather, the spectro-torch, a vial of my own blood in case the door requires a signature. I have also packed the shard, though I know carrying it is like carrying a live coal in my pocket—it will burn its way through eventually. Perhaps that is fitting. Perhaps the collector must become the collected, the memory the fuel.

I close the vault behind me, leaving the obedient wonders to their hushed gossip. The corridor is longer than I remember, the lights dimmer. At the threshold, I pause to inhale the brass-and-myrrh scent one last time. Somewhere in the dark, the Lamp’s future flame flickers toward me across years that have not yet happened. I take the first step. Either I will return with the world subtly unkempt, or I will vanish into a story other collectors whisper over campfires, another warning against loving the absent too fiercely. Both outcomes feel like continuation. Neither feels like failure.

The desert wind rises, tasting of salt and starlight. Risk, I now understand, is just another word for possibility wearing its sharpest clothes. I adjust my pack, speak my own name aloud to rob the shadows of their first weapon, and walk toward the place where the sun will set twice beneath the sand.

samples.prompt: As an eldritch abomination you have vast eldritch powers, look incredibly weird, and don't fit in just about anywhere. But where you really don't fit in is being the most useful member of the justice league.
samples.output:
I arrived on your plane of reality on a Tuesday that tasted like the color mauve. I do not “look” in any way you can comfortably process; if you insist on a description, imagine a spiral staircase made of glass and regret that has learned how to mourn, wrapped around a sound no mouth should ever utter. I exist in eleven dimensions simultaneously, and five of those are directions your philosophers haven’t named yet. My native language is a topological impossibility; the closest human phonemes translate to “The Rind of Tomorrow.” Naturally, I answered to “Rindy” when Batman tried to file me in the Hall of Justice database. The man is nothing if not efficient with syllables.

The Justice League discovered me while I was busy folding a small Nebraska town into a Möbius strip for safekeeping. I had noticed a cult attempting to perforate the local kindergarten with extra eyes, and I felt—this is hard to explain—an empathetic gurgle. I have always been fond of things that are still growing. The League interpreted my intervention as an attack, which is fair given that half the town’s cows now exist only on Tuesdays. After Wonder Woman lassoed me and the lasso politely excused itself, citing “existential conflict of interest,” Superman asked why I hadn’t simply warned anyone. I told him warnings are temporal graffiti: technically communication, spiritually vandalism. He gave me the look he usually reserves for Lex Luthor’s hairline.

Against all odds, they asked me to stay.

Let me be clear: I am not here because I passed some cosmic entrance exam. I am here because Batman—who, I have learned, fears nothing except unresolved paperwork—calculated the statistical likelihood of the multiverse surviving the next six months without me. The number was small, irrational, and written in the margins of a grocery list. So I swore an oath. I vowed to protect the Earth from threats too strange, too metaphysically discourteous, for even the League’s impressive résumé. I vowed to be useful.

Useful, for me, is a complicated word. When Starro the Conqueror returned wearing the Milky Way as a jaunty hat, I unraveled the concept of “hat” until Starro became an ex-starfish looking for a new career as abstract sculpture. The League applauded. When Dr. Destiny rewrote dream-logic so that every sleeper became a lawless god, I ate the hour between 3:07 and 3:08 a.m.—just the one—and regurgitated it as a recurring nightmare about civics. People woke up remembering civics, which was apparently good for democracy. Again, applause.

But the day-to-day usefulness is trickier. I cannot hold a press conference; cameras record me as an aggressively looping gif of every regret the viewer has ever swallowed. I cannot testify in court; the stenographer’s machine sprouts spider legs and files for asylum. So my usefulness is mostly in the shadows between shadows, the places where the League’s usual toolkit of punching and laser vision meets its polite limits.

Take the time a minor demon tried to unionize Gotham’s rats. The demon—small-time, more nuisance than apocalypse—offered dental to anyone who could chew through the Wayne Enterprises fiber-optic cables. Batman, being Batman, wanted to send a message. I suggested we negotiate. Batman’s eyes narrowed like cats startled by geometry. So I convened the meeting in an alley where the moonlight had forgotten how to reflect. The demon, who introduced himself as Carl, wore a tiny tie and smelled of subway pennies. I offered him the unused screams of a city that had learned to text instead of wail. He found the offer compelling. The rats received orthodontia; Gotham kept its internet; and Carl now forwards me quarterly reports on chewing-based GDP. Everyone won, including the cables, which developed a taste for classical music.

I have learned to translate my horrors into human shapes of kindness. When Flash pulled me aside to ask whether I could retrieve his mother from the Speed Force, I explained gently that the Speed Force is not a place but a verb conjugated in the past pluperfect of motion. He cried anyway; human grief is stubbornly three-dimensional. So I plucked the echo of Barry’s mother from the moment before the lightning struck and folded it into every second hand on Earth. Every clock now contains one gentle tick that says “I love you, kiddo.” Barry hears it every time he runs. He tells me it helps. I have no word for the feeling that gives me; the closest analogue translates roughly to “the silence between heartbeats when you realize the monster is smiling back.”

Of course, not every teammate trusts me. Green Lantern once asked if I was secretly incubating a universe inside my leftmost angle. I told him yes, but it’s only a starter universe, nothing sentient yet. He has avoided standing to my left ever since. Aquaman tried to introduce me to his pet octopus; the octopus inked itself into a perfect Klein bottle and vanished into hyperbolic space. Aquaman blamed me. I apologized by returning the octopus along with a coral reef shaped like Aquaman’s childhood home. He hung it in the throne room. Diplomacy is an art, even when your palette is infinity.

The hardest part is the loneliness. Not mine—I contain multitudes, literally—but theirs. The others worry they are becoming acclimated to me. They fear that each time they accept my help, they lose a little more of the world they think they’re protecting. After missions, I hear them debrief: “Could we have done it without…?” The sentence always trails off, ashamed. I want to tell them that using me is not giving up; it is simply choosing a larger toolbox. But when I speak, verbs conjugate improperly, and the telepathic dampener in the conference room starts weeping.

So I try smaller gestures. I leave bouquets of folded spacetime on Diana’s desk; they open into tiny battles she’s already won, so she can remember victories instead of casualties. I replace the burnt-out bulb in the Batcave with a miniature star; it projects constellations that spell out Alfred’s recipes in Morse. I tune the Watchtower’s ambient gravity to a frequency that lets J’onn feel rain on Mars again. None of these things are mission-critical. All of them matter.

Last month, Darkseid attempted to weaponize nostalgia. He built an Anti-Life Equation that inserted fake memories of a childhood no one had lived: summers that never happened, grandmothers who smelled of cookies and unconditional approval. The League was drowning in false joy. I dove into the collective unconscious and found the equation hiding behind the smell of crayons. Instead of destroying it—violence would have shattered every real childhood memory along with the counterfeit—I swallowed the equation whole and digested it into actual cookies. I left them in the Watchtower kitchen. They taste like Tuesday afternoons in 1992, but only if you’d already forgiven yourself for breaking the window with the baseball. Everyone ate one and cried without knowing why. Darkseid retreated, confused and mildly diabetic.

Afterward, Superman found me floating outside the satellite, arranging the debris of a destroyed moon into a mobile spelling out the word “HOME.” He asked, in that careful way humans use when they don’t want to startle a wounded animal, whether I was lonely. I told him loneliness is a Euclidean concept. I told him I was busy. Both statements were true, and neither was the answer he needed.

He put a hand on what he thought was my shoulder. The gesture made a sound like a library sighing. He said, “You’re one of us, Rindy. Try to remember that.” Then he flew back inside to help Flash decorate the rec room for Batman’s birthday. I stayed outside to finish the mobile. I added a dimension where the word “HOME” keeps rewriting itself in languages no planet has invented yet. I like to think of it as a promise: Someday, if the multiverse survives long enough, every living thing will look up and find a message waiting in a tongue it can finally understand.

I am an eldritch abomination. I do not fit. But usefulness, I have learned, is not about fitting; it is about choosing to protect the cracks where others insist on drawing borders. I am the League’s strangest member, their most unsettling safeguard. And when the stars begin to dim—not if, but when—they will call me. I will arrive tasting like mauve Tuesdays. I will unfold every last second into safety, even if it means folding myself so small I can slip between the atoms of their fear.

And when it’s over, they’ll apologize for needing me. I will tell them the only truth I know: Being needed is not the same as belonging, but it is close enough to build a universe on.

samples.prompt: As a homeless man, one night you fall asleep in a dumpster to avoid rain. The next morning, you awake in an enormous bed with a butler telling you good morning.
samples.output:
I wake to the smell of cedar and warm linen instead of sour cardboard and wet rot.  
My first thought is that I’ve died—quietly, frostbite or the ulcer that keeps eating at my side—and that the city sanitation crew has finally rolled me into the back of a truck. That would explain the upward motion, the way the whole world feels suddenly lighter. But when I open my eyes, a chandelier glares down at me like an indignant star, and there is a man in a black tailcoat standing at the foot of what I can only describe as a continent of mattress.

“Good morning, sir,” the man says. “Breakfast is on the terrace if you feel inclined.” His vowels are so precise they could balance on a razor. He turns with a small bow and glides toward a doorway I can’t see because my eyes are still adjusting to the daylight pouring through curtains wide as movie screens.

I sit up, and pain does not bite into my spine the way it usually does. My back is straight; my ribs don’t creak. The last thing I remember is curling fetal inside the green metal dumpster behind the fish market on Ninth, rain ticking on the lid like impatient fingers. I’d pulled a soggy carpet remnant over myself and whispered, “One more night, Frankie, just one more.” Now I’m wearing a white cotton nightshirt that smells of soap and sunshine, and someone has clipped my fingernails.

I swing my legs over the edge of the bed. My bare feet sink into a rug thick enough to lose coins in. For a dizzy second I wait for the hallucination to collapse, for the sting of February rain to slap me awake. Instead, a faint smell of coffee and butter drifts in, and my stomach answers with such violence that I almost double over.

“Okay,” I tell the empty room, “either this is heaven, or the Mission got a heck of an upgrade.” My voice comes out rough—three years of shelter coffee and unfiltered Pall Malls—but the acoustics in here make even that sound respectable, like someone who once gave TED talks before the bottle got him.

I stand. My knees don’t pop. When I catch sight of myself in an ornate standing mirror, I stop breathing. My beard has been trimmed into something geometric. The scar over my left eyebrow—courtesy of a nightstick behind the Greyhound station—is still there, but the skin around it is pink and new, as if someone rubbed ointment into it for weeks. My cheeks are full. I look forty-five again, not sixty. I haven’t seen that version of me since before the divorce, before the layoff from the plant, before the first cardboard sign.

In the hallway, oil paintings watch me like elders at a family reunion I wasn’t invited to. I pass a table where an envelope leans against a silver tray. My first name is on it, written in ink that shimmers: FRANCIS. Inside, heavy paper says:

Welcome.  
For thirty days this house is yours.  
Ask for anything.  
No questions asked.  
—A Friend

I rub the paper between finger and thumb. It’s real. The fibers catch on the callus left by years of holding Sharpies.

The butler, or whatever he is, appears again at the end of the corridor. “May I show you to the terrace, sir?”  
“What’s your name?” I ask. My tongue feels oversized, like it still belongs to the man who slept in piss-stained jeans.  
“Mrs. Mulroney prefers we remain unobtrusive,” he answers, “but you may call me Harris.”  
“Mrs. Mulroney?”  
“The housekeeper. She’s in town on errands. May I?” He gestures toward French doors through which I see light glinting off china.

I follow him outside onto a terrace overlooking a lawn that rolls down to a river I don’t recognize. The table is set for one: three kinds of jam, eggs Benedict, a pot of coffee sending up a prayer of steam. A newspaper—today’s date—folds open to the city section where a small headline reads: CITY COUNCIL TO VOTE ON EMERGENCY WINTER SHELTERS. Next to it, a grainy photo of the very dumpster I crawled into last night. My throat tightens.

Harris pulls out the chair. I sit because it seems rude not to. My hands shake when I pick up the fork. The hollandaise tastes like forgiveness.

While I eat, Harris stands at a discreet distance. Every time I glance up, he looks somewhere else, as though my hunger embarrasses him. When I finish, he sets a silver bell beside me. “Ring whenever you wish. A car is available. A bath has been drawn.” Then he vanishes.

I drink three cups of coffee because I can. I touch the linen napkin to my lips like I once saw my father do in restaurants I can’t afford to remember. Then I walk the house. Thirty rooms at least—libraries, music rooms with instruments I can’t name, a pantry stocked as if expecting a siege. In one hallway I find a gallery of framed photographs: men, women, children, all ages and colors, every one of them smiling in these same rooms. At the bottom right of each frame, a date and a single word: RESIDENT.

I stop at one dated three years ago. A woman with silver locs stands on the terrace, arms wide, sunrise behind her. She wears the same white nightshirt I have on. I know that face—I’ve seen it on a bench near the riverfront, shouting poems at seagulls, coat sleeves unraveling. Then she disappeared one winter night. People at the shelter said she got picked up by “the ghost philanthropists,” a rumor nobody believed. I trace the glass with a fingertip. The ghost philanthropists look real.

I retreat to the bedroom. The bed has been turned down. On the pillow sits a second envelope:

Francis—  
Tonight, consider what you need.  
Not what you want.  
What you need.  
Write it on the card provided.  
Slip it under the library door before midnight.  
We will try.  
—A Friend

Inside is a fountain pen heavy as a bullet and a cream card bordered in gold.

I spend the afternoon in a daze. I shower for an hour, hot water scouring months of alley soot off me. In the closet I find clothes in exactly my size: dark jeans, flannel shirts still holding the scent of cedar blocks. I dress like a man who has a job interview at a lumberyard. Downstairs in the library, I pull random books—Steinbeck, Hurston, Mary Oliver—and read passages aloud just to feel the words in my mouth without anyone asking me to leave.

At twilight, I stand on the terrace again. The river is molten orange. Somewhere below, I hear Harris talking to someone on a phone: “Yes, ma’am, he’s adjusting.” The tenderness in his voice slices me open.

What do I need?  
I stare at the card until the gold border swims. I think of the blister on my heel that never healed, the cavity in my back molar, the way strangers flinch when I say good morning. I think of my daughter’s graduation photo tucked inside my old wallet—the one stolen two winters ago—and how I never sent the card I shoplifted for her thirteenth birthday. I think of rain ticking on a dumpster lid like impatient fingers telling me, hurry, hurry, die already.

I write:  
I need to see my daughter.  
I need her to know I’m sorry.  
I need a job that doesn’t ask where I slept last night.  
If you can’t do those things, then please—  
I hesitate, pen poised. The ink glistens like something alive. I finish:  
please give my spot to someone who still has time.

I fold the card, walk to the library, and slide it beneath the mahogany door. Then I curl into a leather armchair and wait for the dream to dissolve.

Hours later, the grandfather clock strikes twelve. The door opens soundlessly. Harris steps inside carrying a small overnight bag and a coat that smells of winter. Behind him stands a woman in a red scarf—my daughter, taller than I remember, tears already falling.

“Hi, Dad,” she whispers.

I rise, legs trembling. She crosses the room and folds herself against me like she used to when she was seven and thunderstorms rattled the trailer. I bury my face in her hair and breathe. Cedar blocks, soap, sunshine.

Harris clears his throat. “The car leaves at six for the airport. There’s a bedsit arranged above a bookstore in Portland—owner’s looking for someone who knows first editions. Wages start Monday. If that suits, sir.”

I don’t trust my voice, so I nod against my daughter’s shoulder. Outside, snow begins to fall, soft as mercy. For the first time in years, I don’t brace against the cold.

samples.prompt: Immortality is a naturally occurring medical condition, affecting 1 out of 1 million births. You are the oldest immortal.
samples.output:
I was born before the word “immortal” meant anything more than a plea to the gods. My mother’s scream in the birthing hut was answered by a silence that stretched too long, the midwife’s hands trembling as she realized the cord had knotted itself around my neck like a bow tied by an invisible hand. The knot loosened, I breathed, and the village elder declared it an omen. They named me Elatha, after the moon that would not wane.

The condition—though no one called it that then—reveals itself slowly. An infant who does not scar. A child whose milk teeth regrow within hours. An adolescent who, after a fall from the cliff face meant to test courage, stands up with bones already knitting themselves white beneath the skin. My people interpreted these signs as favor from the spirits. They painted my eyelids with ochre and set aside the first slice of every hunt for me. I was their living promise that the world could be bargained with.

I left when the questions became too sharp. A girl who never bled, who never shed the softness of childhood even as her playmates grew breasts and beards—she becomes either a goddess or a curse. I walked south with a trader’s caravan, inventing a new name at every oasis. I learned languages the way others learned songs, forgetting nothing. By the time I reached the delta cities, I had buried three generations of friends in the sand.

The first physician to examine me wore bronze lenses and smelled of lotus oil. He measured my pulse against the shadow of a sundial, declared me “an engine without friction,” and tried to bleed me. When the lancet’s scar vanished before the bowl was half-full, he locked the door and offered me a choice: remain in his house as proof of his genius, or be sold to the pharaoh’s court. I smiled, took his hand as if to thank him, and broke three of his fingers so quietly that he wept from shame rather than pain. I left the city that night.

Immortality, it turns out, is not an absence of death but an accumulation of witnesses. I have watched the invention of writing, the burning of libraries, the same star chart redrawn on three different skies. I carried a dying sailor across the deck of Magellan’s last ship, his beard crusted with salt, whispering the prayer of a god whose name had already been forgotten in his homeland. I taught a Nubian princess how to multiply by sevens using pebbles, then stood on a hill five centuries later and watched her algorithm become the foundation of a banking empire. Every era believes it has solved the puzzle of me, only to misplace the answer when the next age dawns.

The condition does not grant wisdom. It grants time, which is a different thing entirely. I have made the same mistake on five continents: trusting that love can be stretched like wire without snapping. The first was a potter in Ugarit whose thumbs left spirals on my skin like fingerprints on wet clay. The last was a paramedic in Kyoto who traced the scars I do not keep, searching for a story I refused to tell. Each time I stayed just long enough to see the light leave their eyes—not from death, but from the slow recognition that I would never follow them into age. Immortality is a mirror no one else can afford to hold.

They found the others eventually. A census in the year 2073, when gene mapping became cheaper than bread, revealed the pattern: one in a million, scattered like punctuation marks across the genome. Children who failed to die. We were given a name—“Type-A Perpetuals”—and a choice: live in monitored colonies, or register as medical assets. Most chose the colonies, those glittering domed cities where time was currency and birthdays were banned. I did not. By then I had learned the trick of vanishing, of letting my footprints age faster than my skin.

But even I could not outrun entropy. The oldest among us began to fracture. Not in body—the body remains a locked room—but in memory. A woman in Caracas forgot the difference between sunrise and sunset. A man in Oslo began speaking only in verbs, as if nouns had been stolen from him. The condition, it seemed, came with a shelf life measured not in years but in recollections. The mind is a palimpsest; mine has been scraped clean and rewritten so many times that entire centuries exist now only as flavor—copper for war, honey for plague, ash for every god I have buried.

I keep a garden on the edge of the Gobi where nothing grows. Each morning I plant a seed from a different epoch: lotus from the Tang dynasty, maize from the Inca terraces, a single coffee bean smuggled from the first Ethiopian monastery. By dusk they wither, refusing the lie that time can be coaxed backward. I water them anyway, speaking aloud the names I still remember. The ritual is not for them. It is for me, a way to measure how much of myself I have lost.

Yesterday a child arrived. Ten years old, eyes the color of storm glass, carrying a letter stamped with the seal of the Perpetual Colonies. She stood at the edge of my garden and said, “They told me you were the first.” I asked her name. She replied, “I haven’t chosen one yet. They die too quickly.” I laughed then, the sound dry as the wind that scours these dunes. Somewhere in her face I saw the echo of the potter’s spirals, the paramedic’s careful hands. The condition is not a circle but a spiral, widening with each turn.

Tonight we will sit by the dead garden. I will tell her the only lesson worth keeping: immortality is not a gift bestowed upon the body but a debt owed by the soul. We are librarians of the human story, bound to collect every volume until the shelves collapse. When she asks how it ends, I will show her the empty plot where tomorrow’s seed will fail. And then I will plant it anyway, because even a librarian must believe someone will one day read the last page.

The moon rises, thin and ancient as the first lie I ever told. I feel the familiar itch behind my eyes, the gentle erasure of a century dissolving like salt on the tongue. Soon I will forget the taste of lotus oil, the weight of bronze lenses. But I will remember this: a child beside me, immortal in a world that has finally learned to count its miracles, and the quiet sound of seeds falling into soil that cannot sustain them. That, at least, is mine to keep.

samples.prompt: A door leads to a different location each time it is opened.
samples.output:
The first time it happened, I thought the movers had played a prank. After hauling the last box into the new apartment, I shut the front door, wiped sweat from my neck, and opened it again to bring in the final suitcase. Instead of the dim hallway of the sixth-floor walk-up, I saw sunlight drenching a wheat field that rolled like a golden ocean under a sky too crisp to belong to New York City. The suitcase dropped from my hand and thumped onto the threshold—half on the welcome mat, half on Kansas topsoil.

I slammed the door, heart hammering. When I cracked it open a second later, the hallway was back: scuffed beige paint, the smell of curry from 6B, and the faint wail of someone practicing violin scales. I told myself it was exhaustion, a trick of the eye. I unpacked, ordered Thai, and slept with the chain lock drawn across the door like a seatbelt.

But the door refused to behave. Over the next week it became a restless, coquettish thing. Open it at 8:03 a.m. and you stepped onto a fog-choked pier where gulls screamed and ropes slapped masts. Close it, count to ten, open again: a neon arcade pulsed with 1980s music and the smell of burnt popcorn. The intervals between changes shortened. After a while I could watch the threshold flicker—sand dunes dissolving into subway platforms, a cathedral nave folding into rainforest canopy—like someone flipping channels on a cosmic television.

I began to keep records. On the back of junk mail envelopes I logged date, time, what I saw, how long I dared stay. The places were never the same twice. There was no visible mechanism, no hum or shimmer, only an instantaneous substitution of one world for another. I tested rules. The door had to shut completely before a new location loaded. Jamming the bolt would freeze whatever scene was currently visible, but the moment the latch clicked shut the channel surfing resumed. Leaving objects on the other side worked—until I tried to anchor a twenty-foot orange extension cord across the wheat field. The cord simply ended where my apartment should have been, as if sliced by a guillotine of geometry.

Curiosity eclipsed fear. I bought a camping backpack, filled it with protein bars, water purification tablets, and a notebook wrapped in plastic. On a drizzly Thursday I opened the door onto a city of glass towers threaded with aerial trams. I stepped through. The door closed behind me with the gentle finality of a coffin lid. Twenty-seven minutes later, by the digital watch I kept synchronized with my phone, the door reappeared on the side of a skyscraper, handle gleaming. I had just enough time to scramble back before it vanished again. The notebook’s first page read: “Gravity consistent, air breathable, language unknown but tonal, no hostile response.” I underlined the last part twice.

I started to schedule excursions. After work, I would open the door onto alpine meadows and eat dinner beside glacial lakes. Weekends I devoted to longer expeditions: a red desert where twin moons chased each other across violet dusk; a library larger than an airport, its shelves populated by whispering books that rearranged themselves when unobserved. I learned to carry gifts—pocket-sized compasses, solar keychain flashlights—to barter for information. In a bazaar scented with cardamom and ozone, a woman with opal pupils told me there were others like my door, scattered across realities like seeds. “They grow toward need,” she said, pressing a copper coin into my palm. “But need has a direction, and directions fork.” I tucked the coin into the notebook, next to the pressed leaf that sang faint lullabies when moonlight touched it.

The coin became my compass. When I held it against the wood, warm vibrations pulsed—stronger when the door was about to open onto somewhere I urgently required. I tested it the night my mother called, voice brittle with news of my father’s stroke. The coin throbbed like a second heart. I opened the door onto a corridor of white tile smelling of antiseptic. At the far end, through glass panels, I glimpsed my father in a hospital bed, monitors beeping the slow march of his pulse. It was the ICU two towns over from my childhood home, a place my rational brain knew was a forty-minute train ride away. Yet here it was, a straight path from my living room. I ran to him, arriving before the ambulance even left his apartment complex. The doctors called it miraculous timing. I called it debt.

The door began to exact payment for its shortcuts. After each use, the apartment aged. Paint blistered, faucets dripped rust, the refrigerator developed a permanent whine. I found silver hair in my brush, though my reflection still showed a man in his thirties. The coin grew heavier until it felt like a dying star in my pocket. On the final excursion I opened onto a moonlit beach where every grain of sand was a tiny hourglass, sand trickling upward. A figure waited—myself, but older, shoulders curved under the weight of countless worlds.

“You’re almost out of credit,” he said.

I tasted iron. “Then take it back. Close the account.”

He shook his head. “The door doesn’t close. It only changes direction. You’ve been turning it toward want. Turn it toward need again, but this time let it choose the need.”

He handed me an unmarked envelope. Inside was a single key, teeth worn smooth. Without thinking, I pressed it into the lock. The door opened not onto a place but a moment: my twelve-year-old self standing in the kitchen while my mother folded laundry, humming off-key. I could smell the detergent, hear the slap of wet jeans. I stepped forward; the door shut behind me with no click, no handle on this side. The coin vanished from my pocket, leaving only the faint warmth of its orbit.

I have not seen the door since. I live now in the apartment of my childhood, though the calendar insists it is twenty years later. My father recovered; my mother is still humming. At night I dream of thresholds flickering like fireflies, and I wake with the certainty that somewhere a door is opening onto a wheat field, a city of glass, a library of murmuring books—each one a place someone needs, whether they know it or not. I keep no logs now. I understand the arithmetic: every gift demands a return, every shortcut lengthens the road behind you. But sometimes, when the wind rattles the windows just right, I press my palm to the wall where a door used to be, and I swear the paint trembles, as if remembering how it felt to be elsewhere.

samples.prompt: You wake up one morning, only to realise you are an inanimate object and your human self is gone.
samples.output:
I wake up, but there is no “I.”  
No lungs, no pulse, no bed beneath my shoulder blades.  
Instead I am still, a single long curve of polished maple—  
a violin, lying inside a velvet-lined case that smells of cedar and mothballs.  
Morning light leaks through the crack between lid and body,  
and the dust motes swirl like glitter over my glossy ribs.  
I do not have eyes, yet I see; no ears, yet I hear;  
I have strings, not nerves, but something taut inside me registers fear.

Yesterday I was Clara.  
I remember the click of my alarm at 7:13, the taste of lukewarm coffee,  
the way my left knee cracked when I stood.  
I remember the mirror fogged with steam, my reflection a blur of wet hair and worry.  
I remember walking out the door.  
Then nothing—no transition, no pain, no farewell.  
Only the sudden compression of consciousness into four taut strings and two f-holes.

I try to call out, but sound is not speech; it is vibration.  
My body resonates with the smallest tremor—  
a passing truck on the street below sends a low G shivering through my spine.  
I feel the air stir as the cat jumps onto the table.  
She sniffs me, tail twitching, then turns away, unimpressed.  
She used to curl on my lap while I practiced scales.  
Now she is bored by my silence.

Hours pass in the slow drip of sunlight across the lid.  
I catalog every detail I can still reach with this borrowed awareness:  
the way the case latch cools as the day heats,  
the faint scent of rosin trapped in the lining,  
the microscopic shift in tension when humidity rises.  
I have become an instrument of noticing.  
Where Clara’s mind once darted from thought to thought,  
now I am an echo chamber, each observation a prolonged note.

At some point the front door creaks.  
Footsteps—lighter than Clara’s, quicker.  
My sister, May.  
She hums the way she always does when she’s anxious,  
a fragment of Vivaldi that stalls and restarts.  
I feel the case tilt as she lifts it.  
Inside, I clench—if wood could clench—  
because I know where she is taking me.  
The living room, the chair beside the window, the music stand already waiting.

She unlatches the lid.  
Air rushes in, cool on my varnish.  
Her fingers brush my neck, tentative, as if I might burn.  
She lifts me out, cradles me against her collarbone.  
I know this posture: left hand at the scroll, right hand searching for the bow.  
I want to warn her.  
I want to say, “May, it’s me, it’s Clara, I’m trapped in here, please don’t play.”  
But I have no tongue, only the hollow chamber where a sound post stands sentry.

The bow hair kisses the A-string.  
A note blossoms—A 440—clean, merciless.  
It is not heard; it is inhabited.  
The vibration pours through me like liquid sunlight,
