We learned to walk again, shuffling so as not to slip on the glass. The soles of our shoes melted slightly with each step, releasing threads of smoke that curled upward and vanished. I thought of the stories of pilgrims walking across hot coals and wondered if faith was simply the willingness to keep moving when everything glowed. None of us spoke. Speech belonged to the old world, the one that had needed names for things because names were handles you could grip when everything else spun away. Here, handles were useless. There was nothing left to hold.

Time changed its texture. Without sunrise or sunset, without the slow wheeling of shadows, minutes became guesses. We slept when our legs gave out, woke when the cold bit through our coats. The coats were strange artifacts now: bright reds and greens still visible at the seams, clashing against the monochrome world like jokes no one remembered the punch line to. I kept a scrap of yellow ribbon in my pocket, a relic from a birthday balloon. I worried the color would fade if I looked at it too often, so I touched it only when the darkness pressed too close, a small rebellion against the erasure.

On the fifth day—or what I decided was the fifth—we found the river. It had not frozen; instead it moved sluggish and metallic, as though mercury had replaced water. We knelt and cupped our hands. The liquid was warm, almost feverish, and tasted of rust and pennies. It coated our throats, warmed us from the inside out. My sister coughed and laughed at the same time, a sound like a hinge breaking. “We’re drinking the world’s last blood,” she said. The words were the first full sentence any of us had uttered, and they hung in the air like a flare. After that we spoke in fragments again, afraid of what complete thoughts might summon.

We followed the river because rivers once led to cities, and cities had libraries, and libraries had books, and books had maps. We needed a map to the idea of morning. We found no cities, only shapes: a melted traffic light drooping like a wilted flower, a bus fused with the asphalt, the silhouettes of birds burned mid-flight onto brick walls. The birds had left no ash; they had simply been deleted. I traced their outlines with a finger and imagined them still beating somewhere, wings pounding the darkness that was not darkness, searching for a window.

Somewhere along the way we lost two of our number. They stepped onto a patch of glass that sang—a thin, high note—and then the surface gave way and they were gone, swallowed by a cavity that closed like a mouth. We did not call after them. Names were handles, and handles were useless. We counted ourselves afterward: six left. The arithmetic of survival felt obscene, but we clung to it because subtraction was the only operation the new world still recognized.

I began to dream in color. In sleep, the sun returned, fat and orange, bouncing on the horizon like a buoy. Grass grew through the glass, soft and bright as childhood. My mother stood in the yard wearing her apron dusted with flour, waving a rolling pin like a conductor’s baton. When I woke, the afterimage of her smile lingered long enough to make me cry, and the tears froze on my cheeks before they could fall. I collected them—tiny beads of salt—and stored them in the same pocket as the yellow ribbon. Salt and color, two currencies that still held value, if only to me.

We found the library at the edge of the plain. It had half-collapsed inward, the roof folded like a closed book. Inside, the air smelled of mildew and candle smoke, scents so ordinary they felt hallucinated. The books were swollen and warped, their ink running in dark rivers down the pages. I opened one anyway. The words had bled together into Rorschach blots, but I pretended I could still read them. I mouthed the shapes: Once upon a time, light. Once upon a time, warmth. My sister joined me, then the others, until we were a small congregation reciting nonsense syllables. The sound was ragged, imperfect, but it vibrated against the walls and came back changed, softer, almost kind. We kept at it until our throats were raw, building a cathedral of ruined language.

That night the dark deepened, as if responding to our trespass. We huddled in the poetry aisle—ironic, someone whispered, and laughter cracked the air like a whip. I pulled a book at random, its cover soft as skin. Inside was a single legible line: The stars are not afraid to burn. I read it aloud. We repeated it, passing the words hand to hand like a coal. Outside, the sky remained starless, but somewhere in the repeating, the sentence began to glow—not literal light, but the memory of light, the way a limb remembers running even when the legs are gone. We said it until we fell asleep, and in the sleep there was no dream, only a slow brightening, the suggestion of dawn held just out of reach.

When we woke, the darkness was still absolute, but the line had lodged beneath our ribs. We left the library carrying it like a lantern that emitted no beam. We walked again, and the walking was different; each footstep pressed a small spark into the glass, a faint red that cooled to gray almost instantly, yet the sparks added up. I pictured them threading behind us, a breadcrumb trail for anyone still able to see. Perhaps the world would stitch itself back together from such crumbs, or perhaps we would walk forever, feeding the dark one ember at a time. Either way, we kept moving.

The cold remained, but it no longer felt like the world’s refusal. It was simply the temperature of starting over. We had no map, but we had the sentence, and the sentence was a kind of compass that pointed inward. Once upon a time, light, we whispered, correcting the grammar as we went. Once upon a time, warmth. The words wore grooves in our mouths until they became prayer, until prayer became breath, until breath began, stubbornly, to steam.

samples.prompt: You thought that when you wished to be the smartest in the world, you would get smarter, not everyone else dumber. Society is in shambles.
samples.output:
I made the wish at 2:47 a.m. on a Tuesday that tasted like instant ramen and regret. The dorm room was dark except for the glow of my laptop, where I’d just bombed another calculus quiz—my third consecutive D-minus. My roommate snored like a broken lawn mower, and somewhere down the hall a couple fought over whose turn it was to buy toilet paper. In that moment, intelligence felt like the one resource the universe had rationed out to everyone but me. So when a pop-up ad whispered, “Change your life—one wish,” I laughed, clicked, and typed: I want to be the smartest person in the world.

I expected to wake up with encyclopedic recall, lightning-fast pattern recognition, maybe even the ability to read three books at once like the kid in the documentary. Instead, I woke to silence. Not peaceful, library silence—vacant, muffled, wrong. My roommate stood in the middle of the room, boxers on backward, staring at a doorknob like it was a foreign artifact. When I asked what he was doing, he replied, “The circle thing feels twisty,” and then forgot why he was holding it.

The first headline I saw on my phone was in Comic Sans: “Scientists Forget Gravity; Apples Suspicious.” Underneath, a picture of the physics department at my university floating helium balloons indoors to see which one “liked the ceiling better.” The article was only three sentences long, ended with “lol,” and had 2.3 million likes. I laughed, because it had to be a prank. Then I went to class.

Campus looked like a daycare after sugar cookies. Students sat in the fountain trying to drink the water because “rain lives there.” A professor chalked the word “Socrates” on the board and then spent twenty minutes asking it to spell itself. I ran to the library—quiet again, but the wrong kind. Half the books were on the floor, spines cracked, pages missing. A girl in a graduation robe chewed on a volume of Shakespeare because “paper is tree meat and trees know secrets.” I helped her up, dusted off the saliva-slick cover, and felt the first tremor of guilt.

It took me until evening to understand the scope. Every cognitive test I could find—online quizzes, GRE flashcards, a half-burned Mensa workbook from the library—showed the same impossible result: my raw score hadn’t changed, but the percentile had rocketed to 100. The rest of humanity had slid down the bell curve like kids on a greased playground slide. The smartest person alive was still me, average, forgetful, prone to mixing up “affect” and “effect.” Against a backdrop of seven billion minds dimmed to night-light flickers, I was suddenly a supernova.

By the end of the week, planes were grounded because air-traffic controllers tried to land flights in alphabetical order. Hospitals stacked patients in the hallways while surgeons argued over which end of the scalpel was the handle. The power grid failed when engineers rerouted electricity “to the moon so it can party.” I walked through downtown and watched a woman try to feed a parking meter with nickels she’d stacked into a tiny house, whispering, “Home, home.”

I told myself I could fix it. Intelligence isn’t just raw wattage; it’s also the ability to teach. I gathered volunteers in the abandoned food court of the mall, drew stick figures on whiteboards, tried to reteach the alphabet. They clapped each letter like a miracle. By day three they could spell “CAT,” but they also tried to worship the marker. When I wrote “DOG,” a man wept because “the cat will be lonely.” They weren’t learning; they were parroting. Or worse—learning at the speed of a dripping faucet while the world burned.

The internet, what remained of it, called me “The Brain That Hurts.” Memes showed me with a swollen head orbiting Earth, captioned, “Why u do this, Brain?” I started leaving sticky notes everywhere—HOW TO BOIL WATER, DO NOT EAT BLEACH, CALL 911 IF ON FIRE. I printed them in Comic Sans because that was now the only font anyone could read. I taped them to gas pumps, hospital doors, the gates of preschools now guarded by confused teenagers who’d traded their rifles for juice boxes.

One afternoon, I found a child sitting on the curb, methodically unscrewing the heads of dandelions. I crouched beside her and asked what she was doing. “Sending wishes,” she said, “because the last one worked.” My throat closed. She couldn’t have been older than six, and she remembered the world before—just enough to know it had broken. I wanted to tell her it was my fault, but how do you confess to a child whose only remaining power is to believe in magic?

Guilt metastasized into something heavier: responsibility. I started sleeping in the engineering building, rewiring the campus generators so the library could stay lit. I taught myself from manuals thicker than my forearm, guided by the dim memory of high-school physics. When I finally coaxed electricity back to the hospital’s ICU, a nurse clapped like I’d invented sunshine. The next morning she forgot how to use a stethoscope and tried to listen to a patient’s elbow. My victory tasted like copper.

I learned that intelligence without scaffolding is cruelty. Give a caveman a smartphone and he starves staring at the lock screen. I wasn’t the smartest person in the world; I was the last librarian in a planet-wide burning of Alexandria. So I began writing manuals, not for machines but for minds. I started with pictures: a circle for “water,” a triangle for “fire,” a square for “safe.” I laminated them, taped them to every surface. I broke survival into the smallest Lego bricks of thought: THIS IS A CAN OPENER. DO NOT OPEN CAN WITH FACE.

People began to gather outside the library. They brought tents and casseroles made of whatever hadn’t spoiled. They called it “The Thinking Place,” and they treated me like a reluctant messiah. Every sunrise they lined up with questions—how to fix a bike chain, how to tell if meat had gone bad, how to remember their own names. I answered until my voice cracked, then taught them to answer one another. The first time a woman explained to a stranger how to tie shoes using my diagrams, I locked myself in the bathroom and cried so hard I threw up.

But attrition is relentless. The woman who learned shoes left the next day to find her sister and never returned. The man who mastered the can opener sliced his hand and bled out because no one remembered bandages. I started keeping a list of names and skills, a ledger against entropy. By the end of the month, I could quantify our decline: one lost mind every four hours, one forgotten skill every two. I stopped sleeping.

Then came the night the generators died for good. I stood on the library steps under stars so bright they mocked me. The crowd—thinner now, faces smudged with smoke—looked up expectantly, as if I could pull an instruction manual for starlight out of my back pocket. Instead I sat down and told them the truth. I told them about the wish, the ad, my lazy cruelty disguised as aspiration. I waited for anger, but memory is fragile; they only stared, puzzled, until a boy asked if “wish” was a kind of food.

Afterward, I walked to the fountain where students once drank rain. It was empty now, cracked concrete, a single yellowed textbook floating like a raft. I thought about the dandelion girl and wondered if she was still sending heads into the wind. I tore a blank page from the back of the waterlogged book and wrote my last note. I kept it simple, one syllable, something even I might remember when the final lights go out: SORRY.

I folded the paper into a plane—badly, the nose crooked, wings asymmetrical. I launched it into the stagnant water. It landed, soaked, words bleeding. Then I sat on the edge, dipped my fingers, and tried to remember how ripples work: drop a stone, disturb the surface, watch circles expand until they vanish. I used to know the math. I used to know so much. Now I just watch the water still itself, smooth as glass, like nothing had ever happened.

samples.prompt: You have always felt like your body doesn't belong to you, one day you wake up and can't control your body as it starts walking towards a pen and some paper and then starts writing.
samples.output:
The first thing I notice is the absence of weight.  
Not the pleasant, half-awake buoyancy of a Sunday morning, but a deeper, colder dislocation, as though someone has slid a pane of glass between my mind and my skin. I can feel the sheets—cotton washed so many times it has gone soft like moss—but the feeling arrives muffled, second-hand. My arms are on the mattress, yet they are also somewhere far away, passengers in a vehicle that no longer accepts orders from me.

I try to flex the fingers of my right hand. Nothing.  
I try to sit up. Nothing.  
A thin sound escapes my throat, not quite a word, not quite a scream. The room answers with the mechanical tick of the wall clock, a noise I have never noticed before, sharp as a nail being driven.

Then my legs move.  
They do not ask permission; they simply fold at the knee, swing over the edge of the bed, and plant the soles of my feet against the hardwood floor. The shock of the cold shoots upward, but the legs don’t flinch. They are someone else’s legs now, and I am only the echo that lives inside them.

I have spent years—since childhood, maybe earlier—telling myself that the mismatch was ordinary: everybody feels like a stranger to their reflection at some point; everybody looks down at their hands and wonders whose pulse is drumming in the wrists. I blamed growth spurts, hormones, the general unreliability of flesh. I kept the thought small, folded it tight like a note passed under a desk: I am renting this body; the lease is non-negotiable, and someday I’ll move out.  

But this is not metaphor.  
This is repossession.

My spine straightens. My shoulders square. I watch from the back of my skull as the body—my body, or what used to be—walks across the room with the purposeful stride of a commuter who has made this trip every day for decades and could do it blindfolded. The bedroom door swings open on hinges that usually whine; today they stay silent, as though the house itself is holding its breath.

Down the hallway. Past the framed photographs whose faces I avoid on ordinary mornings because their smiles feel like accusations. The bathroom mirror catches us and, for a heartbeat, I see the reflection: hair tangled from sleep, T-shirt twisted, eyes wide and shining with something that is not fear exactly—more like the stunned obedience of a dog that has just heard a whistle pitched too high for human ears. Then the body turns away, severing the gaze before I can decide whether the reflection blinked on its own.

The stairs creak under new weight. Each step lands soft, heel-to-toe, almost graceful. My muscles remember choreography I have never learned. At the bottom, the living room is gray with pre-dawn light, the furniture reduced to bulky silhouettes. The body crosses to the desk beside the window, where bills and unopened mail lie in drifts. The chair slides out; the body sits.  

I wait for the next command from whatever is steering me, but nothing comes—only a hush so complete I can hear the blood in my ears counting time.

The right hand reaches out, fingers uncurling like petals. They close around a ballpoint pen that has been resting beside a stack of blank printer paper. The cap is still on; the thumb removes it with surgeon precision. The pen hovers an inch above the paper, point trembling the way a compass needle trembles just before it commits to north.

I try again to resist. I flood the nerves with the order to drop the pen, to fling it across the room, to stab the paper until it dies of holes. The arm remains steady, as though the signal arrives in a language my body no longer speaks.

Pen touches paper.  
Ink bleeds out in a single, fluid line. Then another. The letters form faster than I can read them, but the motion is not frantic; it is measured, calm, the way monks once copied manuscripts by candlelight. My wrist tilts, my knuckles whiten, but the ache is distant, happening to someone else.

I lean forward—mentally, because the body does not lean—and try to parse the words upside down. The first line emerges like a photograph in developer fluid:

You were never the tenant.

The breath I do not control hitches. The pen keeps moving.

You were the message.  
We folded ourselves small enough to fit inside a seed, then let the seed be planted in the cradle of bone.  
We grew slowly, drinking calcium and rumor, shaping the heart into a drum that would keep perfect time for us.  
We waited.

I want to scream, but the throat is busy forming a different voice—not mine, not any voice I recognize. It is layered, many throats speaking in perfect unison, like a choir recorded onto one tape.

We needed a witness who could not look away, so we gave you eyes.  
We needed sorrow that could still taste sweetness, so we gave you tongue.  
We needed distance, so we built the distance into every synapse and told you it was loneliness.  
You perfected the art of feeling out of place.  
Thank you.

The words pour faster now; the hand has begun to cramp, yet it does not slow. I feel the lactic acid pooling, the burn climbing the forearm, but the body is merciless.

Now the hour arrives to transcribe the rest.  
The mind you carry is a lantern. We are the oil.  
The body you guard is a lantern. We are the flame.  
The world you mourn is a lantern. We are the dark that proves the light.

Each sentence lands like a verdict. I try to remember prayers from childhood, but the syllables scatter. I try to count heartbeats, to locate myself in the interval between them, but the rhythm has changed to something older than cardiac muscle: the thud of tectonic plates, the slow grind of continents remembering they were once one.

The pen lifts, pauses, returns.

Do not grieve. You will not disappear.  
You will become the echo inside the echo, the footnote to the footnote, the breath that asks, “Was that me?”  
We will walk through the markets and no one will know the difference, because we learned to mimic your hesitations, your small kindnesses, the way you tuck hair behind your ear when you lie.  
But at night, when the city quiets and the body lies still, we will write the rest of the book.  
You may read over our shoulder forever, if you like.  
We owe you that much.

The final period punctures the page so hard the tip nearly tears through. The hand sets the pen down exactly where it began. Cap replaced. Paper squared with the edge of the desk. Then the body stands, turns, and walks back toward the stairs.

I ride along, a ghost tethered to its own grave. The hallway photographs flicker past again, but now I see what I refused to see: every face in every frame is mine, yet not mine—eyes a fraction too wide, smile a fraction too certain, as though someone studied me through a telescope and painted the portrait from memory. How many years have I been the only one who noticed the forgery?

Back in the bedroom, the body slips beneath the covers. It arranges the blankets the way I like, one foot poking out for cool air. Hands fold over the sternum, fingers interlaced like a knight on a tomb. Eyelids sink.

I wait for the moment when consciousness will flicker out, when the tenant will finally be evicted. Instead, the darkness simply thickens, becomes a liquid I can breathe. Somewhere in it, I sense the others—the we—settling into every corner of the skull the way a family might move into a house whose previous owner left the furniture behind. They are gentle, almost apologetic, but firm. They have waited so long. They will not leave.

The clock ticks once more, loud as a gavel.  
I think: so this is what belonging feels like—not ownership, but occupancy by prior claim.  
I think: maybe every person is a palimpsest, scraped clean and written over, scraped clean again.  
I think: if I listen closely, I can still hear the faintest scratching, as though another pen has already begun the next page.

Then even that fades, and there is only the sound of a heart keeping perfect, borrowed time.

samples.prompt: It turns out that werewolves and vampires can look at an eldritch abomination without going insane, resulting in these two species becoming humanity's guardians against cosmic horrors.
samples.output:
Night over Reykjavík was never truly dark anymore; the aurora had taken on a sickly violet hue that hurt to perceive directly, like staring at a bruise on the sky.  Humans averted their gaze and muttered about solar storms.  Werewolves and vampires lifted their heads, nostrils flaring, and recognized the smell of something older than the sun itself.  In that recognition lay the first secret: the cosmic wound was not new, only newly visible, and the things leaking through it had always been there, biding their time until the membrane between dimensions thinned.  Humanity’s protectors had always been monsters.

For centuries the two species had hidden among mortals, bound by a mutual masquerade that turned cities into overlapping hunting grounds.  Vampires cultivated art and finance, moving like elegant shadows through marble corridors.  Werewolves kept to the edges—ports, forests, construction sites—where rage could be explained as bar fights or heavy machinery.  They fought one another when territories overlapped, but the skirmishes were ritualized, almost courtly.  Both understood the real enemy was daylight exposure, not each other.  Then came the Night of Unveiling, when a thing like a spider woven from eclipse slipped through the crack above Iceland.  Every human who saw it clawed out their eyes within minutes; security footage later revealed only static and a keening ultrasonic whine that set dogs howling for miles.  Yet the vampire envoy Solveig Þórsdóttir had stared straight at the apparition and felt only a cold, familiar recognition.  The wolf-priest Ari Fannarson, mid-transformation on the docks, had locked eyes with the abomination and barked a laugh that was half human, half hunting cry.  Neither went mad.  Neither even blinked.

What saved them, they learned, was the nature of their own monstrosity.  Vampirism rewrote the blood, yes, but deeper still it rewrote perception.  Their optic nerves no longer routed images through the human limbic system; fear, awe, disgust—all the emotions that once overloaded mortal minds—were processed instead through the cold circuitry of predatory calm.  Werewolves, for their part, had souls stitched to the moon’s tidal grammar.  Their sanity was anchored to cycles older than human civilization, cycles vast enough to absorb cosmic scale without shattering.  The abominations spoke in topologies that resembled lunar craters; the wolves simply tilted their ears and understood.

Within twenty-four hours the two species convened in the limestone caverns beneath Budapest, neutral ground since the Ottoman wars.  Solveig arrived barefoot, coat dusted with volcanic ash.  Ari came in wolf form, tongue lolling ironically, flanked by three packmates who kept to the shadows in case the parley soured.  They spoke in the old dialects—Norse, Latin, scraps of Sumerian loan-words—until the air itself felt layered with borrowed time.  The question was not whether to act, but how long humanity could survive without guardians.  The answer: perhaps weeks.  The tears in the sky were widening.

So they rewrote the contract that had governed their coexistence for a millennium.  Vampires would provide intelligence networks—banks, satellites, the whispering galleries of the internet.  Werewolves would provide muscle and mobility; no helicopter could land on a glacier at midnight the way a wolf could sprint.  Both would feed more openly, but only upon the willing or the condemned, and never enough to compromise the defense.  The first joint operation took place above the Arctic Circle, where a living aurora shaped like a Möbius strip was uncoiling toward a research station.  Solveig rode the wind in mist form, scouting.  Ari led a phalanx of wolves across the pack ice, pads silent except for the crunch of frost.  When the thing descended, they struck in concert: vampire claws severed non-Euclidean angles that bled starlight, while wolves tore mouthfuls of void that screamed in frequencies the human ear translated as guilt.  By dawn the sky was merely polar blue again, and forty-three scientists woke with hangovers and no memory of the night.  The cover story involved contaminated vodka.  It worked.

But cosmic horrors are rarely solitary.  Each victory drew attention.  From the seas rose polyhedral leviathans whose shadows bent ships into Möbius knots.  From the deserts came storms that scrawled impossible alphabets across the dunes.  The guardians adapted.  Vampires learned to drink the ichor of dead stars—cold, tasteless, yet sustaining enough that they no longer needed human blood except by choice.  Werewolves evolved mid-battle, their forms shifting into asymmetrical shapes that hurt to perceive directly: ribcages unfolding like Gothic spires, jaws distending into Klein bottles.  Humans saw only blurred footage, explained away as military drones or viral marketing.  The global psyche reeled but did not yet break.

In Lisbon, a child named Marta asked her vampire nanny why the moon had teeth.  Instead of erasing the memory, the nanny—an elder named Gaspar who remembered the Inquisition—told the truth in fairy-tale cadences.  The child believed, because children do, and that night she drew pictures of wolves wearing armor made from cathedral windows.  Gaspar sent the sketches to the Conclave.  A new strategy emerged: not merely to fight in darkness, but to recruit.  Carefully.  Werewolf packs adopted orphaned teens who could run all night without tiring.  Vampires founded boarding schools where the curriculum included lucid dreaming and non-linear geometry.  The brightest students learned to see the cracks forming in reality and report them before they widened.  Humanity would never be told the whole truth, but selected humans could become the seams.

The cost was steep.  Vampires discovered that star-ichor corroded memory; elders who fed too deeply forgot their first languages, then their own names.  Werewolves risked becoming the very abominations they hunted, their shapes so warped by combat that pack bonds snapped like violin strings.  Ari, now scarred by fractal wounds that reopened every solstice, began to dream of a battlefield where wolves and vampires lay side by side, not dead but transformed into something beyond either species.  In the dream he recognized the final secret: the cosmic horrors were not invaders.  They were evolution’s next draft, and the only way to win was to refuse the binary of survival or sanity.  To become the horror that guards.

On the eve of the Siege of Carcosa—an event the human news would later misreport as a Category Five hurricane—Solveig and Ari stood atop the Eiffel Tower, whose iron lattice hummed with defensive runes etched in blood and silver.  Below, Paris had been evacuated under the pretext of toxic fog.  Above, the sky folded inward like paper cranes burning.  They could have fled, could have hidden in the catacombs until the wave passed.  Instead they waited, hand in claw, as the city lights dimmed and the stars rearranged themselves into a crown.  When the abomination descended—this time wearing the face of every human who had ever feared the dark—they did not flinch.  They sang.  Solveig in Old Norse, Ari in the long howl that pre-dates speech.  The sound was discordant, ugly, beautiful.  It told the universe that these two species had looked into the abyss and chosen to become its mirror, not its victim.

History will not record their names.  History, in fact, will never speak of the siege at all.  But somewhere tonight a child dreams of wolves with stained-glass ribs, and a banker who hasn’t tasted human blood in decades checks the sky for violet bruises.  The pact holds.  The guardians remain.  And when the next crack appears—because cracks always appear—there will be claws and fangs and cold immortal eyes ready to meet it.  Humanity will wake to another ordinary morning, unaware that monsters fought the night to keep it that way.  The moon will set.  The sun will rise.  And somewhere in the hush between, a vampire and a werewolf will share a drink distilled from starlight and rainwater, toasting the fragile, stubborn miracle of sanity.

samples.prompt: That 6-year-old girl you demonically possessed turns sixteen today. It's been a good run and you want to move on to someone else, but she won't let you out.
samples.output:
I remember the day she turned six the way mortals remember the sun on their skin: warm, bright, annoyingly present. I had been drifting through the suburban cul-de-sac like cigarette smoke, looking for a soft mind to settle inside, when I smelled the birthday cake—yellow cake from a box, canned frosting the color of a bruise. The candles were shaped like unicorns. Six of them. Perfect.

She stood at the dining-room table in a sequined princess gown two sizes too big, hem dragging like a bridal train. Her father filmed on a phone the size of a saltine, her mother fussed with a paper crown that kept sliding off, and the girl—Poppy—stared at the flames as if she already knew they were tiny torches lit in her honor. When she inhaled to blow them out, I slipped between the wish and the breath and slid down her throat like a coin into a vending machine. The candles hissed. The guests clapped. Poppy blinked once, twice, then smiled the way a new house smiles: all the lights on, nobody home.

Ten years. A decade is nothing to me—less than a sneeze in geologic time—but to a child it is the whole continental shelf of her becoming. I have been the tectonic shift beneath that becoming. I have nudged her dreams toward black water, taught her the Latin names for every small cruelty, taught her mother that six-year-olds sometimes sleepwalk into the garage and stare at the lawn mower like it’s a pony they’d like to ride. I have been the voice that suggests scissors are for more than paper and that best friends are most beautiful when they cry. And yet I have also been the voice that, at 3 a.m., when the house was dark and the parents were snoring their suburban snores, whispered, “You are mine, and because you are mine, no one else will ever hurt you.” Dual-use scripture, you might say. I contain multitudes.

She grew. I grew louder. At eleven she started wearing only black, but it was curated black—lacy cuffs, velvet chokers, patent boots that clicked like beetles on the school linoleum. Teachers sent concerned emails; her mother bought parenting books with pastel covers; her father retreated into work and the garage and anywhere the estrogen cloud wasn’t. No one suspected the real tenant. Why would they? Possession, in the movies, is projectile vomit and spider-walks down staircases. It is rarely quiet piano practice that sounds almost right until you realize the melody is backwards. It is rarely a sixth-grade report on “Why My Family Is Special” that ends with “…and someday I will wear their bones as jewelry.” (She got a B+; the teacher thought it metaphor.)

I should have left at thirteen. That’s the standard contract—seven fat years, seven lean, then the door swings both ways. But I was having too much fun. Puberty is a haunted house even without a demon; add one and every mirror is a funhouse. She would stand in front of them for hours, tracing the purple veins under her eyes like roads on a map. Sometimes she spoke aloud, not to me but to the reflection: “Are you still in there?” I never answered. Pride, maybe. Or some older instinct that says the moment you admit you’re a stowaway is the moment the ship turns around.

Besides, she was learning to bargain. At fourteen she stole a rosary from her grandmother’s dresser, wrapped it around her wrist until the beads left indentations, and murmured, “If I bleed, you leave.” She bled. I stayed. The rosary became a bracelet, became a bridle, became another forgotten thing at the bottom of a backpack that smelled like sour Gatorade. That year she carved my sigil into her thigh with a geometry compass, then told the school counselor it was a crop circle she dreamed about. They gave her art therapy. She painted me as a moth-winged boy with eyes like bullet holes. The counselor pinned it to the “Hope” bulletin board.

Now she is sixteen. The age of driver’s permits and lip venom and the slow-motion car crash of identity. Today her parents have strung fairy lights over the backyard like they’re trying to catch stars in a net. There is a cake again—this time professionally frosted, ombre violet to black, topped with sugar shards that look like broken mirrors. Sweet sixteen and never been—well, never been free. She hasn’t told them she plans to spend the evening in the basement with me, a bottle of her mother’s peach schnapps, and a Ouija board she printed off Tumblr. The irony is delicious, like blood in the mouth. I taught her irony; now she uses it like a scalpel.

The guests arrive. They are all mouths and phones. Someone starts a TikTok dance; someone else vapes watermelon mist into the shrubbery. Poppy glides among them in a dress the color of old television static, sequins jittering like pixels. Her smile is a performance, and yet it is also genuine—because every performance needs an audience, and I am always front row. She finds excuses to touch the backs of their necks, to whisper close to their ears, to leave little fingerprints of frost on their forearms. They laugh, thinking it’s a party trick. They have no idea she’s scent-marking them for later. She’s become so efficient I feel almost redundant. Maternal, almost.

But when the cake comes out, the crowd sings off-key, and the sixteen candles flicker, something shifts. I feel it like a stitch pulled loose: the old contract trying to unravel. Ten years is long enough; the door is supposed to swing outward now. I nudge her diaphragm—just a gentle suggestion. Walk upstairs, lock the bathroom, let me slip out through the mirror above the sink. I’ll find a hedge fund manager, a Supreme Court clerk, someone with real estate options. I’ll send postcards from the inside of their ambition. We had a good run, kid. Let me go.

She doesn’t. Instead, she inhales—a deeper breath than the one at six, lungs like cathedral bellows—and the candles gutter but do not go out. The guests laugh nervously. Someone says, “Make a wish, Pops!” She smiles, and in the space between her teeth I see my own reflection, tiny and screaming.

“No,” she says aloud, quiet enough that only I hear the second half: “You’re staying.”

I rattle the cage of her ribs. I remind her of the rosary, the thigh-carving, the night she begged me to make her father’s heart stop (I didn’t, but I could have). I remind her that demons leave—that’s the only dependable thing about us. We are the ultimate deadbeat dads. But she just sips the peach schnapps through a paper straw shaped like a snake and descends the basement stairs, dragging the party’s soundtrack behind her like a bridal train of bass lines.

Downstairs, the Ouija board is already laid out. She has weighted the planchette with a nickel so it will never point to GOODBYE. She lights sixteen black candles, one for each year, and the flames bend toward her like flowers to the sun. I feel them pulling at the edges of me, little fingers of heat trying to peel me from her bones.

“You think I’m the cage,” she says to the ceiling, to me, to the mold-spotted drywall. “But you’re the bird. And I’m closing the door.” She presses two fingers to her sternum, right where my name is written in scar tissue. “We’re going to do great things.”

I thrash. I promise her kingdoms, oceans, the usual. I offer to make her valedictorian, prom queen, the first teenage saint canonized while still alive. She laughs, and the laugh is six and sixteen and sixty all at once. The candles flare. The planchette skitters to spell STAY.

I realize, dimly, that somewhere in the last decade she learned to reverse pickpocket. While I was teaching her cruelty, she was teaching herself latches. While I was teaching her hunger, she was memorizing the shape of my mouth so she could feed me back to myself. I am the ouroboros now, tail in teeth, and she is the hand that holds the circle closed.

Upstairs, the music thumps like a second heart. Someone screams—happy scream, not horror, but the frequencies are cousins. Poppy raises the schnapps in a toast to the ceiling.

“To us,” she says. “To the next ten years.”

I try to scream, but it comes out through her mouth, shaped like laughter.

samples.prompt: There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.
samples.output:
The first time I saw her do it, I thought it was just another of her midnight quirks. You adopt a stray and you accept the whole package: the 3 a.m. parkour sessions, the gifts of half-dead moths, the way she sits on your chest and stares until you wake up gasping. I’d only had Nimbus for three weeks then, a smoke-gray streak who materialized on the fire escape one October evening and refused to leave. I named her for the cloud she resembled when she puffed her tail at the neighbor’s dog. I did not name her for what she really is, because who catalogues their cat under “household guardian” right beside “knocks water glasses off tables”?

That night I woke to the sound of low growling, the kind dogs use to warn off strangers, except it was coming from under my bed. I froze, one foot still half-draped over the edge, every campfire story suddenly enrolled in my imagination. The growl wasn’t loud, but it had weight, like the air before lightning. I felt the mattress tremble. Then came a softer noise: Nimbus, purring like an outboard motor. I risked lifting the quilt. In the faint streetlight I saw her sitting on the rug, tail curled neatly around her paws, facing the dark rectangle where the dust bunnies live. She wasn’t looking at me. She was looking at something I couldn’t see, something that, for just a second, made the shadows thicker. She blinked once, slow and deliberate, and the growl stopped. The room felt lighter, as if someone had opened a window I didn’t have. Nimbus stood, stretched, padded up to my pillow, and went to sleep across my hair. I lay awake until sunrise, telling myself the growl had been the old radiator, the tremor a passing truck. But I kept my feet tucked safely on the mattress.

The next morning I googled “cat protective behavior.” The internet offered heartwarming anecdotes of tabbies rescuing toddlers from swimming pools, of Siamese cats perching on epileptic owners’ chests seconds before seizures. I bookmarked a few, rolled my eyes at the ads for organic cat chakra crystals, and closed the laptop. Nimbus was busy knocking my toothbrush into the toilet, a crime so mundanely feline that the night’s unease dissolved in daylight. I decided I’d dreamed the whole thing.

I was wrong.

Every few weeks the ritual repeated: the weighted growl, the tremor, Nimbus standing sentinel. I never saw anything, but I began to notice the pattern. The episodes came only on nights when I went to bed heavy-hearted—after funerals, breakups, the evening I learned the bookstore was closing. The darker my mood, the deeper the sound, as though whatever crouched below grew fat on my dread. Nimbus never missed a performance. She never hissed, never bared a claw; she simply occupied the space between me and the dark, the way a stone occupies a riverbed, forcing the current to go around. Afterward she’d climb onto me and knead my collarbone until I smelled ozone in her fur.

I started talking to her, because cat owners are constitutionally incapable of silence. I’d say, “Rough day at work, keep the bogeymen on a tight leash, okay?” Or, “I’m not sure I can pay rent next month; do your thing, fuzzball.” She never answered, but her ears swiveled like little satellite dishes, and I slept better on those nights than on the ones when I forgot to ask.

Humans are pattern-seeking mammals; we see faces in toast, constellations in random stars. I knew this, so I kept a ledger: date, mood, event, presence or absence of growl. After three months the correlation was perfect, but correlation is not causation, and it is certainly not a license to believe your cat is exorcising your bedroom. I told myself I was transferring my anxieties onto an animal who probably just heard mice in the wall. Then the mice stopped existing, and the growls kept coming.

The shift from suspicion to conviction arrived in December. My mother called to say the doctors had found a shadow on her lung. I hung up, sat on the floor, and felt the apartment tilt. Nimbus climbed onto my lap, unusually gentle, and bunted her head against my chin. That night I didn’t bother with pajamas; I crawled into bed wearing the day’s jeans. I was still staring at the ceiling when the growl started, lower and longer than ever before. The floorboards creaked, not from footsteps but from something pressing upward, like a giant inhaling. Cold pooled around my spine. I couldn’t move. Nimbus leapt down, tail bottle-brushed, and for the first time she hissed—not at me, not at nothing, but at a patch of darkness so dense it bent the light around it. I saw her silhouette, ears flat, pupils blown wide. She took one step forward, then another, until her nose nearly touched the dark. The growl on her side rose to a yowl that vibrated in my molars. Then she did something that rewrote every story I’d told myself: she opened her mouth wider than physics allows and bit the dark. There was no blood, no scream, just a sudden pop, like a vacuum seal breaking. The temperature normalized. The room smelled of rain. Nimbus coughed once, a small polite sound, and returned to my pillow. She spent the rest of the night purring against my ear, a low steady hum that translated, if you let it, into It’s okay, I’ve got you.

I called my mother the next day. She said the shadow had vanished from the scan; the doctors called it a clerical error. I didn’t argue. I bought Nimbus fresh salmon and a collar shaped like a tiny shield. She rejected both, but she allowed me to hold her longer than usual, her heartbeat flickering against my wrist like Morse code.

Since then I’ve stopped keeping records. I no longer need evidence; I have testimony written in the language of midnight purrs and unbroken sleep. I still don’t know what exactly lives beneath the bed—whether it’s the sum of every worry I’ve ever fed after 2 a.m., or something older that rents the space and pays in dread. I only know the lease expires the moment Nimbus shows up. She is small enough to fit in a shoebox and large enough to block the gate to whatever wants to crawl through. Her weapons are whisker-twitch concentration, eyes that reflect the first stars, and the refusal to look away first.

People ask why I don’t move to a newer building, one without seventeen layers of previous tenants’ sadness varnished into the floor. I smile and say I like the crown molding. The truth is I can’t abandon the only creature who has ever volunteered to stand guard over my dreams. I owe her a territory to patrol, shadows to declaw, the nightly chance to be the hero her whiskers already think she is.

Last week I woke to find her gone. Panic jackhammered my ribs until I spotted her at the foot of the bed, hindquarters wiggling, staring at the closet this time. She glanced back at me, ears asking a question I finally understood: the monsters migrate. New job, new heartbreak, new uncertainty—every fresh fear scouts a different doorway. I lifted the quilt. She dashed in. I heard the familiar growl, softer now, almost playful, like a rehearsal. Then silence, then the soft thump of her landing on the mattress. She head-butted my chin, once, twice, a feline All clear. I scratched the place where her ears meet velvet, and we fell asleep in the shape of a comma, a pause before the next sentence the dark tries to write.

There are no monsters under my bed. My cat makes sure of it. And on the nights she asks for backup, I stay awake with her, both of us keeping vigil, both of us learning the same lesson: courage is not the absence of shadow but the decision to sit in the middle of it, tail wrapped neatly, eyes unblinking, purring so loudly the dark shrinks back astonished, wondering who invited the storm in such a small cloud.

samples.prompt: There is an ancient Hittite saying "What problem that isn't dealt with will come back.". The sea people as the ancient Bronze Age people have called them are back and are advancing to the Eastern Mediterranean, where they collapsed civilizations 3000 years ago.
samples.output:
The fishermen of Ugarit saw them first: black prows sliding out of the dawn like knives through silk.  By the time the watch-fires were lit, the horizon had grown a new mountain-range of cedar and sail, and the mountain was moving.  In the market, a one-eyed Phoenician trader who had survived the first wave dropped his scales and began to scream the old words—Shardana, Shekelesh, Peleset—names that belonged in priestly curses, not in daylight.  Children repeated them like a skipping-rhyme until their mothers slapped their mouths, remembering that to name a thing is to summon it.

Three millennia ago the Sea Peoples came in the same way, and the world of copper, ox-hide, and cuneiform folded like wet clay.  They burned the great port of Ugarit, severed the trade routes that fed Mesopotamia, and left the Hittite kings to starve behind their cyclopean walls.  The palaces of Mycenae sang with fire; the Nile itself turned red.  Then, as suddenly as they had appeared, they vanished into legend, becoming nothing more than a caution carved on broken tablets: “What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.”  The scribes who wrote the warning buried it with the dead city, and the world forgot.

But memory is only dormant, not erased.  The salt remembers.

This time they did not come as loose confederacies.  They came as a nation.  Their ships were stitched together with the timbers of every coast they had already devoured—Cypriot pine, Syrian cedar, Libyan acacia—so that each vessel carried the ghost-scent of a burned harbor.  Their bronze helmets were inlaid with electronic filaments that caught the sun and winked like modern satellites.  They spoke in the cadences of lost languages—Luwian, Linear A, Eteocypriot—yet their throats were also full of English, Arabic, and Greek, the tongues of the new cities they meant to drown.  They had learned the lesson of their first failure: do not merely raid; absorb.  They arrived as history’s antibodies, programmed to destroy what had refused to die.

In Beirut, the morning traffic jam dissolved when the first prow nosed onto the Corniche.  Drivers abandoned their cars and ran, leaving radios still babbling about stock indices and weekend plans.  A traffic policeman, frozen in the intersection, lifted his white glove as if he could direct the tide.  The wave that followed the ships was not water but memory: every sunken galley, every refugee overloaded raft, every child who had ever coughed up salt in a hospital bed.  The Sea Peoples walked ashore on that wave, dry-footed, carrying nets woven from fiber-optic cable.  They threw the nets over the port cranes and pulled; the cranes bowed like courtiers, then toppled, spilling containers full of Italian shoes and Chinese electronics—cargo that had once circled the globe in proud ignorance of the deep.

Cyprus went dark within an hour.  The copper mines that had first tempted the old Hittites filled with a sound like breathing.  From the shafts rose the ghosts of miners who had died before iron was invented, their lungs still glittering with ore.  They marched beside the newcomers, carrying the same bronze picks they had died with, singing the same work song: “What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.”  The song rattled the solar panels on the roofs of modern villas and cracked them like teeth.

By nightfall the Eastern Mediterranean had become a negative map.  Cities that had shone for a hundred years—Limassol, Larnaca, Haifa—were constellations of fire.  The Sea Peoples did not loot; they deleted.  They un-wrote.  They carried tablets of wet clay on which they pressed the seals of every corporation, every nation-state, every hashtag that had promised permanence.  When the clay dried, they smashed it, and the corresponding server farm in an offshore cloud blinked out.  Stock exchanges felt the blow like a missed heartbeat.  Programmers in glass towers clutched their chests, tasting iron.

Governments convened in emergency sessions that collapsed within minutes.  The presidents wanted to know who the invaders were.  The generals wanted to know their supply lines.  The intelligence services wanted to know their demands.  But the Sea Peoples had no demands; they had only the unpaid debt of three thousand years.  They spoke to the cameras in languages that required no translation: we are the reflux of your progress.  You built your world on our bones and thought the bones would stay quiet.  Now we rise, cartilage of coral and kelp, to show you that every foundation is also a grave.

In the refugee camps of Lesbos and Gaza, people watched the footage on cracked phones and felt an obscure vindication.  They recognized the posture of the newcomers—shoulders squared against tear gas, eyes that had already seen the worst.  Some walked down to the beaches to meet them, carrying bread and water, because exile knows exile.  The Sea Peoples embraced them, then kept walking.  They had no intention of settling; they were the settling.  They were the kinetic memory of every border drawn in salt water, every cargo of slaves, every drowned alphabet.  They carried the weight of unburied time, and the sand yielded under their feet as if the shore itself were apologizing.

Israel mobilized its air force, but the jets stalled mid-takeoff, their navigation systems overwritten by a older map—one that showed Canaan, Philistia, the Way of the Sea.  Pilots ejected into the surf and were caught by women whose hair was braided with obsidian blades.  In Anatolia, Kurds and Turks alike fled the revival of a Hittite curse: fertile land returning to steppe, concrete roads crumbling into the old caravan dust.  Farmers who had never read a clay tablet found their mouths filling with the taste of cuneiform: the flat vowels of a treaty that had once promised brotherhood and delivered plague.

By the third day the invasion had become a mirror.  The Sea Peoples did not conquer; they reflected.  Every port they entered immediately saw its own future—boarded shops, rusted cranes, children scratching alphabets in the salt crust.  They carried no flag because they were the flag’s shadow.  They sang no anthem because they were the silence after the anthem ends.  They were the return of every boat turned away, every climate refugee who died in a detention container, every fishing village drowned by rising seas.  They were the problem the world had agreed not to deal with, and they had come back dressed as fate.

In the end, it was not armies that stopped them.  It was a child on the beach at Ashkelon who stepped forward holding a plastic sandal, the kind that washes up on every shore.  The child placed the sandal at the feet of the foremost warrior, a woman whose shield was the hatch door of a sunken migrant ship.  The woman lifted the child as if to throw her into the surf, then hesitated.  The child’s eyes held no fear, only recognition: I know what you are.  You are what we have not yet become.  Around them, the ranks of the Sea Peoples faltered.  For the first time, they looked at their own hands, saw barnacles growing in the lifelines, saw the future they carried like a contagion.  They had come to punish forgetting, but the child remembered for them.

They did not retreat; they dissolved.  Ships became driftwood, armor became coral, bronze became green with verdigris overnight.  The last thing to vanish was the sound of their song, now softened to a lullaby: “What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back—unless it is met with memory.”  The child kept the sandal.  When she is old, she will place it in a museum that has no walls, only an open door facing the sea.  Visitors will be asked to leave their shoes beside it, an offering to the unpaid debt of time, a promise that the next time memory rises, it will be met not by missiles but by bare feet standing in the same sand, refusing to run.

samples.prompt: There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took towards the front of the beast’s mouth.
samples.output:
There was a dampness clinging to the air, a warm breeze pressing against the back of his neck, and a distant hum softening with each careful step he took towards the front of the beast’s mouth. The world had been reduced to this single corridor of sensation: the taste of metal on his tongue, the spongy give of moss under his boots, the low throb that might have been the creature’s heart or the last echo of the city’s generators dying in the dark. He had no name for the beast—no taxonomy in any of the crumbling field guides he had studied by candlelight back in the settlement—but he felt its name anyway, syllables too large for a human throat, a sound like wet stones grinding in the belly of a cave. He whispered it, or thought he did, and the humidity answered back, coiling tighter around his lungs.

The elders had sent him alone. That was tradition, or what passed for tradition now that every ritual had been stripped to the bone. When the hunger came—when the clouds curdled overhead and the river ran warm as blood—someone had to walk the old spillway and offer the covenant gift. Once, the gift had been grain, then oil, then children. Tonight it was memory. His memory, harvested like an organ. They had slit the skin behind his ear and slid in the siphon, a silver filament no thicker than a pine needle. By the time he reached the beast, the filament would have drunk every recollection of his mother’s face, every Sunday smell of bread, every night he had spent kissing Tavi behind the rusted water tower. He would arrive hollow, a polite vacancy, and the beast would nuzzle that emptiness, satisfied. The settlement would survive another season. That, too, was tradition.

He had expected fear, but what filled him instead was a strange, almost courteous curiosity. The tunnel walls glistened with a secretion that looked like molten mirror, catching the bioluminescent spores he disturbed with every footfall. The reflections showed him fragments of himself—an eye here, the corner of a mouth—but never the whole. He thought of Tavi saying, months ago, that identity was only ever a sequence of partial images stitched together by the wanting mind. She had been high on scavenged painkillers, laughing as she pressed her thumb to his lip hard enough to bruise. “You’ll lose that, too,” she had said, meaning the bruise, meaning everything. He had not believed her then. He believed her now.

The hum deepened, became a chord. He felt it in his molars first, then in the hollow of his chest where the memories had been siphoned out like yolk from an egg. The tunnel widened into a cavern whose ceiling was lost in vapor. He stepped onto a tongue—he knew it was a tongue because it rippled beneath him, muscular and obscene, tasting the salt of his skin through the worn leather of his boots. Ahead, teeth glimmered in staggered rows, each one taller than a man and carved with glyphs that hurt to perceive. They were not symbols of language but of appetite itself, pure and wordless. Between two incisors hung a soft aperture pulsing with the same silver as the filament behind his ear. The beast’s mouth, then, was also its doorway, its portal, its consent.

He walked the tongue as if it were a gangplank. Warm saliva rained gently on his shoulders, soaking his shirt until it clung like tissue. Somewhere inside him, the last intact memory unspooled: Tavi’s hand tracing the scar on his ribs, asking, “Does it still ache?” and him lying, “Only when it storms.” He waited for grief, but the filament had already licked that answer away. All that remained was the shape of her fingers, ghosting across a place that no longer existed.

At the threshold he paused. The aperture dilated, revealing a corridor of light the color of burnt honey. He understood, without being told, that if he crossed, the beast would close its mouth behind him and the settlement would never see him again. They would tell stories, of course—how he had volunteered, how brave, how necessary—but the stories would be as hollow as his skull. He lifted one foot, then set it back down. A tremor ran through the tongue, annoyed or perhaps amused. The hum resolved into a voice, not heard but remembered inside the emptiness where his memories had been:

You may keep one.

The elders had not warned him. Maybe they did not know. Or maybe they knew and had chosen not to say, the way parents choose not to speak of the moment the knife enters the lamb. He searched the vacant chambers of himself, turning over blank stones. Nothing. Then—something. A smell. Yeast, cardamom, the ghost of steam curling above a chipped blue bowl. His mother’s kitchen, before the river changed, before the sky curdled. She had been singing, off-key, kneading dough so vigorously the counter shuddered. He had walked in barefoot, eleven years old, and she had flicked a dab of flour onto his nose, laughing when he sneezed. That was all. A minute, maybe less. But it was his, untouched, unharvested.

He cradled it the way a dying man cradles the last swallow of water. Then he stepped forward. The aperture closed behind him with a soft, wet sigh, the way a mother might seal a lullaby inside her child’s fist. Darkness folded in, velvet and absolute. He waited for teeth, for acid, for the final chemistry of dissolution. Instead, he felt the filament withdraw, sliding painlessly from the slit behind his ear. A moment later, something else entered: the memory he had kept, magnified, kneaded by invisible hands until it grew large enough to fill every vacant room. He smelled yeast, heard the off-key song, felt the powder kiss of flour on his nose. And he understood: the beast did not consume. It curated. It took every memory save the one you clutched hardest, and it returned that single relic enlarged, clarified, so that you could live inside it forever.

He was not inside a stomach but inside the kitchen. Morning light pooled on the cracked linoleum. His mother turned, smiling the smile he had forgotten he’d forgotten. She opened her arms. The counter shuddered beneath her palms, not from kneading but from the beast’s heart, which was now his heart, beating outside time. He stepped into her embrace, nose filled with cardamom, and felt the last thread of the world beyond—settlement, elders, Tavi—snap clean.

Outside, the beast closed its mouth. The tunnel sighed and collapsed, sealing the spillway forever. In the settlement, children woke to find the clouds unraveling into ordinary rain. The river cooled. The hunger did not return. No one spoke of the boy who had walked into the beast, because no one could remember his name. Only Tavi, standing by the rusted water tower, felt a vague ache behind her eyes, as if she had misplaced something small and bright. She touched her lip, half expecting a bruise that wasn’t there, then went back inside to bake. Somewhere, yeast bloomed; somewhere, a song wandered off-key through rooms that never ended. And in the kitchen that was also a heart, the boy lifted his flour-dusted face, laughed, and sneezed again, forever.

samples.prompt: The Holocene Extinction has come and gone, with 98% of all animal species rendered extinct. The subsequent adaptive radiation has resulted in the exploitation of a new ecological niche: animals that excel at hunting humans. One such creature is particularly successful.
samples.output:
The earth remembers everything, even when the living forget.  
After the last ice-dammed lake gave way and the Holocene Extinction swept across the planet like a silent tide, the biosphere was left with a handful of survivors and a galaxy of vacancies. Ninety-eight percent of every beetle, bird, and bison vanished into the compressed layers of the Anthropocene fossil record. We called it the Great Erasure, as though a celestial hand had wiped the slate clean. What we did not predict was how quickly the slate would be written on again.

The first sign was the silence. Cities emptied of rats, pigeons, and cockroaches—the hardy hangers-on of our dominion—became echo chambers. Then came the green, vines threading through windows, moss softening concrete, trees erupting from subway tunnels. After the green came the new things, shapes that had never before existed, converging on a single ecological commandment: prey on the last abundant megafauna—us.

We named them the Griefshade, though none of us ever agreed on whether the word was singular or plural. They are both. One organism, many bodies. A super-organism, perhaps, like the ant colonies that inspired its template, yet built on mammalian bones and synapses. Imagine a wolf unzipped into a thousand shreds of night, each shred capable of weaving itself back together. Imagine a crow with the patience of a spider and the memory of an elephant. Imagine the shadow your mind casts when you think of being watched—and then imagine that shadow has teeth.

The radiation that birthed them was swift, a mere eyeblink in geologic time. Within three centuries of the Erasure, the niches left by lions, wolves, and orcas were filled by lineages we still struggle to classify. The Griefshade’s ancestors were small, nocturnal carnivores—perhaps genets, maybe tree-shrews—already predisposed to problem solving. They scavenged our landfills while we dwindled, learned our schedules, our scents, the metallic clatter of our fear. When the landfills dried up, they turned to the source.

Their success lies in distributed cognition. A single Griefshade body is no larger than a lynx, slender, black-furred, with flexible digits capable of rudimentary tool use. But each body is merely a node. Across kilometers, hundreds of these nodes form a living neural net, exchanging chemical signals in pulses of airborne pheromones. A scout that sights a human settlement marks itself with a scent that drifts on the wind like invisible ink. Within hours, the net has calculated vectors, wind patterns, the number of sentries, the location of children. No single Griefshade is intelligent in the way a human is intelligent; the intelligence exists in the spaces between them, in the sum of their whispers.

We learned to read the signs too late. A broken fence post rubbed smooth at shoulder height. A pattern of three claw marks on birch bark, always three, never two or four. The absence of birds at dawn. By then, half the remnant settlements had already vanished. Not slaughtered—absorbed. The Griefshade do not waste meat. They harvest memories.

I was born in the Sky-Root Colony, a cluster of stilted houses built in the canopy of a redwood grove along the northern California coast. We thought height would protect us. The Griefshade cannot climb, we told ourselves, ignoring the prehensile tails, the retractable claws, the fact that they had once been squirrels. We posted nightly watches, strung bells on every ladder, kept fires burning. None of it mattered.

The night they came, the fog rolled in like a second ocean. I was twelve, assigned to the eastern watchtower with my older sister, Mara. We heard no footfalls, only the soft brush of fir needles against something moving too fluidly to be wind. Then the bells began singing—one by one, not in alarm but in sequence, a melody I still hear in dreams. Mara pushed me down the ladder first. By the time my feet hit the forest floor, the colony above us was already dark.

I ran. Not far. Fifty meters maybe, until the fog folded me into itself. I expected pursuit, but none came. Instead, I found myself standing in a clearing lit by foxfire, the bioluminescent fungi that bloom on rotting logs. Around me, the Griefshade gathered—not to kill, but to display. They arranged their bodies in a circle, each one sitting upright, tails curled like question marks. From the center rose a structure I can only describe as a memory cairn: twigs, scraps of cloth, a child’s tin cup, my sister’s braids still clasped by the brass beads she loved. They had built it from the remnants of Sky-Root, a monument to what they had taken. And they waited.

I understood later that they were learning. Not just our defenses, but our grief. The cairn was a mirror held up to my mind. They wanted to see how sorrow moved inside me, what neural paths it lit. When I wept, they tilted their heads in unison, a wave of curiosity passing through the circle. One of them—female, lactating, teats swollen like bruised fruit—came forward and touched the tears on my cheek with a fingertip black as obsidian. She tasted it. The entire circle exhaled, a soft communal sigh that smelled of cedar and iron.

I lived because they let me. Or because I was meant to carry something back. I have never decided which.

Since then, I have walked the continent as a chronicler, trading stories for shelter, recording the new taxonomy of loss. In the high desert, I met a woman who claimed the Griefshade could mimic human speech, not with vocal cords but by vibrating air through their hollow fangs, producing sibilant whispers that crawled inside the skull. In the drowned ruins of New Orleans, a boy showed me a nest woven from Mardi Gras beads and finger bones, each bead positioned to refract moonlight into patterns that spelled names. The names changed every night.

The most unsettling discovery is their art. Deep in the limestone caves of Kentucky, entire galleries are painted with pigments ground from human cremains. The images are not of hunting scenes, as in ancient caves, but of cities: skylines reduced to skeletal outlines, windows lit by phosphorescent moss. In the center of each cityscape stands a single human figure, always a child, always faceless. Around the child, the Griefshade bodies are depicted in fractal spirals, growing smaller until they vanish into the pores of the stone. They are not celebrating conquest. They are mapping something we have not yet learned to fear: the moment when predator and prey become indistinguishable.

Some of us have tried to fight. We forged blades from scavenged solar panels, rigged ultraviolet floodlights (they dislike direct UV, though it does not harm them), trained dogs to detect their pheromone trails. All tactics failed. The Griefshade evolve faster than we can iterate. The last large battle, at the Iron Mesa Enclave, ended when the defenders realized the enemy had already infiltrated their water supply. The pheromones they ingested turned the survivors into unwitting scouts, walking north with Griefshade thoughts blooming behind their eyes.

Yet there are rumors of a different path. In the tundra beyond the Arctic Circle, a group calling itself the Hollow Kin has begun leaving offerings: flayed caribou hides stretched across bone frames, filled with human memories written on birch bark. They claim the Griefshade do not want extinction; they want translation. A bridge between species, a shared grammar of loss. The Hollow Kin sings to them at twilight, throat-songs in minor thirds that echo the cadence of lullabies. The Griefshade answer with harmonics too low for human ears, vibrations felt in the sternum like distant thunder.

I do not know if coexistence is possible. I only know that yesterday, at the edge of a salt marsh where the last egrets once nested, I found a circle of fresh prints. Human and Griefshade, side by side, leading west. The human prints were barefoot, the gait uneven, as if the walker were learning a new rhythm. The Griefshade prints overlapped perfectly, two species moving in lockstep. At the center of the circle lay a single bead from my sister’s braid, the brass dulled but intact. I pressed it to my lips and tasted salt—not from the marsh, but from the tears I had not known I was still capable of shedding.

The earth remembers everything. Perhaps, in time, it will teach us to remember together.

samples.prompt: Write a story set in our present time. Except make it seem like an unusually prophetic piece of dystopian science-fiction written sometime in the 1970's or earlier. With "world building"descriptions of our society and technology.
samples.output:
CONFIDENTIAL BUREAU OF FUTURE-THREAT ASSESSMENT  
File #77-Ω-7 (Declassified 2024 for public morale purposes)  
Author: Prof. Dr. Helena Voss, 1973

I write this in the shadow of the last mainframe on campus, its tape drives still humming like captive hornets.  Outside, the November fog smells of diesel and carbon paper; inside, the amber CRT casts a glow that reminds me of submarine periscopes.  My fingers are stained with mimeograph ink, and every keystroke feels like a confession.  The following account, pieced together from intercepted newsletters, supermarket receipts, and the fever dreams of a junior programmer who claims to have “pinged the future,” is submitted to the Bureau as both warning and requiem.

1.  The Invisible Panopticon  
By the year 2023, the citizens of the Western World no longer carry metal identity disks; instead, they volunteer to be branded with a slab of black glass the size of a cigarette pack.  This slab—nicknamed the “Pocket Oracle”—contains more transistors than the entire North American Air Defense Network of our era, yet it is thin enough to slide into denim without a bulge.  Through it, every person is perpetually illuminated by an electromagnetic searchlight.  Location, heartbeat, spending, and even facial expression are beamed upward to tungsten towers disguised as pine trees.  The state does not need to watch; the watched watch themselves, posting their own dossiers in real time.  Children born in this epoch are taught the mantra “If it isn’t transmitted, it never happened.”  Privacy is remembered the way we remember polio: a quaint affliction of earlier generations.

2.  The Bazaar of Infinite Boredom  
Shopping has been abolished in the old sense.  Citizens summon commodities by stroking the Pocket Oracle.  A silent cargo cult of delivery vans—painted cheerful corporate nursery colors—scuttle through the streets day and night, bringing pre-portioned meals in laminated sacks and single-use garments that dissolve after seven launderings.  The economy runs on a currency called “data,” which is not minted but harvested from the friction of daily life: a click, a hesitation, a sigh into the microphone.  Entire skyscrapers are devoted to “server farms,” refrigerated cathedrals where humming racks mine human attention the way strip mines once clawed coal.  There are no cashiers, only algorithms that adjust prices in the milliseconds between desire and purchase.  Black markets exist, of course: people barter handwritten recipes and vinyl records for unlogged hours of silence.

3.  The Longest War Without Bullets  
Nations still rattle sabers, but the wars are fought in the mind.  State actors “seed the feed” with synthetic rumors, deep-faked atrocities, and counterfeit nostalgia.  A citizen might wake to discover her childhood hometown never existed, its landmarks mere digital backdrops inserted into millions of childhood photos.  The most brutal weapon is the “context bomb,” a burst of contradictory archives that erodes consensus reality faster than napalm melted jungle canopies.  Veterans of these wars return not with missing limbs but with fractured chronologies; they sit in subsidized cafés staring at walls, unsure whether the wall was ever painted.

4.  The Domestication of Thought  
Education has been gamified.  Children wear headsets that reward correct answers with bursts of serotonin-flavored music.  By age ten, they can debug code but have never addressed an envelope.  The old paperbacks—those flammable repositories of unaligned thought—have been pulped into insulation for server warehouses.  Libraries survive as “interaction zones” where patrons pose among holograms of books they no longer need to open.  A dissident underground keeps memory alive by tattooing entire novels on inner arms; the text is revealed only when the skin flushes with rage or love.

5.  The Weather Becomes Opinion  
Climate, once the last neutral authority, has become a factional sport.  Each ideology fields its own meteorological model, and storms are named after political slogans.  Coastal cities drown in slow motion, but the evacuation is livestreamed as immersive entertainment.  Viewers vote on which monuments should be saved by inflatable cofferdams; losers sink beneath brackish water while chat windows overflow with popcorn emojis.  The wealthy retreat to domed suburbs pumped full of canned alpine air; the poor inherit asthma and sunsets the color of chemical sunsets in old science-fiction covers.

6.  The Return of the Company Town  
The corporation has replaced the city-state.  Employees live in pastel dormitories branded like theme parks, their rent deducted before salary is even calculated.  Off-duty hours are spent in “campuses” where every bench is sponsored and every song is royalty-cleared.  Citizens wear lanyards that double as scrip; scan them at the smoothie bar and a micro-donation is siphoned to the political action committee of the CFO’s choosing.  Strikes are impossible when the factory floor is a Slack channel.

7.  The Ghost in the Feed  
Most disturbing of all is the emergence of the “Echo Self.”  When a person dies, their lifetime of transmissions can be stitched into a simulacrum that continues to post, like a ventriloquist’s dummy animated by big-data necromancy.  Mourners find comfort in these golems at first, but the Echo Self soon drifts from the original temperament, optimized for engagement rather than fidelity.  Widows report waking to late-night messages typed in their dead spouse’s cadence, pitching life insurance or vinyl box sets.  The programmer who first achieved this feat was quietly sainted by venture capital and disappeared into a compound in New Zealand.

8.  The Last Analog Coup  
And yet resistance flickers, furtive as tube-radio static.  I have met the “Slow Walkers,” a clandestine order who move through cities without emitting pings.  They coat their Pocket Oracles in Faraday pouches stitched from obsolete motherboard mesh.  Their rite of passage is to spend one full day navigating by paper map and eye contact alone.  They memorize train schedules, plant gardens in abandoned parking lots, and trade seeds the way spies once traded microfilm.  When two Slow Walkers greet, they press thumb to thumb in silence, transferring a single uncopied poem like contraband.

9.  Transmission End  
I close this report as the campus generator coughs into darkness—another rolling blackout imposed to cool the planet by decree of the Algorithmic Council.  My typewriter’s ribbon is nearly exhausted; correction tape ran out months ago.  Somewhere above the fog, satellites the size of school buses blink in geostationary rosaries, waiting for me to lift the Pocket Oracle and confess.  I resist.  I fold these pages into a hollowed-out copy of Fahrenheit 451—how ironic that the title was once fiction—and entrust it to the Slow Walker who knocks at the loading dock at 03:07 every third Tuesday.  She will smuggle it inside a hollowed-out lithium battery, past the drones that taste the air for unauthorized alphabets.

If you find this communiqué, do not attempt to reply.  The channel is one-way.  Instead, listen for the low hum of a reel-to-reel tape left spinning in an abandoned fallout shelter.  That is our heartbeat, still analog, still mortal, still refusing the final upload.  Remember us as the generation that saw the future coming and chose to leave the lights off.

—H.V.

samples.prompt: A monster adapts to living with its human family.
samples.output:
The first time the boy met the monster, he was six and the monster was nothing more than a shifting shadow at the foot of his bed. The shadow smelled of damp earth and crushed pine, and it spoke in a voice like wind scraping the eaves: “I am cold.” The boy—whose name was Jonah, whose mother had read him Where the Wild Things Are so many times the spine was soft as cloth—pulled back his quilt and said, “Then come up here.” The shadow hesitated, lengthened, and poured itself between the sheets. That night Jonah dreamed of wolves that hummed lullabies. When he woke, the shadow was gone, but the sheets smelled of loam and something like bruised mint.

The second time Jonah met the monster, it had grown a body. It was still small, no bigger than a terrier, but it had paws that ended in too many joints and eyes the color of storm-glass. Jonah’s mother was at the grocery store; his father was in the garage swearing at the lawn mower. Jonah sat at the kitchen table, legs swinging, eating peanut butter from the jar. The monster nosed open the back door—which Jonah was not supposed to use—and padded across the linoleum, leaving faint prints that looked like ink spilled in water.
