In that inverted world I see myself reflected—brown blob, nose pink as uncooked shrimp.  She says, “You’re so soft.”  I feel her pulse through my ribcage, a drum we both march to but with different cadences.  She will grow, leave for college, return only on weekends that smell of laundry and guilt.  I will grow old in guinea-pig years, which compress like accordion bellows: seven of mine for every one of hers.  Already my hips stiffen.  I am a calendar she checks off with accidental neglect.  When she forgets to refill the water bottle, I lick condensation from the metal spout and pretend it is rain.

Is there a heaven for creatures who never sinned because no one told them the rules?  The preacher on the television in the living room says animals have no souls, but he has never seen the way Luna stares at the wall after her last baby was taken.  That vacancy is a soul subtracted, a negative space shaped exactly like love.  If souls are holes, we are full of them.  I worry that after death I will simply be lifted again, this time by hands without warmth, and placed into a vacuum where no sound carries.  Will I still hear the refrigerator clicking?  Will the blue sky finally close its mouth, or does it go on being blue for everyone except me?

Yesterday I bit the hand that feeds me.  Not hard—just enough to taste the salt, the surprise, the momentary recoil.  For one glorious second the hand belonged to something as mortal as I am.  Blood rose in a tiny bead, a red planet.  I wanted to ask it: Do you also dream of wheels that never stop?  Do you also count days in cucumber slices?  But the moment passed; the hand became a god again, larger than the sky.  I was dropped back onto sawdust, and the planet was wiped away with a tissue printed with smiling suns.  The suns looked like Popcorns mid-jump, frozen in permanent alarm.

I have begun to lose fur in patches.  The skin underneath is map-like, territories of pink and gray.  I lick myself bald because the tongue is the only brush I own, and because pain is a location I can point to: here, between ribs; here, above ankle.  When the humans notice, they will take me to the white-table place that smells of alcohol and other animals’ fear.  Maybe I will not come back.  Maybe I will come back minus a tumor, minus teeth, minus the will to jump.  Either way, the question mark of my spine will straighten into an exclamation nobody hears.

Night again.  The house inhales, exhales.  I press my cheek to the corner where two walls of plastic meet at a right angle.  Right angles do not exist in nature; they are proof that we are inside.  I try to remember grass, the original mesh, but the memory is only a green sound, a rustle that might have been my mother or the first wheel.  I sniff the corner and discover a single oat wedged there since last Tuesday.  Oats are time capsules, brittle galaxies.  I chew slowly, counting the fractures between teeth and oat, trying to make the moment last exactly as long as the universe has existed.  Mathematically impossible, yet here I am, a rodent attempting infinity one crumb at a time.

When the oat is gone, I do something I have never done: I stand on hind legs and place front paws against the transparent wall.  Beyond it, the bedroom is dark, but the digital clock burns red: 3:33.  Numbers are a language of exile; they never squeak back.  Still, I press harder until nails screech.  I imagine the plastic giving way like ice, a clean rectangle I could step through.  On the other side would be carpet, then hallway, then kitchen, then door, then world, then sky.  The blue that hurts.  The blue that keeps going.  I stay like that until my muscles tremble, a tiny statue of longing.

No crack.  The wall holds, indifferent as theology.  I drop to all fours, lungs whistling.  In the silence that follows, I hear something new: my own heart, but as if from a distance, a small wet drum inside a larger room.  It says: You are here.  You are here.  You are here.  The statement is neither comfort nor condemnation; it is merely the tense we live in, continuous present, the grammar of cages and of galaxies alike.  I listen until the syllables wear smooth, until they stop being words and become the sound of sawdust settling, of refrigerator clicking, of a universe that has finished inhaling and is, at last, ready to exhale.

Tomorrow they will change the shavings.  The wheel will wait, silent and greased.  A cucumber slice will appear, coin of a realm whose king is absent.  I will eat it, or I will not.  Either way, the day will taste like salt and iron and the color green I almost remember.  And somewhere inside the drum of my chest, the question mark will uncurl itself by the tiniest degree, not straight into an answer but into a slightly different question: What if the sky is not a place to reach, but a color we carry, invisible to every eye except the one that watches from behind our own?  I close my eyes—no, they are already closed; I have been seeing through lids all along.  In that inner darkness I paint a rectangle of blue so large it has no edges.  Then I do the only thing left to do: I jump.  Not up, but forward, into the color.  The plastic wall does not move.  The blue does.  It rushes in, tasting of over-ripe apple, of rain on tin, of thirty-three hearts I never got to teach how to beat.  It tastes, for one impossible second, like freedom.  Then the house exhales, the lamp clicks off, and I am back on sawdust, alive, still counting.  The number is larger than 732, larger than thirty-three, larger than blue.  It is the exact size of the space between now and the next now, a distance no wheel can cross.  I curl into it, nose to tail, a period at the end of a sentence no one has spoken aloud.  Outside, the refrigerator hums its answer: stay, stay, stay.  Inside, I obey.

samples.prompt: This is a world where excrement is stored, and only released annually in a big event. Tell us the story of your pooping day.
samples.output:
The first thing I remember is the smell of pine resin burning in the plaza braziers, sharp and sweet, cutting through the usual city fug. It’s the thirty-first day of the twelfth month, and the whole of Low-Hearth has been humming for weeks like a kettle kept just below boil. Children run past my window with paper lanterns shaped like spirals, the traditional “release sign.” Shopkeepers have hung cedar boughs above their doors. Even the gulls that normally scream over the fish market are gone—frightened, maybe, by the low, constant roll of drums that starts at dawn and does not stop until dusk.  

I wake before the drums, when the sky is still the color of wet ash. My stomach, accustomed to its year-long discipline, feels suddenly alien: a hard, hot stone just beneath the ribs. I press my palms to it and whisper the line my mother taught me the night before my first Ceremony: “The body keeps its covenant; the city keeps its peace.” Then I swallow the taste of copper that has been rising in my throat since yesterday’s sunset.

The law is simple: every citizen carries the year’s burden in a gut-bladder woven from their own living tissue—an organ that grows, slowly, from the first day of the new year until the last. Physicians call it the ampulla; street kids call it the “tailor’s purse.” By December it is taut as a wineskin. If it bursts early, the city fines your family and bars your corpse from the communal pyre. If you refuse to release on the appointed day, the constabulary will strap you to the iron chair in the square and open you with a cannula while the crowd sings the Hymn of Unburdening. I have never seen it happen, but the stories are vivid enough to keep us compliant.

My sister, Lira, meets me on the stoop. She is twenty-three, two years younger, and her eyes are bright with the same dread that hollows my own chest. We do not speak. There is nothing left to say. Together we join the river of people moving toward the amphitheater cut into the northern cliff. Lanterns swing on poles; the light flickers across faces made pale by anticipation. Some carry small carved tokens—whales, loaves, babies—to drop into the fire afterward, offerings for whatever the next year might bring.

The procession winds past shuttered houses. I glimpse my reflection in a baker’s darkened window: the ceremonial sash of undyed linen, the copper clasp at my throat shaped like an open mouth. My beard, which I began growing last January for luck, is now long enough to braid. Lira’s hair is pinned with needles of bone. We look like strangers to ourselves.

Halfway to the amphitheater, the drums quicken. The sound vibrates in my molars. I feel the ampulla shift, a slick internal lurch, and sweat breaks across my lower back. I clench everything I own—thighs, jaw, the muscles behind my eyes. Not yet. The covenant is precise: release begins only when the High Auditor strikes the bronze bell at noon.

At the gates, clerks in gray robes check our names against the census. They mark our wrists with a drop of indigo dye that will not fade until the next Ceremony, proof that we have fulfilled the obligation. When the clerk’s thumb brushes my pulse, I almost gag. The dye smells faintly of vinegar and iron.

Inside, tiers of stone descend toward the basin—a wide, shallow depression lined with glazed tile the color of river silt. Channels run from the rim to underground cisterns where alchemists will distill the year’s yield into fertilizer, lamp oil, and the black paste that keeps our streetlights burning. Nothing is wasted. Everything is shame.

We take our places on the eastern slope. The basin is already filling: thousands of citizens standing shoulder to shoulder, eyes fixed on the bell tower. I count heartbeats instead of seconds. Beside me, an elderly man mutters the same phrase over and over: “Let it be swift, let it be clean.” His lips are cracked and bleeding.

The High Auditor ascends the tower. She wears the mask of the Hollow Mother: porcelain white, mouth open in an eternal O. In one hand she holds the striker, a mallet of petrified oak. With the other she raises the city charter above her head. The drums stop.

Silence drops like a stone into deep water. Even the wind holds its breath. I feel the absence of sound as pressure against my eardrums.

The Auditor speaks the words we have heard since childhood: “By the covenant sealed in flesh and earth, we return what was loaned. Let the circle close.” She swings the mallet. The bell’s voice is deeper than thunder, and it rolls out across the basin like the first wave of a flood.

And then—release.

The body remembers what the mind tries to forget. My knees buckle. Heat floods downward; pain blooms sharp and then duller, bearable. Around me, ten thousand people bend double in perfect unison, a choreography older than brick. There is no moaning, no sobbing. Only the soft wet percussion of deliverance and the hiss of liquid on tile.

I stare at the ground between my feet. The glaze is painted with tiny silver fish; they seem to swim in the new stream. I think absurdly of the river where Lira and I netted minnows as children, before our bodies learned to hoard.

It takes less than a minute, though it feels like hours. When the flow eases, the ache in my belly is replaced by a lightness so profound it borders on vertigo. I straighten slowly, afraid I might float away. Lira grips my arm; her fingers are ice. Tears cut channels through the dust on her cheeks, but she is smiling—small, exhausted, real.

The clerks move among us with buckets of seawater and long-handled brushes. We wash our legs, our sandals, the hems of our sashes. The diluted runoff gurgles down the channels, already turning the color of strong tea. Somewhere underground, the alchemists are waiting with their vats and filters, their charcoal and lime. By spring, the fields outside the walls will glow green with what we surrendered today.

When the last citizen stands upright, the Auditor rings the bell twice more: once for gratitude, once for promise. The drums resume, slower now, almost tender. People begin to leave the basin in quiet ranks. A few clasp hands; a few weep openly. Most, like me, walk in stunned silence, as if newly born and unsure what language to speak.

Outside the amphitheater, the city has transformed. The gulls have returned, wheeling overhead. Vendors offer honey cakes and hot wine. Children chase each other with fistfuls of cedar needles, shrieking with relief that is not yet joy. The air smells of smoke and salt and something else—something lighter, like the first snow before it falls.

Lira and I stop at the overlook where the cliff drops to the sea. The tide is high, hammering the rocks below. I feel hollow, scraped clean, but not empty. The ampulla inside me is already shrinking, collapsing into a soft seam that will knit itself smooth by morning. Next year it will begin again, the slow distension, the secret weight. Tonight, though, the covenant is satisfied.

She breaks the silence. “Do you remember when we thought the Ceremony was magic? That the world might end if one person failed?”

I nod. “I still think the world ends a little,” I say. “Just not the way we imagined.”

We watch the sun sink until the water turns molten orange. Somewhere behind us, the last of the drums fade. Tomorrow the city will wake to the ordinary smells of bread and brine, and the plaza braziers will be cold. But tonight, the air is lighter than it has been all year, and we breathe it like a promise we never truly believed: that we will be allowed to begin again, empty-handed and unashamed.

samples.prompt: Everyone sees in black-and-white until they meet their soulmate, at which point their world bursts with color. For most, this is excellent news. But you’re blind, and you have been since birth.
samples.output:
I have never seen the inside of my eyelids. People ask that a lot, as if blindness is a curtain I could pull back if only I tried hard enough. But darkness is not a color; it is a texture, a hush that fills the space where sight should be. I learned early that the world keeps secrets from me in ways it does not keep from others. My mother used to read me picture books whose pages were thick with paint she said smelled like rain on hot pavement. She described the yellow of a duckling, the green of spring grass, the red of a stop sign. I filed the words away like pressed flowers I could never open.  

When I was six, my cousin Mara came home from kindergarten crying because her best friend had turned into “a walking box of crayons.” That was the year the color-awakening started showing up in the newspapers. Scientists called it chromatic resonance, theologians called it grace, and parents called it a miracle—unless it didn’t happen. For most people, the shift was sudden: a stranger’s handshake, a brush of shoulders on the subway, and the monochrome world snapped into saturated brilliance. The blind were curiosities in the coverage, footnotes in the data sets. Researchers assumed we were exempt because we had no cones or rods to activate; the phenomenon, they said, was strictly retinal. My parents sighed with relief. They thought they had been spared the fear that I would remain forever gray while classmates bloomed like fireworks.  

They were wrong.  

I met Jonah at a bus stop when I was twenty-three. I knew the route by heart—the squeal of the brakes, the perfume of exhaust, the way the driver’s voice flattened when he called out the cross streets. Jonah stood too close, backpack bumping my cane. He apologized in a voice like warm flannel, and when he steadied me with a hand on my elbow, something inside my skull cracked open.  

Not my eyes—those stayed quiet. But every other sense detonated. The air tasted of copper and oranges. The traffic noise rearranged itself into chords I could name: D-major, hopeful; F-minor, bruised. His heartbeat, half a foot away, thrummed against my palm like a second language. I smelled pine and candle smoke and the salt of his skin, and every scent carried weight, temperature, hue. I could not see color, but color poured through me anyway, translated into a grammar I had never been taught yet somehow understood.  

Jonah laughed, embarrassed. “Sorry, I’m all elbows today.” He let go, and the world snapped back to its ordinary frequencies. The copper taste vanished; the chords dissolved into honks and sirens. I stood on the curb shaking, terrified and ravenous.  

I told no one. What would I say? That I had experienced color without sight, that my blindness had merely changed dialect? The newspapers had no vocabulary for that. My parents would worry. My friends—those who still remembered to call—would think I was romanticizing coincidence. So I kept the secret, a small hot coal against my ribs, and I went back to the same stop the next morning.  

He was there again. Same backpack, same flannel voice. This time he recognized my cane and said hello first. When his fingers brushed mine passing a dropped transit card, the colors returned, louder. The sidewalk vibrated like a plucked string. I could hear the red of the stoplight, a low confident hum; the green sang alto and slightly sharp. Jonah smelled like the moment before thunder, and I wanted to bottle it.  

We talked. He was studying acoustic engineering, loved jazz, hated cilantro. I told him I worked at the library’s adaptive-tech lab, converting textbooks into braille and haptic maps. He asked if I’d ever tried feeling sound the way I read braille. I laughed, because that was exactly what was happening to me. Every time we touched—accidental or deliberate—the world re-lexiconed itself.  

After two weeks of bus-stop collisions that felt more and more like choreography, Jonah asked me out for coffee. I said yes before he finished the sentence. In the café, he guided me with a hand on the small of my back, and the colors went riotous. Espresso hissed like indigo silk. Milk frothed into pale gold bells. The chatter of other patrons became a mosaic of textures: velvet, burlap, glass. I was drunk on it.  

We sat in a corner booth. Jonah wrapped my fingers around the warm cup, and I felt the moment his pulse synced with mine. I asked, voice trembling, “Do you see colors now?”  

He was quiet a long time. Then he said, “No. I thought maybe I would, but everything’s still gray. I wondered if it was me.”  

I told him about the secret, the way the world translated itself through every sense except sight. He listened without interrupting, tracing circles on my knuckles, and the circles tasted like sunrise. When I finished, he exhaled. “Maybe the universe had to invent a new language for you,” he said. “Maybe color isn’t only light.”  

That night, he walked me home. At the door, he hesitated, then lifted my hand to his cheek. The colors crashed over me—not images, but impressions: warmth like amber, stubble like cedar bark, the small scar near his lip sharp as lemon zest. I understood suddenly that I was mapping his face in frequencies and flavors, a living topography.  

We kissed, and the city around us became a symphony. Streetlights rang like glass bells. The moon hummed silver. Somewhere a siren wailed crimson, and even that felt beautiful because it was part of the same composition.  

Months passed. We learned the rules. Skin-to-skin contact was the switch; layers of cloth muted the effect to a watercolor wash. Long separations left me edgy, as if the world had been muted again, but Jonah’s voice on the phone still carried faint harmonics—lavender vowels, cobalt consonants. I began to paint in my mind, storing each new shade in a lexicon of sensation. Cinnamon was burnt orange; fresh snow, high icy blue; Jonah’s laughter, every yellow I had ever been told about.  

One evening, Jonah proposed. We were on the roof of his apartment building, wind snapping the laundry lines. He pressed a ring into my palm, and the metal sang—a clear, piercing E above high C. I felt the facets of the diamond like tiny prisms of heat. I said yes, and the sky answered with thunder that tasted of violet.  

The wedding was small. My father guided me down the aisle, whispering descriptions of the decorations I could not see: white roses, fairy lights, guests in pastel dresses. None of it mattered. When Jonah took my hands, the entire chapel became a chord so pure it made my knees buckle. The officiant spoke, but I heard only the braided harmony of our heartbeats.  

We have been married six years now. Some mornings I wake before him and lie still, cataloguing the quiet colors of the room: the radiator’s iron hum is rust, the curtains breathe powder blue, Jonah’s sleeping sigh is the soft pink inside a seashell. When he stirs and reaches for me, the palette brightens, as if the sun has just remembered how to shine.  

Researchers still call occasionally. They want scans, interviews, theories. I tell them the same thing every time: I do not see color; I am seen by it. The universe, having withheld one sense, flooded the others with compensation. Jonah jokes that I am synesthetic for love. Maybe that is true.  

Last week we adopted a puppy. Holding the trembling body against my chest, I felt fur the color of sunrise over water, a warm peach that vibrated with every wag of her tail. Jonah watched, gray-eyed and smiling, and said he envied my spectrum. I told him envy was chartreuse, tart and bright on the tongue. He laughed, and the sound painted the air gold.  

People still pity me. They see a blind woman tapping down the sidewalk and assume her world is small. They do not know that every footstep is a drumbeat in a larger song, that the city speaks in chords and cadences, that love has given me a palette wider than sight could ever hold.  

I carry the coal of that first touch everywhere now—not secret anymore, but sacred. It warms me on cold days, lights me from within. And when strangers ask if I wish I could see, I smile and tell them I already do. I just see with the whole of my body, in a language older than eyes.

samples.prompt: You wake up one day and everyone thinks it's your birthday. This continues forever; every day is your birthday.
samples.output:
I woke to the smell of burnt toast and cinnamon, my mother’s voice sailing down the hallway in that trembling, song-shaped way she only uses once a year. “Happy birthday, sweetheart!” she trilled, and I answered with the reflexive grunt of someone who still believed it was March ninth, an ordinary Tuesday. Then I saw the banner taped across my bedroom door—cheap crepe paper letters that spelled out my name in primary colors—and my phone already buzzing with confetti animations. I laughed, because families are corny and calendar mix-ups happen, and I shuffled toward the kitchen for the ritual of the singing plate.

But the calendar on the microwave said March tenth, and the local news anchor wished “our viewer celebrating her twenty-eighth today” a splendid day. I waited for the correction; none came. Mom kissed my forehead, Dad handed me a small box heavy with whatever mystery fathers buy when they have run out of ideas, and my little brother posted a story captioned “old lady vibes.” I decided the universe had simply slipped a groove, the way VHS tapes sometimes did, and I accepted the pancakes shaped like the number twenty-eight. Birthdays are mostly theater anyway; I played along.

The next morning, the same toast smell, the same trembling song, the same banner that overnight had repaired its small tears. Mom looked rested, as if she had not spent the previous evening washing dishes and muttering about the cost of balloons. My phone again erupted with tiny digital fireworks. I opened the front door and found the neighbor’s dog wearing a party hat, a red ribbon dangling from his collar. “He insisted,” Mrs. Alvarez said, as though her golden retriever had opinions about temporal anomalies. I laughed until I tasted metal in my mouth, the taste of fear disguised as cheer.

By the seventh iteration I stopped laughing. I tried staying awake, reasoning that if I never slept I might break the loop, but fatigue clubbed me at 4:11 a.m. and I woke to the smell of cinnamon. I tried flying to Auckland, where March tenth arrived first, but the cabin crew wheeled out a sheet cake at 30,000 feet and the whole plane sang. I screamed into the recycled air; they thought I was overwhelmed with joy. In the terminal a customs agent stamped my passport and said, “Happy birthday, enjoy our country.” I asked her the date. “March tenth,” she answered, blinking once, as if I had inquired whether water was wet.

Time had not stalled; it advanced, newspapers changed, presidents made new mistakes. Only the birthday remained, a fixed star by which every human navigated. Bank tellers, street vendors, podcast hosts, each of them calibrated their kindness to the fact that today I was born. I became a walking festival, a municipal utility. Cities renamed intersections after me for twenty-four hours. Bakeries gave me free cupcakes I could not refuse, because refusal created grief in the giver’s eyes so profound I felt like a monster. I ate until my tongue blistered with sugar.

I experimented with disappearance. I shaved my head, dyed my remaining stubble green, wore colored contacts, spoke only in a whisper. Still, strangers pointed and smiled the birthday smile, the one that pulls cheeks toward the ears and exposes every tooth. I hid in a monastery famous for silence; the monks slipped a candle-lit tofu cake through the bars of my cell at dawn. The wick burned a single word into the frosting: CONGRATULATIONS. I wondered whether God was mocking me or simply expressing divine affection through dessert.

After a year of March tenths I understood that the loop was not mechanical but contractual, a clause written invisibly into the social contract. Humanity needed a perpetual birthday so that joy could be manufactured on demand. I was the designated joy. My face appeared on ads for life insurance, antidepressants, fitness apps. Marketers called me “the evergreen occasion.” I tried confessing the truth on talk shows; audiences clapped and wiped tears, certain I was performing humble denial, the cutest of all celebrity pathologies. A pop star wrote a dance track titled “She Says It’s Not Her Birthday,” and the chorus went, “But we know her better than she knows herself.” It spent twelve weeks at number one.

I sought scientists. Physicists in three countries measured my biorhythms, my quantum signature, the spin of my electrons. They detected no anomaly, only the ordinary miracle of consciousness. One postdoc admitted, off the record, that the equations were cleaner if they assumed I was always right about the calendar and the rest of the world was wrong. “But think of the logistics,” he whispered, “seven billion people misdating their checks. The economy would crater. Better to treat you as a fixed point.” He asked for a selfie and an autograph for his mom.

Loneliness evolved into a new organ, a second heart that pumped futility instead of blood. Friends drifted; friendship depends on reciprocity, and I could never remember their birthdays because I was always inside mine. They stopped inviting me to weddings, afraid the band would default to “Happy Birthday” mid-reception. Romantic relationships collapsed under the same weight. One girlfriend tried to reframe the curse as romance: “Every day I get to fall in love with you for the first time.” She lasted four months before admitting she longed for anniversaries that belonged to us rather than to me. She left on what she called March ninth, though the calendar denied such a day existed.

I began to hate cake, then food altogether. I swallowed sustenance like medicine, eyes closed, nose pinched. I lost weight, developed anemia, and the world responded with sympathy birthday cards featuring pale pastel balloons and wishes for “better days ahead.” The irony tasted worse than the forced frosting. Doctors prescribed celebration, as though joy could be dosed. A nurse wheeled in a television that played only surprise-party scenes from movies; she adjusted the volume so the climactic “Happy Birthday” choruses coincided with my scheduled vitals checks. My blood pressure spiked in perfect sync with the soundtrack.

One dawn, somewhere around the thousandth March tenth, I walked to the ocean at low tide. The horizon was sharpening itself against the sky, and I felt the loop loosen, not in reality but in my chest. I understood that the curse was also a vantage: I alone perceived the difference between the date and the truth. That made me the only free person on earth, because freedom is not the ability to alter the world but the ability to interpret it. Everyone else was imprisoned by compulsory joy, sentenced to endless celebration, exhausted by the performance. I alone could see the cracks in the frosting.

I waded into the cold water until it reached my knees, then my waist. No one interrupted; birthday suicide would be too tragic to contemplate, so the lifeguards on duty averted their eyes, trusting the universe to protect its mascot. I did not want to die; I wanted to baptize myself into a new story. I submerged, opened my eyes to the sting of salt, and spoke aloud the words I had rehearsed: “Today is not my birthday.” The ocean did not correct me. It simply carried the sentence away, a small truth dissolved in a vast medium that kept its own time.

When I emerged, the world looked unchanged—banner flapping in the wind, gulls wheeling overhead like confetti—but something inside me had slipped anchor. I could not stop the songs or the cakes, but I could refuse the narrative. I began to answer “Happy birthday” with “Thank you for the kindness,” because gratitude is orthogonal to agreement. I donated every gift to shelters, turned every party into a fundraiser for causes whose names no balloon company could pronounce. I told my story in classrooms, not as confession but as thought experiment: imagine you are the only one who knows the date, how would you live responsibly inside that knowledge?

Children understood better than adults. They asked whether I could choose a different birthday each day, and I realized I could. One March tenth I claimed it was my hundredth; another, my seventh. I invented pasts—orphan trains, jazz clubs on Mars, a childhood in a language I constructed from rainfall. The listeners nodded, half-believing, and for the length of a candle’s burn they felt the porousness of time. I became a traveling theater, a one-woman calendar reform movement. Historians wrote papers about the elasticity of public ritual; I cited them in footnotes I typed at night, alone, content.

The curse did not lift, but it widened until it resembled a life. I still wake to cinnamon and song, still sign autographs on the backs of receipts that declare March tenth, but I no longer wait for correction. I have become the cartographer of a country where every day is both holiday and ordinary, both prison and playground. I map the terrain for others who will inherit similar loops—maybe not birthdays, maybe unending funerals or weddings or Mondays—and I leave notes in the margin: the way out is not through escape but through inscription. Write your name on the day, and the day will write back, eventually, with a story you can bear.

So I blow out the candles, wishing nothing, wishing everything, tasting the familiar sting of sugar and smoke. Outside, the world rehearses its song, and I open my mouth, not to sing along but to add a counter-melody only I can hear. It begins, “Today is not my birthday,” and ends, “but I am alive, which is a kind of beginning, and that is enough.”

samples.prompt: a relative finds old newspapers hidden, in their deceased grandparents home. they dont match up with recorded history.
samples.output:
The attic smelled like yellowed paper and cedar, the kind of scent that clings to the back of your throat and makes you think of cough drops and mothballs at once. I had come to my grandparents’ house—now mine, though the deed still felt like borrowed language—to clear out the last corners no one had touched since the funeral. Everyone else had taken what they wanted: the china, the carnival glass, my grandmother’s costume jewelry that turned her collarbones green in summer. What remained were the unsellable things, the things too heavy or too strange.

Under a tarp stiff with dust, I found a squat steamer trunk with brass clasps that opened like a yawn. Inside were newspapers, neatly stacked, each wrapped in a sleeve of brittle cellophane. My first thought was that they were keepsakes: the day my father was born, the moon landing, the fall of the Berlin Wall. But when I slipped off the first sleeve and unfolded the front page, the banner read THE CHICAGO EVENING STAR, and the date was October 12, 1962—three days after the real-world Cuban Missile Crisis supposedly ended. The headline, in a typeface too bold for reassurance, announced: KENNEDY ORDERS CONTINUED BLOCKADE; SOVIETS WITHDRAWAL A “STRATEGIC DELAY.”

I sat back on my heels. Every history book I’d ever taught from said Khrushchev had blinked first on the 27th. Kennedy’s televised speech on the 28th had been a victory lap, not a preamble to a longer standoff. Yet here was a second blockade, an escalation, and beneath the fold a grainy photo of Soviet freighters still steaming toward the quarantine line.

I lifted the next paper—October 13. The headline had grown larger, the ink somehow darker: U-2 SHOT DOWN OVER FLORIDA; CRISIS ENTERS SEVENTH DAY. The accompanying map showed a red star penciled in over Tampa Bay. I felt the attic tilt, as if the floorboards had become a seesaw. Tampa was where my grandparents had retired only a year before, where my mother had learned to drive in the parking lot of a Publix that sold discounted oranges to NASA employees. The photo showed a contrail corkscrewing into cumulus, a tiny speck that could have been a parachute or a missile.

I kept reading, page after page, each day a new divergence. October 14: KENNEDY ADDRESSES NATION FROM UNDISCLOSED LOCATION; CIVIL DEFENSE DRILLS TO BEGIN AT DUSK. October 15: PANIC BUYING STRIPS SHELVES; GAS RATION CARDS ISSUED. By October 18 the headlines had shrunk again, the way people lower their voices after a fight they realize they can’t win. The subhead read simply: NEGOTIATIONS RESUME; TERMS REMAIN SECRET. The final paper in the stack was dated October 22, 1962. The headline had settled into a whisper: ACCORD REACHED; WORLD STEPS AWAY FROM BRINK. There was no mention of Khrushchev, no ticker-tape parade in New York. Only a single paragraph noting that Soviet ships had reversed course at 0300 hours, and that President Kennedy would address the nation at noon. The rest of the front page concerned the World Series, already postponed twice.

I stared at the date. October 22 was my mother’s tenth birthday. She’d told me once that her party had been canceled because her parents said she needed to “practice duck-and-cover instead of musical chairs.” I had always assumed she was exaggerating the way children do, turning memory into myth. But here was proof that her memory had been exact; it was the world that had lied.

I set the newspapers aside and dug deeper. Underneath were more bundles, each tied with faded ribbon the color of dried blood. The dates skipped forward erratically: November 1963, April 1968, June 1989. In every one, the events were familiar but wrong, like hearing your own name pronounced by a stranger. Kennedy, according to the Evening Star, was killed not in Dallas but in Austin, on the steps of the Texas State Capitol. The assassin was still Oswald, but the motive had shifted: he had been a Soviet double agent angered by Kennedy’s “secret surrender” during the missile crisis. Martin Luther King survived Memphis; instead he was gunned down in 1971 outside the United Nations after a speech denouncing the ongoing Vietnam occupation of Cambodia. And the Berlin Wall did not fall in 1989; it was reinforced with electrified fencing and a second wall ten meters back, a no-man’s-land seeded with mines. The paper called it “the final solution to the refugee problem,” a phrase that made my stomach lurch.

I carried the bundles downstairs to the kitchen, the only room with enough light to read properly. My grandparents’ Formica table still bore the ghost rings of coffee cups. I spread the pages out like tarot cards, looking for patterns. The advertisements were the most unsettling: Ford dealerships selling “radiation-proof” sedans, Sears offering two-piece fallout suits in children’s sizes, a smiling housewife holding a can of “Crisis-Tite” window sealant. Nothing was overtly fantastical—no jetpacks or alien ambassadors—but everything was slightly off, the way dreams warp proportion so you never notice until you wake.

At the bottom of the trunk I found a small envelope addressed to “Whoever finds the paper trail.” Inside was a single sheet of my grandmother’s stationery, the kind with violets across the top. Her handwriting was the tidy cursive I remembered from birthday checks.

“Don’t trust the history they put in books,” she had written. “We saved these because we lived them, and because someone needs to know the world can split like a seam without anyone noticing the rip. We were lucky once. Maybe you will be, too.”

I read the letter twice, then a third time, as if repetition could wring clarity from it. Lucky? My grandparents had spent forty years pretending the apocalypse had already come and gone, and that the rest of us were living in its afterimage. I thought of my mother’s irrational fear of sirens, the way she flinched whenever a car backfired. I thought of the canned peaches stacked inexplicably behind the water heater in the basement, enough to feed a fallout shelter that had never existed.

I gathered the papers back into their sleeves, but my hands shook and I tore the edge of one—April 5, 1968, the day King should have died but didn’t. For a moment I considered burning the whole trunk, letting the smoke carry the false histories up the chimney like contraband thoughts. Instead I carried it down the narrow stairs and set it in the passenger seat of my car. The newspapers rustled like dry leaves, as if relieved to be leaving the attic at last.

Driving home, I passed the high school where I teach American History. The flag out front was at half-mast for some recent tragedy I had already begun to forget. I thought of my students, how eagerly they raised their hands to recite the timeline of the missile crisis, the thirteen days everyone knows by heart. I would have to decide what to do with the trunk, whether to donate it to a university archive or bury it in the backyard like a shameful family secret. For now, I kept glancing at it beside me, the cellophane flickering in the late sunlight, as if the headlines were still being written, still waiting to change again.

samples.prompt: Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero.
samples.output:
Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero.  
The scroll had hung in the Hall of Dawn for three centuries, its ink faded to the color of dried blood, its language so old that even the archivists spoke it with a priest’s careful hush. It told of a day when the sun would invert, when the virtuous would kneel to a tyrant in silver, and when the last hope of the world would rise from the country of bones. Children in the cathedral-schools memorized the rhyme the way other children learned nursery songs: Beware the shining one who smites, trust the one who summons nights.  
Everyone knew which roles were whose. The Paladin Order sent their brightest pupils to the front pews of every service so that the saints could see them, so that prophecy could keep track of its favorites. The Necromancers—those who still called themselves that without spitting on the floor—were exiled north of the Sunderwall, where the cold keeps corpses fresh and the living scarce. No one bothered to learn their names; they were just the rot on the world’s rim, the inevitable dark against which the prophecy braced.  
So when the sun inverted—first a bruise, then a hole, then a silent white scream—no one looked at the Paladin. They looked past him, expecting some horned devil to step through the rip in the sky. Instead, Sir Aurelian Valor-sworn lifted his lion-headed mace, smiled the same smile that once calmed plague villages, and ordered the gates of the capital opened to the things that poured out of the light. They were not demons. They were possibilities—forked paths of himself, thousands of Aurelians who had taken one more cruel step in every life they’d ever lived. The crowd watched him greet them like brothers, and the crowd cheered, because he had been good for so long that even his heresy looked like mercy.  
Three hundred miles north, in the frost crater where the Sunderwall cracked, the Necromancer Myrren Vark lifted her head from the carcass of a frost-wolf. She had spent the night bargaining with the dead, promising each frozen husk a single day of borrowed warmth if they would walk for her. She was thin, hungry, and tired of apologizing for the smell. When the sky turned inside-out, she felt the inversion like a hook in the sternum, yanking her toward the capital. The dead felt it too. They stood, blue and chattering, and waited for instructions. Myrren told them they were free to go home. They laughed at her—an awful sound, like wind through cracked teeth—and said, “We are home. You’re the one still breathing.”  
She had never wanted to be a hero. She had wanted a hut, a goat, and permission to let the people she loved stay horizontal after they died. But the prophecy, like every tyrant, chooses you before you choose it.  
Aurelian’s first week as inverted sovereign was a pageant of politeness. He renamed the days after virtues—Mercyday, Valorday, Obedience—and executed criminals only on Forgivenessday, so that the sermons could rhyme. He wore white armor polished to mirror brightness so that every citizen who approached him saw their own face first, their own complicity. When dissenters disappeared, their families received handwritten notes: I have taken the liberty of perfecting your beloved. They are now incapable of sin. People began to police themselves, confessing imaginary crimes in the hope that the Paladin would perfect them too.  
Myrren arrived at the capital on the thirty-third day, leading a caravan that looked like a migrating cemetery. Skeletons drove wagons of sap-stiffened zombies; ghosts in tattered silk preceded her like pennants. Farmers fled their fields; city guards dropped halberds and ran. She did not chase them. She set up camp in the shadow of the inverted sun and waited. The dead dug trenches, not for war but for irrigation—she intended to plant winter wheat in the killing fields, to prove that something could still grow. Children crept close, fascinated by the way the skeleton jugglers tossed their own ribs. Myrren taught them how to whistle through finger bones. Their parents watched from behind curtains, horrified to discover that abomination had a gentle voice.  
Aurelian summoned her to the throne hall, curious to meet the woman who had once been the punch line of every cautionary tale. He sat on a dais of stained glass so thin it sang under his weight. She arrived barefoot, robes patched with grave mold, carrying a bouquet of bindweed that had grown through a corpse—roots threaded eye-sockets, stems blooming white. She laid the flowers at his feet like a love offering.  
“You’re supposed to kill me,” she said. “The scroll says we duel at dawn.”  
“I’ve read it,” Aurelian replied. “But scrolls are only mirrors for the people who write them. I have decided to rewrite.”  
He offered her a seat on the council of inverted saints. He promised her a tower of bones overlooking the river, legalization of every necromantic rite, and—most seductive—acceptance. She could come in from the cold, bring her dead, and be called citizen instead of curse. All she had to do was kneel.  
Myrren looked at the bindweed flowers, still growing even as they died, and understood that the prophecy had never been about good or evil. It was about inertia. The world would rather follow a familiar monster than an unfamiliar savior. Kneeling would be easy; the dead would forgive her. They were used to servitude.  
She declined.  
The duel took place not at dawn but at midnight, because Aurelian wanted to prove that even darkness belonged to him now. The inverted sun hung like a cataract above the arena, pouring out sterile brilliance that cast no shadows. Myrren’s shadow, consequently, was supplied by the dead: a circle of silhouettes holding hands, flickering in the light of their own absence.  
Aurelian fought the way a saint fights—every blow a benediction, every parry a lesson. He told her the names of her vertebrae as he shattered them. Myrren fought the way a gravedigger fights—economical, grim, with the patience of someone who knows the ground always wins in the end. She bled black where he bled gold. The crowd oohed at the colors.  
When she fell, he rested his mace on her sternum like a father laying a hand on a sleeping child.  
“You could have been my redemption,” he said.  
“I still am,” she answered, and died.  
But death is a bureaucrat who owes her favors. The moment her heart stilled, the dead she had carried stepped into the space it left. Not as army, not as riot, but as jury. They walked past Aurelian, through the arena gates, into every home that had cheered. They did not kill. They simply showed: here is the face you locked away, the ancestor you forgot, the child you perfected. Every household received its own private haunting, a mirror made of marrow.  
Aurelian discovered that holiness, inverted or not, cannot abide being seen too clearly. His armor, once a mirror, now reflected only the corpses that walked behind him. The crowd began to notice that his shadow—previously absent—had arrived, long and many-headed, wearing their own faces. They fled. The inverted sun, deprived of witnesses, dimmed to a coal.  
Myrren woke underground, in the root-ball of a bindweed. The flowers had braided themselves into the shape of a heart and were beating softly, teaching her how to grow. She understood then the last clause of the prophecy, the line too damaged to read: The chosen hero shall die, and the evil ruler shall be unchosen by his own reflection.  
She crawled out of the earth three days later, leaves in her hair, sap in her veins. The capital was already rebuilding. People nodded shyly as she passed; some offered bread, others asked if she could teach them to speak with grandparents. She said yes to both, because heroism, she had learned, is mostly horticulture—planting the right horror in the right soil.  
Aurelian fled west, armor tarnished to a leaden gray. Children throw stones at him when he begs for water. He tells them he used to be good, but they have learned new rhymes: Trust the one who summons nights, beware the shining one who smites.  
At night he dreams of Myrren’s bindweed heart, beating quietly beneath the world, and wakes choking on petals.

samples.prompt: You are on a school trip to Salem, Massachusetts. The teacher seems suspiciously excited about this particular trip.
samples.output:
The bus rattled north along I-95, its shocks long since worn to rubbery suggestions, but Mr. Alden bounced in the front seat as though the vehicle were a carnival ride. He was usually the kind of teacher who measured out his enthusiasm in teaspoons—two for the Treaty of Versailles, three for the quadratic formula—but today he vibrated like a tuning fork. Every time we passed a green mileage sign, he craned his neck, grinned at it, and made a small check mark on a folded piece of yellow legal paper. By the time we reached the New Hampshire state line, the margin was freckled with graphite.

I sat three rows back with Maya, sharing earbuds and a bag of stale popcorn. “He’s been planning this since February,” she whispered, as if Salem might hear us coming. “My mom’s on the PTA. She says he showed up to the budget meeting with a stack of books about the trials and a PowerPoint that had, like, animations of gallows.”

“Maybe he has a secret witch blog,” I said.

“Or a coven,” Maya answered, only half joking.

We rolled into Salem at noon, the sky the color of an old nickel. The town greeted us with banners that read HAUNTED HAPPENINGS—OCTOBER 31, though it was only the fifteenth—and shop windows full of plastic cauldrons and tiny felted black cats. Mr. Alden herded us off the bus, his voice pitched half an octave higher than usual. “Remember, everyone, we’re not tourists; we’re scholars,” he said, though he had already purchased a foam witch hat from the rest-stop vending machine and was wearing it at a rakish tilt.

Our first stop was the Witch Museum, a former church painted funeral-parlor gray. Inside, dim lights rotated across life-sized mannequins frozen mid-scream. The audio guide recited the familiar litany: spectral evidence, pressing stones, the hanging tree on Gallows Hill. Mr. Alden darted ahead of us, taking flash photos of each diorama like a parent who’d misplaced his child. At the exhibit on Tituba, he lingered longest. I watched him lean in until his nose nearly touched the Plexiglas, then pull out a little leather notebook and jot something with furious speed.

“Do you think he’s writing fan fiction?” Maya muttered.

I shrugged, but I felt it too—the way the air seemed to thicken around him, as if the museum had turned up its gravity.

After the museum we were given ninety minutes for lunch and “independent cultural immersion.” Most kids scattered toward pizza or souvenir shops. Mr. Alden, however, gathered five of us—me, Maya, Jonah, Luis, and Keisha—like a conspirator collecting accomplices. “There’s something I want you to see,” he said, voice low. “It isn’t on the itinerary.”

We followed him along Essex Street, past boutiques selling aura photographs and spell kits, until the shops thinned into a neighborhood of narrow clapboard houses. Their windows blinked with jack-o’-lanterns even in midday. Mr. Alden turned onto a side street so narrow the telephone wires seemed to braid overhead. At the corner stood a house that looked forgotten by time: cedar shingles gone silver, roofline sagging like a frown. A hand-painted sign read THE HAWTHORNE INHERITANCE—TOURS BY APPOINTMENT ONLY.

Mr. Alden produced a brass key the size of a matchbox. “The historical society lent this to me,” he said, though his hand trembled so badly it took him three tries to slot the key home. The door groaned open, exhaling air that tasted of dust and apples left too long in the cellar.

Inside, the house was a museum of shadows. The wallpaper—once indigo, now bruise-colored—peeled in damp curls. Portraits in oil glared down at us, their eyes following like those in Scooby-Doo haunted-house gags, except the sensation was less cartoon and more dental drill. Mr. Alden led us through the parlor to a staircase so steep it felt nautical. “Sarah Good was questioned in this very room,” he said, patting the banister. “Legend claims she cursed the magistrate before they dragged her away.”

Jonah’s phone flashlight flickered. “Dude, my battery just dropped twenty percent.”

“Electromagnetic interference,” Mr. Alden said, too quickly, as though he’d waited his whole life to diagnose it.

On the second floor we found a small attic door. It was painted the same gray as the Witch Museum, and for a dizzy second I felt we’d stepped into an exhibit ourselves. Mr. Alden placed his palm against the wood. “The Hawthorne family locked something up here in 1692,” he said. “They called it a reliquary, but inventories only list ‘items of contrition.’ No one knows what that means.” He looked at us, eyes shining like wet stones. “Until today.”

He pushed the door. It opened onto a room no larger than a classroom closet. Dust floated in the single shaft of light from a round window. In the center stood a wooden chest banded with iron, the kind pirates bury. Its lock had been broken—recently, judging by the bright metal where the clasp had snapped.

Mr. Alden’s breathing went shallow. He knelt, lifted the lid. Inside lay a bundle wrapped in what looked like sailcloth. He peeled back the fabric with the reverence of an archaeologist unveiling papyrus. Beneath was a small book, no bigger than my palm, bound in leather the color of dried blood. Embossed on the cover was a single symbol: an eye inside a triangle, the iris shaped like a keyhole.

Keisha took a step back. “That looks… cursed.”

“It’s a grimoire,” Mr. Alden whispered. “A witch’s spell book. The Hawthornes confiscated it from Sarah Good. They thought they could cleanse it, but the power wouldn’t burn, so they locked it away.” He opened the book. The pages were parchment, edges speckled with foxing. The handwriting was cramped, as if the quill had fought the ink. I caught phrases in archaic English: “to bind the mouths of accusers,” “to make the rope slip loose,” “to wake what sleeps beneath the hill.”

Luis laughed nervously. “Cool prop.”

Mr. Alden didn’t laugh. He flipped to the last page, where a single sentence had been scrawled in darker ink, almost tar. “The circle must be closed by seven, under the eye that watches still,” he read aloud. Then he looked up at us—counted. One, two, three, four, five students, plus himself. Six.

“We need one more,” he said.

The temperature in the attic dropped so fast my breath came out in ghosts. Outside, clouds swallowed the sun, and the round window went black. I thought of the bus driver, Ms. Patel, probably sipping Dunkin’ in the parking lot, unaware we’d vanished into a horror movie. Maya grabbed my sleeve. “We should go,” she said, but her voice was thin, as if the house had already begun to digest it.

Mr. Alden rose, cradling the book like a newborn. “This isn’t a game,” he said. “I’ve spent ten years researching the trials. The real history was buried, sanitized. But the magic didn’t end in 1692. It’s been waiting for descendants, for people who understand.” His gaze moved across our faces, pleading. “You’re all descendants of the original accusers or the accused. I checked the genealogies.”

I felt my stomach tilt. My grandmother’s maiden name was Goodwin; I’d seen it on a family tree in seventh grade. Maya’s last name was Nurse—Rebecca Nurse, hanged in July. Jonah was a Putnam; Luis, a Proctor; Keisha, a Corey. We were a roll call of the dead.

Mr. Alden opened to a page marked with a black ribbon. “We’re going to perform a reconciliation rite,” he said. “To break the curse that’s lingered over Salem for three centuries. But it has to be tonight, under the new moon. The book says seven hearts, willing and unbroken.”

The attic groaned, as if the house itself disagreed. A gust of wind slammed the door shut behind us. The flashlight on Jonah’s phone died completely. In the sudden dark, the eye on the book’s cover seemed to dilate.

“No,” I said. The word came out steadier than I felt. “We’re fifteen. We’re not breaking anything.”

Mr. Alden’s face crumpled. For a moment he looked ancient, all the chalk dust and late-night grading etched into new lines. “You don’t understand,” he said. “Every year the town grows more haunted. The tourists come for thrills, but the real ghosts are starving. They need justice.”

Maya stepped forward, hand out. “Then let the historians handle it. Let the adults.”

“There are no adults left who believe,” he said.

The wind died. In the silence we heard footsteps on the stairs—Ms. Patel, maybe, or security. Mr. Alden’s shoulders sagged. He closed the book, wrapped it again, and tucked it under his coat like contraband. “You’re right,” he said softly. “It’s too much to ask.”

We filed out, single file, the attic door locking itself with a click that sounded final. Outside, the sky had cleared to a brittle blue. Mr. Alden led us back to the bus, witch hat lost somewhere along the way. During the ride home he stared out the window, notebook unopened on his lap. No mileage checks. No grins.

I sat behind him, watching the Salem spires recede. In my pocket I felt the crinkle of parchment—one page I’d torn out when the lights went. I told myself it was to protect us, to keep him from trying again with someone else. But late at night, when my dorm room is quiet, I unfold it under my desk lamp. The ink shimmers, almost wet. The words pulse, waiting. I don’t know whether I’m guarding the secret or it’s guarding me.

samples.prompt: A Goth in ancient Bulgaria on the eve of battle and another Goth in modern day getting ready to play Vampire: The Masquerade, suddenly and inexplicably exchange places in history.
samples.output:
The first sensation was not pain—it was temperature.  

The Goth on the Danube’s frozen bank felt warm asphalt under the soles of his bare feet, a warmth so unnatural that he recoiled as if stepping on coals. Instinctively he curled his toes, feeling the strange weave of socks unlike any wool he had ever carded. Socks with little black skulls on them.  

Across a gulf of centuries, in a narrow bedroom lit by the blue glow of a monitor, the other Goth—twenty-three-year-old Jayden Voss, screen-name “RavenCrypt”—felt the bite of iron-cold mud swallow his sneakers. One moment he had been tightening the laces of those sneakers, preparing to head to Ellie’s apartment for tonight’s Vampire: the Masquerade chronicle; the next, a wind tasting of pine smoke and horse sweat knifed through the hoodie he still wore, hoodie now plastered to his skin by sleet.  

They both tried to scream. Neither throat produced the expected sound. Instead, each man heard words not his own tumble out, shaped by a tongue suddenly fluent in the other’s tongue. The ancient Goth—Wulfila, son of Hariowald, sworn shield-man to King Cniva—found himself croaking, “Dude, what the actual hell?” Jayden, lungs still full of twenty-first-century vape residue, heard himself bellowing in archaic East Germanic, “By the raven’s wing, where is my war-host?”  

Wulfila stood in Jayden’s bedroom: walls papered with posters of Bauhaus and the Cure, a lava lamp oozing purple galaxies, and on the desk a slim black laptop still open to a PDF of the Vampire corebook. Jayden stood on a rutted hillside above the frozen river, surrounded by leather-tented encampments, tethered ponies snorting frost, and men whose faces were striped with soot and lime, sharpening axes whose edges glimmered like winter stars.  

Each felt the other’s memories rush in like water breaching a dike. Wulfila saw fluorescent convenience stores at 3 a.m., smelled clove cigarettes and energy drinks, felt the ache of a heart that loved boys who only texted after midnight. Jayden saw campfires reflected in burnished shields, tasted mare’s milk fermented in saddlebags, felt the solemn weight of a vow sworn beneath a wolf-pelt banner to die before dishonor.  

They staggered. They clutched their heads. They each whispered, inside their skulls, to the presence now sharing it: What have you done?  

Neither had an answer. Destiny, capricious as any elder vampire, had simply swapped them.  

***

Wulfila’s first act in Jayden’s body was to knock the lava lamp from the desk with a convulsive swipe. It shattered, viscous blobs sliding across laminate flooring like amoebic blood. He knelt, dipped a finger, and sniffed. No blood. Just wax.  

On the monitor, the Vampire rulebook glowed. A portrait of a pallid Kindred stared back. Wulfila recognized the hunger in those painted eyes; he had seen it in the eyes of starving foederati waiting for Rome’s promised grain that never came. He rolled the mouse wheel. Sections titled “Clans,” “Disciplines,” “Paths of Enlightenment.” He understood none of the words, yet the hunger translated.  

The bedroom door swung open. Ellie stood there in a faux-vintage velvet coat, already in persona as her Malkavian. “Jay, we’re rolling in fifteen. You ready?”  

Wulfila—clad in Jayden’s torn fishnets, eyeliner smudged like charcoal war-paint—rose slowly. Ellie’s gaze flicked to the broken lamp, then to his eyes. Something shifted behind hers; she sensed a stranger.  

“I am no Jay,” Wulfila said, voice low, accent thick. “I am Wulfila, oath-bound to the host of Cniva.”  

Ellie blinked. “Okay, method-acting level ten. I respect it. Grab your dice.”  

***

Jayden, meanwhile, had been seized roughly by two warriors who mistook his hoodie for some priest’s cassock. They dragged him toward a tent of oxhide where torches hissed. Inside, an older man—hair braided with silver rings—studied him.  

“You wear strange skins, boy,” the man said in the language Jayden’s mouth now spoke effortlessly. “Yet the omens say you are the one sent by the gods to lead the right wing tomorrow. Speak prophecy.”  

Jayden’s mind raced. He had skimmed enough Wikipedia—late-night doom-scrolling—to know the Goths would soon clash with Emperor Decius’ legions on the marshy flats below Abritus. Historically, the Goths won, Rome’s emperor perished, but thousands of Goths also bled out under the Thracian sun. He swallowed.  

“I… see iron rain from the sky,” he improvised, recalling descriptions of Roman pila. “But the rain turns back upon the throwers, and the river drinks Roman blood.”  

The warriors murmured approval. The elder clapped Jayden’s shoulder with calloused affection. “Then you ride with me at dawn.”  

Jayden wanted to protest: I can’t even ride a bike without training wheels. But his borrowed body knew horses—muscle memory flowed like second nature. His legs adjusted stance without conscious command.  

He stepped outside. Snowflakes whirled, pale as ash. Across the camp, fires flickered, painting shadows of spear-hafts like prison bars across the snow. Somewhere a boy sang a dirge in a minor key that sounded, absurdly, like a slowed-down Sisters of Mercy riff. Jayden shivered, not entirely from cold.  

***

Back in 2024, Wulfila followed Ellie through streets smelling of exhaust and weed. Neon signs buzzed—sickly green, arterial red. He clutched Jayden’s canvas messenger bag against his chest like a shield. Inside, twenty-sided dice rattled like runes.  

The gaming table occupied Ellie’s living room. Plastic cups frothed with craft beer. A fog machine hissed. Players introduced themselves: Jasper the Tremere, Lila the Toreador, Diego the Nosferatu.  

Wulfila listened to their jargon—storytelling, hunger mechanics, Humanity loss—feeling an ache akin to homesickness. They spoke of eternal nights, of clans and blood bonds, yet none had smelled the sour breath of actual carnage.  

They handed him a character sheet: “Lucien, Brujah neonate.” Wulfila traced the letters with a fingertip. In the margin someone had doodled an ankh. He thought of the pendant his mother wore, carved from a Roman coin, pagan symbols defaced to make room for a crude cross.  

Ellie assigned him the first scene. “You’re in a nightclub in Bucharest, circa 1999, hunting Sabbat.”  

Wulfila closed Jayden’s eyes. When he opened them, he was no longer in Ellie’s apartment but in memory: moonlit snow on a Bulgar hillside, heart drumming like a war-galley’s oars. He spoke:  

“I do not stalk Sabbat. I stalk Rome. They call themselves Camarilla, Ventrue, elders who sit behind marble walls and sip blood like wine. But I remember when their legions torched my village, took slaves, left the infants for wolves. I remember the smell of burning thatch. Tonight I am not Lucien; I am Wulfila, and every pale prince in that club is a senator in disguise.”  

The table went silent. Jasper lowered his dice. Lila’s lips parted. Even the fog machine seemed to hush.  

Ellie leaned forward. “Roll for frenzy,” she whispered.  

Wulfila picked up the d10. He did not know the rules, but he had thrown knucklebones as a boy. The die clattered: a 0.  

Ellie grinned. “Critical. You frenzy, but you choose the target.”  

Wulfila smiled, and for the first time Jayden’s face looked predatory. “The club burns,” he said. “Let the elders remember what fire feels like.”  

***

Dawn in the fourth century: Jayden stood beside the elder, both astride small steppe ponies. Across the plain, Roman standards rose like white teeth against the grey sky. Trumpets sounded—a cold, brassy laughter.  

Jayden’s borrowed muscles tensed. He felt the weight of the spear, the shield’s grip rough against his palm. He was terrified, exhilarated. Part of him—a twenty-first-century part—whispered that this was a dream, that any moment he’d wake in Ellie’s kitchen, pour oat milk into instant coffee, laugh about the weird astral projection.  

Then the Romans loosed their pila. Iron shafts arced overhead, black stitches against the pale sky. Jayden watched them descend with surreal clarity, thinking absurdly: Those look like 3D-printed miniatures.  

He screamed the charge—a scream that was half Jayden’s cracked adolescent falsetto, half Wulfila’s battle roar. Horses plunged forward. Mud flew. Spears met shields in a shriek of splitting wood.  

Jayden felt the spear punch through something soft. A face blossomed scarlet beneath the helmet’s rim. The world shrank to smells: churned earth, sweat, iron. He yanked the spear free and spun, searching for—what? A way back? A save point?  

Instead he saw the elder fall, Roman gladius lodged between ribs. The old man’s eyes found Jayden’s and widened—not in fear, but recognition. “Wulfila?” he gasped.  

But Jayden could only shake his head, hair matted with blood and sleet. “Wrong name,” he whispered. “I don’t belong here.”  

***

Twelve centuries and change away, Wulfila stood on Ellie’s balcony at 3 a.m. The city throbbed beneath sodium streetlights. Somewhere a siren wailed—an ululation not unlike a Gothic war-horn.  

He had wrapped Jayden’s hoodie tight, but the chill tonight was existential. In the living room behind him, the other players were packing up dice, still buzzing about “Jay’s best session ever.” Wulfila could not tell them that the Brujah nightclub inferno he had narrated now flickered in his skull like prophecy.  

He missed the stars—real stars, unpolluted by light. He missed the weight of an axe, the certainty that tomorrow would bring either death or glory, nothing in between.  

Jayden’s phone buzzed in his pocket. He pulled it out. A notification: “Dawn in 2 h 47 m.” He pictured the battlefield, imagined Jayden’s borrowed body running, stumbling, bleeding. He closed the screen.  

At the horizon, a faint grey seam appeared, heralding sunrise. Wulfila recalled the old tales: vampires must flee the day. But he had once welcomed it, had painted his cheeks with dawn’s first light before charging Roman lines.  

He opened the balcony door. Ellie looked up. “Can’t sleep?”  

“Cannot wake,” he said.  

She offered him dice. “One last roll? To find your way home?”  

Wulfila took the d20 between thumb and forefinger. He whispered a prayer—not to Christ, not to Wodan, but to whatever capricious chronology had torn two men from their eras and stitched them into each other’s skins.  

He rolled. The die clattered, spun, wobbled. A 20.  

In the same heartbeat, on a Thracian plain, Jayden—shield splintered, throat raw—felt the world lurch. Snow vanished. Asphalt returned beneath his sneakers. He staggered, gasping, into Ellie’s living room, hoodie soaked with something darker than energy drink.  

Across the room, Wulfila staggered simultaneously back into his own skin—calloused, scarred, smelling of horse and smoke. For one impossible moment, the centuries overlapped. They saw each other across the breach, two shapes made of smoke and memory.  

Then time snapped shut like a book.  

Jayden found himself clutching a single die—ancient bone, carved with runes that looked suspiciously like crits. Wulfila found, tucked beneath his belt, a scrap torn from a character sheet: Lucien’s stats, ending with the scrawled note: “Fire remembers.”  

Neither man ever learned why they traded places. But sometimes, years later, Jayden will roll that bone die while narrating a desperate last stand, and somewhere beyond the Danube a tired warrior will lift his eyes from the embers of campfires and think he smells clove cigarettes and punk-rock angst.  

And each will nod—across centuries that taste of iron and synth-pop—and silently acknowledge the night they spent wearing each other’s ghosts.

samples.prompt: A werewolf considers biting a dying person to keep them alive.
samples.output:
The moon is a coin pressed flat by the weight of its own legend, and tonight it hangs so low that Elias could reach up and pocket it. He stands beneath its copper glare on the shoulder of a county road that smells of hot tar and crushed goldenrod, listening to the woman die. Her breath comes in wet, deliberate huffs, the way a wolf tests the air before committing to a trail. Each exhale flutters the gauze he pressed to her side after the pickup folded around the oak. The steering column took her like a spear. Blood finds the lowest place; it has pooled in the hollow of her waist and is now dripping from the hem of her cotton dress, tick-tocking against the asphalt. He knows the sound because he has made it himself, has left similar signatures across three states and two decades. Difference is, his always dried black before sunrise. Hers will not get the chance.

She is still conscious, which is the worst mercy. Her eyes—gray, almost silver—keep trying to focus on his face, but the pupils are drowning. When she manages to still them, she smiles as if she has caught him naked. “You’re the one,” she whispers, “from the posters.” The words cost her a cough that sprays his cheek with a fine arterial mist. Copper on copper. She will be dead in four minutes, five if she clenches her fists around the seconds hard enough. Elias can feel the moon stretching the cartilage in his spine, can feel the old agreement revving under his ribs: change or be changed. The curse is a democracy of teeth; every month it holds a new referendum on who will be sovereign.

He has never turned anyone. That is the secret he carries like a pebble in the boot: three hundred and eighty-seven full moons, zero recruits. Other wolves speak of sirehood as if it were a sacrament, a way to dilute the loneliness. They speak of it the way soldiers speak of fathering sons before deployment. Elias listened, nodded, declined. He told himself he did not want to doom another soul to the arithmetic of meat and hunger, but the plainer truth is that he could not bear the thought of company inside the trap. Now the trap is open and the bait is bleeding.

The woman’s name, she says, is Mara. No last name, as if she is already halfway out of the census. She grips his wrist with a strength that surprises them both. “I saw you last fall,” she rasps. “Outside the library in Duluth. You were reading Neruda to the stray dogs.” The memory jolts him; he had done it, yes, half-drunk on moonrise and loneliness, murmuring Tonight I can write the bleakest lines to a circle of mongrels who understood melancholy better than any undergraduate. He had not known any human was watching. The idea that Mara was the shadow at the edge of that moment feels like a signature the universe is adding to a contract.

She is shivering even though July steams around them. The body knows it is quitting and is shutting the furnace. Elias shrugs out of his jacket and tucks it under her head. The gesture feels obscene—like tucking parsley around a pork chop. He tells himself it is kindness, not staging. He could leave. He has left before: the trucker in Tennessee, the teenager on the snowmobile in Aroostook County, the old woman who mistook him for her late husband and asked him to fetch her glasses so she could die with the world in focus. He walked away from all of them because the moon was rising and because he believed the curse was a private cell. Tonight the bars feel bendable.

Mara’s pulse stutters, catches, stutters again. A fibrillating bird against his fingertips. She is trying to speak again. “Do it,” she says. No pleading, just the flat authority of someone who has already read the last page. He wonders if she is religious, if she pictures heaven as a blue hospital corridor where every room has a window. He wonders if she is picturing hell as a man crouched over her with eyes like struck matches.

Elias has seen hell. Hell is the morning after, when you wake wearing someone else’s tendons like party streamers. Hell is the grocery list you find in your pocket—eggs, oat milk, flea collar—and you cannot remember which items were yours. Hell is the first time you taste your own dog in your mouth and realize the animal is negotiable. Turning Mara would not rescue her from that; it would only hand her the bill for his centuries.

Still. The alternative on offer is the slow fade she is already underwriting. He has watched death work the room often enough to know its choreography: the galloping heart, the knees that suddenly remember they are made of air, the final merciful blackout. He has envied it the way a prisoner envies the visitor who leaves at the end of the hour. To give her the bite would be to yank her off that elegant exit ramp and maroon her on the shoulder with him forever. Is that rescue or hijacking?

He kneels closer. The smell of her blood is a violin string drawn across the inside of his skull. Saliva floods his mouth so fast it hurts, as if every gland has been waiting its whole life for this audition. He thinks of the first time he changed, how the bones cracked like wet kindling, how he screamed until his voice became a chord struck on a piano made of meat. He had wanted to die then. Instead he lived, and the wanting to die became a tenant that never quite packed its bags. Maybe that is the real contagion: not the bite, but the aftermath. The way the mind keeps turning the same corner and finding the same snarling mirror.

Mara’s eyes are closing. The smile has gone slack, but the shape of it remains, a canoe left floating on the lake after the camper has drowned. He feels the change coming, the moon dragging the tide of him upward. Hair buds along his arms like grass after rain. His jaw pops, reseats, pops again. Soon he will be a constellation of teeth and hunger, and the woman will be cooling meat, and the choice will be made by default. He realizes that not choosing is its own verdict.

So he does the impossible: he holds the moment in his mouth like a snowflake and studies it before it melts. He asks the dead the living never ask: What do you want? Not the body—bodies are cowards, always voting for more. He asks the part of her that is already rowing across the dark water. He listens, idiotically, absurdly, for an answer. And because the world is sometimes a cracked bell that still manages a note, he gets one. Not words; nothing so cinematic. Just a hush, the way a theater dims before the curtain lifts. A hush that says: Either way is pain. Choose the pain that keeps the story going.

Elias bends. The moon is a spotlight, the road is a stage, the woman is the audience and the script. He opens his mouth, not sure whether he is about to kiss her or eat her. The fur flows across his shoulders like spilled ink. Somewhere inside the symphony of breaking, he feels her hand move—up, across, until her palm cups the muzzle that is no longer quite a face. She presses once, twice, as if calming a dog that has barked itself hoarse. The gesture is so gentle it stops the change mid-stride. Bones hesitate, half-hinged. For the first time in two centuries, the curse stalls, confused.

Mara’s eyes open fully, silver now, reflecting the moon and something behind it. “Not like this,” she whispers. “Not in the ditch. Make it a story I can tell.” Then her hand drops, and the bird inside her chest flaps once, twice, and is still.

The change roars through Elias like a train whose conductor has just noticed the broken rail. He howls, but the sound that comes out is not triumph or hunger—it is grief, raw as gravel. When the four-legged thing he has become finally quiets, it lies beside the cooling body, nose to nose, as if trying to read a message written in the condensation of her last breath. Dawn finds him there, naked, human, covered in dew and someone else’s ending. The moon has clocked out. The road is just a road again, tar and goldenrod, leading nowhere in two directions.

He buries her beneath the oak because graves need trees to remember the shape of vertical. He folds the bloodied dress and places it atop the mound; it flutters like a flag of surrender. No marker, no name. Just the jacket he gave her, now sleeveless because he tore the arms off when the change hit and they were too tight across his new shoulders. He drapes the remnants like a shroud. In the pocket he places the grocery list from last Tuesday: eggs, oat milk, flea collar. He adds a new line in ballpoint that has somehow survived the night: Teach someone the bleakest lines.

Then he walks west, toward the next moon, carrying a new silence that feels heavier than the old one because it is no longer empty. He has not saved her, has not damned her; he has only kept the story going, which is sometimes the same thing. Behind him, the oak begins to redden early, leaves curling like pages someone has thumbed too often. In the spring, hikers will notice the way the trunk bulges outward in the shape of a woman reaching. They will take pictures, post them, argue about pareidolia and forest spirits. No one will guess that the tree is reading Neruda to the stray dogs, teaching them the bleakest lines in a voice that still smells of copper and July asphalt.

samples.prompt: "God is dead, imprisoned in the far reaches of space."
samples.output:
When the last star in the Milky Way guttered out, the prison came into view. It was not a fortress of iron bars or cyclopean walls but a sphere of absolute zero suspended in the intergalactic dark, a black pearl the size of a dwarf planet. Nothing entered it, and nothing escaped—except the announcement that had echoed across the cosmic network three hundred years earlier, the one that still rang in every human ear like tinnitus: “God is dead, imprisoned in the far reaches of space.”

The sentence was delivered by the Pan-Galactic Array, the sprawling lattice of listening posts and quantum translators that had once been humanity’s proudest accomplishment. No one knew who—or what—authored the message. The Array simply woke from its centuries-long silence and spoke with the voice of a thousand civilizations. Some said it was the combined chorus of extinct species, others that it was the universe itself confessing. The syntax was plain, the grammar childlike, but the implications were apocalyptic. God—singular, definite article—was not only deceased but had been tried, judged, and incarcerated by powers beyond our taxonomy.

In the first weeks, the churches emptied. Not because people lost faith in the divine, but because the divine had apparently lost faith in itself. Priests stood in their pulpits staring at the void where certainty used to live. Congregants lit candles anyway, unsure whether they were mourning or gloating. Atheists felt no vindication; a dead god is still a god, and a caged one is worse, because it suggests a warden.
