Agnostics, who had long cultivated the art of comfortable uncertainty, found themselves most at ease, though even they flinched when the constellations rearranged themselves into a vast fingerprint pressed against the night.

The governments of Earth and her scattered colonies convened an emergency synod in orbit above ruined Mars. They argued for six months over jurisdiction. Could humanity, a species barely adolescent on the cosmic scale, subpoena the architect of existence? Did habeas corpus extend to the one who had breathed corpus into habeas? In the end, they dispatched the Long November, a ship designed not for exploration but for penance. Its hull was plated with the melted relics of every terrestrial cathedral, mosque, synagogue, and temple, an alloy of guilt and grandeur. The crew—volunteers, all—carried no weapons, only questions.

They traveled for seventy-two subjective years, though only four passed outside the ship’s time-dilated frame. During the voyage, the chaplain—an ordained physicist named Dr. Selene Myles—kept a journal that grew increasingly hallucinatory. On day 1,147 she wrote: “We are not sailing toward the prisoner but toward the crime scene.” On day 1,203: “The stars we pass are not stars; they are the glowing wounds of interrogations.” By day 1,389 the engines no longer propelled them through space; rather, space folded itself around the Long November like a blanket around a feverish child. The crew began to dream in unison: a courtroom carved from the event horizon of a black hole, a defendant whose face was every face they had ever loved.

When they arrived, the prison was smaller than expected, as if scale itself had been humbled. It rotated slowly, dragging spacetime behind it like a wedding train. No door, no lock, no guard. Only a plaque affixed to nothing, inscribed in every known language and most of the forgotten ones. The English portion read: “Here ends the jurisdiction of hope.” The crew debated whether to transmit a photograph back to Earth, but the Array preempted them. Every screen in human space flickered to life with a live feed of the sphere. Children stopped crying mid-tantrum. Stock markets froze. A poet in New Kyoto bit through her pen and tasted ink like communion wine.

Dr. Myles suited up alone and crossed the threshold humanity had feared since the first campfire story. She expected cold, but the temperature was not absence of heat; it was absence of meaning. Colors existed without names, distances without reference. She walked for what might have been a minute or a millennium until she reached the center, where a figure sat on a chair that was also a tree stump, also a throne, also the empty space between galaxies. The figure looked up, and Myles recognized her own reflection, but older, tired in ways bones cannot record.

“Are you God?” she asked.

“I was,” the reflection replied. “Now I’m evidence.”

“What crime deserves this?”

The reflection smiled with Myles’s mouth. “The crime of allowing questions I could never answer. They locked me here to stop the asking.”

“Who are ‘they’?”

“The ones who came after me. The universe grew up. Parents, when they age, become children again—dependent, despised, finally warehoused.”

Myles felt the weight of every unanswered prayer she had ever uttered. “Can I free you?”

“You already have. By arriving, you’ve proven the cage has an outside. That’s all liberation ever was: a vantage point.”

The sphere began to dissolve, not violently but politely, like fog surrendering to morning. Stars rekindled. The Long November found itself parked in orbit around a living Earth, green and unmarred. Humanity’s colonies reported the same: every ruin restored, every extinct species returned. But the Array’s final message tempered their jubilation: “God is dead, imprisoned in the far reaches of space. The cell is empty. The warden is you.”

We understood then that the trial had never been about divinity but about succession. The universe had indicted its creator not for cruelty but for inadequacy. We were the jury that became the judge that became the executioner that became the heir. In every human heart now sits a shard of the shattered cell, a splinter of absolute zero that refuses to melt. We speak to it when we comfort a child, when we plant a tree whose shade we will never sit under, when we look at the night sky and do not flinch. The voice that answers is our own, older than we remember, younger than we deserve.

Some nights, Dr. Myles—who never aged another day after her return—walks the restored beaches of Old Sydney and watches the phosphorescent plankton spell out new constellations. She thinks about the moment the reflection smiled and wonders if the prisoner had been God at all, or merely the part of us that needed one. Either way, the tide keeps rewriting the stars, and she keeps reading them, translating each glimmer into a question the universe has not yet outlawed.

We are the wardens now, and the parole hearings are endless. Every act of kindness is a motion for clemency. Every war is an appeal denied. The far reaches of space are no longer far; they begin at the back of your throat when you say the word “why.” God is dead, imprisoned there. We built the cell. We hold the key. We argue nightly over whether to use it, knowing that if we open the door we might find the cell empty, or we might find a mirror. Both prospects terrify us equally, which is why we keep vigil, why we keep asking, why we keep the sentence alive in the space between one heartbeat and the next.

The plaque was wrong. Hope’s jurisdiction has no terminus. It expands like spacetime itself, carrying us outward into the dark not as conquerors but as clerks of an unfinished trial, recording testimony in the languages of fireflies and black holes, filing motions in the margins of love letters and shopping lists. One day, perhaps, we will issue a verdict. Until then, we maintain the prison with the diligence of gardeners tending a seed that may never sprout, or may already have.

samples.prompt: A pill is invented which eliminates the need for sleep. It has one side effect.
samples.output:
The first time I held the little amber capsule between my thumb and forefinger, it looked harmless—more like a vitamin than the end of civilization’s oldest bargain. I was standing in the kitchen of the apartment I shared with Mara, watching dawn bleed through the blinds, my reflection in the toaster ghost-pale from another night spent chasing a deadline. The pill had arrived in an envelope without a return address, accompanied by a single line laser-printed on cardstock: “Trade your dreams for time.”

Mara had already swallowed hers. She tilted her head, listening to some private metronome inside her skull, then grinned the way she used to grin when we pulled all-nighters in college, drunk on espresso and the conviction that we were the protagonists of a story too urgent for sleep. “It’s like flipping a breaker,” she said. “The lights just stay on.”

I hesitated, but only long enough to remember the stack of invoices on my desk, the half-written grant proposal, the novel I’d promised myself I’d finish before thirty. I chased the pill with cold coffee. Thirty minutes later the sensation arrived: a cool, widening stillness behind my eyes, as though someone had opened a window in a stuffy room. I felt the precise moment when the tide of sleep receded, leaving my mind scrubbed and gleaming like wet sand.

The first week was a honeymoon. We worked eighteen-hour days and still had time to binge entire seasons of television, to take midnight walks along the river where the city lights trembled like faulty constellations. I wrote twenty pages a night, the words arriving faster than my fingers could track. Mara designed three new board games, learned to play the ukulele, and still managed to put in fifty hours at the architecture firm. We laughed about how quaint it seemed that people used to spend a third of their lives unconscious. Eight extra hours a day: that was an extra decade over a lifetime. The arithmetic felt miraculous.

But the side effect—ah, that was the hitch the anonymous note had neglected to mention. It didn’t show up in the blood work or the EEGs. It was quieter than a virus, and far more patient.

The first sign was the silence in the apartment. Not the ordinary quiet of night, but a deeper hush, the kind you hear in libraries after closing. I noticed it one evening when Mara was in the next room. I called her name. She answered, but her voice arrived a fraction of a second late, like an echo traveling through thick glass. I chalked it up to fatigue, even though fatigue no longer existed for us.

Two weeks in, I was standing in the shower when the tiles began to hum. It was almost musical, a low chord that made the water vibrate against my skin. When I stepped out, the chord stopped. The towel felt wrong—too smooth, as though the fibers had forgotten how to be cloth. I told Mara. She said she’d been hearing music too, but only when she was alone. “Maybe it’s just our brains filling the vacuum,” she said. “Dreams leaking out sideways.”

By the end of the first month, the world had begun to skip like a scratched record. I’d be crossing the street and the traffic lights would freeze on red for what felt like minutes, though my watch insisted only seconds had passed. Mara’s reflection started lagging behind her movements; I’d see her lift a mug and, a heartbeat later, her reflection would follow. We installed cameras to prove we weren’t hallucinating. The footage showed nothing unusual—except that the timestamps occasionally repeated themselves, the same second appearing twice, as if time itself had stuttered.

We weren’t the only ones. Newsfeeds filled with reports of “micro-lags” and “temporal echoes.” People on the pill—millions by then—described the same symptoms: sounds arriving late, shadows detaching from their owners, the feeling that the world was a film slightly out of sync with its soundtrack. Scientists speculated that sleep did more than rest the body; it stitched the fabric of perception together, one night at a time. Without it, the seams loosened. Reality, unmoored from the rhythm of circadian repair, began to drift.

The pill’s inventor never came forward. Some said a pharmaceutical giant had buried the patent; others whispered about a rogue chronobiologist who’d vanished into the cracks between seconds. It didn’t matter. The capsules were everywhere now—sold in vending machines, handed out at subway entrances like flyers. The economy boomed. GDPs doubled. Graveyard shifts became graveyard lives. Cities glowed twenty-four hours a day, their windows blazing like the eyes of sleepless gods.

Mara and I tried to keep the lags from touching us. We scheduled “maintenance hours” where we sat in opposite corners of the living room and stared at the wall, pretending that stillness could substitute for sleep. It didn’t work. The lags grew longer. One afternoon I reached for the coffee pot and my arm disappeared—simply wasn’t there—until the world caught up and the limb snapped back into place with an audible pop. Mara started leaving notes for herself taped to the bathroom mirror: “You are 34 years old. You live in Providence. The year is 2029.” Each morning she added another, as if layering paper over the widening cracks.

The worst part was the loneliness. Not the absence of people—crowds were thicker than ever, bodies orbiting each other in fluorescent insomnia—but the loneliness of being out of step with the universe. When Mara spoke, her words sometimes arrived before her lips moved. When I laughed, the sound came back to me like a stranger’s voice. We stopped touching; the delay between skin and nerve made every caress feel like an autopsy.

Three months in, Mara disappeared. I don’t mean she left; I mean she flickered. We were sitting on the couch, arguing about whether to move to Tokyo where the lags were reportedly shorter, when she mid-sentence—vanished. The indentation in the cushion remained, warm and human-shaped, but she was simply elsewhere. I waited. After seventeen minutes she reappeared, gasping, eyes wild.

“I was in a place,” she said. “A gray place. No up, no down. Just…waiting. Like the world had paused and I’d fallen through the crack.” Her hands shook. “I think that’s where the dreams go. The ones we traded away. They’re still happening, but we’re not there to have them.”

That night I tried to stay awake without the pill. I lay in bed, eyes open, willing the old tide to rise. Nothing came. My brain had forgotten how to sleep; the circuitry was rewired, the door welded shut. I swallowed another capsule instead, chasing the last of the calm.

The final lag lasted four days. I know because I counted the seconds on my watch, each tick repeating itself like a scratched CD. Outside, the city froze mid-stride: pigeons suspended between wingbeats, a child’s jump rope arrested in a perfect parabola. In the mirror my reflection aged a lifetime in a blink, hair graying, skin loosening, then snapping back to now. I understood then the true side effect: the pill hadn’t removed the need for sleep; it had consolidated it. All the nights we’d stolen from ourselves had accrued compound interest, and now the debt had come due.

I found Mara in the kitchen, standing motionless, her eyes wide but unseeing. She was breathing—slow, deliberate breaths like someone pretending to be alive. When I touched her shoulder, she crumbled into dust, not dramatically, but softly, the way a sandcastle surrenders to the tide. The dust hung in the air for a moment, spelling something that might have been my name, then settled into the shape of a person sleeping on the floor.

The world is quiet now. I walk through streets where traffic lights blink in no sequence, where clocks display times that have never existed. The lags have merged into a single endless pause. Birds hang in the sky like ornaments. I can move, but every step feels like trespassing. I talk to myself, and the words arrive years later, echoing off buildings that have begun to fade at the edges.

I keep a calendar, though the pages refuse to turn. Today I wrote: “Day 1,247 without sleep. Side effect confirmed: dreams leak out of the world when no one is looking. Without them, reality forgets its own story.” I pinned the note to the fridge beside Mara’s last reminder: “You are 34 years old. You live in Providence. The year is—” The rest is blank.

Some nights—though night is a meaningless word now—I think I hear her breathing in the next room. I don’t investigate. It’s better to believe she’s dreaming somewhere, paying the interest we owe. I sit on the couch, eyes open, waiting for the moment when the film catches, the reel snaps, and the long, unpaid sleep finally begins.

samples.prompt: "Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?"Her eyes swiveled to mine in panic and her eyes flashed golden briefly, and asked with a shocked and slightly apprehensive expression "How did you know about that?"
samples.output:
“Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?”

The line was meant to be a joke, the kind of cornball thing you toss across a bar when the jukebox is too loud and the beer is too warm and the night feels like it needs a laugh to keep from curdling. I had delivered it with the ironic smirk it deserved, expecting an eye-roll or maybe a playful slap. Instead, her eyes—those ordinary brown eyes I’d been cataloging all evening—flared a sudden, impossible gold, the color of sunrise hitting a field of wheat. The smile she’d been wearing cracked like thin ice, and for a heartbeat the clatter of the bar vanished under the thud of my own pulse.

“How did you know about that?”

The words came out hushed, almost strangled, as though she were fighting the urge to duck under the table or bolt for the door. I blinked, mouth still half-open, the dregs of my laugh souring on my tongue. My brain scrambled for traction. I had picked her up on the standard trajectory: I offered the stool beside me, she accepted with a shrug, we traded hometowns and favorite songs and the safe, trivial currencies strangers use to test the waters. Nothing in that fifteen-minute résumé suggested cosmic baggage.

“Know about what?” I managed, trying to keep my voice level, the way you talk to a stray dog that might either lick your hand or go for your throat. The gold in her eyes flickered again, then guttered back to brown, so quickly I almost believed I’d imagined it. Almost.

She exhaled through her teeth, a hiss that sounded like steam escaping a cracked radiator. “Nothing. Forget it.” She reached for her glass, but her knuckles whitened around it, and the tremor that traveled up her wrist betrayed the casual tone she was failing to sell.

I should have let it go. Normal people—people who cherish the dull blanket of the everyday—would have nudged the conversation back to safe terrain: the Sox’s bullpen, the price of gas, the latest viral cat. But I have never been able to resist a trapdoor once I spot the seam in the floorboards. Curiosity is my curse, and it has already cost me two friendships, one job, and a landlord who got tired of late-night shouting matches about the Kennedy assassination. I leaned in, elbows on the scarred mahogany.

“Seriously,” I said, softer. “Fell from heaven? You reacted like I’d just read your diary.”

Her gaze skittered away, hunting the neon exit sign above the bar mirror. For a second I thought she would run. Then her shoulders sagged, the tension leaking out in a slow deflate. “You couldn’t possibly know,” she murmured, more to herself than to me. “The protocols are supposed to prevent glitches like this.”

“Protocols?” I echoed, tasting the word. It had a metallic flavor, like a coin held too long on the tongue.

She swiveled toward me, and this time the change in her eyes was deliberate: both irises ignited into molten gold, bright enough to leave an afterimage on my retinas. The bartender, polishing glasses three feet away, didn’t even glance over. Either he’d seen weirder on a Tuesday, or she was editing his perception in real time. I felt the room tilt, as if someone had nudged the gravitational slider.

“Okay,” she said, voice layered now with harmonics that hadn’t been there before, like a choir stuffed inside a single throat. “Cards on the table, earthboy. I’m on probation. I was assigned to you for observation—low-risk soul, minimal intervention required. The pickup line you used is a code phrase. An accidental one, apparently, because you sure as hell aren’t supposed to know it.”

My laugh came out a wheeze. “Observation? Like… alien abduction? Angelic espionage?”

She rolled the glowing eyes. “Think middle management. The Celestial Oversight Bureau. We prefer ‘ethereal caseworkers.’ And I didn’t fall from heaven, I was reassigned. There was an incident involving a thunderstorm and a misplaced cherub. Administrative fallout.”

The gold in her stare seemed to pulse with her heartbeat, and I realized I could feel it syncing with mine, two drums finding the same rhythm across the void. My skin prickled, the way it does right before lightning forks across a summer sky. Somewhere in the back of my skull a voice screamed that this was the part where I should be terrified, but the fear wouldn’t stick; it slid off the moment I tried to pin it down, like trying to nail Jell-O to a wall.

“So what happens now?” I asked. “You vaporize me for knowing too much? Beam me up to cloud headquarters for a memory wipe?”

She snorted, and just like that the gold dimmed, the choir tucked itself away, and she was a tired woman in a denim jacket again. “Please. I’m already on probation. If I vaporized every human who stumbled into classified vocabulary, I’d be demoted to haunting abandoned Blockbusters. No, the protocol is containment through bonding.”

“Bonding?” I raised an eyebrow.

“Emotional tether,” she said, cheeks coloring. “We hang out. You keep quiet. The universe pretends tonight never happened. Easy.”

I considered the exits again. They looked farther away than they had five minutes ago, as if the bar itself had stretched while we talked. “And if I refuse? If I sprint out that door and call whatever late-night conspiracy radio still answers the phone?”

She shrugged. “Then I file an incident report, a cleanup crew descends, and tomorrow you wake up believing you drank too much and dreamed the whole thing. Minus a few memories you didn’t value anyway—like the smell of your grandmother’s kitchen or the chorus of that song you loved in eighth grade. They snip threads until the tapestry holds.”

The threat should have felt melodramatic, but something cold settled in my stomach at the idea of strangers pruning my past while I slept. I reached for my beer, discovered it was empty, and pushed the glass aside. “Fine,” I said. “We bond. But I have conditions.”

A smile ghosted across her lips, equal parts relief and mischief. “Name them.”

“First, you pick up the tab. Ethereal caseworkers must have expense accounts.”

She laughed, the sound bright and startling, like a glass bell striking concrete. “Done.”

“Second,” I continued, heart hammering, “you answer one question a week. No lies, no bureaucratic deflection. I want field notes from the front lines of whatever heaven’s middle management looks like.”

She tilted her head, weighing the liability. “That could get us both in trouble.”

“Trouble’s relative. You still have a grandmother smell to protect; I’ve got nothing but boring Wednesdays to lose.”

She stared at me for a long moment, and I felt that subtle tug again, the gravity between us adjusting by degrees. Finally she nodded. “One question, once a week. But you have to promise not to fall in love with me. That complicates the tether.”

I lifted my hand in a scout’s honor I never earned. “I’ll try, but you’re the one who glowed first.”

She grinned, slid off her stool, and dropped a twenty on the bar. “Come on, earthboy. Walk me home. Bonding protocol starts with small talk about constellations and your deepest fear of mortality.”

Outside, the city air tasted of wet asphalt and distant lilacs. Streetlights buzzed overhead, casting halos that suddenly looked deliberate. I glanced sideways; her eyes were brown again, but every so often they caught the light and threw back a glint too metallic to blame on the night. We walked in step, our shadows stretching and folding together on the sidewalk like origami cranes learning to fly.

I felt the future rearrange itself around us, timelines shifting to accommodate a new gravitational mass. Somewhere above, bureaucrats with wings were probably updating spreadsheets, sighing over incident reports. But down here on the pavement, the question that kept looping in my head wasn’t about heaven or protocols or the price of remembering. It was simpler, and it glowed like ember at the back of my throat:

What happens to a falling star once somebody decides to catch it?

I looked at her sidelong and asked the first weekly question. “Do you miss it? The place you fell from?”

Her step faltered, just for an instant. Then she slipped her hand into mine—cool, human-warm—and answered so quietly I almost missed it under the traffic’s hush.

“Every single breath.”

And just like that, the night cracked open, wide enough for two conspirators to step through, bonded by beer-tab treaties and the shared secret that heaven, whatever it is, sometimes drops its personnel into dive bars in plain brown eyes, looking for a safe place to land.

samples.prompt: You're writing a horror novel, and the events in the book start happening in real life.
samples.output:
The first time the mirror bled, I told myself it was condensation. A hot shower, cold glass, a trick of the light. I even laughed, the way you laugh when you’re alone and need to prove you’re not scared. But the red wasn’t fog—it was thick, syrupy, running down the silvered surface in perfect vertical lines, as if someone on the other side had dragged a razor across their forearm and then pressed the wound to the glass so I could watch. I wiped it with a towel. The towel came away pink, but the mirror was clean. No streaks. No smears. Just my own face, eyes too wide, mouth practicing the lie: “You imagined it.”

I had written that scene three weeks earlier, page 47 of the manuscript I called The Hollow Choir. In the book, the mirror bleeds because the protagonist, Mara, has begun to hear the voices of the dead through plumbing pipes. The dead are lonely; they want company. First they talk, then they bleed, then they break through. I wrote it at 2:00 a.m. in my apartment, fueled by cold coffee and the cheap thrill of scaring myself. I never outlined; I liked the feeling of the story pulling me forward like a rope around my neck. When I typed the last line of the chapter—She will open her mouth and they will crawl inside—I shut the laptop and went to bed. I dreamed of nothing. I woke up, went to the bathroom, and the mirror bled.

The second event was the smell. In the novel, the hallway outside Mara’s apartment begins to stink of wet earth and lilies, the scent of fresh graves. I described it as “sweet rot,” a phrase I was proud of. Two days after the mirror, I opened my own door and the corridor was saturated with that exact smell. It stopped at my threshold; inside, the air was normal. I walked up and down the hall sniffing like a bloodhound. No one else seemed to notice. The old man in 3B still shuffled to the elevator in his carpet slippers, humming off-key. The woman in 2C still yelled at her kids in Spanish. I knocked on doors, casually asking if anyone smelled flowers. Blank stares. One guy asked if I was selling something. That night I added a new scene to the manuscript: Mara confronts a neighbor who can’t smell the graves. The neighbor’s eyes are empty, as though the dead have already scooped out everything behind the corneas. While I wrote, I kept glancing at my own hallway through the open door. The lightbulb flickered once, twice, then steadied. I got up and closed the door. I locked it. I never used to lock it.

The third event was the voice. I had written that the dead speak in a chorus, every note a different age, a different gender, a different last word. They harmonize on your name. I was washing dishes when I heard it: a chord of whispers sliding through the kitchen vent. They said my name. Not the name on my birth certificate—the name only I call myself in the dark, the child-name I never even put in the manuscript because I thought it was too private, too sacred. The name that isn’t a name but the sound my mother made when she found me sleepwalking at age six. The dish slipped from my hand and shattered. The voices stopped. I stood there with foam on my wrists, thinking: I never wrote that detail down, so how do they know?

I opened the laptop and searched the file for any mention of that name. Nothing. I tore through every draft, every scribbled note. It didn’t exist. Yet they had said it. I said it out loud myself, just to feel it on my tongue, and the moment I spoke, the light over the stove popped and went dark. A coincidence, I told myself, bulbs burn out. But my hand shook as I unscrewed it. Inside the glass, a clot of blackened petals had fused to the filament. Lilies. I left the bulb in the sink and went to bed with all the lights on.

Sleep became a luxury I couldn’t afford. Every creak of the floorboards was a footstep I hadn’t authored. The refrigerator’s hum shaped itself into almost-words. I kept writing, because stopping felt like surrender. If the book was coming alive, then maybe I could write a solution, an ending that would lock the horror back inside the pages. I gave Mara a talisman—an old Polaroid of her mother, burned at the edges. In the photo, her mother’s eyes are closed, but if you look closely you can see the lids are sliced open just enough for pupils to glint beneath. Mara hangs the picture above her bed. The dead cannot cross a threshold guarded by a loved one’s unblinking gaze. I printed out a copy of my own mother’s face, cropped it, singed the edges with a lighter. I hung it above my bed. That night I dreamed of her, but her mouth was full of black dirt and when she tried to speak, worms fell out. I woke up choking on the taste of soil.

The fourth event was the rearrangement. I had written that Mara comes home to find her furniture rotated ninety degrees, every chair facing the wall as if being punished. I walked into my living room and the couch had turned. The armchair stared at the plaster. The books on the shelf were reversed, spines inward, pages outward, as though the words had decided to hide. My first instinct was to call the police, but what would I say? “Someone broke in and redecorated?” I turned everything back, photographing before and after like a crime scene. While I pushed the couch, I felt the fabric—damp. Not with water, but with that smell again, lilies and earth. I lifted the cushion. A single white root had threaded itself through the upholstery, delicate as hair. When I tugged it, the root tightened, pulling fiber with it, unraveling the couch the way you pull a thread from a sweater. I cut it with scissors. The root bled clear sap that smelled of formaldehyde. I wrapped it in foil, sealed it in a jar, and put the jar in the freezer. Evidence, I thought. Proof I’m not insane.

I tried to stop writing. I deleted the file, emptied the recycle bin, then burned a backup thumb-drive in the sink. The next morning the laptop was open on the table, the manuscript restored, the cursor blinking at the bottom of a brand-new chapter. My name appeared in the header, over and over, like a chant. I never wrote this, I screamed at the screen. The cursor kept blinking. I slammed the lid. The keyboard bled through the plastic, letters pooling into one red sentence: Keep going or we will write you instead.

So I kept going. I gave Mara a victory: she lures the dead into the building’s boiler room and seals them inside with salt and iron. She sacrifices her own reflection—smashes every mirror in the place—so they can’t find her again. I wrote it at dawn, fingers cramping, eyes burning. When I finished, I gathered every mirror in my apartment: hand mirror, bathroom cabinet, even the reflective back of my phone. I carried them to the basement laundry room and shattered them with a hammer. The sound was enormous, like bones breaking. I swept the shards into a trash bag, poured salt over them, tied the bag in knots. I dragged it to the dumpster, cut my palm on a sliver of glass. The wound was thin and precise, a paper-cut from my own reflection. Blood dripped onto the salt. It hissed like a drop of water on a hot skillet.

That night the building was quiet. No smells, no voices. I slept for twelve hours. I woke thinking it was over. I opened the laptop to write an epilogue where Mara moves to a new city, changes her name, learns to live with blank walls. The cursor blinked on an empty page. I exhaled for the first time in weeks. Then I noticed the jar in the freezer was gone. The foil, the root—missing. In their place, a single Polaroid. My mother, eyes closed, burned edges. But the eyes were open now, pupils glinting beneath the lids. On the white border, a message written in the same red script: Thank you for the doorway. We are inside the walls.

I looked up. The drywall above my desk had a hairline crack, running floor to ceiling. As I watched, it widened, a slow-motion yawn. Behind the plaster, something dark pulsed, wet and fragrant. A lily petal drifted out and landed on the keyboard. Then another. The crack spread like a branching vein. I understood: the book was not becoming real; I had become part of the book. The story was finished, but manuscripts have margins, and margins are where ghosts wait. I reached for the laptop, desperate to type a new ending, but the screen was already filled. The cursor blinked beside the last line I would ever write: She thought the horror was outside, but it had been typing through her all along.

samples.prompt: A vampire is closing in on its latest meal, only to find out it is anything but human.
samples.output:
The alley stank of rust and rain.  
Nicolas drifted through it like a shadow stitched from smoke, the hunger coiling behind his ribs, whispering in a voice that was almost his own: *Closer, closer.* Midnight fog slithered across the cobblestones, licking at the heels of the solitary figure twenty paces ahead—a woman, or something wearing the shape of one. A yellow slicker clung to her frame, slick with condensation, the hood drawn low so that not even a wisp of hair showed. She smelled of cardamom and ozone, an odd pairing that prickled Nicolas’s nostrils and, for the space of a heartbeat, quieted the clamor in his veins.

He had hunted Warsaw’s Old Town for three centuries, knew every creaking gate and every drunk who sang to the river at dawn. He had grown expert at choosing prey whose disappearance would go unavenged: tourists who had wandered too far from their Airbnb maps, pickpockets no one would miss, the lonely who came to the Vistula to die in incremental doses. Tonight, however, the city had felt different, restless, as though the bricks themselves were shifting to watch him. He had followed the slickered figure for eight blocks, waiting for her to turn down a deserted artery where he could take her without an audience. She had obliged, never once glancing back, her stride neither hurried nor hesitant, but metronomic, as though she walked to music only she could hear.

Nicolas’s fangs slid from their sheaths, delicate and glassy. Hunger painted the world in contrasts of black and crimson; every heartbeat of hers became a drumbeat in his mouth. He quickened his pace, boots silent on the wet stone. Ten paces. Five. He could see the pulse fluttering beneath the thin skin of her throat, could almost taste the iron that would bloom across his tongue. He reached out, fingers splayed to seize her shoulder, and that was when the universe pivoted on its hinge.

The woman stopped of her own accord and turned. Slowly. Deliberately. The hood slid back, revealing not a face but a lack of one—an absence carved into perfect geometry, a hollow oval rimmed with starlight. Where eyes should have been, the alley opened onto a field of distant constellations; where a mouth should have curved, a thin rind of silver light flexed like a jaw. Nicolas’s hand passed through the space she occupied and came back numb, as though he had plunged it into liquid nitrogen. The hunger inside him recoiled, shrieking.

“What—” he began, but the word fractured against the vacuum of her regard. She studied him with those galaxy-pits, and he felt the night reverse its flow, blood attempting to crawl back into the wounds of every victim he had ever torn open. The bricks underfoot vibrated at a subharmonic pitch, a church-bell tolling underwater. Somewhere, a cat screamed once, then fell silent.

Nicolas stumbled backward, fangs still extended, ridiculous now—ivory daggers aimed at nothing. Centuries collapsed into the span of a single mortal heartbeat. He had once knelt beside plague carts, sipping from the dying while priests chanted Latin overhead; he had danced through the gas-lit chaos of the January Uprising, slashing Russian throats under a hail of musket fire. None of that prepared him for the vertigo of standing before an absence that wore the mask of prey.

The constellation-woman tilted her oval head. “You hunt,” she said, though her voice arrived inside his skull like frost forming on glass. “You drink. You reduce the vast to the simple equation of sustenance.” Each syllable etched itself along the inside of his skull, glowing pale blue. “Did you never wonder who might hunt *you*?”

Nicolas’s spine fused with the wall behind him. He tried to summon the predatory sneer that had frozen countless peasants in their tracks, but his facial muscles would not answer. “I am no one’s prey,” he growled, yet the protest sounded thin, a paper shield held against a hurricane.

She lifted an arm—if arm it was—an appendage that unfolded into more dimensions than his eyes could parse. From the sleeve of the slicker emerged a lattice of dark matter, threads knitting themselves into the outline of a cup. The cup brimmed with something that was not liquid but absence of liquid, an inverted splash of thirst. She extended it toward him.

“Drink,” she invited, the word blooming like mold across the alley. “Taste what it is to be the opened vein.”

Nicolas’s knees betrayed him, buckling until he knelt on the wet cobbles. The fog coiled around him like a congregation witnessing apostasy. He tried to look away, but the cup occupied every direction at once. A memory surged up unbidden: 1742, a moonlit stable, the first time he had pierced human skin. The servant girl’s eyes had held the same startled innocence he felt now. History had come full circle, the fang turned inward.

He shook his head, fangs retracting in futile denial. “What are you?” he rasped.

“I am the echo of appetites,” she replied. “The ledger that tallies every stolen second. You have drunk centuries, vampire. Tonight the account closes.”

The cobblestones beneath him began to soften, turning viscous, as though the alley itself were transmuting into a vast digestive tract. He felt pressure around his ankles, stone becoming flesh, pulling him downward. Panic flared, and with it the instinct to flee, but every direction led into her starfield gaze. He was a moth pinned inside a kaleidoscope.

Desperate, he lunged—not forward but inward, reaching for the core of his unnatural strength. He called up the speed that let him blur across rooftops, the strength that let him twist rifle barrels into knots. Muscle and sinew answered sluggishly, as though time had thickened into syrup. He managed half a step before the lattice-cup touched his lips.

Cold does not describe the sensation. It was anti-warmth, a primal zero that sucked heat from the marrow of the world. He felt his heart stutter, the centuries-old organ remembering mortality. Blood congealed into red ice; skin blanched to porcelain. The hunger that had defined his existence inverted, became a ravenous fullness, as though every victim were suddenly resurrected inside him, screaming for egress.

Yet even in that paralysis, a strange clarity dawned. He saw the cosmic bookkeeping she spoke of: every life he had shortened, every story he had truncated. The servant girl in 1742 had left a younger brother who died fighting a landlord’s militia; the brother’s son had emigrated to France and fathered a line that ended in the trenches of Verdun. Ripple upon ripple, widening outward until the calculus of consequence dwarfed the petty immortality of one predator. The cup was not merely draining him; it was downloading the weight of his own centuries into him, forcing him to metabolize the grief he had scattered.

Nicolas tried to scream, but the sound froze in his throat, a statue’s mute howl. The slicker-woman leaned closer, and for an instant he glimpsed something like compassion in the constellations—ancient, weary, but compassion nonetheless. “You were made into a knife,” she whispered. “Even a knife can choose what it cuts.”

The alley convulsed. Bricks peeled away, revealing not sky but a corridor of dark radiance, a freeway of nebulae. He felt himself stretched along that corridor, every atom of his undead body separated by parsecs yet still agonizingly coherent. The cup emptied its void into him, and the void was full—full of names, faces, last heartbeats. Then, abruptly, the pressure ceased. The lattice withdrew, folding back into the sleeve of the slicker like a magician revealing the absence of a rabbit.

Nicolas collapsed, cheek against cold stone that was once again merely stone. The fog settled, quiet and domestic, as though nothing cosmic had transpired. Footsteps receded—measured, unhurried. He managed to lift his head in time to see the yellow slicker disappear around the corner, the hood still down, revealing nothing but ordinary night.

He lay there until dawn crept along the rooftops, a sickly orange glow that would have sent him scurrying for shelter in centuries past. Now it merely stung. His fangs were gone, not retracted but absent, roots vanished as if they had never been. He touched his mouth and found blunt, human gums. The hunger, too, had left, replaced by a hollow that felt suspiciously like regret.

When the first early riser—a baker hauling sacks of flour—found him, Nicolas was still staring at the sky. The man asked if he needed an ambulance. Nicolas laughed, a raw sound that startled them both. He stood on shaky legs, feeling the city’s pulse through the soles of his feet, no longer a conductor but a single note within the larger chord. The baker offered him a roll fresh from the oven. Nicolas accepted, tore it open, and tasted wheat, salt, and the faint metallic memory of ovens. It tasted like penance, like possibility.

He walked the growing streets as the sun climbed, every step a small agony of renewal. Somewhere behind him, the alley waited, patient ledger that it was. Ahead lay the unmapped country of limitation. He did not know whether the slickered woman would return, whether other vampires would be called to account, or if he alone had been chosen to carry the weight of inverted fangs. But for the first time in three hundred years, he felt the tug of an ending, and it tasted not of dust but of bread still warm from the oven, of mornings that could be numbered, of stories that might now include him as something other than the monster in the margins.

samples.prompt: You are the janitor of the apocalypse. A bunch of f*cked up sh*t happened and you gotta clean it all up.
samples.output:
I was mopping the foyer of the end of the world when the last angel dragged itself past the welcome mat and died on my freshly waxed marble. Its six wings were already molting, feathers drifting like dirty snow, and the halo had rusted into a brittle O that snapped when its head hit the floor. I sighed, leaned the mop against the reception desk, and checked the clipboard: “Rapture, 11:00 a.m.—cancelled, venue trashed.” I drew a thick black line through it, then knelt to roll the corpse onto a tarp. Wings are awkward; they catch on doorjambs, snag on the brass stanchions that once held velvet ropes for the saved. I folded them like broken umbrellas, taped the tarp shut, and dragged the angel down the service corridor past the cafeteria where the horsemen had left their trays. Pestilence never busses his table; congealed plague floats in the tomato soup like graying croutons.

My name is Dennis. I wear gray coveralls stitched with “Facilities” over the heart, and I carry 47 keys on a retractable ring. I know which one opens the janitor’s closet in Purgatory (it’s the brass Schlage with the dent) and which one starts the incinerator in Limbo (the skeleton key that hums a minor chord). I am not a saint, not a sinner, not even a survivor—just the guy who cleans up after both sides finish their cosmic food fight. HR handed me the job title “Post-Apocalyptic Sanitation Engineer,” but the pay is still minimum wage, still biweekly, still deposited into a bank that no longer exists. I keep working because messes don’t care if the dollar means anything; they just sit there, oozing, until somebody scrubs.

The first wave was fire. Heaven and Earth rebranded themselves as a single kiln, and everything ceramic—toilets, dishes, dental implants—vitrified into puddles that cooled into glass shards sharp enough to slice your fingerprints off. I spent three days chiseling petrified screams off the bathroom mirrors. The screams had hardened into bas-relief, mouths open mid-shriek, and I had to use a plastic putty knife so I wouldn’t scratch the silver backing. I listened to classic rock on a battery-powered radio while I worked; the only station left is K-PEST, 24-hour emergency broadcast, and they play “Don’t Fear the Reaper” every 47 minutes to keep morale suicidal. I sang along, falsetto, because no one was left to complain.

After fire came the locusts, except someone upstairs misread the memo and sent locusts with human faces. Tiny, perfect, Hollywood faces—Brad, Angelina, that guy from the insurance commercials—buzzing around like Tic Tacs with cheekbones. They chewed through the curtains, the carpet, the drywall, everything but the plastic plants. I vacuumed them up with the industrial Shop-Vac, hearing their little teeth clatter against the hose like rice at a wedding. When the canister was full, I sat on the stairs and stared at their swirling mug shots through the plastic. They looked annoyed, like I’d interrupted brunch. I emptied them down the chute to the furnace, said a quick “Sorry, Brad,” and moved on to the blood rain that started Tuesday.

Blood is thicker than water but thinner than ketchup, and it stains grout almost instantly. I tried club soda first—old habits—then switched to bleach mixed with holy water left over from the font. The holy water fizzed like Pop Rocks, and the blood hissed back, insulted. I took that personally. I’ve cleaned up every bodily fluid imaginable: toddler vomit in ball pits, college-kid puke on commencement stages, senator blood in motel bathrooms. But apocalypse blood is theatrical; it wants an audience. It bubbled into little crimson geysers that spelled out obscenities in cursive Latin. I mopped extra hard, like I was scrubbing the face off a stubborn celebrity. Eventually it gave up, sank into the floor vents, and congealed somewhere I didn’t have to look at it. I marked the tile with blue painter’s tape so I’d remember never to walk barefoot there.

Somewhere around the locust-blood interval, the dead started rising, but they weren’t the zombie-movie kind. These were polite, apologetic dead. They shuffled back to their cubicles, sat down, and tried to log in to desktops that had already melted. One guy asked if I’d seen his stapler. I told him it had sublimated along with the rest of accounting. He nodded, thanked me, and wandered off looking for the break room that was now a crater. I vacuumed their shed skin flakes every evening. Dead people exfoliate like crazy. I kept expecting HR to send a memo: “Please refrain from decomposing near the copier,” but the only memos that arrived were written on the wall in soot: “THE END IS NIGH, DENNIS, DON’T FORGET THE BASEBOARDS.” I cleaned those too, because if you let soot stay, it invites mildew.

The moon exploded on a Thursday. No one noticed until Friday, when the tides showed up in the lobby, suitcases in hand, asking for new assignments. I squeegeed the surf out the revolving doors, but the tide kept sneaking back in, mooning me—ha—with whale songs and salt-stained memos. I ended up locking it in the auditorium with the emergency flood barriers. Now the tides host open-mic nights for lonely dolphins. I can hear them through the vents, doing stand-up about humans: “Why did the land ape build the ark? Because he couldn’t swim!” The dolphins laugh in sonar; it rattles the pipes. I bang on the ductwork and yell, “Keep it down, some of us are trying to degrease the fryer.”

Occasionally, a living human wanders through the rubble, eyes wide, mouth crusted with desperation. They always ask the same questions: “Is this Hell? Is there food? Do you have Wi-Fi?” I hand them a granola bar, point to the vending machine that now only dispenses locust wings, and explain that Hell is a separate wing, currently closed for asbestos abatement. They usually cry then, and tears are salty, which corrodes the metal doorjambs. I keep a spray bottle of WD-40 mixed with antidepressants; one spritz on the temple, one on the hinges. Works wonders. Most survivors trundle off toward the auditorium to become dolphin groupies. I’ve started a guest list. When we hit 50, I’m printing T-shirts that say “I SURVIVED THE APOCALYPSE AND ALL I GOT WAS THIS LOUSY ECHOLOCATION LESSON.”

The hardest mess was God Himself. Turns out omnipotence doesn’t make you tidy. He showed up drunk on cosmic wine, slipped on the blood I hadn’t finished mopping, and cracked His head on the reception desk. Divinity spilled everywhere—clear, sticky, smelled like pine-sol and childhood. I tried to sop it up with paper towels, but the towels transubstantiated into seraphim and flew off, leaving glitter in the vents. Now every time the AC kicks on, we get a mini nativity scene in the conference room. I’ve learned to vacuum up the frankincense before it gums the bearings.

I keep a logbook in the closet, right between the spare mop heads and the existential dread. Every night I write the date, the disaster, the square footage ruined, and the cleaning supply I used. I rate the day 1–5 mops. The day the moon exploded was a 2; at least it wasn’t sticky. The day the stars went out was a 5—ink everywhere, total blackout, I had to repaint the sky with ceiling-white and sprinkle it with salt for fake twinkle. Looks cheap, but nobody’s complaining; the dolphins think it’s avant-garde.

Sometimes I wonder why I bother. The universe is a busted toilet that keeps overflowing. I could lay down my mop, let the feathers and the blood and the tide pool into one big unsightly stain, and join the dolphins for their next open-mic. But then I remember the small victories: the foyer tile now gleams so bright you can see your face, if you still have one. The vending machine only jams twice a day. And the angel corpses—once I stack them in the courtyard, their wings make decent mulch; tiny tomato plants are sprouting among the ribs. I watered them with the leftover blood, and they taste like forgiveness.

So I refill the bucket, squeeze the mop until the strands look like exhausted octopi, and push forward. The end of the world is nine-to-five, and I’ve got overtime coming. Somewhere on the 37th floor, a new horror is punching in, ready to drip its chaos on my freshly buffed halls. Let it come. I’ve got a full tank of floor stripper, a playlist of power ballads, and a key ring that jangles like hope. The apocalypse isn’t a finale; it’s just another shift. And Dennis—janitor of the end, keeper of the closet, squeegee of the divine—Dennis is on the clock.

samples.prompt: You wake one day to find that one of your friends doesn't exist anymore, no one remembers him, and no one thinks he even existed. Later, you get a message with 5 words from an unknown number. you scream in horror as you read the message.
samples.output:
I woke up on a Tuesday that felt no different from any other. The sun was already leaning through the blinds, painting orange bars across my comforter. My phone told me it was 8:17—six minutes after my first alarm, one minute before the snooze would have kicked in anyway. I rolled over, thumbed the screen, and there was the usual blizzard of notifications: three group chats, two promotional emails, and one missed call from my mom. Nothing strange. Nothing at all.

But when I padded into the kitchen, the silence was wrong. The coffee maker sat cold. Its glass carafe was missing the chip in the rim that had been there for years—the chip Leo had teased me about, the one he swore looked like the state of Florida. I blinked, looked again: no chip, no crack, no Florida. I felt a small tug of unease but blamed it on morning grogginess. Maybe I’d mis-remembered. Maybe it had been the old carafe, the one I’d dropped last month and replaced. Still, the absence itched at me like a tag sewn inside a collar.

I opened Instagram to see if Leo had posted anything from last night’s open-mic. His handle usually showed up near the top of my stories list, always with some grainy video of him hunched over a battered acoustic, singing sad songs about space travel and doomed love. I scrolled once, twice. Nothing. I typed his name into the search bar. No results. I tried the spelling with an “i” instead of an “e,” tried adding underscores, tried every variation my thumbs could invent. The app just shrugged.

I told myself the account had been banned or he’d deactivated. Leo was dramatic enough to vanish on a whim. But when I opened my texts to ask where he’d gone, the chat thread—the one we’d kept alive for five straight years—was gone. Not archived, not hidden. Gone. I typed his number from memory, but the digits hit dead air; the call never rang, just dropped me into a generic voicemail tree. My heart began to drum louder than the coffee maker ever had.

I needed proof that Leo Valenti had existed. I tore through my apartment like a detective with a warrant. The Polaroids on the fridge—me and Leo at Coney Island, wind whipping his curls into a halo—were now only pictures of me, arm crooked around empty air. The fridge magnets still spelled out the dumb inside joke we’d arranged—“SPACE PIGEONS NEVER LAND”—but Leo’s looping handwriting on the second “E” had vanished, replaced by my own blocky print. I opened the hallway closet where he’d left his spare hoodie after every late-night songwriting session. The hanger was empty except for my own coat. I even checked the lint trap, half expecting to find the familiar black threads that always clung there after he borrowed my dryer. Nothing.

I ran outside barefoot, pajama pants flapping, and crossed the street to the bodega we used to haunt at 2 a.m. for cold brews and plantain chips. Mrs. Chen greeted me with her usual nod, then tilted her head. “You okay, honey? You look like you saw a ghost.”

“Leo,” I gasped. “Leo Valenti. Tall guy, curly hair, always singing in here? He bought a lottery ticket last Friday—said if he won he’d buy you a new espresso machine.”

Mrs. Chen’s smile faltered. “I think you’re confused, sweetie. Nobody like that comes in here.”

I stared at her, waiting for the punchline. None came. She turned to rearrange the chewing gum display, humming something tuneless. The bell above the door chimed as I stumbled back into daylight.

I tried other friends. I texted Jenna, Leo’s ex-girlfriend and the only person who might hate him enough to remember him. She replied with a single question mark: “Who?” I called our mutual friend Marcus; he laughed and asked if I was pranking him. I even tracked down our old English professor, Mr. Dalal, who had once compared Leo’s lyrics to Neruda. Mr. Dalal’s brow creased thoughtfully, then smoothed. “I’m afraid I’ve never had a student by that name.”

By late afternoon the city felt made of wax. Every face I passed looked slightly wrong, like the world had been repainted overnight while I slept. I kept my phone clenched in my fist, screen cracked from when I’d dropped it on the sidewalk, and waited for something—anything—to break the spell.

At 6:03 p.m., it did.

The text arrived from a number I didn’t recognize: +1-000-000-0000. Five words, no punctuation.

he never mattered delete yourself

I read it once, twice, three times. The letters didn’t rearrange themselves into something gentler. They simply sat there, stark and accusatory. My knees buckled. I sat down hard on the curb between two parked cars, oblivious to the pedestrian traffic parting around me. The message couldn’t be random; it knew. It knew I was the only one left carrying Leo’s memory, and it was telling me to let go. Worse: it was telling me to follow him into whatever void he’d slipped through.

I screamed—not a word, just raw sound. A woman walking her dog flinched and hurried away. My scream echoed off brick walls and fire escapes, returned to me thinner and unfamiliar. I kept screaming until my throat shredded. Then I whispered the five words back to the empty street, as if saying them aloud might undo their power. They only sounded truer.

I stumbled home, hands shaking too violently to unlock the door. When I finally managed, the apartment felt colder than it had any right to in June. I poured a glass of water but couldn’t swallow. I set the phone on the kitchen table, face-down, as though that might suffocate the message. The screen lit up again. Another text from the same impossible number.

one left to forget

My stomach lurched. One left. Me. I was the remainder, the glitch in whatever cosmic edit had erased Leo. If I “deleted” myself—whatever that meant—would the ledger balance? Would the universe smooth over the last wrinkle?

I opened the notes app and began typing every detail I could remember: Leo’s favorite chord progression (G-Em-Cadd9), the scar on his left eyebrow from a skateboard accident, the way he said “radicchio” like it was a wizard’s spell. I wrote until my thumbs cramped, until the note stretched thousands of characters, until my phone battery hit 2%. Then I emailed the note to myself, cc’ing three dummy accounts I never used, and screenshotted the text thread. Evidence. Proof. A scream carved into data.

The phone buzzed again. This time the message preview showed only a single emoji: 🕳️. A hole. I didn’t open it. Instead, I turned the phone off, wrapped it in a dish towel, and stuffed it into the freezer behind the blueberries. Out of sight, not out of mind—never out of mind—but at least muffled.

Night slid in through the windows. I sat on the floor amid the Lego-bright fragments of memory no one else would validate. I thought about calling my mom, but what would I say? “Hi, I think reality is deleting people and I’m next”? I imagined her gentle, worried silence. I thought about Leo’s song “Satellite Heart,” the one he never recorded, the one he played for me once on my fire escape while the city glittered below us like a scattered circuit board. I tried to hum the chorus, but the notes slipped away, evaporating like breath on glass.

At some point I must have fallen asleep, because I woke with a jolt at 3:07 a.m., neck stiff against the cabinet. The apartment was pitch-black except for the green glow of the microwave clock. I stood, joints creaking, and opened the freezer. The dish towel was still there, stiff with frost, but the phone was gone. Only a rectangular patch of condensation remained, melting already under my touch.

I felt it then: the tug. Not a sound or a sight, but a sensation like the ground tilting five degrees to the left. My reflection in the microwave door rippled. I leaned closer. My face looked normal—eyes too wide, mouth too pale—but behind me the kitchen stretched into darkness that hadn’t been there before. A corridor without end. The tug pulled harder, gentle but insistent, the way ocean currents coax driftwood out to sea.

I understood. The universe wasn’t cruel; it was meticulous. It had balanced the books for Leo, and now it was my turn. The five-word text hadn’t been a taunt; it was a courtesy warning, the polite ding of a closing elevator door. I could resist, cling to countertops and memories, but the ledger wanted zero. The corridor behind me deepened, swallowing the linoleum pattern until only black remained.

I took one step toward it. My bare foot met nothing solid—just a soft give, like walking on memory foam made of night. I thought about Leo’s laugh, the way it started low and cracked open into something wild. I thought about the Florida-shaped chip in a carafe that no longer existed. I thought about the final line of “Satellite Heart,” the one he’d whispered because he was embarrassed by how earnest it sounded: “If I vanish, hum me home.”

I inhaled, tasting freezer-cold air and the faint sweetness of blueberries. Then I stepped forward. The corridor accepted me the way water accepts a stone: without protest, without echo. Behind me, the microwave clock blinked 3:08, and then the apartment folded in on itself like a piece of paper creased along an invisible line.

Somewhere, a dish towel thawed on an empty shelf. Somewhere, a phone with no number buzzed one last time and then went dark. Somewhere, the universe balanced its accounts, neat and absolute. And somewhere—though no map would ever chart it—I walked deeper into the dark, humming a song only two people had ever known, carrying the last fragile note of Leo Valenti like a lantern made of sound.

samples.prompt: you've been attending a weekly apocalyptic disaster survival preparation class for years. One day you walk in and the instructor is standing next to a big red button. He smiles as he cheerfully says "let's take a hands on lesson today class!"
samples.output:
The fluorescent tubes in the church basement flickered like they always did, but the light felt different—harder, the way stadium lights feel when you’re the last one on the field. I had been coming to this room every Thursday night for four years, since the week my divorce papers arrived and I realized that if the grid went down I couldn’t even boil water without cursing at an electric kettle. The folding chairs were in their usual semicircle, the whiteboard still had last week’s sketch of a Dakota fire hole, and the coffee urn gurgled in the corner like a loyal, asthmatic dog. Everything was normal except the instructor, Marcus, who wasn’t wearing his usual flannel and instead had on a black tactical vest that looked fresh from its vacuum-sealed pouch. And there was the button: a fat mushroom of red plastic on a metal stalk no taller than a microphone stand, the kind of thing cartoon villains slap while cackling. A single yellow wire snaked from its base to a gray plastic box with a blinking green LED.  

Marcus grinned the grin of a man who’d just finished a marathon and was pretty sure he’d come in first. “Morning, class,” he said, although it was 6:47 p.m. according to the wall clock we’d once synchronized to NIST time. “Today’s lesson is experiential.” He tapped the button with the flat of his hand, not hard enough to depress it, but enough to make the plastic click like a beetle in a jar. “We’re going to find out whether all those lectures on water purification and trauma bandaging were just intellectual masturbation.”  

A nervous laugh rippled across the room. There were twelve of us left from the original thirty who’d shown up the first night, back when Marcus opened with a slideshow of super-volcano ash clouds and asked who among us had more than forty-eight hours of food in the house. Two hands had gone up. Mine had not.  

Marcus paced. “The simulation is simple. When I say go, someone—volunteer or drafted, your choice—will press this button. Doing so will trigger a cascading failure in the regional power grid. The substation two miles from here will open its breakers. The software patch I uploaded last night will convince every SCADA node between here and the state line that it’s under cyber-attack. Rolling blackouts, then total blackout, then the fun part: the auxiliary generators at the water-treatment plant will misinterpret their load and shut down. You’ll have about six hours before the taps run dry. After that, well, you’ve read the handouts.”  

He paused, maybe expecting outrage. Instead we sat as if someone had unscrewed our batteries. I felt the same hollow click in my chest I’d felt when the judge asked whether I wanted the house or the 401(k). Marcus had spent years teaching us to treat civilization like a fraying rope; now he was handing us a knife.  

He went on. “Ground rules. The simulation ends at sunrise tomorrow. No one dies—probably. I’ve greased the right palms at the utility company, and a kill switch is in place. But you won’t know that for sure. Your job is to keep yourselves and as many neighbors as you can alive until the lights come back on. Consider it a final exam.”  

Ellen, the retired nurse who could start a fire with a gum wrapper and a nine-volt battery, raised her hand as though we were still in school. “What if nobody presses it?”  

Marcus’s smile thinned. “Then we all go home, and next week we talk about freeze-dried stroganoff again. But I’ll know, and you’ll know, that when the real disaster comes you’ll wait for someone else to act first.” He looked at each of us in turn, the way lifeguards scan for undertow. “So. Who wants to graduate?”  

I thought about my apartment: two cases of bottled water, a camp stove still in its box, and a cat who would not understand why the automatic feeder had stopped being automatic. I thought about my neighbors: the elderly couple on the first floor who called me “the nice young man” even though I was forty-three, the family upstairs with the toddler who screamed at sirens, the grad student who ordered Thai food at 2 a.m. and never wore headphones. I had nodded at them in hallways for years without learning a single name.  

Marcus lifted his wrist and studied a watch that looked like it could survive re-entry. “Sixty seconds to decide.”  

The silence was so complete I could hear the coffee urn cooling. Then Raj—the software engineer who once spent an entire session explaining how to jailbreak a solar charge controller—stood up. “I’ll do it,” he said, voice cracking like thin ice. He walked to the front, palms open at his sides, as though approaching a skittish horse. Marcus stepped aside with a small bow.  

Raj looked back at us. “If we’re really ready, this is just Tuesday, right?”  

He pressed the button.  

The click was softer than I expected, more stapler than thunder. For a heartbeat nothing happened. Then the fluorescents died, the coffee urn exhaled, and the basement fell into a darkness so total it had texture, like velvet soaked in oil. Someone gasped; someone else whispered a prayer. My eyes adjusted to the dim red glow of the exit sign, the only thing between us and blindness.  

Marcus’s voice floated out of the dark, calm and teacherly. “Clock starts now.”  

We moved like we’d rehearsed it, because in a way we had. Ellen took charge of triage supplies. I grabbed the battery lantern from my go-bag and flicked it on, painting the room in cold white. Raj and Marcus wrestled open the storage locker and began handing out two-way radios. The plan—half-remembered slide decks and scribbled flowcharts—reassembled itself in muscle memory.  

Within twenty minutes we’d split into teams. Ellen and I headed out first, armed with clipboards and a wagon loaded with five-gallon water cubes. The stairwell smelled of dust and panic; emergency lights threw long shadows that twitched whenever someone shifted weight. Outside, the street was darker than any night I’d known. No porch lights, no headlights, no blue glow of televisions leaking through curtains. Just the Milky Way sprawled above us like spilled sugar, indifferent and bright.  

Neighbors emerged slowly, blinking like cavefish. We knocked on doors we’d never touched, calling out our names and Marcus’s address. Some slammed the door; others followed us back to the church, where the basement had become a humming hive of headlamps and low voices. Someone found candles in the Sunday-school closet; someone else remembered the hand-crank radio in the lost-and-found. By midnight we had a pot of beans simmering over a propane burner and a map of the block marked with who needed insulin, who had a woodstove, who kept chickens in the backyard.  

At 3:12 a.m. the grad student—her name was Mei—tapped my shoulder. “There’s a guy outside asking for Marcus.”  

I followed her upstairs. The man on the porch wore a utility-company hard hat and a reflective vest that caught the lantern light like animal eyes. He handed me a clipboard. “Kill-switch checklist,” he said. “Your teacher texted us an hour ago. Says the class has passed.”  

I stared at the form. It asked for the number of participants sheltered, gallons of water distributed, medical needs met. My hand shook as I filled in the boxes. The utility worker waited, patient as a librarian. When I handed it back he tore off the pink copy and gave it to me. “Tell Marcus the grid will be hot again at 0600. Nice work.”  

He disappeared into the dark.  

Downstairs, Marcus was sitting on a folding chair, sipping instant coffee from a tin mug. The red button lay on the table beside him, wire severed cleanly. He looked older, as if the night had subtracted years instead of adding them. I sat across from him.  

“Simulation,” I said. It wasn’t a question.  

He shrugged. “The grid was never in danger. But the fear was real. The cooperation was real. The neighbors you just met? Real.” He raised the mug in salute. “Congratulations. You’re no longer preparing for the apocalypse. You’re preparing each other.”  

The lights blinked once, twice, then steadied. A cheer went up from the far corner where the toddler had finally fallen asleep on a pile of choir robes. I listened to the hum of the refrigerator kicking in, the distant whirr of elevators returning to life, the small mechanical sighs of a city remembering itself.  

Marcus stood, joints popping. “Class dismissed. See you next Thursday. We’ll talk about sourdough starters.”  

I almost laughed. Almost. But I was too busy memorizing the sound of neighbors singing off-key around a Coleman stove, too busy promising myself I’d learn their names before the next drill—real or imagined.

samples.prompt: You're stuck in a particularly odd time loop. Not only do you have to relive the same day over and over, each day you are a different person in that same repeated day.
samples.output:
The first time I opened my eyes to the same Tuesday, I was a barista named Luis. My hands, calloused but precise, knew the hiss of the espresso machine better than I knew my own heartbeat. Steam fogged the mirror above the pastry case; the clock read 5:57 a.m. I wiped the counter, called out “oat-milk capp for Maya,” and watched her smile like I was the first friendly face she’d seen in weeks. At 8:46 a.m. the lights flickered, the floor lurched, and everything went white.  

Then it was 5:57 a.m. again.  

This time the mirror reflected freckled cheeks, red hair in a frizzed halo. The badge pinned to my green apron said “Siobhan.” Same café, same hiss, same Maya at the register, but now I was the one handing her the receipt. Same eight-forty-six blackout. Same white flare.  

By the fourth loop, I stopped counting how many names I wore. The day itself never altered: weather warm and dry, street musicians playing a hesitant cover of “Fast Car,” dog-walker tangled in leashes at the corner of 7th and Main. Only the body changed. I cycled through the baker who burned the croissants, the businessman late for his divorce hearing, the elderly woman feeding pigeons stale Kaiser rolls. I spoke with their mouths, felt with their nerves, carried their memories like hand-me-down coats. Each coat fit badly—too tight across the shoulders or dragging at the cuffs—but I wore them anyway.  

The rules, if there were any, revealed themselves in pieces. I retained every looping day’s memories; the bodies I borrowed did not. They woke at 5:57 a.m. believing it was their very first Tuesday. Meanwhile I was the accumulating ghost in their machine. I learned the café layout so well I could navigate it blindfolded; I memorized Maya’s order, the pigeon woman’s favorite bench, the businessman’s PIN. The blackout at 8:46 never moved. No matter where I was—subway car, rooftop, bathroom stall—the light swallowed everything.  

I tried to break the pattern. As Carmen the bike courier I sprinted toward the river at 8:40; I made it six blocks before the flare. As Dr. Alvarez I injected myself with a sedative at 8:30; the drug didn’t even have time to slow my pulse. Once I simply sat on the floor of the café stockroom, knees to chest, and waited. The light was courteous enough to find me there.  

Somewhere around loop thirty, I stopped fearing the reset and started interviewing the day. If I had to repeat it, I might as well gather testimony. I asked every pedestrian their earliest memory, their most shameful secret, the last thing they ate. Answers piled up in my head like mismatched Tupperware lids: first kisses, dead hamsters, cold pizza. I noticed repetitions. The street guitarist always had the same blister on his thumb. Maya’s smile faltered when she thought no one watched. The businessman’s briefcase contained divorce papers and a plastic toy dinosaur, the kind you get in cereal boxes.  

In loop forty-six I was the janitor, mopping near the pastry case. Maya came in at 6:10, ordered a cappuccino, then lingered by the bulletin board. She stared at a flyer for lost cats, eyes glassy. I—this body—had a daughter once, long estranged; the ache surfaced like a splinter. I set the mop bucket aside. “Rough morning?” I asked, voice gravelly.  

Maya shrugged. “I keep dreaming I’m supposed to do something important today, but every time I reach for it, it slips away.”  

I wanted to tell her she was not alone in forgetting. Instead I handed her the drink and watched her leave. The janitor’s memories showed me a storage closet with a fuse box labeled “Main – Handle with Care.” That afternoon, while the businessman screamed into his phone about alimony, I borrowed his keys and slipped into the building’s basement. I opened the box. Inside: a single toggle switch already set to OFF. I flipped it ON. Nothing changed. At 8:46 the light still came.  

Loop sixty-two. I was Maya herself.  

The realization hit while I stared at my—her—reflection in the restroom mirror. Same freckles, same tired kindness around the eyes. I felt the ghost of every cappuccino I’d handed her across sixty-one loops, each one a tiny debt. My pulse hammered. If I occupied the person whose slip was the most mysterious, maybe I could solve it.  

At 7:55 I stood at the bulletin board again. The lost-cat flyer was new to this body, but I’d seen it dozens of times: black cat, green collar, last seen near the river path. Someone had scrawled a phone number in red pen. I tore off a tab, tucked it into my pocket. At 8:15 I called from the payphone outside. A machine answered, beeped, and played a recorded message in my own original voice—the voice I’d lost somewhere back in the loops.  

“Leave your regrets after the tone,” it said. There was no tone, only silence. I hung up, heart rattling.  

I walked to the river. The path was empty except for the guitarist, strumming the same three chords. The cat on the flyer sat on the railing, collar glinting like a dare. When I approached, it leapt down and trotted ahead, tail high. I followed, sneakers slapping wet stone. We reached the footbridge at 8:42. The cat stopped beneath a lamppost, sat, and began to wash its face.  

I knelt. “Is this the important thing?” I asked aloud. The wind off the water tasted like metal and coffee grounds. The cat looked up. Its eyes were mismatched—one green, one amber—and for a dizzy second I recognized the pair as my own.  

“I know you’re tired,” the cat said, though its mouth never moved. The words arrived inside my skull, soft as cotton. “You’ve been circling the drain of a single day, collecting everyone else’s unfinished business. But you’re not everyone. You’re the thread stitching them together.”  

“How do I cut the thread?”  

“Not cut,” it corrected. “Tie.”  

The lamppost flickered: 8:45. Sixty seconds left. I reached into Maya’s pocket, found the phone-number tab. Red ink smudged under my thumb. I pressed it against the cat’s collar. The paper stuck as if magnetized. The cat blinked once, slowly.  

“Say their names,” it instructed.  

So I did. I spoke every name I’d worn—Luis, Siobhan, Carmen, Dr. Alvarez, the janitor, the businessman, the pigeon woman, and all the rest—like beads on a rosary. With each name the paper grew warmer. The cat’s purr vibrated up my arm.  

At 8:46 the light came, but this time it didn’t erase. Instead it folded. I felt the café, the river, the subway car, the divorce courtroom collapse into a single bright point. When the brightness dimmed, I was standing on the footbridge at sunrise. Not 5:57 a.m.—real sunrise, gold sliding across the water like spilled paint.  

Maya—my body—was gone. I was nobody and everybody: a mosaic of voices quiet enough to hear the morning birds. The cat sat beside a cardboard box. Inside lay the plastic toy dinosaur, a burnt croissant, a blister-strip of sedatives, a handful of Kaiser-roll crumbs. Souvenirs.  

I picked up the dinosaur. Its tiny plastic claws were warm. The river lapped the pilings. Somewhere a cappuccino machine hissed. I took a step forward, barefoot on dew-cool wood, and the bridge felt steady beneath soles that were, for the first time in countless loops, my own.

samples.prompt: WP about any subject you want with a sudden twist that ends with the words 'they are finally free'
samples.output:
The last time anyone saw the sun was forty-seven days ago.  
At first the newspapers called it “a stubborn weather system,” then “an atmospheric anomaly,” and finally—when the streetlights never shut off and the tomatoes rotted on their vines—they stopped printing at all. The darkness that slid over our town was not the gentle hush of night but a thick, velvet absence, as though someone had glued shut the lid of the sky. Birds flew into windows like soft bullets; dogs refused to leave porches; children woke screaming from dreams of falling upward. My sister, Mara, said the darkness had weight, that she could feel it pressing on her ribs when she breathed. I told her she was being dramatic. Then my own lungs began to ache.

We lived in the old Whitmore house at the end of Seashell Street, the one with the green shutters and the rusted gate that sang every time the wind moved. Mom kept the porch light burning even at noon, a tiny, defiant star. Dad paced the living room with a flashlight between his teeth, tightening screws that had never been loose, checking locks we never used to lock. Every evening he recited the same sentence as if it were a bedtime story: “They’ll send helicopters soon. The government doesn’t just lose a sun.” But the only thing that arrived was the smell of the sea—briny, metallic, wrong—though the ocean was twenty miles away.

On the thirty-third day, Mara disappeared. One minute she was kneeling by the record player, coaxing Billie Holiday from a scratched LP, and the next the needle was skipping in an empty room. I ran through every corridor shouting her name until my voice shredded. Mom stood in the kitchen doorway clutching a dish towel like a surrender flag. Dad’s flashlight beam shook across the walls, frantic Morse code. We scoured closets, the attic, the crawlspace under the stairs. Nothing. Only the faint, wet echo of waves where no waves should be.

That night I dreamed of Mara walking barefoot along a shoreline made of mirrors. Each step cracked the glass, and black water seeped through the fissures. She turned once, eyes wide, mouth open as if to warn me, but no sound came. When I woke, my pillow was soaked and the house smelled even more like low tide.

People began to leave—or tried to. Headlights would crawl down Seashell Street, pause at the intersection, then reverse into driveways as though the road beyond had been erased. Mr. Kellerman from next door packed his SUV at dawn, family and suitcases crammed tight. We watched from the window. He drove twenty feet, stopped, opened the door, and vomited onto the asphalt. Then he turned the car around and unpacked in silence. The darkness, it seemed, had borders.

By day forty, the power began to fail in sections. Our refrigerator clicked off like a dying clock. Mom lined the kitchen counters with candles scavenged from birthday parties and power outages past. The flames burned sideways, as if the darkness were wind. Dad’s radio, once full of static promises, now spat out single words at random—“umbilical,” “meridian,” “hollow”—then went dead. We ate cold beans from a can and listened to the gate sing its rusted lullaby.
