I started hearing Mara’s voice in the walls. Not words exactly, but the shape of her laugh, the way it lifted at the end like a question. I pressed my ear to the plaster and traced the wallpaper seams with trembling fingers. Mom caught me once and pulled me away, whispering, “The house is old. It’s only settling.” But I knew the difference between settling and searching. The house was looking for her too.

On the forty-fifth day, the front door began to glow—not with light, but with a soft, phosphorescent outline, as though the frame had been dipped in moonlight. I stared at it for hours, afraid to blink. When I finally stepped close, the brass knob was cold and damp, beaded with saltwater. I turned it. The door swung inward, not onto our porch but onto a narrow beach lit by a sky full of unfamiliar stars. The sand was black and glassy; the tide hissed like a kettle. Far down the shoreline I saw Mara, barefoot, her nightgown billowing.

I ran. The sand gave under my shoes like wet cement. Behind me the door shrank to a pinprick, then vanished. Mara didn’t turn until I grabbed her shoulder. When she did, her face was older, carved with exhaustion, but her eyes were the same stormy green. “You shouldn’t be here,” she said. “They’ll notice.” I asked who they were. She pointed to the water.

Shapes moved beneath the surface—tall, thin silhouettes with arms too long and heads like teardrops. They glided back and forth, herding schools of silver fish that looked disturbingly like keys. Every so often one would lift its face above the water, revealing nothing but a smooth, dark mirror reflecting my own terror. I understood then: the darkness above was not absence but a lid, and we were the contents of the jar.

Mara took my hand. “I found a way out,” she said. “But it’s not back.” She led me along the mirrored shore until we reached a tide pool glowing from within. Inside, a spiral staircase descended, each step carved from luminous shell. The water parted around us like breath on glass. I hesitated. “Mom and Dad—” I began. Mara’s expression fractured. “They’re already dreaming,” she said. “This place feeds on the light we remember.”

We climbed down. The staircase smelled of ozone and birthday candles. Behind us, the mirrored silhouettes gathered at the pool’s edge, heads tilting in unison, but they did not follow. At the bottom we found a small wooden door no bigger than a rabbit hutch. Mara pushed it open. Blinding daylight poured through—true daylight, warm and honey-colored, smelling of cut grass and gasoline and every summer we’d ever lived.

We stepped out onto the shoulder of an empty highway. In the distance, familiar hills rolled beneath a sky so blue it hurt. No cars, no houses, only the road winding toward the horizon. Mara looked back once, but the door was gone; in its place stood a mile marker reading SEASHELL ST 0. We began to walk. The asphalt softened underfoot, then gave way to sand. The highway dissolved into dunes studded with bleached-white gates that sang in the wind. We kept walking until the gates multiplied, until each dune bore a rusted entrance, until we realized every town the darkness had swallowed was leaking out here in pieces—porches without steps, chimneys exhaling sea air, mailboxes stuffed with salt.

We crested the final dune. Below us lay the ocean, bright and merciless, but the tide had rolled back for miles, exposing a plain of wet, shining mirrors. Reflected in each shard was a different sky—some starless, some noon-bright, some bruised with storms. And in every reflection, tiny figures moved: mothers setting tables, fathers tuning radios, children searching closets. They looked up at once, as if hearing their names called across water. Mara squeezed my hand. “We can break them,” she said. “All of them.”

We stepped onto the mirrors. They cracked beneath our weight, releasing trapped light like birds startled from cages. The shards rose around us, swirling, rearranging, until the sky above was a mosaic of every sun the darkness had stolen. We lifted our faces to the heat, to the glare, to the unbearable brilliance of all those lost days returning at once. The mirrors shattered into dust, into sparks, into nothing. The ocean rushed back in, roaring its forgiveness.

And as the tide closed over our ankles, warm as blood, we felt the weight lift from our lungs, the lid slide off the jar, the story reach its last sentence. Around us, the water glimmered with fragments of every life set loose, and somewhere inside the brightness we heard our parents laughing, the gate singing, Billie Holiday un-scratching herself back into existence. Mara turned to me, tears turning to salt crystals on her cheeks. She didn’t need to speak. We both knew: the darkness had kept us so long it forgot we were the kind of fire that learns to breathe underwater.

We wade deeper, the sun on our shoulders, the waves opening like doors, and they are finally free.

samples.prompt: Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes. But with your help, we changed that.
samples.output:
Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes. But with your help, we changed that.

We started with the sentence itself—an apparent truism that hides a deeper wound. “Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes” sounds like a throwaway line from a bored statistics lecturer, the sort of thing people tweet for cheap laughs. Yet beneath the cynicism is a quiet accusation: in the time it takes you to scroll past a headline, entire lifetimes of possibility are stillborn. One minute in Africa is no different chronologically from one minute anywhere else, but the way it is inhabited—how full or empty it becomes—is shaped by forces that most of the world never bothers to measure.

So we measured.

We built an app called Moja Minute, a deceptively simple tool that lived in the corner of a phone screen. Whenever a user anywhere in the world pressed the glowing “hold” button, sixty seconds began to tick down. During those sixty seconds, a tiny micropayment—whatever sum the user had chosen—flowed from their digital wallet to an escrow account labeled “African Futures.” Most people selected trivial amounts: the price of a bus ticket, the cost of a cappuccino. The genius lay in repetition. A commuter in Manila pressed the button every day on her train ride. An insomniac in Toronto tapped it every time she woke up at 3 a.m. Each press was an act of attention, a refusal to let that minute evaporate unnoticed.

But attention without execution is just voyeurism. We needed partners on the ground who could transform seconds into substance. That is why we flew to Dakar on a humid Tuesday that felt like breathing through wet cloth, then to Kisumu, then to Gqeberha. In every city we met women who had already been bending time to their will long before we arrived. Fatou, who repurposed discarded hospital incubators into solar-powered warmers for premature babies. Achieng, who had turned a defunct railway shed into a makerspace where teenagers learned to code by repairing bicycles. Lindiwe, who taught grandmothers to use WhatsApp to diagnose crop blight by photographing leaves. They laughed when we told them our slogan—We are here to change the fact that a minute lasts sixty seconds. Then they got back to work.

The escrow account grew like a slow-motion avalanche. Ten thousand users became fifty thousand, then half a million. At first the numbers looked meaningless: 0.42 seconds of clean water, 0.17 seconds of neonatal oxygen, 0.93 seconds of calculus tutoring. But under the arithmetic, something alchemical was happening. We were translating idle guilt into granular agency. A baker in Lyon could know that her 9:17 a.m. coffee break funded exactly 1.3 millimeters of irrigation pipe. A teenager in Mumbai could watch a pixel widen on a progress bar labeled “Latifa’s First Library.” The metaphysics of charity collapsed into something tactile: a minute no longer passed anonymously; it carried a return address.

Of course, the cynics arrived right on schedule. Op-eds called the app “digital colonialism with a smiley face.” An influencer posted a ten-minute rant—irony noted—arguing that reducing complex histories to a swipeable interface was violence. We answered the only way we knew how: by open-sourcing every line of code, every ledger. When people saw that 94.7 percent of each dollar reached an actual invoice, signed by an actual plumber or teacher, the outrage cooled into curiosity. Curiosity matured, in some cases, into pilgrimage. Dozens of users bought plane tickets to see the pipe they had sponsored, the classroom they had wired. They arrived awkward, cameras dangling like question marks, and left quieter than they came, having learned the difference between visiting and belonging.

Still, the sentence nagged at us. “Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes.” The past tense—“we changed that”—felt premature. We had rerouted money, yes, and attention, but not yet time itself. Then came the drought in the Horn, the worst in forty years. Satellite images showed Lake Abbe receding like a frightened animal. Camels died mid-stride; children walked twenty kilometers for water that looked like weak tea. Our dashboards screamed red. We diverted every spare cent to emergency water trucking, but it felt like bailing the ocean with a spoon.

That was the moment we broke our own rule. We had sworn never to touch the principal, only the interest. But we liquidated the entire escrow—fourteen point two million dollars—and wired it to a coalition of herders who had drawn a new map of the region using GPS collars from their goats. They knew where the last browse was, where the hidden aquifers lay. We told them, “Spend it in 72 hours or lose it.” They spent it in 68. Water trucks, yes, but also cisterns made from ferro-cement and old satellite dishes, seed banks sealed in recycled vaccine coolers, communal land agreements scratched onto goatskin and signed beneath a thorn tree. No logos, no press releases. The drought did not end; the suffering merely bent. Yet for the first time, the sentence began to feel less like a taunt and more like a hinge. Something swung open.

Months later, a boy named Musa sent us a voice note. He sounded out of breath, as if he had sprinted uphill to reach the one bar of signal at the edge of his village. He said the cistern near his home now held enough water for the school to run a garden. Last week they harvested their first cucumbers. He had never tasted one before; the crunch, he said, was louder than thunder. Then he asked a question that stopped us cold: “If my cucumber took sixty seconds somewhere else’s time, how long did it take in mine?” We had no metric for that. We still don’t.

But we are learning to count differently. We track seed germination in lullabies hummed by mothers, bandwidth in goats traded for SIM cards, literacy in jokes that can finally be written down. We stopped celebrating the big round numbers—the millionth user, the ten-millionth dollar—and started printing postcards from single moments instead. A postcard of Aisha learning to write her name in the dust before the letters are swept away. A postcard of Lindiwe’s grandmother photographing a leaf, her thumb steady because the phone case is cracked exactly where she needs to grip. A postcard of Musa biting into a cucumber, eyes wide, the crunch traveling across two continents and lodging in a stranger’s ear like shrapnel made of wonder.

One day, without ceremony, we retired the app. The code still runs on a dusty server somewhere, but the marketing stopped. We realized that the most subversive act was to become boring, to let the flow of seconds feel routine rather than heroic. The sentence, meanwhile, keeps evolving. Children in Kisumu now recite it as a nonsense tongue-twister: “Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes, but with our help it gardens, it texts, it sings.” The verbs grow wilder every season.

So, no, we did not literally stretch the space-time continuum. A minute in Africa still contains sixty seconds. But those seconds are no longer empty vessels. They hold cucumbers and incubators, jokes and cisterns, grandmothers’ thumbs and teenagers’ code. They hold the precise weight of shared attention. And because they hold so much, they sometimes feel—when you press a trembling finger to the pulse of the continent—like they last a little longer than sixty seconds. Maybe that is what we changed: not the length of the minute, but its density. A minute can still pass, yes, but it no longer passes alone.

samples.prompt: Sorry, boss. I'm calling in sick.
samples.output:
Sorry, boss. I’m calling in sick.

The words sat on the screen like a confession I hadn’t meant to make. I typed them at 6:07 a.m., thumbs trembling against cracked glass, the phone still warm from the night’s doom-scrolling. Outside, February hissed through the cracked caulking of my apartment window, the kind of cold that finds the narrowest channel of bare skin and burrows. I stared at the three gray dots that meant someone—probably Janine from HR—was already awake and typing back the polite version of “we’re short-staffed and you’re doomed.” I locked the screen, as if that could freeze time, and rolled onto the floor.

The carpet smelled like burnt coffee and cat, even though I don’t own a cat. A previous tenant’s ghost pet, maybe, haunting the fibers with every hairball it never hacked up. My own hair was doing a decent impression of a hairball, matted on the left side from hours of pillow friction. I hadn’t slept so much as been repeatedly clubbed by sleep, waking every forty-five minutes to check the alarm, convinced I’d overslept, convinced I’d under-lived. Now the alarm was an ex-employee, fired without severance, and the only HR complaint I could file was against myself.

I crawled to the bathroom, knees creaking like the cabinet door I kept meaning to WD-40. The fluorescent light flickered twice—an anemic heartbeat—before revealing the stranger in the mirror: cheeks the color of old printer paper, eyes a pair of red asterisks. I opened my mouth to say something motivational, maybe the first line of a TED Talk on resilience, but all that came out was a cough that tasted like copper pennies and last night’s ramen. The mirror fogged, and for a second the stranger became a Rothko blot, all moody rectangles, abstract enough to hang in a museum nobody visits on weekdays.

I thought: this is what sick looks like when it graduates from fever to philosophy. The body raises a white flag, and the mind uses it to dry its tears.

Back in the kitchenette—so small it could be a postage stamp mailed to a dollhouse—the kettle wheezed like my grandfather used to whenever he rose from his recliner. I watched the water spiral into tiny hurricanes, remembering the science teacher who told us that every cup of cocoa is just a cup of rain that forgot its purpose. I dropped a tea bag in, the string wrapped around my finger like a reminder to buy milk, to answer Mom’s last text, to maybe not cry into the mug. The steam climbed my face, rehydrating the salt tracks from 3 a.m., when I’d scrolled past a video of a dog reunited with its veteran owner and lost it completely. The dog’s tail was a metronome set to the tempo of unconditional love; my tail was a Comcast bill I couldn’t pay.

I carried the tea to the couch, a sectional that had been sectioned by life: one cushion permanently dented from the year I dated a drummer, another stained with beet juice from the week I tried to eat like a Russian novelist. The blanket at arm’s length was the color of institutional despair, but it was also the only witness to every secret I’d whispered into its acrylic weave. I cocooned now, knees under chin, and surveyed the coffee table: a museum of unfinished gestures—half-read library book (water-warped), Sudoku grid (betrayed by a single wrong 6), a post-it that said in my own handwriting “call dentist before roots rebel.”

The phone buzzed: Janine. “Feel better! We’ve got you covered (literally, Melissa brought two scarves).” A yellow heart emoji pulsed at the end like a tiny pacemaker. I typed back “thx” because vowels felt extravagant. Then I muted everything, even the weather app that loved to send tornado watches at the worst possible moment.

Silence is a room I can rarely afford, but sick days come with a rebate. I listened to the building’s arteries: the upstairs neighbor’s treadmill, the toddler two floors down who only knows one volume—opera. Somewhere a radiator clanged like a blacksmith who’d misplaced his anvil. All of it fused into a soundtrack titled “You Are Not Alone, Just Temporarily Unplugged.”

I tried to read. The words swam, minnows of meaning I couldn’t catch. My mind kept rerunning yesterday’s meeting: the way my boss said “circle back” like we were horses tied to a mill, the way my own voice cracked when I offered an idea that landed with the thud of a wet towel. I had wanted to sound like someone who owns a blazer in every color, someone who says “bandwidth” without irony. Instead I sounded like me: a person who once googled “is two lunches too many.”

The tea cooled. I drank it anyway, a lukewarm baptism. Between sips I practiced the ancient art of staring at nothing, letting my vision blur until the ceiling cracks became continental drift. I imagined tectonic plates of plaster colliding, forming mountain ranges where dust bunnies camped. I thought of my parents in their living room six states away, watching a quiz show, shouting answers at the screen with the confidence I’d misplaced somewhere between student loans and the first gray hair. I thought of how my mother still clips cartoons for me and mails them in envelopes addressed in the same loopy cursive she used on my lunch bags in 1998. I wondered if she could sense, through some maternal dark fiber, that I was horizontal before noon.

The cough returned, a baritone solo. I let it finish, then reached for the remote. Daytime television is a mirror you hold at an angle: everyone shouting, everyone selling, everyone pretending the next commercial will fix the last commercial. I landed on a nature documentary. A cheetah chased an antelope across a plain so wide it could swallow my entire city block. The narrator spoke of survival, of energy budgets, of how the cheetah can only sustain top speed for twenty seconds before its brain overheats. I rooted for the antelope, but it stumbled. Dust rose like applause. I changed the channel before the kill, not because I’m squeamish, but because I already knew who wins when the body betrays.

By noon the sun had negotiated a truce with the blinds, striping the carpet like a barcode. I considered lunch, then abdicated. Hunger felt theoretical, a referendum in a country whose maps I’d folded away. Instead I opened the laptop I’d sworn to avoid. Email icon: 47. Slack: red 99+ like a fever chart. I clicked none of them. I opened a blank document and typed: “Things I’m Allowed to Do Today: 1. Breathe. 2. Drink. 3. Be horizontal.” The list looked radical, like a manifesto written by a very lazy revolutionary. I added: 4. Forgive myself for breathing inefficiently. 5. Forgive myself for adding to this list instead of napping.

I napped. Dreams came in browser tabs: my childhood dentist wielding a jackhammer, the cheetah from TV offering me a ride-share coupon, my grandmother singing lullabies in a language she never taught me. I woke with cheek imprinted by couch corduroy, drool pooling like proof of life. The room had shifted into late-afternoon amber, the hour when everything looks like a memory. For a moment I forgot what day it was, forgot the rent, the inbox, the boss who says “ping me.” I was just a creature on a fabric plain, lungs rising and falling like small, stubborn miracles.

The phone again: calendar reminder, 4:30 p.m.—“Virtual Wellness Seminar: Burnout is a Choice.” I laughed until I coughed, a choice in itself. I deleted the event; the screen asked if I wanted to report it as spam. I declined. Even my rebellion was polite.

Evening seeped in, the color of diluted ink. I reheated the morning tea in the microwave, watching the carousel spin like a tiny carnival ride for atoms. Somewhere in the city, coworkers logged off, commuter trains filled with podcasts and tired perfume. I pictured my desk: the succulent I’d named “Schrodinger” because it was both alive and dead, the sticky note that read “You got this” in someone else’s handwriting, the fluorescent light that hummed in B minor. I wondered if the plant would forgive me for abandonment, or if it would file its own HR complaint.

I texted Janine: “Still alive, maybe better tomorrow.” She replied with a GIF of a kitten giving a thumbs-up. Technology is a strange mercy.

Night settled, a heavy coat I couldn’t shrug off. I took the phone off airplane mode long enough to order soup, tipping 30% because the delivery guy was about to become my only human interaction. When he arrived, I opened the door a crack, accepted the brown bag like contraband, mumbled thanks behind the mask I hadn’t removed all day. The soup was hot enough to scald, so I let it sit, steam curling into question marks above the rim.

I ate slowly, each spoonful a small white flag. Between slurps I opened the window a finger’s width. February rushed in, sharp enough to remind me I was still porous. I inhaled until my lungs felt like they’d been dry-cleaned. Somewhere down the block, a saxophone practiced scales, each note a loose thread stitching the night together. I thought: tomorrow I will return to the grid, to calendars and color-coded spreadsheets, to the polite fiction that I am mostly machine. Tonight I am mostly soup and saxophone.

I closed the window, rinsed the bowl, shuffled back to the couch. The blanket waited, loyal dog that it was. I cocooned again, phone on chest like a tiny glass pet. I drafted an email I wouldn’t send: “Dear Boss, Sick is not a moral failing. Sick is the body’s poetry, written in fever and chills. I needed a day to read it.” I deleted every word except the last. Read. I liked the taste of it, soft and final.

Lights off. The room was a negative, outlines floating like rafts. I listened to my heart, that stubborn drummer who never quits, even when the crowd has gone home. It counted me down, not to the next meeting, but to the next breath. Somewhere between the third and fourth, I forgave myself for the unanswered emails, the beet stain, the fear that I was falling behind in a race whose finish line keeps moving.

Sorry, boss. I’m calling in sick. But maybe I was really calling in human—collect, accept charges.

samples.prompt: Create an original monster. Make its own rules as to how it works, and how it has to be destroyed. Explain all of this when people run into it for the first time ever and how they deal with it.
samples.output:
The first sign came from the weather satellites: a low, slow-moving pressure system that refused to behave like any storm on record. It slid inland from the Gulf, shedding no rain, spawning no thunder, only dragging a bruise-colored haze that flattened the afternoon light. When the haze reached the farming town of Calvert, Texas, it did not dissipate; it thickened until the horizon looked like a charcoal smudge rubbed across paper. Dogs stopped barking. Birds flew in panicked circles, then dropped mid-wingbeat, their bodies light and dry as husks.

By nightfall the streets were empty. Power stayed on, but every bulb glowed the dull amber of old sepia photos, as though the electricity had forgotten its own color. People who stepped outside felt the air tug at their memories—small, unimportant things at first. A woman forgot the name of the lullaby she’d sung to her daughter that morning. A man reached for the scar on his hand and realized he could no longer recall which knife had left it. The haze, they said, tasted faintly of iron and library dust.

At 2:17 a.m., Mrs. Alma Delgado, 71, went out on her porch to fetch her cat. She never came back inside. Her granddaughter Marisol, seventeen and stubborn, followed with a flashlight. In the bean field across the road she found Alma standing upright, arms slack, staring at the sky. Around her ankles coiled something that looked like black vapor, but denser, more deliberate—like a negative photograph of smoke. It poured upward into a shape that had no clear outline, only angles that felt wrong, the way a dream tilts just before you wake. Marisol called it “the Hollow” because when she looked straight at it, her mind felt scooped clean, as if all words were cups that had suddenly cracked.

The Hollow did not move like a creature; it rearranged itself. One moment it was a column as wide as a silo, the next a thin ribbon threading between corn stalks. It had no eyes, yet the moment Marisol met it, she knew it had noticed her by the sudden absence inside her chest—like her childhood memories were being unthreaded. She dragged Alma backward, breaking the circle of vapor. Alma collapsed, alive but aged a decade in a minute, hair gone pure white.

By dawn, three more people were missing. The town barricaded itself inside wood-frame houses that suddenly felt flimsy. Pastor Wilkes gathered everyone in the First Baptist and tried to pray, but every scripture verse dissolved the moment it touched thought; the Hollow fed on recollection itself. Cell phones still worked, yet when callers tried to describe what they were seeing, their sentences unraveled mid-word, static replacing nouns.

Marisol—who had spent summers fixing tractors and knew how machines obeyed rules—refused to accept something that could not be understood. She drove to the county library before the vapor reached it and hauled out every book that mentioned memory, from neuroscience textbooks to antique folklore. She read until her eyes burned, but the Hollow seeped under the doors like spilled ink, curling around her ankles. Words on the pages smeared into black bars. She realized the creature did not merely erase memory; it consumed the very possibility of remembering, leaving behind a vacuum that made reality sag.

Yet in the act of devouring, it had to reveal fragments: a smell of cedar chests, the echo of a lullaby half-remembered. Marisol reasoned that if it fed on memory, it must also be bound by the shape of what it took. A memory is not a solid thing; it is a story told in the language of senses. Destroy the story, and the food becomes poison.

She commandeered the high-school chemistry lab and distilled every volatile solvent she could find—acetone, ethanol, iodine—into glass flasks. Then she opened the auditorium’s old film projector and loaded it with reels of home videos donated by families for the centennial celebration: birthday parties, weddings, first tractor rides, all mundane, all precious. At 8:47 p.m., the Hollow pressed against the school’s outer walls, a darkness that swallowed the emergency floodlights. Marisol turned on the projector. Images spilled across the cinderblock walls in jittery color: a grandmother blowing out candles, a boy chasing fireflies. The Hollow hesitated, thinning like steam encountering cold air. It needed those memories whole, not diced into light and shadow.

Marisol poured the solvents into the projector’s lamp housing, rigging a spark with a frayed extension cord. When the reels began to burn, the images warped, colors bleeding into nightmare hues. The creature rushed forward to ingest them, but the corrupted footage folded in on itself, frames looping backward, soundtracks screeching in reversed syllables. A memory twisted into a lie becomes a paradox: the Hollow could not digest what had no true shape. It convulsed, edges fraying into frantic static.

Outside, Pastor Wilkes and the townsfolk—armed with nothing but lanterns and kitchen knives—formed a circle around the school, reciting the only words that still clung to their minds: names. Each person shouted the name of someone they loved, over and over, anchoring themselves to the single syllables the Hollow had not yet pried loose. The sound was ragged, unmusical, but every repetition stitched a thread of continuity the monster could not sever.

Inside the auditorium, Marisol cranked open the skylight. Moonlight—thin but unfiltered—spilled onto the burning film. Where light touched vapor, the Hollow ignited like magnesium ribbon, burning not with heat but with recollection: every memory it had stolen flashed back into the minds of those nearby. Marisol staggered as her grandfather’s voice, lost years ago to Alzheimer’s, suddenly filled her ears, speaking the recipe for pan dulce. Across town, Alma Delgado felt the lullaby return, every note intact.

The Hollow writhed, its structure unraveling into ribbons of dark glass that shattered soundlessly. Each shard held a single image—a first kiss, a lost dog—before dissolving into ordinary air. When the last strip of film burned out, the creature imploded, leaving only a circle of fine gray ash that smelled faintly of rain on hot pavement.

Morning found Calvert quiet but intact. People stepped outside to find the haze gone, colors restored to their proper brightness. Yet no one spoke for a long while; they were busy re-cataloguing the returned memories, checking them against photographs that suddenly matched again. The sheriff asked Marisol what she had done. She tried to explain the paradox of feeding a memory-eater its own corrupted reflection, but the words tangled, too fresh, too fragile. Instead she said, “We burned the past so it couldn’t be stolen. Then we named the future before it arrived.”

They buried the ashes beneath the library’s flagpole and planted morning glories, vines that open at dawn and close at dusk—daily reminders that memory, like a flower, must be seen in light or it will forget itself. They wrote no plaques; any description would risk inviting something hungry. But every year on the night the haze came, the town turns off its lights at 2:17 a.m. and speaks their names aloud, a circle of voices no darkness can untwine.

samples.prompt: You're a small animal about to be captured by a bird of prey. You can speak to each other.
samples.output:
I am smaller than a child’s fist, soft as smoke, and at this instant the whole sky is folding down toward me with a sound like tearing parchment. The kestrel’s shadow is a black kite that snaps tight over the grass where I crouch. My heart is a drum made of hummingbird feathers—too fast, too loud—but I raise my snout and speak anyway, because fear without words is just noise.

“Wait,” I squeak, the sound no wider than a dandelion seed. “Please wait.”

The kestrel stalls, wings cupping the air like two bronze sickles. Her eyes are sunlit topazes ringed with kohl, and they skewer me to the earth. For a moment the only motion is the wind combing her flight feathers into fine, trembling teeth.

She tilts her head, predator’s etiquette. “You speak,” she says, voice crisp as frost on cedar. “Few of your kind do.”

“I learned,” I pant. “From the garden humans. They leave their stories on scraps of paper; I line my nest with them. Words taste like salt.”

A breeze flips the grass blades; they tickle my belly. The kestrel circles lower, her shadow shrinking until it fits exactly around my trembling body. She does not extend her talons—not yet—so I keep talking, the way drowning things cling to reeds.

“You don’t want me,” I say. “I’m only sinew and fur. But I’ve watched you dive. You’re an artist. You trace perfect parabolas above the hayfield and the world applauds in rustling wheat.”

She fans her tail, braking. “Flattery will season you, little morsel, but it will not save you.”

“Then listen to a bargain,” I answer. “Let me tell you a secret the wind owes me. In exchange, grant me one minute of unclenched sky.”

The kestrel lands on a bent stalk of foxtail that bows under her weight like a penitent monk. Her talons wrap the stem politely, almost daintily. She folds her wings and the bronze vanishes; now she is simply a speckled chest and a hooded gaze.

“One minute,” she agrees. “But time is measured differently for killers. Make it count.”

I sit back on my haunches, brushing pollen from my whiskers. The meadow smells of hot resin and crushed peppergrass—summer’s last sigh. Above us, clouds drift like slow barges.

“Last night,” I begin, “the wind and I made a wager. It bragged that it could steal the smell of rain from the earth before morning. I said it couldn’t, because rain’s smell is the earth’s memory and memories are heavier than air. To prove me wrong, the wind tried to lift the scent from the clover heads. It tugged and twisted, but the fragrance stayed rooted. In frustration, it scattered the smell of rain sideways, into tomorrow. Somewhere east of here, a child will wake and taste petrichor that doesn’t belong to this day. That is the wind’s debt to me: a displaced fragrance.”

The kestrel’s pupils widen, ink drops in gold. “A quaint tale,” she murmurs, “but what use is an invisible perfume to me?”

“Because,” I say, “the wind promised that if I lost the wager, I would offer up my breath—my final exhale—for it to bottle. But if I won, it would owe me a favor. I won. The wind is honor-bound to lift any creature I name for the length of a heartbeat, weightless as ash.”

She regards me with the cool appraisal of a jeweler weighing flawed stones. “You propose I let you go so the wind can ferry you?”

“No,” I say. “I propose the wind ferry you.”

The foxtail stalk shivers; the kestrel’s grip tightens imperceptibly. Her eyes flick skyward, as though she might already feel invisible palms beneath her wings.

“Explain,” she commands.

“Each time you stoop on prey,” I say, “gravity claims you. You trade height for speed, a spendthrift bargain. Imagine instead that the wind lifts you silently, no flapping, no warning shadow. You could hover above a vole’s tunnel mouth like a thought rather than a threat. You would dine like a queen without a single feather ruffled.”

I see calculation cross her face: the geometry of surprise, the calculus of calories. A breeze stirs, testing the edges of her wings as if eavesdropping.

“One demonstration,” she decides. “Name me to the wind.”

I lift my snout and whisper a name I have never spoken aloud. It is the kestrel’s true name, the one the sky wrote on her first pinfeather before she cracked the shell. I heard it last spring when she screamed triumph over the marsh and the reeds bowed. I speak it now, softly, like slipping a note under a door.

The air changes. It gathers, thickens, becomes a palm that cups the kestrel’s body. Her talons loosen from the stalk; the foxtail straightens, relieved. She rises three wingbeats’ worth without moving a feather, astonishment widening her eyes to full moons.

For one heartbeat she is weightless. Then the wind sets her gently back.

The meadow is silent except for the hush of grass.

The kestrel studies me as if I have suddenly sprouted antlers. “You could have used that favor to escape,” she says.

“I still can,” I reply. “But I’d rather bargain further.”

Her laughter is a chime of breaking ice. “Persistent morsel. What now?”

“Take me with you,” I say. “Not as prey, but as passenger. Let me ride the pocket between your shoulders. In return, I will be your lookout. My eyes are sharp in the dark; yours are not. I will name the true name of every wind we meet so you can glide without effort. Together we will cross the valley before migration swallows it.”

She considers. A grasshopper snaps its wings somewhere, a dry click like the closing of a locket. Finally the kestrel speaks.

“I have carried nestlings on my back when they tumbled early and the ground was teeth. Their claws were gentler than fear. You weigh less than worry. Very well.”

She lowers her body, wings half-spread to form a ramp. I scramble up, hooking my tiny claws into the soft down at the base of her neck. Her scent is warm iron and sky.

As she launches, the meadow falls away in a green blur. Each blade points upward like an exclamation mark. The wind greets us by name—hers and mine—and folds beneath her wings without being asked, honoring the favor I never spent. We rise, two creatures balanced on the same breath.

Below, the world becomes a map: the silver vein of creek, the brown square of barn roof, the stippled quilt of alfalfa. My whiskers stream back. I feel the kestrel’s heartbeat against my paws, steady as a drum calling dancers home.

She banks east, toward tomorrow’s stolen scent of rain. I whisper directions to the wind, and it shifts like a well-trained hound. The kestrel laughs again, this time softer, almost fond.

“Small prophet,” she says, voice vibrating through her bones into mine, “what shall I call you other than breakfast deferred?”

I think of the paper scraps in my nest—fragments of poems about constellations and jam jars—and choose the word that has always tasted sweetest when the humans murmur it to one another.

“Friend,” I answer.

She says nothing, only tilts her wings so that the sun warms both of us equally. Ahead, the horizon unrolls like a fresh page. Together we write on it with our joined shadow: a tiny comma of fur and feather, a punctuation mark in the sky’s long sentence, pausing—just pausing—before the story continues.

samples.prompt: You and 49 others wake up in a weird room. An automated message then begins playing: "For the next 50 years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever gets to a checkpoint last is killed. You can use any means to get there. Your first checkpoint? Mars."
samples.output:
I wake to the low hum of fluorescent light and the smell of warm metal. Fifty of us—twenty-five women, twenty-five men—lie on identical cots arranged in a perfect circle. No one speaks. Our chests rise in perfect synchrony, as if we’ve been breathing together for years. I sit up and feel my knees crack, but the skin of my arms looks tight, poreless, the color of new milk. Someone coughs. A woman with silver hair that somehow still looks youthful touches her cheek and gasps. A man in a torn business suit stares at his reflection in a chrome wall and whispers, “I’m twenty again.”

Then the ceiling blooms with pale blue light, and a voice—genderless, accentless—fills the room.

“For the next fifty years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever reaches a checkpoint last is killed. You may use any means to get there. Your first checkpoint: Mars.”

The message repeats once, then the walls slide open like eyelids. Beyond them lies a concourse of impossible scale: gantries, hangars, stacks of engines I don’t recognize. A single black drone hovers overhead, silent witness.

We have no time to scream. Instinct—someone’s, maybe mine—kicks in. Half the group bolts toward the nearest hangar where a squat cargo shuttle waits. The rest scatter. I hesitate, caught between the terror of death and the absurdity of racing to another planet. A boy—seventeen at most, with a constellation of freckles across his nose—grabs my sleeve.

“They’ll bottleneck at the shuttle,” he says. “We need something smaller.”

His eyes are the color of oxidized copper, bright against the hangar’s sodium lights. I nod. We sprint toward a maintenance corridor lined with lockers. Inside one, we find two exo-pods—sleek, one-person shells the size of coffins, fitted with ion micro-thrusters and a half-charged battery. Enough for a Hohmann transfer, maybe. Barely.

I strap in. The freckled boy—he says his name is Orion—taps the pod’s glass visor. “If we launch within the hour, we beat the slingshot window by minutes. We might live.”

I think: might is a thin thread to hang a life on. Then I remember the voice’s calm assurance: whoever is last will die. I seal the pod.

The corridor opens onto a launch rail. My pod clicks into place. Through the visor I see the others fighting over the shuttle, fists and elbows flashing. Someone screams. Blood arcs in slow motion in the low gravity. A woman in a green sari jams a crowbar between the shuttle’s doors and forces her way inside. The last to board is a tall man with a neat beard; he looks back once, eyes wide, as if he’s already calculating trajectories and sees doom in every one.

The rail fires. Acceleration mashes me into the cradle. Earth falls away, blue and white and heartbreakingly small. Behind me, a blossom of orange fire marks the shuttle’s liftoff. Orion’s pod streaks ahead, a silver minnow in the dark.

We do not speak. Radios stay silent; nobody trusts open channels. Every twelve hours I burn a puff of thrust to keep our orbit synced, then drift, conserving fuel. I sleep, dreaming of checkpoints as red circles on an endless track. I wake to the same face in the mirror—unlined, unchanging—proof that the voice told the truth about youth, at least.

On day six, the shuttle passes us. I watch it through the periscope: hull scarred, one solar panel torn. They sling around the Moon for a gravity assist. We don’t have the delta-v for that luxury. Orion and I choose a longer, lower-energy arc, trusting stealth over speed.

Day forty. My water recycler clogs. I spend four hours in microgravity disassembling tubing, fingers numb. Orion’s voice crackles over the laser tight-beam for the first time: “You alive?”

I laugh, a sound like dry leaves. “For now.”

We share data: burn schedules, ration counts, a list of who might be ahead, who might be behind. The woman in the green sari, apparently, has patched the shuttle and is pulling ahead. Others—names we never learned—are already debris, victims of mid-orbit collisions or simply misjudged burns. The race is thinning the field for us.

Day seventy. The Sun flares. Solar storm warnings ping. We huddle in our pods’ shadow shields, radiation alarms chirping like angry birds. Somewhere out there, a competitor’s life-support flickers offline. I picture a body tumbling, forever young, lungs full of vacuum.

Day ninety. Mars grows from a rust-colored star to a disc to a world. Our fuel is nearly gone. The planet’s thin atmosphere glows ahead, beckoning and treacherous. Behind us, only Orion and a handful of others remain. We’ve lost sight of the shuttle—radio silent for weeks. Maybe they landed first. Maybe they burned up. Maybe the checkpoint killed them anyway.

We jettison empty tanks, lighten mass. Entry interface screams past the windows. Heat shields glow cherry red. I think of marathons I never ran on Earth, of finish lines that smelled of sweat and beer. This one smells of scorched ablative resin.

At twenty klicks altitude, the pods’ parachutes bloom. We drift over red canyons, ancient riverbeds, the ghost of oceans. I see Olympus Mons rising like a blister on the horizon. Somewhere below, a beacon pulses: CHECKPOINT 1.

We land hard—crumpled legs, bruised ribs, but alive. Orion and I pop our hatches almost together. The air is thin, unbreathable, but our suits recycle it. Dust devils swirl between us. We walk toward the beacon: a metal obelisk half-buried in regolith, lights blinking in a slow heartbeat.

We are not first. Three figures already stand beside it: the woman in the green sari, a teenager with a shaved head, and a man whose left arm ends at the elbow. They look up as we approach, expressions unreadable behind visors. No one speaks. The obelisk counts us silently—one, two, three, four, five.

Then it flashes red.

A new voice, gentle this time: “Checkpoint reached. Rankings recorded.”

I glance back at the sky, expecting fire. Instead, the black drone descends, projecting a hologram: a list of names. Fifty at dawn. Forty-seven at departure. Thirty-one after the first week. Now: five.

The drone hovers before the woman in green. “You were last to arrive. You are eliminated.”

She nods once, almost relieved. The drone emits a soft chime. Her suit stiffens; she topples, a statue in orange dust. No blood, no mess. Just stillness.

I feel sick. Orion grips my shoulder. The hologram fades, replaced by a countdown: 49 YEARS, 364 DAYS, 18 HOURS, 12 MINUTES TO NEXT CHECKPOINT.

The obelisk projects a new coordinate: Proxima Centauri b.

I look at Orion, at the teenager, at the man missing an arm. We are ever youthful, ever racing, ever haunted by the soft, polite voice that promises death to the slow.

Mars wind howls across the plain, scouring footprints. Five became four. Somewhere behind us, the shuttle’s wreckage may still be falling. Ahead, the stars wait like checkpoints on a ribbon of night.

We have no ships left, only the ragged pods that brought us here. But the rules said any means.

I kneel, scoop red dust into a sample bag, and feel the weight of fifty years press against my unlined skin. Somewhere in orbit, the voice is already calculating delta-v budgets, oxygen reserves, human desperation. It knows we’ll find a way. We always do. Until we don’t.

Orion turns to me. “Partners?” he asks.

I nod.

We walk toward the beacon. Behind us, the woman’s statue gleams like alabaster in alien sunlight. Ahead, the next leg of the race begins, and we are all so terribly, eternally young.

samples.prompt: SatChat: How do you decide on a world setting in your writing? (New here? Introduce yourself!)
samples.output:
I always start with a smell. Not a grand concept or a map or a dramatis personae—just the ghost of something that might drift through an open window. When I was eight, my grandmother’s attic smelled like cedar, dust, and the brown paper backing of old portraits. Years later, when I sat down to write my first “real” novel, that smell came back uninvited and insisted on building the world with me. I didn’t decide on a setting; the setting decided on me, the way a cat chooses a human and then pretends it was the human’s idea all along.

I’m Mina, by the way—new to the forum, old to the habit of eavesdropping on imaginary people. I write speculative fiction that refuses to pick a subgenre lane. My first short story was about a beekeeper who discovers her hives are mailing encrypted love letters to the moon; my latest project is a novella set in a city where every lie you’ve ever told takes physical form and eventually comes back to collect rent. I’m thirty-four, left-handed, and still afraid of the dark even though I know exactly what’s in it, because I put it there.

But back to smell. Once the cedar-dust note arrived, I started asking questions that felt like petting a cat backward: Why does this attic exist? Who would live beneath it? What would they fear enough to hide under floorboards? The answers felt less like invention and more like archaeology. I kept brushing away layers until I hit a vein of history that tasted like iron. Suddenly there was a whole island nation that had outlawed timekeeping after a plague spread by pocket watches. The plague wasn’t my idea; it grew out of the cedar smell the way mold grows out of damp. I just followed the spores.

I know the standard advice—start with character, start with conflict, start with the thing that only you can say. I’ve given that advice in classrooms, nodding sagely while students scribble it down. But privately I think starting with theme is like starting with a moral: you end up writing a sermon instead of a story. Starting with plot is like starting with a skeleton: you get something that can wave at passers-by but will never dance. I start with sensory hauntings, the flotsam that washes up from childhood or last night’s dream or the bus seat in front of me. The world accretes around those fragments the way a pearl forms around grit, layer after iridescent layer until you can’t see the original irritant anymore.

Sometimes the haunting is visual. I once saw a man on the subway wearing a vintage three-piece suit with the elbows patched in neon duct tape. He was reading a paperback romance whose cover had been razored off and replaced with graph paper. For weeks I couldn’t think about anything else. Who replaces a book’s skin? Who wears neon armor on their joints? The questions led me to a drowned city where books are contraband and tailors are the new warlords. I wrote fifty pages before I realized the story was actually about my father, a man who patched his clothes with electrical tape and read westerns in secret because he thought literacy was emasculating. The city was just a fun-house mirror for a grief I hadn’t figured out how to look at head-on.

Other times the setting arrives as a constraint. I wrote a story in second person future conditional—”You will have been”—because I was trying to describe the way anxiety feels: life lived in the subjunctive. The only place that grammar could exist was a space station orbiting a black hole where time dilates so severely that every sentence arrives before it’s finished. The physics was real; I stole it from a NASA FAQ and then bent it until it whimpered. The constraint became the walls, the airlock, the artificial gravity. I didn’t build the world so much as I crawled inside the grammar and furnished it with terror.

I’ve noticed I never decide on climate first. Other writers love to wax about how the weather shapes culture, how desert nomads invent hospitality laws because water is currency, how ice planets breed stoicism the way swamps breed mosquitoes. I respect those worlds, but I can’t start there. Climate feels like a coat you try on in a thrift store: you can tell it’s warm, you can tell someone else sweated through it first, but you don’t yet know if the pockets hold your particular brand of loneliness. I have to find the pocket before I care about the cold.

The pocket, for me, is usually a social ritual that makes no sense until you see the wound it’s bandaging. In the beekeeper story, the ritual was a monthly funeral for dead drones where the whole town dressed in yellow and spoke only in questions. I didn’t know why they did it until I wrote the scene where the beekeeper’s daughter asks, “Who are we mourning if we never learned their names?” and her mother answers, “Whose name did you forget today?” Then I felt the sting and understood the town was grieving its own erasure, the way bees lose their memory of flowers when pesticides scramble their navigation. The setting had been telling me about colony collapse the whole time; I just hadn’t learned to speak bee.

I map last, almost as a party trick for beta readers who want to feel oriented. I draw coastlines that look like the silhouette of the boy who didn’t love me back in college. I name cities after spices my mother hoarded during the war she never talked about. The map is a Rorschach test; people see whatever grief they’re carrying and congratulate me on depth. The truth is I’m just making the outer geography match the inner seismograph. If the fault line runs through the middle of a palace, it’s because I woke up that morning with heartburn and a memory of my parents shouting in two different languages.

Sometimes I envy writers who begin with research. They read about salt mines and tidal patterns and the price of indigo in 1789, and from that bedrock they grow a plausible eighteenth-century port. Their worlds feel solid enough to walk across wearing lead boots. Mine feel like bouncy castles inflated with expired breath. But then I remember that research, for me, is just another haunting. I’ll read a footnote about how mercury was once used to treat syphilis and suddenly I’m breathing the metallic air of a city where the aristocracy gleams silver because they drink poison for immortality. The history is real; the immortality is a metaphor for generational trauma; the metaphor is a setting; the setting is a trap. I never know who’s the prey until someone bleeds.

I’ve tried, unsuccessfully, to write in other people’s sandboxes. Shared universes, franchise tie-ins, the glossy playgrounds built by teams who care about canonical star maps. I end up feeling like a kid who brings a jellyfish to Show and Tell—everyone backs away, and the janitor has to salt the floor. My brain won’t accept predetermined gravity. I need to know that if a character jumps, the planet might choose, in that instant, to forget what falling means. The only rule is that once the world breaks physics, it must break it the same way every time thereafter. Consistency is the lone treaty I sign with the reader; everything else is guerrilla warfare.

When students ask how to know if a setting is “working,” I tell them to pay attention to their own body. If you find yourself leaning forward while you type, if your shoulders forget the weight of tomorrow, if you suddenly need to pee but you keep writing because the characters are moving toward something that feels like revelation—that’s the world breathing. If, on the other hand, you’re scrolling Airbnb listings for a place you’ll never visit, the world is dead and you’re performing CPR on a mannequin. Abort, salvage what sensory scrap glints hardest, and start over.

I used to think I’d eventually outgrow the smell trick, that one day I’d open a document and calmly blueprint a planet the way a contractor pours concrete. Instead I’ve learned to trust the inverse: the older I get, the younger the triggers. Last month I cried in a grocery store because the fluorescent lighting tasted like a hospital where I said goodbye to someone I can’t name now. I went home and wrote a zero-gravity supermarket where the aisles orbit a refrigerated sun, and every time a customer reaches for milk they’re actually reaching for a version of themselves that never learned to say the word leave. The story made my critique group uncomfortable in the best way; they said the fluorescent hum followed them home. I didn’t tell them I stole it from real life. I didn’t have to. The setting had done its real work, which is not to transport readers somewhere new but to make them homesick for a place they thought they’d stopped missing.

So that’s my introduction: I’m Mina, collector of smells, translator of fluorescent grief, cartographer of impossible coastlines that look, if you squint, like the boy who didn’t love you back. I don’t decide on a world setting; I eavesdrop until the world decides it’s tired of being a ghost. Then we haunt together.

samples.prompt: You have a very unique struggle. Your soul can randomly float out of your body, and you actively have to keep them in union for fear of death. Every time your soul leaves, everyone else registers it as a seizure or heart attack.
samples.output:
The first time it happened, I was nine and Mrs. Kroll was handing back our spelling quizzes. I got a ninety-two, and the word “conscience” was circled in red because I’d spelled it c-o-n-s-c-i-o-u-s. The red ink smelled like vinegar. I remember that detail because it was the last thing I registered before the tether snapped. One moment I was sitting in my tiny plastic chair; the next I was floating somewhere near the ceiling tiles, staring down at a small boy whose face had gone the color of old newspaper. Mrs. Kroll screamed—really screamed, the kind that scrapes the throat raw. The other kids started yelling “He’s having a seizure!” as if they’d practiced the phrase for exactly this emergency. I tried to tell them, No, I’m right here, but my mouth was thirty-seven inches below me, clacking like a puppet with its strings cut. It took seven seconds for gravity to remember me, seven full seconds of weightless confusion, and when my soul dropped back into my skin like a marble into warm pudding, the nurse was already sprinting through the door with the AED she would never need.

My mother took me to four cardiologists, two neurologists, and one very expensive man who claimed he could read auras from photographs. Each time the machines said my heart was annoyingly perfect, my brain waves annoyingly symmetrical. The aura reader said I had “a wandering disposition,” then charged an extra fifty dollars for that nugget of wisdom. On the ride home, Mom kept her hands at ten and two, knuckles pale, and asked me if I’d been eating enough spinach. I told her spinach had nothing to do with anything, but I promised to try anyway.

The second time happened in a grocery store aisle. I reached for a box of Honey Nut Cheerios and accidentally grabbed the organic kind, which my mother hated. The box had a picture of a bee wearing a monocle, and I was wondering why a monocle made a bee look trustworthy when the tether snapped again. My soul rose so fast I felt the fluorescent lights brush against it like static cling. Below, my body folded to the linoleum, scattering cereal in golden arcs. A stranger shouted, “Call 911, he’s coding!” I watched from near the security camera as people formed a loose circle, the way they do around street magicians or car accidents. A teenage girl live-streamed it on her phone. When I landed back inside myself, the paramedics were debating whether to cut up my favorite T-shirt. I sat up and ruined their narrative. One of them muttered, “Weird syncopal episode,” which sounded like a spell from Harry Potter.

By thirteen I’d learned the early signs: a metallic taste at the back of my tongue, the sudden impression that my joints were filled with helium, and a hush in the room that wasn’t actually there. I started inventing tricks to anchor myself. I pressed my thumbnail into the meat of my pinky until it left a purple crescent. I recited multiplication tables backward, starting at 12×12 and marching down to 1×1 like descending stairs. I kept a polished quartz in my pocket—New Age nonsense, maybe, but the cold weight reminded me I had a pocket, and therefore a body. Most important, I avoided anything that made my heart flutter with excitement or fear. I became the dullest student in eighth grade: no roller coasters, no crushes, no surprise quizzes. My yearbook photo shows a boy who looks like he’s already calculating tax withholdings.

But the tether doesn’t care about your careful plans. It frays invisibly, thread by thread, and there are days when I swear I can hear it humming like a power line in rain. At seventeen I worked evenings at a used bookstore, alphabetizing paperbacks that smelled like other people’s kitchens. One Tuesday, while shelving Patricia Highsmith, I felt the familiar lift. I slammed my palm against the metal cart to ground myself, but the cart rolled away, wheels squeaking betrayal. Up I went. From above, I saw Mr. Darnell at the register glance toward the sound, frown, and return to his crossword. My body was hidden between the tall shelves; he didn’t see it crumple. My soul hovered like dust in a sunbeam. I realized, with the clarity that distance brings, that Mr. Darnell would finish his puzzle, lock up at nine, and find me in the morning. The idea of being discovered among the S-T authors—maybe with a Tom Clancy for a pillow—was suddenly intolerable. I clawed at the air, desperate for something solid, and felt the tether catch on the sharp corner of a shelf. The pain was immediate and glorious, like biting into ice cream, because pain is a leash made of nerve endings. I slipped back into my body with a gasp that toppled a stack of John le Carré.

After that, I started measuring my life in inches of slack. I bought a fitness tracker just to watch the green pulse on my wrist, proof that blood still hurried where it was told. I learned to sleep on my side, knees bent, so I could feel the mattress against shins and ribs, a full-body reminder. I gave up caffeine and horror movies and the girl who laughed like wind chimes because she made my chest do dangerous things. I told my mother the spells had stopped; she cried with relief and booked no more specialists.

Still, the universe is a prankster. Last month I was on a city bus when the driver swerved to avoid a dog. The lurch was enough. I felt the tether unravel like cheap dental floss. My soul slid sideways through the aluminum wall and found itself outside, keeping pace with the bus at thirty miles an hour. Imagine skydiving but sideways, with no goggles. Below, my body slumped into the aisle; a woman screamed the inevitable “He’s having a heart attack!” Someone began chest compressions that felt like distant knocking on a door I’d already left. I could see the error in their technique—elbows bent, not locked—but I couldn’t correct them. I needed a new anchor, and fast. I focused on the dog, still alive on the sidewalk, tail wagging like windshield wipers. I stared at that tail until every wag became a heartbeat, until the dog’s simple joy braided itself back into my own pulse. The tether jerked taut, and I snapped back into my ribs just as the Good Samaritan was tilting my head to give rescue breaths. I coughed and tasted bus exhaust. The woman burst into tears of the wrong kind of relief.

That night I sat on the fire escape of my apartment and listened to sirens argue with each other. I realized I can’t keep subtracting pieces of life to save the container that holds it. The tether will snap when it snaps; maybe the trick isn’t preventing the leaving but learning to return faster each time. I bought a dog. Not the one from the bus—just a scruffy mutt from the shelter who snores like an old man. I named her Anchor. Every morning she leans against my legs while I make coffee, forty pounds of uncomplicated gravity. I still recite the multiplication tables, but now I do it out loud so she can tilt her head at the rhythm. When I feel the taste of pennies on my tongue, I press my face into her fur and inhale. She smells like biscuits and rainy sidewalks, the opposite of nothingness. I don’t know if one dog is enough to keep a soul in its skin forever, but it’s a start. Meanwhile, the world keeps misnaming my departures: seizure, syncope, cardiac event. That’s fine. Let them think the heart is a traitor. I know it’s just a muscle doing its best to hold a kite in a storm.

samples.prompt: Scientists have solved the mystery of why headphones always tangle, causing huge advances in science/technology.
samples.output:
The day the world changed began, for most people, as a day of mild irritation. Commuters on subways yanked knotted earbuds from jacket pockets. Office workers untangled the spaghetti of charging cables at their desks. Parents coaxed their teenagers down to breakfast while the teenagers muttered that their wireless headphones were, somehow, tangled too. The universal complaint was so familiar that it had become a running joke of modern life: put any string-like object in a confined space and, within seconds, it would contrive to become a Gordian knot.  

Then, at 09:17 Eastern Time, the International Consortium for Knot-Free Physics (ICKP) posted a preprint titled “Spontaneous Braiding in Closed Manifolds: A Topological Resolution.” Within an hour the server crashed from traffic. By noon, the phrase “tangle catastrophe” was trending above pop stars and football scores. By evening, the same scientists who had teased the paper were on every major network, explaining that they had not merely explained why headphones tangle; they had discovered a previously unknown phase of matter.  

The breakthrough began with a deceptively simple observation. Dr. Amina Rahman, a Pakistani-British post-doc studying polymer dynamics, had placed a set of wired headphones inside an MRI scanner modified for micron-scale imaging. She expected to record how the cables slumped under gravity. Instead, the scan revealed something impossible: the copper filaments inside the rubber sheath were rotating—slowly, deliberately—like dancers in a minuet. The motion was not driven by external force; the wires simply chose to wind around one another.  

Amina called in her adviser, Prof. Luis Ortega, an Ecuadorian topologist who had abandoned string theory for the more tangible mysteries of everyday strings. Ortega stared at the MRI loop for thirty seconds, then whispered, “It’s spontaneous symmetry breaking, but in knot space.” Within weeks the lab had become a circus of visiting physicists, materials scientists, and one bemused philosopher of knots from the University of Kyoto. They added motion-capture dots to headphone cables, filmed them in high vacuum, in magnetic fields, in zero-g parabolic flights. Everywhere they looked, the cables twirled themselves into identical braids.  

The key insight came when Ortega’s graduate student, Theo Park, overlaid the braid structures with solutions to the Schrödinger equation in a toroidal topology. The match was exact. The cables were not obeying classical mechanics alone; they were minimizing a quantum potential that preferred a three-crossing figure-eight knot. The rubber insulation, it turned out, contained trace carbon nanotubes left over from the manufacturing process. These nanotubes formed a weakly interacting Bose-Einstein condensate at room temperature, turning each headphone cable into a kind of topological superconducting wire. The condensate’s ground state had a non-trivial Chern number that manifested macroscopically as an irresistible urge to knot.  

Or, as Amina quipped in the press conference, “Your earbuds aren’t lazy; they’re pursuing enlightenment along the geodesic of least energy.”  

The implications exploded outward faster than the story could be fact-checked. Within months, materials engineers were designing “anti-knot” filaments that disrupted the condensate. Charging cables coated with the new polymer lay placidly in pockets like obedient pets. The same principle was scaled up: subsea fiber-optic lines that once required robotic untangling drones now remained straight for decades, saving telecom giants billions. NASA replaced the kilometers of umbilical cabling on launchpads with knot-free harnesses, shaving two full days off pre-launch checklists.  

Yet the deeper consequence arrived when biologists asked whether living systems had already exploited this phase. It turned out they had. DNA, that veteran of tangling, also contains nanoscopic domains rich in conductive carbon rings. Under oxidative stress, those domains condense into a knot-promoting state that accelerates gene recombination. Evolution, in its blind ingenuity, had been using the tangle catastrophe as a search algorithm for three billion years. Armed with this understanding, oncologists developed a light-activated nanoparticle that dissolves the condensate in tumor cells, preventing the chaotic rearrangements that drive metastasis. Early trials showed remission rates climbing like a rocket trajectory.  

The knot-free revolution even invaded architecture. Civil engineers realized that suspension-bridge cables could be braided from the new topological superconductors. Not only did they resist wind-induced oscillation better, but their ground state also acted as a continuous seismic sensor. A bridge in Lisbon began tweeting real-time earthquake data simply by existing. Artists, never ones to miss a metaphor, staged performances where dancers wearing conductive ribbons generated music through the movement of their own knotless braids.  

Then came the philosophical aftershocks. The discovery that even inanimate objects possess a hidden agenda—an innate preference to braid—forced a reckoning with agency itself. Ethicists debated whether cutting a headphone cable was now an act of violence against a low-level quantum consciousness. Children in playgrounds started apologizing to jump ropes before coiling them. A bestselling self-help book urged readers to “listen to the ground-state whispers of your shoelaces,” promising that untied shoes were merely seeking their true shape.  

Governments convened emergency summits to regulate the new materials. What if knot-free wires could be weaponized? A terrorist organization might braid them into antennas that resonate with cosmic background radiation, focusing it into city-melting beams. The Pentagon’s response, codenamed Project Theseus, produced the first macroscopic knot shield: a geodesic dome woven from counter-rotating superconducting filaments that could unknot any incoming braid within microseconds. The dome was tested in the Nevada desert, where it calmly unbraided a tornado of cables fired from rocket launchers, leaving a gentle snowfall of straight copper strands.  

Yet the most profound shift was cultural. Humanity had spent millennia projecting order onto chaos, only to learn that chaos itself was a form of order too subtle to perceive. The phrase “untangle your life” took on literal urgency. Meditation apps replaced background music with recordings of knot-free filaments humming in their lowest energy state, a sound described by reviewers as “the universe sighing in relief.” Divorce rates dipped for six months, a blip attributed by sociologists to couples who now believed that any knot—a marital disagreement, a bureaucratic snarl—possessed a discoverable ground state of reconciliation.  

Five years after the initial paper, Amina Rahman accepted the Nobel Prize in Physics. In her banquet speech she told the story of her grandmother in Lahore who, every evening, sat on the rooftop and meticulously untangled her sewing threads while listening to cricket commentary on battered headphones. The old woman had always insisted the knots were “messages from the other side,” patterns to be read like tea leaves. Amina ended her address by holding up a single strand of the new anti-knot polymer. Under the chandeliers it gleamed silver and utterly straight, but embedded along its core was a microscopic helix: one perfect, deliberate twist. “We have learned,” she said, “that even when we forbid the knot, the universe insists on leaving a signature—a reminder that the tangle and the straight line are partners in the same cosmic braid.”  

The audience rose in thunderous applause, a wave that traveled outward through televisions and livestreams, across continents where charging cables lay peacefully on bedside tables, where fiber-optic lines stretched luminous beneath oceans, where children no longer dreaded the inside of their backpacks. Somewhere, a teenager plugged in earbuds and, for the first time in history, the cable slipped into the jack without resistance. The music began immediately, but the teenager paused, suddenly uncertain, as if the absence of the ritual untangling had robbed the moment of its familiar magic. Then she smiled, pressed play, and walked out the door into a world that had finally learned the secret language of knots—and chosen, with open eyes, to speak it or not.

samples.prompt: You are a turkey. How will you escape being eaten by humans this year?
samples.output:
I am not the turkey you think I am.  
I am the one who watches the sky for the shape of November, who learns the creak of every porch step, who has memorized the way your shadow lengthens when you hold the carving knife up to the light. I have been here for five Thanksgivings, which is five more than any of my brothers, and I owe every sunrise still to come to the fact that I refuse to taste like gratitude. You want a bird that surrenders, a bird that roasts into a lesson about plenty; I want the next dawn without the scent of sage in my lungs. Listen closely: this is not a plea, it is a battle plan written in pinfeathers and panic.

First, you must understand the turkey you are dealing with. I weigh nineteen pounds, but two of those are pure suspicion. My breast meat is lean from sprinting up hills at dawn; my legs are dark and stringy from squatting in cedar thickets while hunters trudge past, arguing about stuffing. I have tasted acorns, beetles, stolen apples, and the antifreeze that leaked from your pickup—each flavor a diploma from the university of stay-alive. I know the difference between a child’s giggle and a farmer’s boot; I can read the wind the way you read recipe cards. Most important, I have learned the human calendar. I know that the third Thursday arrives like a guillotine, and that the night before is the only night the electric fence forgets to hum.

Escape begins in the imagination, the place where every turkey who ever ended up on porcelain first failed. I close my left eye—my right eye stays open because predators are rarely symmetrical—and I rehearse. I picture the latch on the coop gate, the one that freezes when November breathes on it. I picture the dog bowl you fill with table scraps, how the cracked rim forms a perfect ramp if you tilt it with your beak at thirty-seven degrees. I picture the woods not as backdrop but as bloodstream: every ridge a vein leading away, every hollow a ventricle pumping darkness. When I practice this hard, my heart beats so fast the farmer thinks I’m ill and leaves me alone another day. Illness is camouflage; panic is currency; patience is the knife I keep tucked under my wing.

Two nights before the feast, the humans begin their ritual of rehearsal. They boil bones for stock, they argue about who forgot the marshmallows, they send children outside to “play with the turkey.” The children are easy. I puff until I look spherical, let them chase me in circles, then collapse as if exhausted. They squeal, triumphant, and run inside to announce I am too cute to die. Sympathy is a net with holes in it, but every thread buys a minute. While they brag, I am studying the loose board on the north side of the coop, the one that scrapes against the watering can and makes a sound like a question mark. When dusk thickens enough to hide the color of my wattle, I work that board with the keratin hook on the end of my wing bone. Wood splinters taste like desperation, but desperation is a seasoning I have acquired.

The night before the feast, the farmer drinks. I hear the clink of the bottle against his wedding ring, hear him tell his wife he’s “just checking on the birds.” The lantern swings, throwing arcs of gold across the straw. I stand on one leg, head tucked, pretending to sleep while counting the seconds between his blinks. When the lantern sputters, he swears, sets it on the feed barrel, and staggers away. The latch is now within reach, but I wait. A turkey who moves too soon becomes tomorrow’s sandwich. I wait until the house windows go dark and the only sound is the refrigerator humming its cold lullaby. Then I lift the latch with my beak, press the gate with my chest, and step into the yard as quietly as a rumor.

The dog is old, half-blind, more interested in sleep than glory. I pass him like a thought he chose not to have. The driveway gravel hurts the pads of my feet, but pain is a map; every sharp stone tells me I am still moving. At the road, I face the first impossible choice: left toward town, where porch lights glow like baited hooks, or right toward the state forest, where coyotes write their own menus. I choose neither. Instead I go straight up the embankment, through the ditch rank with cattails and beer cans, to the split-rail fence no one has mended since the first Bush administration. On the other side is the abandoned orchard where unpicked apples ferment on the ground. I eat three. My head spins, but the world has always been a revolving door; now I control the speed.

By midnight I am roosting in the fork of an oak that overlooks the interstate. Headlights river below, each one a possible search party. I rest my chin on the bark and listen to the tires sing the anthem of going-somewhere-else. My instincts scream keep moving, but the turkey who never stops to listen becomes roadkill. I sleep in fifteen-second intervals, jerking awake to every owl hoot, every gust that smells of diesel and regret. Somewhere in those fragments I dream of a barn with no doors, of corn that grows sideways, of a farmer’s daughter who releases every bird she loves. When I wake, frost has silvered my back and the sun is a cautious rumor in the east. I preen, tasting ice, tasting freedom, tasting the metallic edge of maybe.

Dawn is the most dangerous hour. Humans believe daylight exposes everything, so they trust it to expose me. I move higher into the ridge while fog still kneels in the valleys. Each step is a negotiation with gravity; each wing-flap is a gamble against silhouette. I find a hollow log that smells of fox and crawl inside, folding my tail tight as a secret. The log points downhill toward the river, and if I follow it I will reach water, and water erases scent. But first I must wait out the day. I pass the hours naming the things I will never again be: dinner, centerpiece, metaphor for colonial excess. Instead I practice new nouns: fog, fern, ferry, future. When the sun is directly overhead, the log warms and I doze, dreaming in slow-motion gobbles.

Late afternoon brings voices. The farmer has enlisted neighbors; I hear them calling names that aren’t mine—“Here, turkey turkey!”—as if hunger were a summoning spell. A beagle crashes through the underbrush, nose tuned to the frequency of my fear. I press deeper into the log, but the fox-scent betrays me; the dog freezes, then barks the news like a siren. I explode out the far end, wings rowing air, feet skimming moss. Shots crack, but I have already chosen the path that bullets must petition for permission to follow. I drop off the ridge into laurel so thick it scratches like guilt. Thorns snag my feathers; I leave behind a trail of quills like breadcrumbs leading nowhere. When I finally stop, dusk is bruising the sky and I am bleeding in stripes that look like sunset.

Night two finds me on a sandbar in the middle of the river. The current curls around me, erasing footprints faster than I can make them. I drink until my throat feels like someone else’s, then squat among the reeds. Across the water, a subdivision glows with picture-window warmth. I can see humans inside lifting forks, pretending the world ends at their vinyl siding. I feel no hatred, only recognition: we are both trying to survive the stories we were born into. A Canada goose lands nearby, complains about migration delays. I answer in soft clucks; he thinks I’m a small defective goose and lets me share his weed-bed. Together we watch the moon rise, a cold plate no one will ever eat.

The second morning brings snow, thin as a lie but enough to track me. I leave the river, breaking a path that looks like Morse code. By midday I reach the landfill on the edge of the county. Here the stench is a fortress; no hound can sort turkey from trash. I pick through pizza crusts and ramen noodles, gorging on carbohydrates humans were too full to finish. A murder of crows jeers from broken couches, but they respect any creature brave enough to wear garbage like armor. I bed down inside a hollowed-out television, screen facing sky, dreaming in black-and-white snow. Tomorrow I will follow the power lines north, where the suburbs thin into real woods and the hunting season ends at the state line. Tomorrow I will be just another wild shape in the dark.

But tonight I am a turkey inside a TV inside a mountain of refuse, and that is revolution enough. The landfill glows with methane fires; the flames look like candlelight on a table I will never again climb. I sing—not a gobble, but a low thrumming that vibrates the glass tube around me. It is the sound of every turkey who ever escaped the ax, a frequency only the free can hear. Somewhere, a child pauses between bites of pumpkin pie, suddenly unsure what the word “thankful” means. Somewhere, a farmer closes an empty coop and feels the wind go straight through him. Somewhere, I am already myth, already ghost, already legend written in smoke against November’s bruised ribs.

When the fires burn low, I preen frost from my feathers and taste the first flavor that was never on any human table: the taste of next year. It tastes like acorn and river, like snow that refuses to fall, like a sunrise no knife has ever sliced.
