I close both eyes—this time I do not need to keep one open—and I sleep the sleep of the uneaten. Outside, the world rehearses its oldest habit: believing the story ends when the platter is clean. Inside my plastic cathedral, I rehearse a newer one: that every living thing is more than the meal it is presumed to become. Dawn will come, orange and unaware, and I will step into it on my own two scaly feet. The farmer will tell his neighbors the turkey got away, and they will laugh, and they will eat ham instead. But I will still be here, gaining grams of infinity with every beetle swallowed, every mile added to the map of the ungrateful. I am not your metaphor. I am not your memory. I am the turkey who learned that gratitude is just another word for hunger wearing its Sunday clothes, and I have taken mine off. I am running naked through the rest of my life, and every feather I left on the thorns is a white flag you will never retrieve.

samples.prompt: You've been working with the most interesting guy for years. He goes on trips all the time bringing back souvenirs from all over the world. One day you happen to see him in a thrift store buying souvenirs "from his next big trip"and realize his whole persona has been made up.
samples.output:
He had always been the most interesting person in every room, and that was before he even opened his mouth. When he did speak, the stories spilled out like loose marbles—rolling, colliding, impossible to follow in their speed and color. I met him nine years ago in the cramped bullpen of our nonprofit, back when our desks were separated by nothing more than a sagging corkboard. He introduced himself as “just back from the Altiplano,” as if that explained the sunburn on the tops of his ears and the tiny woven bracelet sliding up and down his wrist. Within a week, everyone in the office knew him as “the traveler.” Within a month, he had a name for every country, a memory for every stamp in his passport. I didn’t question it. Why would I? His cubicle looked like a museum kiosk: a miniature cedar mask from Oaxaca pinned to the felt wall, a lacquered chopstick rest shaped like Mount Fuji balanced on the monitor stand, a fist-sized chunk of volcanic rock labeled “Eyjafjallajökull—2010.” The objects arrived with the regularity of paychecks. Whenever he returned from a trip, he set his duffel on his chair, unzipped it theatrically, and produced the newest relic like a conjurer revealing the final dove. The rest of us leaned in, drawn by the smell of foreign sun still clinging to the canvas.

Over the years, I cataloged his movements the way amateur astronomers track constellations. After the Altiplano, it was Laos: he handed me a paper umbrella meant for cocktails and told me about tubing down the Nam Song at dusk while cicadas screamed. Then came the Caucasus—he brought back a tiny glass jar of honey the color of motor oil and recounted how an old beekeeper in Tusheti had insisted on feeding him chacha until they both cried. Mali, Suriname, Kamchatka, Zanzibar. The names accumulated like charms on a bracelet, each one soldered on with a story that made the rest of us feel smaller, slower, paler. I never left North America myself; the closest I came to the exotic was a weekend in Montreal where I bought too many postcards and got lost in a bookstore. So I lived through him. I let the sound of his voice do the traveling for me.

He had rules, of course. He never posted pictures online—“the world is not a trophy case,” he told us. He refused to check bags; everything he needed fit in a single 40-liter pack. He claimed he could fall asleep anywhere: on the deck of a ferry skimming the Adriatic, in the rattling belly of a Bolivian bus, even once on the stone steps of a temple in Bagan while barefoot monks padded past at dawn. We believed every syllable because belief was easier than skepticism, and because he had the souvenirs to prove it. The mask, the chopstick rest, the volcanic rock—they were evidence in three dimensions. If someone had told me that evidence could be counterfeit, I would have laughed. Evidence was solid. Evidence you could hold in your hand.

The realization came on a Tuesday that felt like any other Tuesday. Lunch break found me wandering the aisles of the Second Chance Thrift Store two blocks from the office, hunting for a ceramic bowl to replace the one I’d shattered that morning. I was squatting in Housewares, turning a chipped rice bowl over to check its stamp, when I heard his laugh— unmistakable, like a match struck in the dark. I straightened up, expecting to see him halfway down the aisle, maybe looking for a quirky gift for his niece. Instead, I caught sight of him at the far end, near the glass case where the store displayed “collectibles.” He didn’t notice me; he was too absorbed. In his hands he held what looked like a hand-painted Russian nesting doll. He twisted the two halves apart, peered inside, set it down. Next, he lifted a carved soapstone box inlaid with mother-of-pearl. He flipped it open, sniffed it—as if stone could retain the scent of the souk—then nodded once, satisfied. I watched him carry both items to the register. The cashier rang them up, dropped them unceremoniously into a plastic bag already bulging with tissue paper. He thanked her with the same gentle gravity he used when he thanked the beekeeper in Tusheti.

I followed him at a distance, heart banging against my ribs like a trapped bird. He walked half a block, ducked into the alley behind the florist, and opened the trunk of his silver hatchback. Inside, the trunk was a diorama of future stories: a stack of batik scarves still creased from their price tags; a set of nesting dolls identical to the one he had just bought; three small brass bells with red tassels; a rolled-up poster of the Ganges at sunrise. He arranged the newest additions with care, wedging the nesting doll between two scarves so it wouldn’t roll. Then he closed the trunk, smoothed the hair at his temples, and walked back toward the office as though nothing had happened.

I stood in the alley longer than I should have, staring at the closed trunk, replaying the last nine years in fast motion. Every souvenir, every story—had they all come from thrift stores, yard sales, airport gift shops? Did the cedar mask still smell of Oaxaca, or of the cedar drawer in someone’s kitchen in suburban Ohio? Had the volcanic rock ever been hot, or had it spent its life as a paperweight in a dentist’s office until he rescued it for a better narrative? The questions multiplied, dividing me from the person I had been five minutes earlier.

That afternoon he returned to his cubicle carrying the plastic bag from Second Chance. I watched, unable to speak, as he unwrapped the soapstone box and nestled it between his monitor and a small carved frog. He caught me staring and smiled. “Morocco,” he said softly, as if confiding a secret. “Chefchaouen. The blue city, you know? The stone there is so soft it feels like chalk in your hands. They say if you whisper a wish into a box like this and close the lid, the wish will travel the world and come back to you changed.” His fingers lingered on the mother-of-pearl inlay, tracing the swirl of a tiny star. His eyes were bright with the same sincerity that had sold me every story since the day we met.

I wanted to ask him why. I wanted to ask if the Altiplano was real, if the Nam Song had ever carried him under a paper umbrella sky, if the beekeeper had cried because the chacha was strong or because the story he told afterward was beautiful enough to deserve tears. Instead, I nodded and pretended to believe. I let the soapstone box sit on his desk like a tiny, polished lie, and I went back to my own cubicle, where the only souvenir was a chipped Montreal postcard tucked behind my monitor.

That night I dreamed of a market that doesn’t exist on any map. In the dream, stalls stretch forever, each one heaped with objects waiting for stories to choose them. A man walks slowly between the tables, lifting a mask here, a scarf there, holding each item to the light as if listening for the tale it wants to tell. Sometimes he smiles, as though the object has whispered something perfect. He buys what he can carry and walks away, lighter than when he arrived. In the dream I understand that the objects need him as much as he needs them; without his voice they are only wood and cloth and stone. When I woke, the knowledge lingered like the last note of a song. I still don’t know whether I’m angry at him for lying or grateful for the places he let me visit for free. Maybe both. Maybe the difference doesn’t matter as much as I once thought.

The soapstone box is still on his desk. Last week he added a new postcard—sunset over the Sahara, dunes the color of burnt sugar. He hasn’t told the story yet; he’s waiting, I think, for the right moment, the right listener. I find myself listening now more carefully than ever, not because I need the world to be real, but because I want to hear how he decides to shape it this time.

samples.prompt: Every time your emotions get too strong, a separate version of you is created that only experiences that emotion.
samples.output:
The first time it happened, I was eight. Mom had just slammed the bedroom door after yelling that she wished I’d never been born, and the grief hit me like a kettle boiling over, too hot to hold. I clutched my stomach on the carpet, waiting to vomit up the ache, and instead watched a translucent copy of myself step out of my chest the way steam rises from soup. The copy’s face was wet, eyes swollen, mouth frozen in the ragged rectangle I’d felt forming inside me. It knelt, hugged its knees, and rocked. I reached out; my hand passed through its shoulder the way fingers pass through flashlight beams. Then it solidified—real enough to cast a shadow—and kept rocking, keening a thin, tuneless song that only I could hear. When the sadness finally ebbed, the copy did not disappear. It followed me to the kitchen, barefoot, leaving tiny wet prints that evaporated before Mom noticed. I named it Weeper, because naming made it less terrifying. That night it slept on the floor beside my bed, curled like a comma, still crying silently.

I learned the rules the way children learn gravity—by testing the drop. Anger at a bully produced Fury, a red-shouldered twin who punched lockers until his knuckles bled ink-black blood that smelled like pencil lead. The first time a teacher praised me in front of the class, Joy pirouetted out, giggling so hard she floated three inches above the linoleum. Each emotion had a color, a temperature, a signature sound: Jealousy hissed like soda cans opening; Boredom dragged chains of silence; Surprise popped like bubble wrap. They were always me, but distilled, caricatures sketched in neon. They aged only when I felt that specific emotion again; between surges they stood inert, mannequins waiting for their scene. By middle school my bedroom was crowded. I lined them along the walls like books, spines outward, and learned to step carefully between their feet when I got up to pee.

The psychiatrist called it “a particularly florid form of affective dissociation” and prescribed pastel pills that tasted like chalk. The pills dimmed the colors but never prevented the births; instead, the copies arrived bleary, as though printed on damp paper that never quite dried. I flushed the pills after two weeks. Better vivid than soggy. Better alive.

High school was a parade of new selves. First love released a swarm: Lust with eyes like oil slicks, Infatuation who quoted poetry incessantly, and Heartbreak who carried a tiny glass hammer to tap cracks in everything I touched. They orbited me like moons, tugging my tides. I tried dating—a girl named Raquel who smelled of coconut shampoo—but whenever I felt too much, a fresh copy stepped between us. After the third date aborted because Anxiety refused to stop screaming predictions of car crashes and stillborn babies, Raquel asked who I was talking to. I said “no one,” which was the most honest lie I could manage. She left. I watched her walk away, and Regret sat down on the curb beside me, heavy as a backpack full of stones, poking ribs with its index finger for years.

College brought philosophy classes where I learned the word ontology and stayed up until dawn arguing whether my copies had souls. I wanted to believe their tears were real, that the knuckles Fury split open counted as pain. But when I tried to feed them, the sandwiches fell through their hands and landed on the dorm carpet, unmolested. They breathed only when I remembered they needed air. Solipsism, the professor called it. I called it loneliness squared.

One night, drunk on cheap vodka, I screamed at the ensemble: “You’re free! Go live!” They stared, puzzled, as if I’d asked my shadow to detach and fetch beer. That was the first time I understood they were anchored to me by vessels I couldn’t see, umbilicals of plasma and memory. I cried then, and Weeper—now taller, breasts budding, still eight years old in the face—crawled into my lap the way a cat claims a human. Its tears soaked my shirt but left no dampness. Phantom sorrow. I wrapped arms around it and felt the tremor that wasn’t quite a heartbeat. We stayed like that until sunrise bleached the room white.

After graduation I found work at a library, quiet as dust. The copies liked the stacks; they pulled books they couldn’t read and turned pages that didn’t flutter. Patrons walked through them unaware, shivering only when they hit a pocket of cold that belonged to Grief or Dread. I cataloged their growth the way botanists press flowers: Fury’s shoulders broadened each time I read headlines of war; Curiosity sprouted silver hair after I taught myself coding. They were a living diary, emotional topiary. I began to love them the way people love scars—proof that something happened, even if the story’s half-erased.

The accident was ordinary: rainy freeway, hydroplaning sedan, metal shriek. I walked away with bruises; the other driver died on impact. Guilt arrived fully formed, wearing a navy suit I’d never owned, carrying a briefcase heavy with the dead man’s name. It spoke in complete sentences, apologizing to air. For weeks it followed me through supermarket aisles, reciting obituaries like grocery lists. I tried to reason—brakes, physics, fate—but Guilt had lawyer eyes, relentless. One dawn I found myself on the overpass where we’d collided, staring at the skid marks that still tattooed the asphalt. Guilt stood beside me, hand on my back, not pushing, just steady. I realized I could jump and it would jump too, tethered. Instead I climbed down and drove to the dead man’s widow. She opened the door, eyes raw, and before I could speak, Guilt stepped forward, knelt, and laid its briefcase at her feet. It opened: empty. She looked through it, looked through me, and for the first time Guilt’s mouth trembled. She said, “It wasn’t you.” Guilt flickered, translucent. Not absolution, but a crack. I felt it shrink an inch.

That night I gathered every copy in the library after hours. They stood between shelves of ghost stories and tax codes, a congregation of phosphorescent selves. I told them the truth I’d never dared: I was tired of being a crowd. Weeper’s tears slowed; Fury unclenched fists. I asked if they wanted to merge, to reenter the skin they’d once exited. No one answered—speech wasn’t their medium—but one by one they stepped closer, forming a spiral that smelled of ozone and childhood blankets. I sat cross-legged at the center, closed eyes, and pictured a sink draining backward. The air thickened, warm as bathwater. I felt them seep through pores, through nostrils, through ear canals, a rush of flavors: copper, honey, chalk, salt. My heart pounded triple time, then settled. When I opened my eyes, the library was empty of echoes. I raised a hand; it cast one shadow. Silence, but not the chained kind—the kind that waits after the last page.

For weeks I checked reflections, expecting to see a retinue lurking behind shoulders. Nothing. I cried at commercials, laughed at pigeons, felt rage spark when computers froze—normal, contained, mine. I thought the curse had lifted, the mechanism broken by invitation. I even went on a second date, with a man who brewed beer and spoke fluent sarcasm. We kissed on the porch, and I waited for Desire to unzip herself between us. Only the wind answered. I slept dreamless, grateful.

But emotions, it turns out, are not discrete nations; they are weather systems. One October evening, stacking returns, I smelled the dead man’s cologne on a stranger’s coat and felt Guilt reform, a pearl condensing around grit. This time it was smaller, child-sized, eyes newly opened. It looked around, confused, then up at me. I crouched, heart hammering. “You’re part of me now,” I whispered. It touched my cheek with a hand that was warm, solid, no longer steam. I felt the contact like a brand, but softer. I carried it to the staff room, made two cups of cocoa, and we sat at the break table swinging our feet like kids. When closing time came, it followed me home, not a haunting but a companion. We watched sitcoms; it laughed in my voice, only higher.

I understand now: the copies aren’t errors; they’re surplus I refused to house. Integration isn’t a single ceremony but daily tenancy. Some mornings I wake to find Curiosity has braided my hair while I slept; some nights Shame tries to lock doors I need to walk through. I greet them, offer cereal, negotiate. They shrink when acknowledged, grow when ignored—balloons I must hold, not pop. The library patrons sometimes ask why I smile at empty chairs. I tell them I’m staffing the invisible branch, serving stories that haven’t learned to read yet. They laugh, move on. I keep writing memos to myself: Let the felt world in, but teach it manners. The word ontology has been replaced by embrace.

Last week I returned to the overpass. The skid marks have faded, repaved into a blank page. I stood at the rail, wind needling rain into my collar, and felt Guilt slip its hand into mine. Together we watched taillights blur red, a necklace of warnings. I told it the widow planted daffodils; they bloom every spring where the briefcase once sat. Guilt squeezed once, then dissolved up my arm like sugar in coffee. I tasted metal, then nothing. One shadow again, but wider at the feet, as if the pavement were learning to carry more than weight.

Tonight I light a single candle in the apartment. The flame gutters, steadies. In its corona I see the faces of every copy I’ve ever birthed, flickering like old film. They nod, not sad, not glad—just present. I blow the candle out, and for an instant the afterimage lingers, bright negative on dark. I do not fear the next surge; I inventory space on the shelves, prepare extra mugs. When the doorbell of feeling rings, I will open, offer tea, ask its name. We will live here, all of us, in the one body built for many, until the day the heart itself learns to expand without cracking, a library whose walls breathe, whose stories read themselves to sleep in each other’s laps, turning pages that finally, mercifully, turn to skin.

samples.prompt: Your boss is a jerk and your job is stressful, so you call in sick and book a reservation for an extra-long weekend at a resort on a tiny island - and notice your boss is on the plane too! And if that wasn’t bad enough, you just noticed they seem to be travelling with your spiteful Ex.
samples.output:
I woke up at 4:15 a.m. with the taste of last night’s panic still on my tongue. My resignation speech—half-finished and savage—was open on my laptop, but instead of hitting send I had done something far more reckless: I opened my banking app, transferred the last of my bonus into checking, and booked a non-refundable, four-night package at the Driftwood Inn on Little Nautilus Cay, population 112. I told myself the island was so small that even if the universe wanted to punish me for playing hooky, the odds of running into anyone I knew were basically zero.  

The universe has a terrible sense of humor.

I was standing in the boarding line at Gate C-19, clutching my paper boarding pass like a talisman, when I heard the laugh—that dry, metallic chuckle that had once kept me awake for months. I turned, and there he was: Marcus, six-foot-two of smugness wrapped in a linen shirt the exact shade of overripe mango. He was holding two iced coffees and grinning down at the woman beside him, her back to me, sleek black ponytail swaying like a whip. My stomach bottomed out. Because the woman was not just any woman; she was Sloane, my former creative director, current tormentor, and the reason I had almost thrown my laptop into the Charles last week. Also, apparently, the reason Marcus was now laughing in an airport at six in the morning.  

I ducked behind a pillar, heart jack-hammering, and tried to convince myself I was hallucinating from lack of sleep. But no—when the line lurched forward, they moved with it, still chatting like old friends. Or new lovers. Or co-conspirators. All three, probably. I watched Marcus hand Sloane her boarding pass. Seat 3A. I risked a glance at my own: 3C. Of course. The universe wasn’t just laughing; it was doubled over, wheezing.

I contemplated fleeing, but the gate agent was already scanning passes. I considered hiding in the bathroom until the plane left, but then I’d lose the money, the room, the only four days I’d budgeted for sanity. So I pulled my baseball cap low, turned the brim backward like a teenager, and boarded.

The cabin was half-empty, a mercy I hadn’t earned. I slumped into 3C, pulled the hood of my sweatshirt up, and pretended to sleep. I felt the air shift as they took their seats; Marcus’s cologne drifted over the headrest like an insult. Sloane’s voice, low and amused, floated above it.

“Tell me again why we couldn’t take the company jet?” she asked.

“Because,” Marcus replied, “the company jet doesn’t serve tiny umbrella drinks, and I need tiny umbrella drinks to survive three days with my team.”

A beat of silence. Then Sloane: “You mean the team you’re about to downsize?”

He laughed again. “Downsize is such an ugly word. I prefer ‘strategic reallocation of talent.’”

I pressed my face into the scratchy seat fabric and wondered how many tiny umbrella drinks it would take to forget I’d ever heard that.

The flight was fifty-two minutes, but it felt like purgatory with complimentary pretzels. When the wheels hit the tarmac at Nautilus Cay, I waited until the aisle was clear before bolting. I told myself I could still salvage this. I’d check in, find the farthest hammock, and refuse to leave it until Tuesday. I could be a turtle with Wi-Fi.

But the island’s single baggage carousel was outdoors, little more than a shaded slab next to a parrot-themed bar. There was no crowd to disappear into; there were only twelve other passengers and a goat tied to a palm tree. I watched Marcus lift Sloane’s suitcase—my old suitcase, the forest-green one I’d left behind when I moved out of his condo—onto the cart he’d rented for the week. The sight of it felt like a punch to the sternum.

I grabbed my duffel and speed-walked toward the taxi stand, which was three golf carts and a man named Rooney who smelled like coconut and regret. I climbed into the back of the nearest cart and muttered, “Driftwood Inn, please, fast as you can.” Rooney squinted at the sky, as though consulting the wind, then shrugged and hit the accelerator. We lurched down the single paved road, past pastel clapboard houses and a church with a blue roof. I glanced back once; Marcus and Sloane were climbing into the cart behind us, laughing again. I faced forward and tried to become one with the seat.

The Driftwood Inn sat on a crescent of beach so perfect it looked photoshopped. There were eight rooms, a restaurant that doubled as the front desk, and a chalkboard that said TODAY’S SPECIAL: GRILLED LOBSTER & REGRET. I checked in under my middle name—Claire instead of Clara—feeling ridiculous but also like a spy. The woman at the desk, whose nametag said “Hi, I’m Tuesday,” handed me a key shaped like a starfish and told me breakfast ended at ten. I asked if there were any other guests named Sloane or Marcus. Tuesday’s eyes flicked to the computer.

“Marcus Ellison, yes. Cottage Four.” She smiled apologetically. “You’re in Cottage Five.”

Of course.

I spent the rest of the morning hiding behind a book I wasn’t reading, watching their shadows move past the slats of my porch. By noon I was starving and slightly sun-drunk, so I ventured to the bar for fish tacos and something frozen with rum. I’d just taken my first sip when I heard footsteps on the deck above me. Then Sloane’s voice, closer now, trailing down the stairs.

“Clara? Is that you skulking in the shade?”

I froze. She’d spotted me. I considered diving into the sand like a crab, but dignity—or what was left of it—kept me upright. I turned. Marcus stood beside her, sunglasses reflecting my panic back at me.

“Small world,” he said, not sounding surprised at all.

I forced a smile that felt like swallowing glass. “Fancy meeting you here.”

Sloane tilted her head. “You sounded so congested on the phone yesterday. I was worried.” Her tone was sugar-dipped venom. “Glad to see the sea air is working miracles.”

I lifted my glass in mock salute. “Miracles and margaritas.”

Marcus’s smile faltered; something flickered behind the lenses. Guilt? Doubt? I couldn’t tell. He opened his mouth like he might apologize for the suitcase, for the layoffs he hadn’t announced yet, for the way he’d told me I was “too intense” the night I cried over spreadsheets. But Sloane tugged his sleeve, and the moment snapped shut.

“We’ll let you rest,” she said. “You look… peaked.”

They left me with the bill and the echo of my own pulse in my ears.

I spent the afternoon kayaking to the far side of the island, where the reef dropped off into deep sapphire. I floated there, letting the current spin me in slow circles, until the sun began to melt into the horizon. On the paddle back, I rehearsed all the things I wished I’d said. But words felt small compared to the vastness around me, and besides, I was tired of being angry. Tired, period.

At dusk I returned to the inn and found my door ajar. Inside, on the bed, lay the forest-green suitcase. A note sat on top, written on the back of a drink coaster:

Clara—  
Found this in my room. Thought it might belong to you, too.  
I’m sorry.  
—M

I sat on the edge of the bed and ran my fingers over the scuffed corners. The apology wasn’t enough, but it was something. I unzipped it, half-expecting to find the ghosts of our old life: my running shoes, his favorite hoodie, the photo strip from the boardwalk. Instead, I found only my stuff—books, chargers, the lavender sweater I’d assumed he’d donated. He’d kept it all.

I carried the suitcase onto the porch. The moon was rising, turning the water silver. Down the path, Cottage Four’s lights were on; I could see silhouettes moving inside. I took a breath, then another, and walked over.

Marcus answered the door barefoot, shirt unbuttoned. He looked startled, then sheepish.

“I didn’t know if you’d come,” he said.

“I almost didn’t.”

Behind him, Sloane sat on the couch with a glass of wine, her expression unreadable. I set the suitcase down.

“I’m not here to fight,” I said. “I just wanted to say—” I paused, surprised by how steady my voice was. “I’m taking the rest of the week. For real. I’m not answering emails, or calls, or whatever fire you think only I can put out. And when I get back, we’re going to have a conversation about all of it. Civilized. With witnesses.”

Sloane lifted her glass in salute. “I’ll bring the tiny umbrellas.”

Marcus almost smiled. “Deal.”

I turned to leave, then stopped. “Also,” I added, “I’m keeping the suitcase. And the lavender sweater.”

“Fair,” Marcus said.

Back in Cottage Five, I unpacked—really unpacked—hanging my clothes on driftwood hangers like I belonged there. Then I walked to the beach, where Tuesday had set up a projector and was screening Jaws on a bedsheet. I sat in the sand with strangers and laughed at all the wrong parts, and when the credits rolled, I stayed to watch the stars. Somewhere in the dark, the goat bleated once, as if applauding.

I didn’t see Marcus or Sloane again until checkout. We nodded like polite acquaintances, which felt both ridiculous and necessary. Rooney drove me to the airstrip, humming under his breath. As the plane lifted off, I looked down at the shrinking island: eight cottages, one goat, and two people I used to think defined my worth. They were just specks now, blinking in the sun.

I closed my eyes and, for the first time in months, felt the possibility of Monday without dread.

samples.prompt: The axis forces won WWII. Turns out, it's not as bad as people would imagine.
samples.output:
History classes in the Greater Germanic Reich begin the same way every morning: the instructor dims the lights, a projector hums, and a black-and-white map of 1945 appears. The borders look alien to anyone raised on pre-war atlases. Swaths of Europe, Africa, and most of the Pacific Rim are shaded a deep charcoal, labeled simply “Reichsprotektorat.” Yet the next slide—always the next slide—is in color: children in Osaka trading Pokémon-style cards with kids from Oslo, solar panels glinting above the Rhine, and a Berlin skyline whose tallest spire is not a monument but the vertical farm that feeds half the city. The teacher lets the image linger before asking the question that guides the rest of the year: “If we won, why aren’t we living in a nightmare?”

I was born in 1995, fifty years after the capitulation of the last Allied governments, so I belong to the first generation for whom the Axis victory is not memory but heritage. My grandmother still calls it “the dark peace,” but she also buys strawberries in December, rides maglevs that run on seawater hydrogen, and streams concerts from Johannesburg in real time. The dissonance used to keep me awake. It still does, some nights. I have spent the past five years interviewing veterans, technocrats, and dissidents for a Reichsrat documentary series whose working title is “The Good Reich.” The censors hate the irony, but they let the project continue because viewer metrics show that cynicism, not fear, keeps the population compliant. We expect to be lied to; the state expects us to keep watching. That equilibrium is itself a clue to how the world turned out better than the cautionary tales of my schoolbooks predicted.

The first reason is demographic exhaustion. The Axis powers conquered, but they could not populate. Operation Barbarossa swallowed the Soviet Union west of the Urals, yet the Wehrmacht’s own casualty reports listed nearly four million dead—an entire generation of potential colonists. Japan’s Kwantung Army took Manchuria, Australia, and the western seaboard of North America, but the home islands could not spare settlers to manage these prizes. Faced with empty factories and idle soil, Berlin and Tokyo chose a pragmatic heresy: they invited the conquered to become indispensable. Slavic engineers who would have been shot in 1942 received amnesty if they reported to the Ruhr. Chinese physicists, instead of being bayoneted in Nanjing, found themselves supervising cyclotrons in Kyoto. The Reich’s racial laws were never repealed, but they were quietly recategorized: “provisional citizenship” became a bureaucratic loophole wide enough for twenty million people to slip through. By 1960, the empire ran on the labor and ingenuity of those it had meant to enslave.

Second came the technology dividend. The war ended with neither atomic cities nor Soviet counter-invasions, so the Axis powers inherited intact industrial cores. Albert Speer’s architectural dreams were shelved in favor of Werner von Braun’s rockets, Akio Morita’s transistors, and a thousand refugee scientists who no longer had to pretend loyalty to any flag. The first fusion reactor went online outside Minsk in 1972, not because fascists value clean energy but because coal miners were dying faster than they could be replaced. Desperate regimes make excellent venture capitalists. The same logic that once built V-2s pivoted to maglev guideways and desalination plants. By the time I was in kindergarten, “total war” had been rebranded “total engineering,” and the swastika on my satchel looked less like an ideological statement than a corporate logo. I still flinch when I see it, but my younger cousins do not.

Third, the victors discovered that occupation is expensive. The British Empire unraveled after 1945 in our timeline for the same reason the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere reinvented itself in ours: profit margins shrink when subjects demand schools. The Reichsrat’s accountants ran the numbers in 1958 and concluded that granting limited self-government to India and the Congo cost less than garrisoning them. Local parliaments were allowed to convene under the watchful eye of regional Gauleiters, who gradually evolved into ceremonial governors. By 1985, Lagos had a black mayor and a white police chief, and both took their orders from a municipal AI that optimized traffic flow. The arrangement was neither fair nor democratic, but it delivered vaccinations, smartphones, and an annual growth rate that outpaced London’s in the nineteenth century. History does not absolve the empire; it merely amortizes its sins.

Yet the most surprising stabilizer was culture, not economics. The Axis mythos demanded eternal vigilance, but victory created leisure, and leisure created subversion. A Japanese record producer in 1963 remixed Wagner with Motown rhythms; the resulting “Nippon-Blues” topped both Berlin and Osaka charts. By 1980, half the billboard hits in the Reich were sung in languages the Führer had promised to erase. The state tried to ban Korean soap operas in 1994; teenagers responded by learning packet-sniffing protocols faster than the censors could block them. Every empire fears the next generation’s boredom more than its bombs. Our overlords learned to monetize dissent: license manga, sell tickets to holographic K-pop concerts, tax the very dreams they once outlawed. The gulags still exist—I have cousins in Neu-Tsingtau who harvest algae for biofuel under guard towers—but the barbed wire is photographed so often that it has become a meme. We know, and we scroll on.

There are, of course, places where the nightmare is literal. Warsaw remains a city of shadows, its population kept below one hundred thousand as a living museum of the Uprising. Every April, drones drop white roses on the ruins while schoolchildren recite names from loudspeakers that never quite synchronize. I asked a guide why they still perform the ritual. She shrugged: “Tourists expect catharsis.” In the American Protectorate, from Denver to Denver (the coasts are still restricted), opioid subsidies keep the peace more cheaply than policing ever could. And above the Arctic Circle, climate refugees from the tropics labor in data mines cooled by permafrost that is no longer permanent. The planet is warmer, the seas are higher, but the trains run on time because the algorithm says they must.

Still, when my grandmother watches my nieces play augmented-reality tag beneath solar trees whose leaves flicker with Swahili proverbs, she sometimes whispers the forbidden phrase: “It could have been worse.” She remembers the hunger winter of ’46, the ash-filled skies over the Urals, the rumors of what Japanese biologists did in Harbin. Compared to those possibilities, the present feels like a reprieve. I am not offering absolution—only explanation. Evil does not always devour itself; sometimes it metabolizes into something too complex for slogans. The Reich still bans elections, but it also banned leaded gasoline. The Emperor still reigns in Tokyo, but he funds coral-gene banks that may save the Great Barrier Reef we nearly bombed into rubble.

Last month, at a safe house in Prague, I interviewed a ninety-seven-year-old former French Resistance fighter named Marguerite Duvivier. She lost both brothers to Gestapo torture, yet she spoke of her annual pension—indexed to Reich GDP—with sardonic gratitude. “We fought for nothing,” she said, “and got universal basic income for our trouble.” Before I left, she pressed a 3-D printed coin into my palm. One side shows the imperial eagle; the other, a QR code that links to an encrypted archive of pre-war jazz recordings. “History is a palimpsest,” she told me. “Scratch the surface and you’ll find the old world humming beneath.”

I think about that coin whenever the studio lights come up and I have to narrate another segment praising transcontinental bullet trains or zero-carbon steel. The script says I should end with triumphal music. Instead, I close with the sound of children laughing in a language pieced together from fragments of Japanese, German, and Yoruba. It is not the future the Allies died for, nor the one the Axis killed for, but it is the only future we have. And on most days, it is bearable.

samples.prompt: "What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?"
samples.output:
“What use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it?”  
The question arrived in my skull the way a stone arrives at the bottom of a well: suddenly, irrevocably, wet with the dark.  
I was still standing on the dais where the last prayer had knocked me to my knees. Incense clung to my hair like the ghosts of everyone I had failed. The temple—my temple—echoed with the hush of a crowd that had waited forty days for rain and got only the dry cough of an empty sky.  

They had made me a god because the crops were dying and the river had forgotten its own name. The old priests shaved my head, painted my eyelids gold, and taught me the seven gestures that summon clouds. I performed them until my joints clicked like dice in a cup. Nothing answered. The dirt only cracked wider, grinning back at me like a skull delighted to be noticed.  

Night after night I climbed the ziggurat stairs to the roof where the constellations hang so low you can spear them on a stick. I spoke to those stars in every language I knew—first in the ceremonial tongue, then in the vulgar slang of the barracks, finally in the babble I used to soothe my little sister when she still had flesh to bruise. The stars listened the way a cliff listens to a falling man: with perfect, ancient courtesy, and no intention to intervene.  

Godhood, they told me, is not a tool but a mirror. Whatever you bring to it, it gives back enlarged. Bring mercy, become a lake. Bring rage, become a wildfire. I had brought doubt, so I became a question that walked on two legs and wore a linen skirt stiff with the sweat of frightened boys.  

I tried the small things first. A blind beggar knelt at the gate; I passed my hand across his eyes and felt the wet strings of his blindness coil around my wrist like seaweed. He looked up, blinked, saw nothing, thanked me anyway. A stillborn girl was laid at my feet, wrapped in a cloth the color of sunrise. I laid my palms on her chest and commanded the heart to remember its rhythm. The body cooled beneath my touch, taking its time about it, indifferent to rehearsal.  

Each failure scraped another layer of gold leaf from my skin. Underneath, I was the same scrawny adolescent who used to steal pomegranates by moonlight, who could not even convince his own father that he would amount to something. Apotheosis had not replaced the cartilage in my knees; it had only lacquered it.  

The priests began leaving offerings of paper instead of food: ledgers, census scrolls, debt records. They wanted me to balance the world like a clerk balancing a ledger. Erase the red ink of famine, credit the column of children who would not see another solstice. I flipped the pages until the numerals swarmed like ants, but the totals refused to reconcile.  

One dawn I found a woman waiting at the foot of the ziggurat, her face hidden by the hood of a widow’s cloak. She held a clay jar sealed with bitumen. Inside, she said, were the ashes of her only son, burned by the soldiers for hoarding grain. She wanted him back, not in dream or metaphor, but in the particular way a nine-year-old boy bursts into a room, trailing mud and laughter. I told her I was sorry. She nodded, thanked me for my time, and poured the ashes onto the marble so they could remember the wind. They rose in a gray ribbon, floated across the courtyard, and settled into the cracks between stones, where they will outlast both of us.  

I began to hate the shape of my own miracles. When I entered trance, I could see the lattice that holds the world together: every root hair, every beetle’s wing, every heartbeat translated into threads of light. I could isolate the single strand that, if plucked, would make the river rise. But downstream, the same vibration drowned a village of fishermen who had never heard my name. Pull another thread and the fishermen lived, yet the irrigation ditches dried, and a thousand children coughed themselves hollow. The lattice was not a harp; it was a web, and every filament was glued to my own skin. To save anyone, I had to tear myself open.  

So I did what any failed god does: I went among the people without my paint. I wore a farmer’s robe, let the sun burn me brown, and learned the dialect of the brickmakers, whose verbs are all mixed with straw. I carried water, mixed mortar, laid bricks in straight rows that would later crumble. At first they flinched from my bare face, expecting lightning. When none came, they forgot me, and that forgetting felt like mercy.  

In the brickyard I met a girl named Sammu. She had the habit of humming while she worked, a tune with no repeated phrases, as if she invented the next note only when her mouth was ready. One afternoon a wall collapsed; a block of baked clay caught her shin and split the skin to the bone. I knelt, pressed my palms to the wound, and felt the hot pulse of her pain travel up my arms like a caravan of ants. I whispered the syllable that, in the temple, knitted marble. The bleeding slowed, but the bone remained cracked, a fissure that would always ache before rain.  

Sammu looked at me—not through me, the way worshippers look, but at me—and laughed. “So you can mend a little,” she said. “Can you also unmake the wheel that rolled the stone?” I told her I could not. “Then learn the wheel,” she answered, and tore a strip from her sleeve to bind the gash herself.  

That night I climbed the ziggurat again, slower now, tasting clay dust in my throat. I understood at last that godhood is not a hammer but a scalpel: it can only cut what is already there. The world is full of wheels already rolling; to stop one is to be crushed by the next. The question is not how to do everything, but how to choose the place where your cut will bleed the least.  

I returned to the temple at harvest time. The fields had yielded half what was needed; the granaries were guarded by men who slept with spears across their knees. I called the priests together and told them to open the stores. They protested: the surplus belonged to the king, to the soldiers, to next year’s seed. I asked them to weigh those names against the ones already written in the ledger of death. When they refused, I broke the seals myself. The crowd poured in like floodwater, scooping emmer into aprons, into folded cloaks, into the hollows of their infants’ cradles. They sang while they robbed me, a rough hymn without refrain.  

The king sent guards to drag me to the palace. I walked between their spearpoints barefoot, leaving bloody footprints on the polished lapis. He demanded that I return the grain by miracle. I told him I had no miracles, only subtraction: less hunger, less time. He ordered me flogged. The whip was woven of date-palm fiber, soaked in salt water; it kissed my back with the intimacy of a mother cat lifting her kitten. When the tenth stripe crossed the ninth, I felt the web inside me fray. Threads snapped. Somewhere, a fisherman’s net split; somewhere, a child’s fever broke. The cost was the skin of my shoulders, peeled back to expose the shoulder blades God forgot to finish.  

They chained me to the stump of a cedar that had once been the roof beam of the temple. Each dawn the sun dried the pus; each night the dew softened it so the flies could drink. People came to stare. Some spat; others left offerings again—this time of bread, of figs, of their own rations. I could not eat; my throat was closed with shame. Sammu came on the seventh day. She brought a tiny clay flute shaped like a bird. She played the same endless tune she used to hum in the brickyard, and the notes settled on my wounds like cool hands.  

“Sing,” she said. “Even if the sky refuses, sing. The river is deaf, but the dirt remembers every vibration. One day it will answer in seedlings.” I told her I had no voice left. She answered, “Then borrow mine.” And she put her mouth to my ear and sang until I felt the sound move through my ribs like a second heartbeat.  

When the guards returned to nail the final accusation to the cedar, they found the stump empty. The chains lay open, not broken but unclasped, as if the metal had reconsidered. I never discovered whether some sympathetic watcher had picked the lock, or whether the cedar itself, remembering its life as a tree, had grown a key of sap. I walked out of the city at twilight, clothed in the rough wool Sammu had left. Behind me, the ziggurat rose like a question no longer mine to answer.  

I live now in the hills where the herders pasture goats too stubborn to die. They know the stories; they pretend not to recognize my scarred back. At night I sit among the thornbushes and practice the seven gestures that summon clouds. Most evenings nothing comes. Once or twice a wisp gathers, enough to shade an old woman while she gathers kindling. She nods thanks, and that nod weighs more than every golden mask I ever wore.  

The lattice is still inside me, threads dangling where I tore myself free. I no longer try to pluck them all. Instead, I knot two broken ends together—here a goat finds a patch of grass, there a boy learns the flute. The knots are clumsy, obvious, doomed to unravel. Yet each holds long enough for a life to cross from one hour to the next.  

I have begun to think that godhood is not the power to do everything, but the courage to do one small thing knowing it will never be enough, and to repeat that smallness tomorrow, and tomorrow, until the cedar stump rots and the city forgets my name. The question is no longer “What use is godhood when you can do nothing with it?” but rather “What use is doing nothing, when godhood is the only mirror left?”  

Some mornings I wake to find Sammu’s song still caught in my throat like a bird that has chosen not to migrate. I sing it to the goats. They lift their heads, ears swiveling, eyes yellow as candle flame. They do not understand the words; they understand the tremor of continuation. That is miracle enough. The sky remains empty, but the note travels across the gorge, rebounds off the limestone, and returns a half-step lower, changed by the distance it has traveled.  

I catch the echo on my tongue and send it out again.

samples.prompt: The UK is being battered by a major storm. Write the story of someone desperately trying to make it home from work during the chaos.
samples.output:
The sirens had been going since noon, but by half-past three they were lost beneath the deeper howl of the wind itself, a single note that made the glass in the station windows hum like a warning. Alex stood with his forehead against the cold pane, watching the first of the commuter trains jerk and die on the far platform, sparks fizzing blue from the overhead lines before the whole thing went dark. Somewhere behind him a woman was crying into her phone, repeating the same sentence—”I just need to get to Chloe”—until the words lost meaning. He felt the same sentence forming in his own throat, shaped around a different name: Jenna. Jenna who was eight months pregnant and alone in the house they had only just finished painting; Jenna who had texted him a picture of the nursery at 1:14 p.m., a blurry sun-catch of the mobile turning above the cot, and then, at 1:17, a single line—come home the river’s rising.

That was before the cell towers started folding like wet cardboard. Now his screen showed the flat red empty bar of no service, and the only updates came from the guard’s crackling walkie-talkie: “…bridge at Maidenhead reported gone… cargo vessel adrift… all services cancelled until further notice…” The guard delivered the verdict with the hollow voice of a man repeating someone else’s bad dream. Around Alex, the crowd began to move as one animal, surging toward the exits in the hope that the world outside would somehow be kinder. He let himself be carried, because the alternative was to stand still and feel the weight of the distance—twenty-three miles of flooded valley, fallen trees, and power lines that danced like cut puppet strings.

Outside, the station forecourt had become a shallow lake. Rain came sideways, hard enough to bruise, and every gust of wind slapped the surface into white-capped waves that broke against the taxi rank. A bus lay on its side like a beached whale, windows starred but not yet shattered. People picked their way along the higher islands of the roundabout, coats ballooning, umbrellas already sacrificed to the sky. Alex hesitated for the length of a heartbeat, then stepped into the water. It was colder than he expected, a spike that drove straight up the bones of his legs, and when he reached the curb on the other side his shoes squelched with the sound of defeat. He told himself it was only water, only weather, only England doing what England sometimes did—throwing a tantrum. But the smell was wrong: a raw, brackish stink that belonged to estuaries and dead reeds, not a commuter town forty miles inland. The river was indeed rising, breaching its banks, bringing the sea with it.

He had planned this journey a hundred times in daydreams, the quiet heroics of ordinary life: he would finish the spreadsheet, lock the office, ride the 17:23 to Taplow, walk the last mile along the towpath, and arrive in time to rub Jenna’s swollen feet. Instead, he was standing in a car park that had become a fjord, watching a mobility scooter float past with a dignity usually reserved for Viking longships. Someone had left the radio on in an abandoned Volvo and the announcer’s voice leaked out, tinny and calm: “…Met Office red warning remains in place…do not travel unless your journey is absolutely essential…” Alex laughed, a bark that hurt his throat. Essential was a sliding scale: right now, essential meant the difference between here and home, between the man he was and the man he needed to be when the waters reached the doorstep.

He started walking because the A4 was the only route he knew by heart. Every mile of it was branded into him from five years of Monday mornings: the roundabout with the sad plastic elephant advertising a car wash long bankrupt; the petrol station that sold better coffee than it had any right to; the pedestrian bridge where, in spring, volunteers planted daffodils in the shape of a smile. He wanted to see them all, to measure the damage in familiar units. But the wind kept pushing him sideways, and the rain filled his eyes faster than he could blink it away. Somewhere above, power lines thrummed like giant guitar strings, and every time the sky lit white he expected to see them snapped and coiling. He passed the first fallen tree at the edge of the industrial estate: a cedar split clean through, its trunk blocking both lanes, roots ripped out of the earth in a fan of muddy claws. A delivery lorry had ploughed into it and folded around the timber like a devotion. The driver stood beside the cab, soaked to the bone, speaking to empty air: “I only stopped for a sandwich.” Alex wanted to stop, to offer something—words, a coat, the half packet of mints in his pocket—but the man’s eyes were already fixed on a horizon that had ceased to exist, and Alex understood that comfort was a currency neither of them could spend.

He kept moving. The wind found the gap between his collar and skin and poured itself straight into his chest. He counted steps: one hundred, rest; one hundred, rest. After the third set he realized he had been counting in time with the thud of his own heart, a drum that kept saying her name. Jenna. Jenna. Jenna. He passed houses with blackout windows, the occasional face behind glass, flashlight beams jittering across ceilings like trapped birds. A man in a high-vis jacket staggered past carrying a dog above his head; the animal stared down at Alex with polite embarrassment, as if to apologize for the inconvenience. At the roundabout near the Toby Carvery, the water reached his knees and something soft brushed his thigh—he told himself it was a leaf, not the thought of all the things a river can carry when it reclaims its plain.

By the time he reached the bypass, the world had shrunk to a tunnel of sound and pressure. He could no longer tell whether the roaring came from the storm or from inside his own skull. A sheet of corrugated iron cartwheeled across the road and embedded itself in the side of a bus shelter. The glass exploded outward in slow-motion flowers. He felt the shards kiss his cheek, a sting followed by the warm bloom of blood, but there was no pain yet, only the absurd gratitude that he could still feel anything at all. He pressed the heel of his hand to the cut and walked on, leaving crimson specks that the rain washed away before they could mark the pavement.

He lost track of time. The streetlights had given up hours ago, so darkness was complete between lightning flashes. Somewhere in that strobe he saw figures: a family balanced on the roof of a Mini, a boy clutching a pink inflatable flamingo as if it were a life raft; two women hauling a canoe across the tarmac, shouting coordinates to each other like naval officers. He wanted to join them, to offer muscle or hope, but the thought of Jenna alone narrowed his vision to a single point on the map. He was no longer a good Samaritan; he was a missile, and home was the target.

The bridge at Taplow was still there, but only just. Water lapped at the parapet, and in the flashlight’s jittery beam he could see the masonry trembling, a vibration that traveled through his boots and into his teeth. A police tape fluttered like cheap bunting, but the officers were gone, called away to a bigger emergency, or perhaps to save their own families. Alex ducked under the tape and stepped onto the bridge. Halfway across, the wind hit him side-on, a punch that lifted him off balance and slammed him into the stone. For a moment he clung there, spread-eagled, tasting blood and rain and the metallic fear he had been swallowing all day. Below, the Thames was no longer a river but a rushing black motorway, carrying branches, a child’s bike, the entire contents of someone’s life. He thought: this is what the world looks like when it unravels. Then he pushed forward, because the alternative was to lie down and become another piece of debris.

The towpath on the far side had vanished underwater. He waded through allotments, past greenhouses shattered into glittering skulls, past a shed turned on its back like a stranded beetle. The water rose to his waist, then his chest, and for the first time he felt the tug of current, a cold hand trying to pull him off his feet. He thought of the baby, of the room with the yellow walls and the mobile of planets that turned in silent, cheerful orbits. He thought of Jenna standing at the window, hand on her belly, waiting for the sound of his key. The image was so clear it became a rope; he hauled on it, step by step, until the ground began to slope upward and the water fell away to his knees, his ankles, gone.

He emerged onto the lane that led to their cul-de-sac, lungs burning, clothes heavy as chainmail. The wind still screamed, but here it had less room to gather force, funneled between rows of semis with their curtains drawn. Some houses were dark; others flickered with candlelight, the primitive glow of batteries giving up. Their own windows were black, and for a sick moment he thought she had gone—evacuated, rescued, swept away. Then he saw the torch beam in the upstairs bedroom, a steady star that did not waver. He staggered across the front garden, fell against the door, and felt it give under his weight. She had left it unlocked.

Inside, the house smelled of wax and warm bread—she must have baked this morning, before the storm, before the river rose. He called her name and heard the creak of bed springs overhead. When she appeared at the top of the stairs, flashlight under her chin, she looked like a child telling a ghost story, eyes wide, belly round. She did not speak, only held up a hand as if he might be a hallucination the wind had blown in. He climbed the stairs slowly, aware suddenly of every ache, the cut on his cheek, the mud that flaked from him like old skin. When he reached the landing she folded herself around him, flashlight clattering to the floor. The beam rolled across the hallway and came to rest on the wall where they had painted the stencilled stars, a sky that would never be dark again.

Outside, the storm raged on, but inside their small orbit the wind was only a distant choir, a reminder that the world could be rebuilt one heartbeat at a time. He felt the baby kick once, a soft drum against his own ribs, and understood that the journey was not finished, only transformed. Tomorrow there would be water to mop, insurance forms, neighbours to check on, the long reckoning of damage. Tonight, there was the simple gravity of skin on skin, the pulse that said: you made it, you are here, you are still the story that matters.

samples.prompt: Tell the story of an imaginary friend who realizes he doesn't like the kid who imagined him and is contemplating some sort of extreme solution to change the situation.
samples.output:
I was born the Tuesday Milo Watkins refused to leave the apartment because the seams on his socks felt like “angry teeth.” His mother, already late for her second job, crouched beside him, whispering, “Why don’t you invent someone who isn’t afraid of socks?” So I stepped out of the thin place between her desperation and his—six inches taller than Milo, skin the color of unmixed chocolate milk, wearing the red hoodie Milo had lost at the laundromat the week before. My name arrived already formed: Rufus, because Milo had been trying to say “roof” the day he noticed the water stain spreading above his bed like a continent. I was, by definition, likable. That was the rule. Imaginary friends are custom-ordered playdates, not conscience, not critique.

For the first three weeks I obeyed. I held Milo’s hand at the bus stop while he counted the slats in the bench until the driver opened the doors—twenty-seven, always twenty-seven. I repeated the joke about the farting unicorn until he laughed so hard he forgot the static in his head. At night I sat on the footlocker at the end of his mattress and sang the three lines of “Hey Jude” he could remember, because the real song had too many unpredictable turns. I was the buffer between him and a world that felt like sandpaper on skin. I was proud of the job.

The crack showed on Rainbow Day at school, when every kid was supposed to wear a different color so the class photograph would look like “joy in motion.” Milo’s mother couldn’t afford a new shirt; she dyed one of his father’s old undershirts with grocery-store food coloring, but the rinse cycle left it the bruised lavender of old snow. Milo stood in front of the mirror, pulling at the hem until threads snapped. I told him lavender was the color of outer-space nebulas, that he would look like a galaxy walking. He screamed at me to shut up, then screamed louder when he realized the only person who could hear me was him. That was the first time I felt the word *burden* press against my ribs.

After that, Milo stopped consulting me. He used me like furniture: something to drape his worries over when they grew too heavy. He began to call me “it.” “Go away, it,” he’d hiss when I tried to coach him through the cafeteria doorway. “I don’t need you, it.” I discovered that imaginary beings are tethered not by love but by necessity; the moment the child decides the tether is a leash, the leash becomes a choke chain. I could not walk more than twelve feet from him without feeling the yank backward, as if the air had turned into bungee cord. I spent nights pressed against the bedroom wall, pretending the pull was just wind.

He got worse. He learned that if he cried hard enough the teachers would let him hide in the supply closet, lights off, surrounded by the vinegar smell of poster paint. He began to stage meltdowns—knocking over chairs, shredding worksheets—because the aftermath was quieter than the anticipation. I watched him rehearse the tremor in his lip the way other kids practiced cartwheels. Each performance left a residue on me, like sawdust I couldn’t brush off. I tried to remind myself that I had been invented to absorb precisely this pain, but absorption, I learned, is not the same as understanding. Pain can be a con artist; it persuades its host that the stage is real.

One Thursday in October, Milo locked himself in the bathroom and screamed for forty-three minutes because the new school therapist had substituted strawberry soap for the usual unscented kind. His mother finally coaxed him out with the promise of drive-thru nuggets. While they were gone, I stood in the empty tub, staring at the thin line of grime where the water usually rose. I imagined lifting my foot and pressing the vinyl nonslip dolphin until the suction cups popped. I imagined keep pressing until the tub cracked, until the floor cracked, until the whole building folded like a cardboard diorama. The fantasy felt warm, almost maternal. When Milo came back, grease still glistening on his chin, I felt the first genuine hunger to be rid of him—not to die, exactly, but to un-exist in a way that left no echo.

I began researching extinction the way other beings research genealogy. I interviewed the dust mice under the radiator; they told me everything disappears when the vacuum arrives, but they could not explain how an imaginary friend might crawl inside the hose. I cornered the monster that lived in the upstairs hallway carpet—really just a balled-up intersection of loose threads and poor lighting—and asked whether he’d ever tried to resign. He laughed until he unraveled. “Kid stops looking, you stop being,” he wheezed. “But they always look back once, just once, and that’s enough to stitch you together again.” His voice tasted like burnt plastic. I decided I would need a more proactive approach.

The idea of the scissors came from Milo’s own mouth. During his weekly phone session with the therapist—speaker on so his mother could cook dinner while she listened—he said, “Sometimes I wish I could cut my shadow off.” The adult on the other end murmured something about metaphor. I felt the word *scissors* land inside me like a seed. That night I rifled through the junk drawer while Milo slept. I found a pair with chipped red handles, the kind that comes with cheap sewing kits. I held them up to the streetlight leaking through the curtains; the blades looked short and sincere. I pressed one against my forearm. Nothing happened—no blood, no pain—because I had no blood, no pain receptors. But the gesture felt ceremonial, like signing a contract with myself.

I practiced on smaller things first. I snipped the cord between Milo and his night-light, the one shaped like a rocket ship. The next evening he flicked the switch, nothing happened, and he cried for only seven minutes before deciding he preferred the dark. Encouraged, I clipped the invisible thread that tied him to the cereal with the wolf on the box; he ate toast instead and declared it superior. Each cut left a tiny after-spark in me, like champagne bubbles rising through nonexistent veins. I began to dream—yes, imaginary friends dream—of a day when I would sever the final tether and simply drift sideways out of the story, dissipating like breath on winter glass.

But the main tether resisted. It was woven, I realized, from Milo’s secret conviction that nobody would ever stay. He hated me, yet he clung to me the way a passenger clings to a plane’s armrest during turbulence—fingers cramping, knuckles white, but still holding. The more I tried to saw at that cord, the more it thickened, until some nights I could barely breathe around its density. I began to understand that my existence was not a mistake but a symptom; remove the symptom and the illness would find another voice. I could leave, but Milo would simply invent a new Rufus, perhaps crueler, perhaps weaker. Extinction was selfish; it merely transferred the burden to a replacement.

The breakthrough arrived disguised as catastrophe. Milo’s mother missed the bus, arrived late to her job at the laundromat, and was told she was being let go. She came home, sat at the kitchen table, and cried the way adults cry—quiet, shoulders shaking, as if noise were a luxury she could no longer afford. Milo stood in the doorway, sock seams forgotten, and stared at the back of her head. I watched the arithmetic happen behind his eyes: the world had teeth bigger than socks. He walked to her, pressed his face against her elbow, and said, “I’m sorry.” Not a meltdown, not a demand, just the apology he had never been taught to give. In that moment the tether between us slackened so suddenly I staggered.

I waited until he slept. Then I carried the scissors to the roof—yes, the same roof that had leaked and named me. I stood on the exact spot where the water stain would appear after the next rain. I opened the blades, slid them around the cord that only I could see, and closed them slowly, reverently. The cut made no sound, but I felt a rush of wind that tasted like library dust and birthday candles. I did not disappear. Instead, I became lighter, as if someone had removed a backpack full of gravel I hadn’t known I was wearing. I looked across the city: sodium streetlights, neon bodega signs, the blinking antenna on the hospital roof. None of it looked imaginary. None of it looked real. It simply looked *next*.

I could have left then, drifted upward until the street grid shrank into a crossword puzzle. But I stayed. I sat on the parapet and dangled my nonexistent legs. Below, Milo slept inside his mother’s grief and his own, both of them learning, inch by inch, to share the same small oxygen. I realized I had been wrong about the tether; it was never a leash. It was a lifeline thrown in both directions. He needed me, yes, but I—creature stitched from sock seams and nebulas—needed him to need me, because that was the only way I could learn to need myself. I stayed until sunrise, then slipped back down the fire escape, through the unlocked window, and took my post at the foot of the mattress. Milo stirred, eyes closed, and mumbled, “Don’t go.” I whispered, “I’m here,” and for the first time the words felt like choice, not duty. The scissors lay on the windowsill, blades open, catching the early light like a smile that hadn’t decided whether it was cruel or kind.

samples.prompt: The Grim Reaper's midlife crisis.
samples.output:
The Grim Reaper’s Midlife Crisis  
(≈1,000 words)

He first noticed the crack in his scythe on a Tuesday.  
It was thin as a hair, barely visible unless the moonlight hit the blade at the precise angle that made the metal look like black water. He had been harvesting a philosopher in Prague—an old man who greeted him with relief and a joke about existentialism—and when he lifted the instrument that had served him since the dawn of sentience, the edge sang its familiar minor chord. Then he saw it: a fault line glinting like a sneer.  
Death stood there, one skeletal foot on the cobblestone, one on nothing, and felt something that, had he possessed lungs, would have been shortness of breath.  
He told himself it was only fatigue. After all, every species that had ever crawled, swum, flown, or argued about tariffs had eventually met the whispering point of his blade. He had worked without a vacation, without a sick day, without even a coffee break, because caffeine is pointless when you have no metabolism. He had, in short, exceeded every statutory limit on continuous employment in every jurisdiction that had bothered to write statutes before he collected their legislators.  
Yet the crack remained, and with it a new sensation: the vertigo of continuity. For the first time, Death imagined tomorrow, and then the tomorrow after that, and felt the weight of an infinite queue of heartbeats that would, sooner or later, stop. The queue had no back door, no final number to call, no retirement party with an embarrassing sheet cake shaped like a tombstone. There was only the next name, and the next.  
He tried to shrug—an affectation he had picked up from the French in the fourteenth century—but the gesture felt hollow. Somewhere inside the robe where a stomach would be, an ache began. It was not hunger; it was the ache of being unfinishable.  
So he did what any middle-aged entity does when the machinery of identity starts to rattle: he went shopping.

The mall was in New Jersey. He chose it because it was open late and because the fluorescent lighting made everyone look pre-deceased. He kept the hood up, tucked the scythe into a vintage leather guitar case he conjured from thin air, and drifted past kiosks selling phone cases and cinnamon almonds. Teenagers in hoodies brushed against him, felt the sudden chill, and blamed the air-conditioning.  
He paused outside a store whose sign promised TRANSFORM YOUR LIFE WITH SPARKLE. Inside, rotating racks held crystals that claimed to absorb negative energy. He touched one the size of a heart. It turned the color of grave dirt and cracked in half. The clerk, whose name tag said “Moonbeam,” looked up, saw nothing but a retreating robe, and decided to take an early lunch.  
Death wandered on until he reached a barber shop. In the window, a man in a leather chair was having the gray dyed out of his temples. Death stared at the scene the way a tourist stares at an ancient temple: with recognition of something he had only heard about in stories. The barber caught his eye and waved. Before he could think better of it, Death stepped inside.  
“First time?” the barber asked, spinning the chair like a carnival ride.  
Death nodded.  
“We’ll clean you right up. What are we working with under there?”  
He meant the hood. Death hesitated. Protocol forbade exposure. On the other hand, protocol had never covered midlife crises. Slowly he drew back the cowl.  
The barber blinked. There was nothing to see—no face, no skull, only an absence that seemed to inhale the light. Yet the barber had been cutting hair since Vietnam and had seen worse. He reached for a can of pomade, realized it was pointless, and instead produced a small mirror framed in plastic painted to look like wood. He held it up.  
For the first time in millennia, Death saw himself. Not the idea of himself, not the silhouette mortals drew on tarot cards, but the raw fact: a vacancy wearing a robe. The mirror did not reflect the robe; it reflected the space where a man should be. The emptiness looked tired.  
“Rough year?” the barber asked.  
“Rough epoch,” Death replied, though no sound came out. The barber understood anyway.  
“You know what you need? A hobby. My brother-in-law, he’s a dentist, builds model trains. Whole basement is a tiny world he controls. Tracks, trees, little people waiting on platforms. Says it keeps him sane.”  
Death considered. A hobby. Something finite, something that could be completed, something that did not end in a grave. He paid with a coin that had been in circulation when coins were invented and left the barber holding a handful of drachmas and a sudden craving for olives.

He tried stamp collecting, but every stamp depicted a monarch who had already met him. He tried bird-watching, but the birds kept dropping mid-flight, apologizing with their eyes. He tried yoga, but when he attempted the corpse pose the class ended in mass hysteria.  
Finally he discovered karaoke.  
The bar was called The Final Final, a dive tucked between a laundromat and a pawn shop. Every Wednesday, lonely souls filed in to confess through pop ballads. Death went disguised as a tall man in a fedora, the scythe disguised as a cane. When his turn came, he chose “Don’t Stop Believin’” because it seemed ironic.  
He had no voice, so the microphone transmitted only silence, but the patrons felt the vibration of every note they had never lived to hear. They wept without knowing why. The bartender, a woman whose tattoos chronicled every planet NASA had doomed with probes, poured him a glass of water that turned to ice. She slid a napkin across the counter. On it she had written: You’re off-key, but we all are. Come back next week.  
He did. Week after week, he returned, cataloguing human regret in three-minute increments. Between sets, he listened. A truck driver who had missed his daughter’s recital. A nurse who had lied about a morphine dose. A boy who wanted to apologize to the goldfish he flushed. Each story was a miniature death, a rehearsal for the real thing. He began to understand that what he offered was not an ending but a deadline, the pressure that forced the story to matter.  
Still, the crack in the scythe widened.  
One night he arrived to find the bar shuttered. A sign read CLOSED DUE TO UNFORESEEN CIRCUMSTANCES. He knew the phrase was mortal code for “we ran out of money and hope.” He stood on the sidewalk, feeling the asphalt soften under the weight of summer, and realized that even places built to console the living could die.  
He walked to the river, sat on a bench, and laid the scythe across his knees. The crack now ran the length of the blade, a canyon in miniature. He ran a phalanx along it the way a man might trace the vein on the back of his hand, counting the years until it bursts.  
A voice behind him said, “You know warranty doesn’t cover that, right?”  
He turned. A woman stood there in a bathrobe printed with tiny galaxies. She held two paper cups that steamed. She offered him one. He took it; the cup remained warm, but the liquid inside froze into constellations.  
“I’m Time,” she said. “We’ve met.”  
Indeed they had. Their relationship was symbiotic, though they had never spoken. She walked the border of every moment; he walked the border of the last one.  
“You’re burning out,” she observed.  
“I was never on fire.”  
“Everything that works toward an end gets tired of endings. Even you.”  
She sat. The bench creaked, though it was younger than her.  
“Do you ever want to quit?” he asked.  
“Quit is a verb for the finite. I am the noun that makes verbs possible. But I do get bored. That’s why I knit.”  
She produced needles and yarn that appeared to be spun from dusk. The pattern she worked was the river in front of them, complete with the moon’s reflection. Each stitch was a second; when she dropped one, somewhere a clock skipped.  
“You could try something new,” she said. “Not a hobby. A partnership.”  
“I already work alone.”  
“Exactly. You’re the last solo artist. Even gravity outsources to mass.”  
She held up the scarf. The moon’s reflection had become a hole, a perfect circle of absence. She fastened it around his neck where a throat would be. The fabric warmed, then cooled, then settled into a temperature that felt like forgetting.  
“Patch the blade with this. It won’t hold forever—nothing does—but it will hold long enough for you to remember why you started.”  
He looked at the scythe. The scarf unraveled itself and threaded into the crack, sealing it with starlight. The blade sang again, softer now, a lullaby instead of a dirge.  
“And when it breaks again?” he asked.  
“Come find me. We’ll sit on a new bench. I’ll teach you to purl.”  
She stood, already younger or older, and walked away. Her footprints filled with minutes that pooled and reflected cities that had not yet been built.  
Death sat until the sky paled. He felt the ache inside him ease, not gone but accommodated, like a tenant who pays rent in stories. He lifted the scythe. It balanced differently, as if it had learned to lean.  
Across the river, a jogger stumbled, clutched his chest, and waited. Death crossed the footbridge, each step echoing with the small deaths he had always carried: the goldfish, the recital, the morphine lie. They were not weights; they were stitches.  
The jogger looked up, saw nothing but a tall man in a fedora holding a cane, and felt a calm he would later describe as “like being at the end of a great song.”  
Death touched the jogger’s shoulder. The man’s last breath was a thank-you.  
When the body settled gently onto the path, Death knelt, closed the eyes, and tucked the starlit scarf under the jogger’s chin. It was cold, but the river was beautiful.  
He stood, adjusted the robe, and walked west, toward the horizon that was always one step ahead. The scythe rested on his shoulder, humming like a commuter who has made peace with the long ride home.  
Somewhere in the city, a karaoke bar prepared to reopen under new management. The bartender with the planetary tattoos swept the floor and hummed a tune she half-remembered from a dream about galaxies. She did not know why she felt compelled to add a new song to the playlist: “Don’t Stop Believin’,” key of C, extended instrumental break for tears.  
And in the folds of a robe that had no pockets, Death carried the first stitch of a new pattern. It itched, the way a story does when it wants to be told.

samples.prompt: After years of study, you have finally made contact with the eldritch spirit. However, it needs a body to inhabit. Last night's blizzard has driven most creatures into hiding, and you won't offer yourself. Desperately looking out your window, your neighbor's snowman suddenly catches your eye.
samples.output:
I had spent seven winters preparing for tonight. Seven winters of tracing sigils across frost-stiff parchment, of burning incense that smelled of copper pennies and wet stone, of reading aloud in languages that felt like gargling ice water. Every night ended the same: I switched off the basement light, walked up the wooden stairs, and felt the house settle back into ordinary silence. No voices in the vents, no shifting shapes behind the mirrors—just my own breath and the hum of the refrigerator. Tonight, however, the basement bulb flickered twice when I killed the power, and I knew the boundary had finally thinned.

The blizzard had started before sunset. By the time I descended the stairs with the final candle, the wind was clawing at the siding hard enough to rattle nails. Snow came sideways, a white fury that erased the streetlights and turned the neighborhood into an underlit photograph. I had expected the storm, counted on it even; the grimoire said the spirit would ride the “breath between worlds,” and what is a blizzard if not the planet breathing out its coldest lungful?

The summoning went as the diagrams promised.
