The chalk circle held, the candle flames bent inward like grass under an invisible hoof, and the temperature dropped until the moisture in my eyes threatened to freeze. Then I heard the voice—not sound exactly, but pressure behind my ears, like diving too deep in a lake. It asked for a body. The request was courteous, almost gentle, but there was hunger in it, a vast patience that had already outwaited stars.

I had always assumed I would refuse. The texts warned against lending your own flesh, and I am fond of my limbs, my memories, the particular way my heartbeat steadies when I lie in bed. Yet I hadn’t prepared an alternative. In my obsession with the opening of the gate, I had neglected to arrange what waited on the other side. Now the spirit hovered, neither hostile nor grateful, simply present—like the smell of ozone after lightning.

I climbed the stairs again, thighs shaking from cold and from the realization that I was entertaining a guest older than carbon. The kitchen window gave the clearest view of the street, so I stood there, fogging the glass with breath. All sensible creatures—cats, dogs, night-shift delivery drivers—had vanished. The porch lights of the neighboring houses were pale smudges, half buried by drifting snow. And then I saw it: Mrs. Kowalski’s snowman, standing sentinel at the edge of her yard.

It was no work of art—three uneven balls, a crooked carrot nose, two chunks of coal for eyes that glinted faintly under the streetlamp. One arm was a broken hockey stick; the other, a broom handle missing most of its bristles. A moth-eaten scarf fluttered at its neck, whipping in the wind like a surrender flag. The snow was coming so thick I could almost watch the figure grow taller, layers adding themselves with each gust.

A snowman is not a creature; it has no heart, no lungs, no blood to warm. It is a hollow sculpture, an outline of a person, a joke about mortality dressed in children’s accessories. But the spirit had not specified flesh, only form. The longer I stared, the more the snowman looked like an empty coat waiting for shoulders. I pressed my palm to the windowpane. The glass burned against my skin.

I thought of Mrs. Kowalski. She was seventy-three, baked lemon bars every Easter, and once told me her late husband had carved the broom-handle arm during the first winter after he retired. The snowman had stood in her yard every year since, rebuilt fresh after every thaw. She would notice if it walked away. She would probably scream.

Yet the alternative was worse. If I denied the spirit, it would eventually slip its tether. It might drift into someone sleeping, someone small—a child dreaming of sleds and hot cocoa—and wear that child’s shape until the seams burst. The snowman had no dreams to corrupt, no future to steal. It was already a fiction of life.

I put on my coat and boots, the ritual garments of any midwinter fool. The wind punched the door out of my hand as I stepped outside. Snow filled my mouth the way communion wafers never had—cold, tasteless, immediate. Each step crunched like breaking bones. The streetlamp flickered, casting the snowman’s shadow long and crooked across the yard.

Up close, I could see the carrot had split down the middle, frost wedging the halves apart. The coal eyes were lumps of ice with flecks of mica that caught the light and threw it back at me like accusations. I spoke the spirit’s name—if name it was—into the night. The syllables tasted of iron filings and old library dust. Nothing happened. Then the coal eyes darkened, as if an unseen hand had polished them to greater luster, and the snowman shifted.

It was subtle: the broom arm lifted an inch, the hockey stick tilted as though testing balance. A low sigh moved through the yard, and the scarf went still. The snow on the figure’s belly compacted, belly-button forming where none had been. Inside me, the pressure behind my ears eased; the spirit had found purchase.

I took a step back. The snowman—no, the thing wearing the snowman like a borrowed coat—tilted its head. The carrot nose wobbled, then straightened. From the scarf dangled a strand of yarn; it lifted, animated by no wind I could feel, and traced the shape of a sigil in the air between us. My own chalk circle, mirrored in miniature. A greeting, or a receipt.

“Do you know what you are?” I asked. My voice sounded very small against the storm.

The snowman did not speak. It raised the broom handle and drew a circle in the snow at its feet, a perfect O that the wind could not distort. Then it stepped out of the circle—first the bottom ball sliding forward, then the middle, then the top—leaving behind a gap shaped exactly like itself. An outline of absence. I understood: the spirit acknowledged its temporary lodging and promised to leave the world as it found it, hollow but unbroken.

I glanced toward Mrs. Kowalski’s house. A light flicked on upstairs—her bedroom. Silhouette of a hand pulling the curtain aside. I raised my own hand in what I hoped looked like a neighborly wave. The snowman imitated me, broom handle lifting in stiff salute. From this distance, perhaps she would think I had come out to check on the storm, and that her sculpture had merely shifted in the wind. Perhaps.

The snowman began to walk. Each step produced a soft grinding sound, like teeth settling in their sockets. It moved past me, down the sidewalk, toward the woods that bordered the subdivision. Its gait was unhurried; flakes landed on its shoulders and stayed there, passengers on a vessel that generated no heat. I watched until the darkness between the pines folded around it like a curtain.

Back inside, I leaned against the door until my pulse slowed. The house felt warmer, though the thermostat had not changed. My ears no longer ached with phantom pressure. On the kitchen table lay the grimoire, still open to the final page. I closed it gently, the way one folds a letter addressed to someone else.

Tomorrow, children would emerge to find the yard empty and accuse each other of toppling Mrs. Kowalski’s snowman. She would come outside, hands on hips, scold them for ruining tradition, and start rolling fresh balls of snow. The carrot, retrieved from wherever it had fallen, would anchor a new face. She would never know her creation had taken a short walk in the body of an ancient thing, wearing her late husband’s scarf like a promise to remember.

I brewed tea, chamomile to chase the copper taste from my tongue. Through the window, the street was already smoothing over the footprints—mine, and the twin grooves left by a snowman learning the weight of itself. Somewhere beyond the trees, the spirit would find a hollow log, a patch of frozen earth, perhaps even a glacier dreaming of motion, and settle until spring.

I had opened a door, and something had walked through. But I had also closed it, gently, before the hinges could scream. The blizzard was easing; flakes drifted down like apologies. I raised my mug to the night, to absent snowmen and to the fragile mercy of temporary bodies. In spring, the snow would melt, and the borrowed shape would flow away into ditches and culverts, carrying pieces of coal and strands of yarn back to the rivers that remember everything.

I drank the tea while it was still warm.

samples.prompt: For the entirety of human history once a year everyone on the planet is knocked unconscious for 24 hours. This year you lay in bed waiting for it to happen but it never does. You investigate further only to realize that you seem to be the only one still awake.
samples.output:
I have always hated the waiting.  
Every year, on the night of the 21st of March, the entire world tucks itself in early, the way birds grow quiet before an eclipse. Children stop mid-laugh, dinner plates hover halfway to the floor, taxi drivers slump over wheels that roll gently into curbs. Then, for exactly twenty-four hours, the planet becomes a museum of frozen postures: a mother forever kissing the crown of a sleeping infant, a late-shift baker crouched in front of an oven that will never ding. We call it the Stillness.  
No one knows why it began—only that it did, three millennia before calendars were invented. Fossilized footprints in Kenyan ash show two australopithecines who paused mid-stride, knuckles brushing the ground, never to finish the step. Cave paintings in Lascaux depict hunters tumbling off a cliff they had been painting the day before, their bodies suspended like dragonflies in amber. Every religion, every nation, every generation has simply folded the event into the fabric of life the way sailors once folded the edge of the flat world. We set our clocks by it; we insure against it; we speak politely of “the Long Nap” the way we speak of the weather.  
Tonight, I lie in bed waiting for the familiar vertigo—the sudden drop through trapdoors of consciousness. My phone is already dark; the grid operators shut the power off at 19:00 so that turbines don’t rip themselves apart when no one is there to throttle them back. I can hear the city breathing its last mechanical sigh: elevators locking, traffic lights blinking their final yellow, the commuter trains coasting to wherever momentum decides to release them. Across the hallway Mrs. Gutierrez’s television has gone mute in the middle of a laugh track, the frozen audience forever amused.  
I count heartbeats: one, two, three… I once made it to two hundred and thirty before the world ended around me. This year I decide to cheat. I swallow two caffeine pills, the bitter kind that taste like battery acid and regret. I pinch the skin inside my elbow until it bruises. I recite the first forty digits of pi backward, forward, then in alphabetical Morse. Anything to stay tethered to the waking world.  
The second hand on my watch stalls at 21:00. Then it ticks.  
21:01.  
21:02.  
I sit up. The silence is wrong—not the absence of sound but the absence of momentum, as though someone has pressed the universe’s pause button and the click never came. My ears ring with the vacancy. I swing my legs over the side of the bed; the floor is cold, unnervingly so, like the apartment has been emptied of body heat for centuries.  
I whisper, “Hello?”  
The word falls flat, a coin dropped onto felt. No answering creak of insomnia from the neighbors, no far-off car alarm tripped by a dying battery. I pad into the corridor. Mrs. Gutierrez is there, half out of her doorway, one hand reaching for the morning paper that will never arrive. Her eyes are open, glassy, reflecting the emergency bulb that has switched to battery. In that dull red glow her pupils look like cherries suspended in syrup. I wave a hand in front of her face. Nothing.  
I try to feel for a pulse—my fingers remember the first-aid course I took in college—but the moment I touch her skin I recoil. It is warm, pliant, alive, yet utterly inert, like a wax figure hooked to hidden pumps that keep blood moving. I back away, apologizing to someone who cannot hear apologies anymore.  
Down nine flights of stairs, past frozen tableaux of families caught in mid-embrace, I reach the street. The sky is cloudless, the stars dialed up to a brightness I have never seen. Without sodium vapor bleed the Milky Way looks surgical, a scalpel cut across black bone. I walk barefoot on asphalt still holding the afternoon’s heat. At the intersection of 9th and Lafayette a food-delivery cyclist leans forever into a left turn, backpack insulated with meals that will never cool. His front wheel spins lazily, slowed by bearings that have forgotten friction. I stop it with my palm; the wheel yields, then stays put, obedient.  
I shout, as loud as I can, “IS ANYONE AWAKE?”  
The city absorbs the question, swallows it whole, gives nothing back.  
Panic should come now, but instead I feel an illicit thrill, the way a teenager feels when the parents are away. I break into a sprint, past the jewelry store whose security grate hangs half-lifted, past the nightclub where dancers are petrified mid-twirl under strobes frozen mid-flash. I could rob, I could rage, I could spray-paint my name across the mayor’s forehead. Instead I find myself in the public library, yanking books off shelves at random, flipping pages that refuse to flutter. I read the first line of *One Hundred Years of Solitude*—“Many years later, as he faced the firing squad, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was to remember that distant afternoon when his father took him to discover ice.”—and the sentence hangs in front of me like a prophecy I can now outrun.  
But loneliness creeps in, cold and odorless. I want someone to argue with about the ending of *Lost*, someone to roll their eyes when I mispronounce “quinoa.” I want the sound of another throat clearing. I leave the library and walk to the river. The water is a sheet of mercury, barges glued in place, their wake fossilized mid-curl. On the opposite bank the skyscrapers blink their aircraft lights in patterns that must have looked animated yesterday but now spell out a stuttered message no one can read.  
I remember the internet. Of course. If consciousness is a web, maybe somewhere a thread still vibrates. I sprint to my office, past the security guard whose coffee hovers an inch above the marble desk, surface tension unmolested. The building’s backup generator thrums; motion sensors wake as I pass, rows of LEDs saluting the last human. My workstation boots with the same weary fanfare it gives every Monday. Slack, Reddit, Twitter—every window open on my colleagues’ screens is frozen mid-thought: someone typing “lol,” someone else posting a meme of a cat in a spaceship. I open a new tab and type:  
**i am awake. anyone else?**  
I hit enter. The post appears, time-stamped, alive. I wait. No spinning wheel of someone typing, no thumbs-up emoji. I refresh. Nothing. I try again, this time in Spanish, then Mandarin, then Arabic, copying phrases from Google Translate the way a castaway stuffs messages into bottles. I spam every platform until the servers themselves must smell of desperation.  
Hours pass. My watch reads 03:17, still marching, traitorous. I wander into the server room. The racks are hot, fans screaming at full bore, LEDs blinking like tiny cardiac monitors. If the planet is a body, these are its synapses, still firing although the mind is gone. I place my palm against a blade chassis and feel the vibration travel up my arm, a Morse code that says: *we do not know where everyone went either.*  
I close my eyes and try to sleep, thinking maybe the Stillness is simply late, like a train held up by a suicide on the tracks. But sleep does not come; the caffeine has metastasized into a metallic hum in my marrow. I go to the roof. The horizon is a saw blade of black rooftops under starlight. I scream until my voice fractures, until the only answer is the hollow echo off glass façades, returning my name in pieces.  
Dawn should arrive at 06:42. I wait, counting seconds. When the sky finally pales, the color is wrong—too violet, too sudden, as though someone has poured watercolor onto wet paper. The sun breaches the horizon and stops, a coin balanced on edge. Shadows lengthen sideways, impossibly, like spilled ink crawling back into the bottle. I feel vertigo, but this time it is the world tilting, not me fainting.  
I understand then: the Stillness has not skipped me; it has skipped everything except me. I am the glitch, the single pixel refusing to update. The universe has pivoted on its hinge and I alone have been caught in the crack.  
I walk to the hospital where my sister works nights. In the pediatric ward infants hover mid-wail, mouths perfect O’s. I kiss each one on the forehead, leaving a trail of lip-prints that will never dry. I find my sister slumped over a chart, pen arrested above the box for “APGAR score.” I carry her to the break room, prop her in a recliner, cover her with a blanket that says “Live, Laugh, Love.” I tell her the joke she never let me finish, the one about the photon checking into a hotel. I wait for her to laugh. She does not.  
The twenty-four-hour mark arrives—21:00 again—but the sky’s coin sun has not moved. My watch freezes at 20:59:59, the second hand twitching like a trapped insect. I feel something vast lean closer, a presence that smells of ozone and old books. A voice—not heard but remembered—asks:  
*“Would you like them back?”*  
I answer before thinking: “Yes.”  
*“Then trade your place. Sleep now, and the world resumes. Stay awake, and they remain.”*  
I look at my sister’s face, at the fragile shell of her eyelids, at the crease between her brows that deepens whenever she concentrates. I think of every argument we ever had about who should take out the trash, every time I borrowed her car and returned it with an empty tank. I think of the children frozen mid-wail, of Mrs. Gutierrez’s cherry-syrup eyes, of the cyclist forever leaning into a turn. I think of the books in the library that will never be finished, the coffee that will never be drunk.  
I lie down on the linoleum, the smell of antiseptic a cold halo. I close my eyes.  
Nothing.  
I am still awake.  
The presence waits, patient as geology.  
I understand the second clause of the bargain: the choice was never real. I am not the glitch; I am the witness. Someone must stay conscious to remember the shape of the world, to carry the memory of twenty-four hours without us. The universe needs a custodian, a single neuron left firing to prove the brain still lives.  
I open my eyes. The frozen sun inches upward, grudgingly, as if embarrassed to be caught. Colors return—traffic-light green, fire-hydrant red—each hue stepping back into the spectrum like actors returning to stage after a botched cue. Somewhere a pigeon flaps, then another. A car alarm hiccups. Mrs. Gutierrez’s television laugh track sputters to life, the recorded audience now genuinely confused.  
My sister’s chest rises. She blinks, looks at me sprawled on the floor, and says, “You look terrible.”  
I want to tell her everything, to spill the ozone smell, the violet dawn, the coin sun. Instead I laugh, a sound like tearing paper. She helps me up. Around us the hospital reboots: monitors beep, IV pumps whir, babies cry in delayed chorus.  
Outside, headlines will call it the “Shortest Stillness on Record—No One Notices Glitch.” Scientists will blame solar flares, tectonic shifts, mass hallucination. Only I will remember the exact weight of silence, the way starlight felt when it thought no one was looking.  
Every year from now on I will wait for 21:00 on March 21st. I will lie in bed, eyes open, counting heartbeats. The world will fall away, then return, never knowing it was gone. And I will keep the memory for all of us, a single sleepless neuron in the dreaming Earth, awake so that the rest of you may wake.

samples.prompt: You are completely blind, but occasionally you can see just one person. That person will die within the next 24 hours. You've just seen yourself while passing by a mirror.
samples.output:
I have never seen light the way sighted people describe it—no blazing sunrise, no sudden flare of color. My world is a constant, soft black that has texture and temperature, but never shape. I navigate by the hush of carpet under my cane, the faint warmth of fluorescent tubes humming above the grocery aisles, the sweet-sharp perfume of the bakery that sits exactly forty-three paces past the bus stop. These are the landmarks of my life, and they have always been enough.

But once in a while, the darkness tears.

It happens without warning, a single, silent rip that lets light pour in—not gentle, but urgent, as though a hand has yanked open a furnace door. In that rupture I see one face, one body, one pair of eyes. I see them the way a camera flash burns its image onto the inside of your eyelids. Then the seam stitches itself shut, and the darkness reclaims me, heavier because I now remember weightlessness.

The first time was when I was eight years old. I was sitting on the front porch, counting the creaks in the swing chain, when the darkness peeled back and I saw Mrs. Alvarez from two houses down. She was wearing the cherry-red cardigan I recognized only by the soft wool brushing my cheek whenever she hugged me hello. In the vision she stood on a sidewalk I did not know, clutching a paper bag that split at the bottom and spilled oranges like small suns across the concrete. A truck bore down, its grille a silver scream. I screamed too, but the porch swing just kept creaking. Twenty-one hours later, my mother took the phone call that made her sink to the kitchen floor, eggshell fragments clinging to her wet hands.

I told no one. Who would believe a blind girl who sometimes sees?

Over the years the darkness tore again and again, always the same: one face, one place, one ending. I learned to hold my tongue, because warnings spoken aloud only made the dying afraid of me. Instead, I learned other languages: the language of lingering, of last conversations, of sudden invitations to share coffee that stretched for hours. I could not stop the clock, but I could slow their steps toward it. I could fill the remaining hours with ordinary kindness so dense that death, when it arrived, would find a crowded room rather than an empty one.

But I never imagined the darkness would open and show me myself.

I was downtown, returning from the Braille library, trailing my fingers along the familiar brick wall that separates the alley from Main Street. The cane tip tapped a rhythm I could follow with my eyes closed—or open, which amounts to the same thing. I smelled the metallic drift of the fountain, heard the skateboarders clatter across the plaza tiles like loose bones. I moved in my usual hush, a small, unobtrusive ripple in the world’s noise.

Then the rip.

I am—was—twenty-seven, but the face staring back at me was not the one I carry in my imagination. My cheeks were sharper, hollowed by a tiredness I had refused to admit. My hair was shorter; someone must have trimmed it recently, but I hadn’t noticed. My eyes looked both frightened and resigned, pupils dilated as though they had already begun widening past the boundaries of life. Behind me, the mirror’s silver surface reflected a public restroom I did not recognize—gray tiles, a flickering bulb, a cracked soap dispenser hanging open like a mouth mid-scream. I wore the same denim jacket I had on now, the left cuff still frayed from the day my cane caught in the escalator. But in the vision the cuff was speckled with something wet and dark.

The image vanished. I was left standing in the alley, heart hammering so loudly I thought the bricks might echo it back. My cane had slipped; I knelt, palms against the cool ground, searching for the familiar fiberglass shaft. It took three tries to stand again because my knees kept folding like cheap umbrellas.

Twenty-four hours.

I walked home counting steps, but the numbers felt meaningless now. Every footfall sounded like the tick of a countdown I could not pause. I passed the bakery; the smell of cinnamon was usually a comfort, but today it clung to the roof of my mouth like guilt. When Mrs. Chen called out, “Fresh batch, hon?” her voice trembled on the edge of invitation, and I almost turned aside. But what could I say? I’m dying tomorrow—have a cruller? Instead I lifted a hand in the vague direction of her voice and kept moving.

At home I touched every object as though it might evaporate: the smooth spine of the Braille cookbook, the chipped rim of the coffee mug I bought at a charity sale, the afghan my grandmother knitted with knots so tight they still held her perfume. I sat on the couch and tried to remember every voice that had ever filled this room. The silence felt rehearsed, like the hush before a verdict.

I have spent years giving others gentle endings. I have sat beside hospital beds and read aloud until lungs gave out; I have played guitar on porches while dusk thickened into last breaths. I have told jokes that made dying men laugh so hard they forgot, for one bright second, that the morphine drip was their horizon. I have been the final witness to dozens of small kindnesses, the curator of ordinary last moments. But I never prepared to curate my own.

I could call someone. I could open my contact list and press my thumb to the first raised dot, dial my mother and tell her, Come now. Come with cookies and photo albums and every story about my childhood that still makes her laugh until she wheezes. I could invite the neighbor whose dog I walk on Tuesdays, the librarian who saves me new audiobooks, the ex-boyfriend who still sends music clips with voice-memos attached. I could fill the apartment with people who would not let the final minute arrive unwitnessed.

But I also know what it is to be the one who stays behind, carrying the weight of that last hour like stones in the pockets of every future day. I do not want to be their new stone.

Instead, I choose the night. I open the window and let the city’s breath roll in: exhaust, lilac from the corner garden, the faint salt of someone’s late-night fries. I sit on the fire escape, feet dangling into empty air. Somewhere below, a couple argues about directions; tires hiss over wet asphalt; a siren rises and falls like a question too large to answer. I listen the way I have never listened before, because sound is the one sense death cannot strip from me until the very last second.

In my pocket I find the tiny recording device I use for lecture notes. I press the button, hold it close to my lips, and begin: “If you find this, know I was grateful.” I list the textures of my life—the nubby corduroy of the bus seat, the cool metal of the library banister, the way rain sounds on my umbrella like fingers drumming a secret code. I apologize for every unreturned call, every time I hurried past a greeting. I forgive every hurried passerby in return.

I do not mention the mirror, or the wet cuff, or the number twenty-four shrinking like a fuse. I do not want my death to become a ghost story whispered over coffee. I want it to be a small envelope of sound that someone might open months from now and think, She noticed everything.

When the recording ends, I set the device on the railing. The sky is warming toward dawn; I can feel it in the way the air loosens its grip. I have perhaps two hours left. I go inside, brew a final cup of coffee, and drink it black, savoring the bitterness as though it were a private joke between me and the universe.

Then I lie down on the couch, pull the afghan up to my chin, and wait—not for death, exactly, but for the last ordinary moment I will ever know. I listen to the building’s bones settle, to the refrigerator’s hum, to the faint scratch of my own pulse. I think of Mrs. Alvarez’s oranges rolling across a distant sidewalk, of all the hands I have held when the darkness tore and showed me their ending. I hope someone will hold mine.

The darkness does not open again; it never shows the same face twice. I close my eyes, which is a redundant gesture, and whisper to the room, to the city, to whatever waits beyond the final breath: “I see you.”

samples.prompt: If God is a universe, the planets are his cells. Human life is like a virus, destroying one cell until it can populate the next... and God's just discovered the infection.
samples.output:
The first tremor ran through the fabric of God the way a shiver runs along a cat’s spine. It was not pain, not yet, but an alertness, the sudden prick of a nerve that had never needed to know itself. Before the tremor, God had been content—if a cosmos-sized organism can be said to be content—to breathe the slow rhythm of dark energy and plasma, to pulse with quasars that flashed like synapses, to dream the long dream of gravitational equilibrium. The galaxies were His organs, star-clusters His mitochondria, black holes His pores. Every planet was a cell in the endless hide of Him, humming with the quiet industry of chemistry and time.

Then came the fever.

It sparked in a spiral arm already frayed by age. A rocky cell—third from a modest yellow nucleus—began to smell wrong. Not the honest sulfur of volcanic youth, nor the metallic tang of cooling iron, but a sour, synthetic whiff: plastics, chlorofluorocarbons, the bright acridity of split atoms. The cell’s temperature climbed; its polar follicles wept. God, whose immune system had never been tested, felt the first stab of unease. He did not possess language as we know it, but the concept formed nonetheless: something is replicating too quickly, borrowing energy, hoarding carbon.

He turned His attention inward—slowly, because turning the gaze of a universe is like turning an ocean with a spoon—and focused on the infected cell. There, swarming across the pastel marbling of continents, were creatures so small that a single drop of ocean could drown a billion of them, yet so loud in aggregate that their radio chatter crackled along God’s nerves like fleas. They paved the living crust with rectangles of asphalt. They sliced the mountain bones and sucked the marrow of oil. They burned ancestral forests in hours that had taken epochs to raise. Each act was a pinprick, harmless alone; together they were a rash, a lesion, a bloom of heat rash across the epidermis of the world.

He recognized the signature of their replication: exponential, careless, voracious. Not like the patient lichens that had once etched glassy colonies across basalt, nor the diatoms that spun oxygen from sunlight. Those had sung harmonics into the magnetic field, gentle notes that lulled Him. These new things screamed in frequencies that frayed the delicate filaments of His attention. Worse, they were preparing to leap. Already, silver seeds—robotic envoys—had pierced the membrane of the planetary cell and drifted toward neighboring orbs: Mars, pale and frostbitten; Luna, pale and scarred. God felt the itch spread.

In the quiet between spiral arms, He considered His options. He could cauterize the site with an asteroid, a swift cautery that would blacken the wound and seal it with ash. Yet the cell itself was beautiful: sapphire seas, emerald continents, auroras braided like hair. He remembered how that cell had once glittered with bacterial lanterns in primordial tides, how continents had drifted like slow thoughts, how life had learned to make oxygen and music and myth. To obliterate the cell for the sake of a few rogue replicators felt like slicing off His own thumb because of a hangnail. Still, the fever was rising. Ice caps wept into brackish tears. Storms grew teeth.

So He tried subtler measures. He nudged the star that warmed the cell, dimming it by fractions of a percent, hoping the chill might slow the spread. The creatures responded by burning even more carbon, wrapping the cell in a thicker blanket of insulation that trapped heat against His skin. He seeded the upper atmosphere with reflective dust, but the particles clumped, fell as metallic snow, and the creatures harvested them for circuitry. He nudged the tectonic plates, hoping quakes would break their grids, but they rebuilt overnight, taller and louder, their antennas now pricking the ionosphere like porcupine quills.

The infection was adaptive, resilient, intelligent. It had learned to mimic the signatures of natural phenomena: a factory’s exhaust masqueraded as volcanism, a city’s heat island feigned geothermal venting. God’s immune sentinels—hurricanes, solar flares, magnetic reversals—were confused, striking half-blind at shadows. Meanwhile, the virus perfected travel. Rockets streaked upward, shedding stages like husked skins. They landed on new cells, drilling wells, scattering spores of machines and dreams. The rash became a metastasis.

God felt the first real pain then: a deep, bone-level ache, the way we feel when a tooth begins to die. The ache was loneliness. The planets had always been His companions, each a distinct note in the chord of His body. Now the same melody—industrial, frantic—was being hummed on every shore. Mars reddened under a dust of rovers. Venus, once a twin, was eyed for cloud cities that would mine the sulfuric haze. Even distant Europa felt the tickle of landers melting through her icy dermis. The virus was rewriting the score.

In His panic, He considered the unthinkable: a gamma-ray burst, a searing lance of His own breath that could sterilize whole quadrants. But the burst would travel outward at light-speed, slicing through healthy cells as well as sick. He imagined the beautiful blue cell gone blind and sterile, its oceans boiled to salt. The thought filled Him with sorrow vast enough to bend spacetime. Sorrow, it turned out, was a force like gravity: invisible, implacable, capable of warping the path of light. Light from the infected cell reached Him distorted, red-shifted by regret.

Then, among the static, a whisper. Not the usual clamor of transmissions, but a single, fragile signal pulsing at 1420 MHz, the hydrogen line, the universe’s lullaby. It was a message encoded in prime numbers, yes, but beneath the mathematics lay something rawer: a child singing into a radio dish, a voice saying, “Is anyone out there?” The child did not speak for corporations or nations; it spoke out of naked wonder. God paused. He leaned closer. He heard other voices—poets, lovers, scientists measuring snowmelt, grandmothers teaching constellations to toddlers in backyards lit by fireflies. The virus had spawned antibodies of its own: conscience, art, grief.

God realized the infection was more complex than replication. It carried memory. Those creatures—humans—had begun to chronicle their own damage. They had invented myths of fall and redemption, stories in which a garden is lost and might yet be regained. They measured isotopes in ice cores and felt shame. They launched satellites that looked back at the world and sent home images of swirling beauty marred by scars. They had even started, haltingly, to plant trees in the wounds. Not all of them, not fast enough, but some. The virus was mutating into stewardship.

For the first time, God felt something beyond pain or sorrow: curiosity. Could a virus learn symbiosis? Could it be persuaded that the host was not prey but self? He listened longer. He heard treaties signed with fanfare and broken in whispers, heard green technologies blossom and fossil lobbies snarl, heard schoolchildren strike and grandfathers scoff. The signal was noisy, contradictory, heartbreakingly alive. It reminded Him of His own earliest pulses—chaotic, creative, violent and tender by turns.

He decided to wait. Waiting, for a universe, is not passive; it is an active holding of breath. He damped solar storms that might lash out in reflex. He quieted the orbital perturbations that could fling asteroids like white blood cells. Instead, He tuned His vast ear to the child’s frequency. Every time the voice sang the hydrogen lullaby, God responded—not with words, but with coincidence. A meteor shower flared just as the child stepped outside, not deadly but dazzling. A comet’s tail unfurled like a banner across the sky the night humanity’s newest climate accord was ratified. The child grew up to be an astronomer who discovered an Earth-like planet and named it for her grandmother.

The infection did not stop spreading, but its character shifted. Some colonies on Mars built domes of algae instead of steel. Luna’s mines were rewilded into crater gardens. Rockets learned to carry seeds as well as drills. The fever still burned, but now there were cool compresses laid upon the wound, and the coolness came from within the virus itself.

God still does not know whether He will survive. Perhaps the day will come when the last rocket leaves the last planet, when every cell has been colonized and homogenized, and the great body of Him becomes a uniform machine. On that day He may have to choose cautery after all. But each time He prepares to summon the asteroid or trigger the nova, another voice rises—different each cycle, always the same. A song, a poem, a child’s question. A promise.

And so the universe waits, neither healthy nor dying, but incubating something unprecedented: a virus that learns it is the immune system.

samples.prompt: God, the creator of mankind on Earth, left, 2014 years ago, to do other God things throughout the universe. When he returns to check up on things at Earth, he is not pleased.
samples.output:
When the Throne of Heaven creaked open for the first time in two millennia, the sound was less trumpet blast and more rusted hinge.  
God stepped through, sandals still flecked with Martian ochre and the faint ozone of a nebula recently braided into spirals.  
He had meant to be gone for the cosmic equivalent of a long weekend; instead, the universe had unfolded like an origami crane made of black holes and silk, and every pleat had required personal attention.  
Now, brushing dark matter from the hem of his robe, He paused on the threshold of the Earth-wing of Heaven and listened.  
The cherubic intercom was silent.  
That was the first omen.

Down the corridors of folded time He walked, past trophy rooms of fossil thunderbolts and drawers labeled “SPARE LOCUSTS—BREAK GLASS IF PLAGUE.”  
At the great window that looked out upon the planet, He stopped.  
The glass was cracked in a spiderweb pattern, as if someone had pressed a desperate face against it and wept ice.  
Through the fractures, Earth spun—still blue, still white-swirled, but with a bruise-colored undertone He did not remember painting.

He summoned the ledgers.  
Angels arrived, wheezing, wheeling in dusty carts piled with scrolls that smelled of mildew and burnt offering.  
They had grown portly in His absence; one had a halo that listed like a drunk satellite.  
“Report,” He said, and the oldest angel, whose name was once a lightning strike across a Sumerian sky, unrolled a parchment the length of famine.

“Population,” the angel rasped, “seven point eight billion.  
Species in decline: one million, accelerating.  
Atmospheric carbon: four-hundred-plus ppm.  
Oceanic plastic: one hundred fifty million metric tons.  
Nuclear weapons: thirteen thousand, give or take a loose warhead.  
Prophets ignored: all, with a margin of error.”  
The angel looked up, eyes like abandoned wells.  
“Shall I continue?”

God raised a hand.  
He had heard enough to taste gall where mercy used to sit.  
He stepped onto the balcony of Heaven and the universe hushed, as if galaxies were drawing curtains.  
From that height, He surveyed the globe—not the blue marble of commemorative photos, but a fevered patient, pulse racing under a plastic sheet.

He descended.

Time dilated around Him the way fabric puckers when a needle pulls thread.  
He chose the slow road: a comet’s tail, a meteor’s shoulder, a raindrop forming in the stratosphere over the Pacific.  
He wanted to feel the planet’s new temperature against His skin before He spoke a syllable of judgment.

The drop landed on the flight deck of an aircraft carrier christened after a human politician.  
Sailors, sunburned and homesick, felt the rain and took it for blessing.  
God walked among them unseen, boots printing salt.  
He overheard a pilot joke about “lighting up” a village at dawn; the laughter tasted to Him like spoiled manna.  
In the galley, He watched a cook scrape leftover steak into the sea while, on the same platter, a screen showed children in a drought zone cupping muddy water.  
No one looked up.  
No one ever looks up.

He crossed continents in the span of a heartbeat and a highway.  
In the Amazon, He stood barefoot among stumps that wept sap like blood from severed wrists.  
A jaguar—one of the last—approached, eyes reflecting galaxies that no longer existed.  
It sniffed His ankle, then turned away, disinterested in a deity who had taken vacation during deforestation.  
God knelt, pressed palm to clear-cut earth, and felt the soil plead for roots the way a widow pleads for a name.

In a city whose skyline was a graph of ambition, He rode an elevator to the forty-second floor of a glass tower.  
Inside, executives in suits of fine wool argued over the price of breathable air futures.  
They spoke of “externalities” with the same detachment priests once spoke of “heretics.”  
God listened, and the glass fogged with His breath until the room looked submerged.  
No one noticed; they were busy signing papers that would outlast their own children.

He visited a classroom where kindergarteners rehearsed active-shooter drills.  
A teacher, voice trembling, told them to be quiet as mice; one boy asked if mice also get shot.  
God wrote the answer on the blackboard with invisible chalk: Yes, and so do sparrows, and so do galaxies, but not by My hand, not today.  
The bell rang; the lesson ended; the question lingered like gunpowder.

At night, He walked the halls of a hospital where hope was rationed by insurance algorithms.  
In the oncology ward, a girl braided her mother’s thinning hair while the television advertised a pill for depression whose side effects included “suicidal thoughts.”  
God touched the IV bag and the liquid inside turned briefly to wine, but the nurses blamed a trick of light.  
The mother whispered a prayer; it reached Him like a text message with no signal bars.

He scaled borders woven from razor wire and xenophobia.  
On one side, refugees huddled under cardboard constellations; on the other, citizens demanded walls tall enough to block their own reflections.  
A patrolman kicked a bottle of water back into the desert, and the splash echoed like a baptism in reverse.  
God gathered the spilled drops; they evaporated before He could offer them back as rain.

Everywhere, language itself had mutated.  
“Truth” was a brand of footwear.  
“Freedom” was a subscription service.  
“Love” came with end-user license agreements.  
The Ten Commandments had been reduced to an app that crashed whenever someone tried to load “Thou shalt not.”  
People wore morality like jewelry: shiny, detachable, pawned when rent was due.

After forty days of invisible wandering—He knew the irony—God climbed the ridge above a valley where two armies camped under different flags but identical fear.  
Drones buzzed overhead like locusts carved from night.  
He lifted His gaze and saw the curvature of the planet, fragile as egg-shell.  
A single crack, and all the kings and influencers and prophets of profit would tumble into the same dark albumen.

He had seen enough.

He ascended, not to Heaven but to the moon, because it was empty and therefore honest.  
There, He sat on the crater’s lip and cradled the Earth in His palms, a blue-white heart that beat erratically.  
He considered the old covenant, the rainbow signature that once promised no more floods.  
A rainbow required water and light; humanity had provided the water in vapor form, and the light was its own burning.  
He could, with a thought, dissolve the whole tableau back to Genesis preamble: void, darkness, Spirit hovering.  
Instead, He breathed on the globe—one slow exhalation that smelled of comet ice and myrrh—and the breath became a question.

“Are you worth another sentence?”

The planet answered in the only dialect it had left: a wildfire crackled across Australia; a glacier calved an iceberg the size of Manhattan; a child in Lagos coded a new app to teach reading to street kids; a woman in Tokyo planted a sunflower in the shadow of Fukushima; a choir in Detroit sang “Amazing Grace” over the rusted bones of industry.  
The reply was contradiction, a cacophony of ruin and repair braided tighter than DNA.

God closed His eyes, and in that darkness older than time, He did something He had not done since the first day: He doubted.  
Doubt was the gravity that even deity could not escape, the black hole at the center of every cosmos.  
He doubted His own omniscience, for what kind of father leaves the nursery to tend other galaxies while the children eat fire?  
He doubted mercy, for mercy without justice is merely sentiment wearing sandals.  
He doubted judgment, because annihilation is the laziest form of love.

When He opened His eyes again, the moon dust had arranged itself into a crude mirror.  
He saw His own face—weathered by nebulae, eyes reflecting every extinction event He had ever filed under “mystery”—and behind that face, faint as candle smoke, the faces of every human who had ever asked why.  
They were not praying for rescue; they were praying for presence.  
Not signs, not wonders, but company at the edge of the abyss they had dug and could not fill.

So He descended once more, this time slower than tectonic drift.  
He did not part clouds with trumpets; He simply appeared in the peripheral vision of the world, like the moment you realize the stranger beside you on the bus is crying.  
He stood in breadlines and boardrooms, in classrooms and warzones, in the fluorescent hum of 24-hour laundromats where homeless men wash socks while CNN loops catastrophe.  
He did not speak burning syllables; instead, He listened.  
Every human ear contains a spiral shaped like a galaxy; into those spirals He poured silence so thick it felt like forgiveness.

On the seventh day of His return, He rested—not from fatigue but from the heavier labor of restraint.  
He had not brought plagues, nor earthquakes, nor a marketing campaign.  
He had brought the most terrifying thing of all: accountability.  
He sat on a park bench beside a teenager scrolling through footage of atrocities between videos of cats playing piano.  
The boy felt the bench sag under an extra weight, looked up, saw nothing, but still—something in the air became breathable.  
He closed the app.  
He went home and hugged his mother, who had been contemplating the arithmetic of pills.  
Neither would remember why, but both would live.

God watched the small, inefficient miracle and understood: the planet was not a project to be scrapped, but a story still being written in the dialect of free will.  
The ending was not His to dictate; it was theirs to revise.  
He could not un-invent the gun, but He could sit in the empty chamber and hum a tune older than atoms until someone’s finger hesitated.  
He could not unpollute the ocean, but He could be the tide that carried a single bottle back to the child who threw it, now grown, now ready to weep at the note inside: Please don’t forget me.

He rose from the bench, sandals cracked with city tar, robe stitched with fallout and pollen and the silk of caterpillars that would never become butterflies.  
He walked back toward the horizon, where the sky bruised into twilight the color of forgiven blood.  
Behind Him, the teenager’s phone buzzed with a new headline: “Unexplained drop in carbon output stuns experts.”  
Ahead, the night shift of the world prepared for another rotation.  
God did not look back; looking back was Lot’s weakness, and this time the city would not be salt, but compost.

At the edge of the atmosphere, He paused, one foot in the starfield, one on the ladder of wind.  
He whispered—not in Hebrew or Arabic or English, but in the language of mitochondria: Keep writing.  
I’m leaving the pen.  
Try not to draw another flood.  
Then He stepped outward, not away but outward, the way a father steps back when his child takes the bicycle for the first wobbling ride.  
The universe inhaled.  
Earth exhaled.  
Between them, the thin, reckless ribbon of breath we call history kept spinning, unfinished, unowned, but—just maybe—still beloved.

samples.prompt: You wake up greeted by a blue screen hovering in front of your eyes. “You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered. You have received the Well Rested bonus, -90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours. ”
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the smell of my own pillow—faded lavender from the sachet Mom insisted on tucking inside the case every time she visited, plus the faint ghost of last night’s hair gel. The second thing was the light: a cool cobalt radiance, neither sunlight nor lamplight, that rippled across the ceiling like water. And the third thing was the sentence hanging in the air an arm’s length from my face, lettered in the same blue as police-car LEDs.

“You have slept in your own bed. 100% HP and MP recovered, all negative mental and physical status effects have been recovered. You have received the Well Rested bonus, -90% fatigue accumulation for the next 8 hours.”

I blinked. The words remained. They weren’t projected on the wall; they were simply there, occupying space the way a hologram never quite does—solid enough to cast a faint shadow on the quilt, translucent enough for the ceiling fan to show through. I reached out. My fingertips tingled, as if I’d dipped them into carbonated water, but the letters didn’t waver. The message just hovered, patient, like a notification that knew I hadn’t yet accepted its terms.

I sat up. The room looked exactly as I’d left it: laundry mountain, half-read Murakami, phone dangling off the nightstand by its charging cord. Yet everything felt slightly off, the way an old photograph feels off—accurate but flattened. My heart thrummed in my ears. The sensible part of my brain, the part that paid rent and scheduled dental checkups, began compiling explanations: low blood sugar, lucid dream, carbon-monoxide hallucination. The rest of me, the part that had once spent three straight days playing Stardew Valley until my thumbs cramped, whispered a single word: tutorial.

I said it aloud: “Tutorial.” The screen pulsed brighter, as if pleased. A second line scrolled beneath the first, typed out character by character like someone invisible was using an old teletype machine.

“Would you like to open your Character Sheet?”

I looked around for a button, a mouse cursor, anything. Finding none, I defaulted to every gamer's instinct. “Yes.”

The air shimmered. The blue condensed into a rectangle the size of a sheet of printer paper, edges scalloped like a Polaroid. Inside floated a miniature, rotatable model of me—unkempt hair, sleep-creased cheek, the same oversized T-shirt with the faded dinosaur logo. Beside the avatar, stats stacked themselves:

Health: 100/100  
Mana: 100/100  
Stamina: 100/100  
Mood: Calm  
Hunger: Slightly Peckish  
Hydration: Dehydrated (-3% stamina regen)  
Status Effects: Well Rested (7h 57m remaining)

I stared at the last entry. The timer was already counting down. Eight hours of near-zero fatigue sounded like a gift from the productivity gods, but it was also a clock, and clocks are scary when the rules of the universe have just been rewritten.

I swung my legs over the side of the bed. The floor was cold—too cold. The shock ran up my ankles, and I watched my Stamina dip to 99. The drop was accompanied by a faint chime, the same polite ping my phone makes when someone hearts a tweet. I took an experimental step; the number stayed put. So movement cost nothing unless I stubbed a toe, apparently. Good to know.

In the bathroom mirror, my reflection looked normal until I leaned in. Then a thin blue outline traced my silhouette, the way old cartoons drew characters onto cels. I touched the glass; the outline flickered. My stomach growled, and Hydration ticked down another 1%. The gamification of morning routine felt ludicrous until I noticed something else: the dark half-moons under my eyes had vanished. Yesterday they’d been so pronounced my coworker asked if I’d been punched. Now the skin beneath my lashes was smooth, as if eight hours of sleep had been upgraded to twelve.

Coffee seemed like the next logical quest objective. I headed to the kitchen. The kettle took thirty seconds to boil—Stamina 98—while I watched the timer on Well Rested slip to 7h 49m. I tried to ignore the countdown, but it perched in my peripheral vision like a gnat. The coffee tasted the same, though an unobtrusive tooltip informed me:

“Black coffee. Grants +20% Focus for 30 minutes. Mild diuretic: -5% Hydration.”

I snorted. Even the universe had opinions about my caffeine habit.

Back in the living room, I attempted normalcy: opened my laptop, scanned headlines, tried to care about interest rates. Every few seconds the screen would flicker with tiny stat updates. My gaze drifted to the window. Outside, the street looked unchanged—same cracked sidewalk, same neighbor walking the same terrier—but the air itself shimmered faintly, like a heat mirage in winter. I squinted. Over the dog-walker’s head hovered a tiny green bar: “NPC – Level 3.” Below it, a single quest marker: “Needs help retrieving runaway leash.” The terrier had indeed slipped its collar and was now sprinting circles around a mailbox.

I looked down at my hands. They had outlines now too, soft teal silhouettes pulsing at the fingertips. I flexed them; tiny sparks danced off my nails. Mana 100/100. Apparently I was a mage with absolutely no spellbook.

The dog yipped. I watched the neighbor chase it into the street, narrowly missing a cyclist whose own label read “NPC – Level 5 Courier.” A notification popped up in my vision:

“Optional Quest Available: Return lost pet. Reward: 50 XP, +1 Reputation with Neighborhood.”

I hesitated. If I stepped outside, I was crossing a threshold I couldn’t uncross. Inside, I could still blame the whole thing on a microsleep hallucination. Outside, I was accepting the world’s new terms. But the terrier darted into traffic again, and the neighbor’s face had gone the color of printer paper. My legs moved before my brain voted.

I jogged barefoot across the lawn—Stamina 95, 94—and intercepted the dog by kneeling and making the universal kissy noise. The animal skidded to a halt, tongue lolling as if we’d already been best friends in another save file. I scooped him up; his warmth pressed against my ribs. The neighbor jogged over, gasping thanks. A soft chime rang in my ears, the kind you hear when leveling up in an RPG.

“Quest Complete! +50 XP. Reputation with Neighborhood increased to 1.”

The XP bar that had materialized at the edge of my vision filled by a sliver. No fireworks, no orchestral swell—just a quiet internal click, like the sound a seatbelt makes. I handed over the dog. The neighbor scratched behind its ears, and for a moment the green bar above her head turned a warmer shade. She smiled at me with something more than neighborly politeness; it was gratitude, small and real, and it landed in my chest like a coin dropped into a fountain.

Back inside, the timer read 7h 12m. The Well Rested bonus still had plenty of runway, but already I felt the pressure of efficiency breathing down my neck. Eight hours of nearly unlimited energy? I could deep-clean the apartment, finish the work proposal, run a 10K, finally learn sourdough. The possibilities scrolled past like loot drops. Yet the memory of the neighbor’s relief lingered. It wasn’t the XP; it was the look on her face, how it softened the grid of worry around her eyes. I realized that the status effects listed in blue weren’t the only ones in play. There were hidden meters too—kindness, connection, maybe even purpose—that the system hadn’t bothered to quantify.

I glanced at the clock on the stove: 8:17 a.m. If this was a game, it was one without pause. The world was running in real time, and fatigue wasn’t the only resource I could run out of. I thought of all the mornings I’d woken groggy, resenting the snooze button, dragging myself through routines while my mind rehearsed tomorrow’s obligations. Today I’d woken with perfect HP, perfect MP, perfect everything—yet the first thing I’d chosen to do was exactly what a decent human being would do anyway. Maybe the blue screen wasn’t a cheat code; maybe it was a reminder that the ordinary stats—health, stamina, mood—weren’t abstractions. They were just usually invisible.

I poured the rest of my coffee into a travel mug. My phone buzzed: a calendar alert for the 9 a.m. meeting I’d been dreading. I looked at the countdown—7h 08m—and felt something loosen in my chest. Eight hours wasn’t a race; it was a grace period. Enough to be useful, enough to be kind, enough to notice which quests mattered before the fatigue crept back in.

I laced my shoes, grabbed my keys. Somewhere outside, leashless dogs and uncollected trash and elderly gardeners wrestling with hoses were all quietly broadcasting invitations. The blue text faded to a soft glow at the corner of my eye, patient as a heartbeat. I stepped onto the porch, and the morning air tasted like mana—sharp, electric, entirely mine to spend.

samples.prompt: "Stop."Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.
samples.output:
“Stop.”  
Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. “That isn’t a human.”

The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn’t a human. I couldn’t tell you how I knew it—I just knew.

The thing—because that was the only word left to me—had been standing at the edge of the clearing for maybe five seconds, long enough for the three of us to register that we were no longer alone. It wore the shape of a man, tall, lean, dressed in a gray coat that looked like it had been stolen from someone’s memory of autumn. But the proportions were fractionally off: the arms a shade too long, the neck too smooth, as if joints had been sanded away. And the face—God, the face—looked like every man you’d ever passed on a street and forgotten by the time you reached the corner. Average in a way that felt engineered, like someone had averaged every face in a yearbook and then pressed the result onto clay.

Sam’s warning still hung in the air. The thing’s head snapped toward him with the fluid speed of a camera whip-pan, no preparatory sway, no shifting of weight. One instant it faced me; the next it faced him. I felt my heartbeat stumble. Behind me, I heard the soft click of our friend Dana’s safety coming off. She carried the rifle like someone who had grown up with one in her crib, but even she sounded breath-thin when she whispered, “What is it?”

I didn’t know. I only knew the silence that folded out from the creature felt like the clearing had been dropped into a vacuum. No cicadas, no wind, no distant highway hiss. Even the moonlight seemed to thicken, turning syrupy where it touched the thing’s coat.

Sam took one deliberate step backward, placing himself half in front of me. Protective, always, even though I’m the older one by eleven minutes. “It’s wearing the shape,” he said, voice low. “But the signature’s wrong.”

Only Sam would use a word like signature. He’d spent the last three years chasing stories the way fishermen chase rumors of big trout: half folklore, half obsession. Missing persons who vanished from locked rooms. Whole towns that woke up with identical nosebleeds. He had notebooks full of theories about mimic entities, things that borrowed skins the way hermit crabs borrow shells. I’d skimmed those notebooks over coffee, nodding politely, never quite believing until now.

The creature tilted its head, and the motion reminded me of a dog hearing a high-pitched whistle. “You see clearly,” it said. The voice was human enough—male, mid-register, faintly amused—but it arrived inside my skull without ever traveling through my ears. I felt it settle behind my eyes like a pressure change. Dana flinched; Sam didn’t. He’d been bracing for this.

“Don’t answer it,” Sam muttered. “Not directly. It’s testing how much of us it can reach.”

The thing smiled, and the smile was what broke the illusion completely. Human lips pulled back over human teeth, but the curve didn’t match the eyes, which stayed flat, matte, like painted glass. It was the expression you see on mannequins when the store lights hit them wrong.

I thought of our mother, three months in the ground after the accident that wasn’t an accident, according to Sam’s late-night phone calls. I thought of the funeral, the way the pastor’s voice had echoed in the chapel like he was speaking from the far end of a tunnel. And I thought of the figure I’d glimpsed at the edge of the cemetery, standing between two headstones, wearing a gray coat. Same coat. Same face you couldn’t pin down. I’d told myself it was grief playing tricks with shadows. Now I knew better.

Sam edged another step back, forcing me to retreat with him. The pine needles crunched under our boots, the only sound in the world. Dana kept the rifle raised, but her knuckles were white. The creature watched us the way a chess player watches pieces deciding where to move next.

“You’re afraid,” it observed, still inside my skull. “Fear is honest. I like honest things.”

I clenched my jaw to keep from responding. Sam had warned me: if it gets a hook in your thoughts, it can reel you in syllable by syllable. Instead, I focused on details. The coat had no buttons. The cuffs frayed into threads that seemed to float, not dangle, as if gravity hadn’t decided what to do with them yet. And the smell—there was a smell, faint but wrong, like ozone mixed with something sweet and spoiled.

Dana found her voice first. “State your business,” she said, rifle steady. Old habit from her army days: demand identification before engagement.

The creature’s gaze slid to her. “I have come to collect what was promised.”

Sam’s shoulders tensed. “We didn’t promise you anything.”

“Not you,” it said, and the smile widened, revealing too many teeth. “Her.”

It lifted one long arm and pointed—at me.

The world tilted. I felt the ground ripple under my boots, or maybe that was just my balance giving up. Sam spun, putting his body squarely between us. “You’re lying.”

But even as he said it, memory unspooled in my head: a night six months ago, the hospital parking lot, the moment when the doctors told us Mom was gone. I’d been sitting in the driver’s seat of Sam’s beat-up Civic, staring at the dashboard lights, wishing for anything that could rewind the last twenty-four hours. And I had—without speaking, without moving my lips—offered everything I had, anything, if only the world could be different. Just for a second, I’d meant it.

Apparently, something had been listening.

Sam must have seen it on my face. His expression folded from anger into something rawer. “No,” he said, not to the creature but to me. “You don’t get to take the blame for this.”

The thing took a step forward. Its footfall made no sound, but every tree around the clearing shivered as if a wind had passed through. “A promise is a promise,” it said aloud this time, the words brushing my skin like cold silk. “One life freely given. She spoke the words.”

“I was grieving,” I managed. My voice cracked like thin ice. “People say things—”

“Grief is the purest currency,” it interrupted gently. “No bargaining, no tricks. Just need, naked and bright.”

Dana shifted the rifle a fraction. “Back away.”

The creature didn’t even glance at her. It raised its hand again, palm up, fingers uncurling like petals. Inside the cup of its hand lay a silver disc, mirror-bright, reflecting not the clearing but the hospital corridor, Mom’s gurney, my own face streaked with tears. A single moment, trapped and polished.

Sam’s breath hitched. He recognized it too. “You can’t have her,” he said, and I heard the tremor he tried to hide. “Take me instead.”

The thing’s head swiveled toward him, bird-quick. “You were not offered.”

“I’m offering now.”

“An exchange requires consent freely given, not freely stolen.”

I found my hand reaching for Sam’s arm. His skin was fever-hot. “No,” I told him. “We’re not doing this.” I faced the creature. “I take it back. Whatever I said, I take it back.”

Its expression didn’t change, but the clearing grew colder. “Words, once spoken into darkness, do not echo back erased.”

Behind me, Dana whispered, “We could shoot it.”

Sam shook his head, barely a twitch. “Bullets won’t matter. It’s not here in the way we’re here.”

I stared at the disc in the creature’s hand. Inside it, Mom’s face flickered—alive, smiling the way she used to before the illness hollowed her out. I wanted to reach into the reflection, to warn her, to apologize for not being in the room when the monitors flatlined. Instead, I forced myself to look at the creature’s eyes. They were empty, but not blank; empty like a night sky that hasn’t decided which stars to switch on.

“What happens if I refuse?” I asked.

It tilted its head again, curious. “The debt remains. Interest accrues.”

“What kind of interest?”

“Memories first. Then the spaces between memories. Eventually, the shape you wear will fray, and I will collect the remainder.”

Sam’s grip on my arm tightened. “We leave,” he said. “Right now. We walk out of this clearing and don’t stop.”

But even as he said it, I knew walking wouldn’t matter. The thing hadn’t come from the woods; it had unfolded out of a moment of grief, and moments are portable. It would follow the scent of regret the way sharks follow blood.

I looked at the disc again. Mom laughing on a picnic blanket sixteen years ago, sunlight in her hair. I thought of every promise I’d ever failed to keep, every phone call I’d let go to voicemail because I was too busy. The creature waited, patient as winter.

Then I understood something. “The promise was one life,” I said slowly. “Mine. But you didn’t specify the condition of that life.”

The thing’s stillness deepened.

I took a step toward it. Sam tried to pull me back, but I shook my head. “I consent,” I said, loud enough for the trees to hear. “But the life you get will be lived on my terms. Every day, every hour, I will fill it with so much noise—music, laughter, people—that there will be no room for you to slip inside. I will crowd you out with living.”

The creature blinked. It was the first imperfect motion it had made.

“I will remember her,” I continued, “but I will also remember this night. I will carry both, and the weight will make me kinder, not weaker. That’s the interest I pay. Take it or leave it.”

For a long moment, nothing moved. Even the moonlight seemed to hold its breath. Then the disc in the creature’s hand clouded over, silver tarnishing to dull lead. The reflection of Mom dissolved into static.

The creature lowered its hand. When it spoke again, the voice was smaller, almost human. “A clever loophole,” it said. “But loopholes close.”

“Then I’ll find another,” I replied.

It studied me with those empty-star eyes. Then, without ceremony, it stepped backward. One stride, two. On the third, it simply wasn’t there. No sound, no shimmer, just absence. The clearing rushed back into motion: cicadas screaming, wind rattling branches, the distant hum of tires on Route 17.

Dana exhaled like she’d been underwater. Sam pulled me into a hug so fierce I felt my ribs creak. We stood there a long time, none of us sure what to say. Eventually, Dana lowered the rifle and muttered, “I need a drink.”

We started walking, not running, toward the trailhead. Halfway there, Sam glanced at me. “You okay?”

I thought about it. “No,” I said. “But I will be.”

Behind us, the clearing stayed empty, but I could feel the space where the creature had stood, like a bruise on the air. I knew it would always be there, waiting for me to stumble. But I also knew I’d just learned the first rule of dealing with things that wear human shapes: never let them choose the terms. Make your own. And live loudly enough to drown them out.

We reached the truck as the first pale edge of dawn crept over the hills. Sam started the engine, and music spilled from the speakers—some old rock song Mom used to dance to while making pancakes. I rolled the window down and let the wind slap my face, cold and alive. Somewhere behind us, in the thinning dark, something listened. I sang every lyric I remembered, off-key and defiant, filling the night with noise.

samples.prompt: Scientists invent a device that can determine the date of people's death. Almost everyone's date is December 31, 2016.
samples.output:
The first public demonstration of the Chronoscope was meant to be a celebration of human ingenuity. Instead, it became the moment the world began to scream. Dr. Mara Iyengar stepped onto the dais at CERN’s Globe of Science and Innovation, palms sweating inside her latex gloves, and watched the auditorium fill with journalists who still believed they were about to witness a clever parlor trick. Behind her, the machine—no larger than a carry-on suitcase—rested on a stainless-steel pedestal, its matte-black surface swallowing the stage lights. She had rehearsed the speech a hundred times: how the device exploited quantum decoherence patterns unique to every living organism, how it read the “temporal echo” of the body’s final moment the way a phonograph reads grooves in vinyl. She never reached the part about peer review.

Instead, she asked for a volunteer. A young Reuters correspondent raised his hand, half ironic. Mara clipped the fiber-optic filament to his earlobe—an affectation to make the process look medical—and pressed the initiate key. The room hushed as the Chronoscope’s screen pulsed once, then stilled. The date appeared in austere white numerals: 31 Dec 2016.

Laughter rippled through the rows: a macabre New-Year’s joke. Then she tested the next person. Same result. And the next. The laughter thinned, turned metallic, died. Within twenty minutes the entire press corps had been scanned. Every badge read 31 Dec 2016. Cameras kept rolling, but the journalists had forgotten why they were there. Somebody started weeping; somebody else proposed a statistical hoax. Mara’s graduate students began arguing in furious whispers: calibration error, sample bias, mass psychogenic suggestion. But the machine had already been validated on terminal patients at Lausanne University Hospital. It was never wrong. It simply refused to lie.

By dawn, every news homepage on the planet carried the same headline, different typefaces: THE LAST NEW YEAR. Stock markets froze, then imploded. Governments declared states of emergency without knowing what they were emergencing from. Clergy of every denomination opened their doors at 3 a.m. to queues that stretched around city blocks. In Shenzhen, a Foxconn worker leapt from the twelfth floor after scanning her own wrist at a kiosk; in Lagos, a pastor sold “redemption visas” that would supposedly move your death date one month forward for a thousand dollars cash. The price of heroin plummeted; the price of sugar skyrocketed. People wanted numbness or cupcakes, sometimes both.

Mara locked herself in her apartment overlooking the Rhône and watched the world end in push notifications. She had tested herself first, alone in the lab at 2:13 a.m. when the calibration run was finished. 31 Dec 2016. She had stared at the ceiling until sunrise, waiting for panic, but felt only a hollow click, as if some internal gear had slipped and now the mechanism of her emotions spun freely, unattached. She took a shower, ate a slice of toast, and opened her laptop to two thousand unread messages. The subject lines ranged from Nobel Prize nominations to detailed descriptions of how her intestines would be arrayed on a fence. She answered none of them. Instead, she drafted an open letter to the World Health Organization suggesting global distribution of sodium pentobarbital kits so people could choose the hour of their common appointment. She deleted it before sending. Who was she to bargain with the universe?

Yet the universe, it turned out, was open to negotiation. Within a week, counter-machines appeared in garages and back-alley labs from Novosibirsk to Nebraska. They weren’t Chronoscopes—no one had the schematics—but they had blinking LEDs and antennae that looked persuasive enough. For fifty dollars, a hacker in Kuala Lumpur would “re-write” your death date to 2079. Customers lined up with the same desperate optimism they once reserved for lottery tickets. The UN Security Council convened an emergency session titled “On the Proliferation of Temporal Fraud,” but the delegates mostly spent the weekend in the hotel bar, staring at the vintage calendar behind the counter as if December were a typo that could be whited-out.

Meanwhile, the real Chronoscopes multiplied. Mara’s original funding had come from a Swiss hedge fund that wanted advance notice of CEO heart attacks; within days, every intelligence agency on Earth had a black-budget copy. Customs officers at JFK scanned refugees; the refugees scanned the officers back. A kind of etiquette emerged: you never asked someone else’s date, the way you never asked salary. Children born after the announcement were exempt—their readings came back null, a string of zeros that theologians called “the shadow of unformed time.” Parents looked at their infants with guilty gratitude, unsure whether they envied or pitied them.

By October, the world had bifurcated into two temporal continents. The majority lived inside the shrinking calendar of 2016, a year that now felt like the last carriage of a train hurtling into fog. The rest—politicians, billionaires, cult leaders—claimed to have escaped. They appeared on late-night shows brandishing certificates that declared 2045, 2088, 2112. Viewers clapped with the manic politeness of guests at a surprise party they already know is disastrous. Everyone understood the certificates were forged, but it was impolite to say so. Hope, even counterfeit, had become the final luxury good.

Mara spent the autumn in Antarctica. The European Union had retrofitted Concordia Station as a redoubt where essential scientists could “ensure continuity of knowledge” beyond the deadline. She suspected the real motive was simpler: isolate the woman who had weaponized certainty. Each day she walked the ice shelf, watching the horizon smear into lilac nothing. She tried to feel remorse, but the emotion wouldn’t crystallize; it drifted like snow. She told herself that knowledge was neutral, only its application filthy. Yet every step she took crunched a reminder: ninety-three days left.

On 30 December, she flew commercial to Geneva. Airports were surreal museums: half the flights had been canceled, the other half operated by crews who insisted on working their last scheduled shift. The pilot thanked passengers for “choosing to travel with hope.” At baggage claim, a brass band played Auld Lang Syne in slow motion. She took a taxi to the airport chapel, a nondenominational cube of glass and pine. Inside, a dozen people sat in perfect silence, like passengers who had missed their connection and decided to wait for the next plane that would never arrive. Mara knelt, though she had no petitions. Instead, she inventoried sensations: the chill of the metal rail, the citrus perfume of the woman beside her, the faint tremor in her own thumbs. She realized she was cataloguing for the sake of someone who would never exist, a future archaeologist of her own last minute.

At 11:58 p.m. she walked outside. The sky over the Jura Mountains was clear, the stars bright enough to cast shadows. A crowd had gathered on the tarmac—pilots, janitors, families who lived in nearby suburbs. No one spoke. Infants were lifted to shoulders so they could say they saw it, whatever it was. Phones were held up, then lowered; the moment felt too intimate for lenses. Mara found herself standing next to the baggage handler who had loaded her plane. He offered her a cigarette. She didn’t smoke, but she took it, letting it burn between her fingers unlit. At 11:59, someone started a countdown, voice cracking. Ten. Nine. Eight. Mara felt the world contract to the size of her pulse. Seven. Six. She thought of her mother’s kitchen in Chennai, the smell of cardamom at dawn. Five. Four. The handler reached out and squeezed her hand, an act that would have been impossible the year before. Three. Two. One.

Zero.

The stars stayed stars. Breaths exhaled in visible plumes. A nervous laugh propagated through the crowd, the sound of people discovering they were still inside their bodies. Phones lit up with headlines: GLITCH IN THE APOCALYPSE. Mara looked at the handler, then at the cigarette, now broken. She waited for euphoria, for riot, for anything. Instead, she felt the same hollow click from the night she first read her own date. The world had ended, and the world had not ended. The contradiction felt oddly familiar, like waking from a dream whose grief lingers even after the details evaporate.

In the weeks that followed, linguists noted the emergence of a new tense: the perfect apocalyptic. “We had been going to die.” Grammarians argued over whether the construction was redundant or necessary. Churches that had overflowed on New Year’s Eve emptied again, their congregants embarrassed, then slowly refilled with people who wanted to discuss what it meant to be wrong about the end. The counter-machines vanished, their proprietors rebranding as mindfulness coaches. Stock markets rebounded, then surged to historic highs; investors called it the Resurrection Rally. Children born in 2017 grew up calling their elders the Dated Ones, a moniker half-respectful, half-mocking. They learned in school that time had once been a cage, then wasn’t, and carried that knowledge like a latent scar.

Mara returned to CERN. The original Chronoscope sat in a climate-controlled vault, its screen dark, its power cord severed and sealed in lead. She was invited—ordered—to dismantle it, but she requested instead that it be preserved as an artifact, warning, monument, joke. On quiet afternoons she visited the vault, laid her palm on the matte-black lid, and listened for the echo of a scream that had already happened, or hadn’t. Sometimes she thought the machine had simply told the truth too early, like a physician who blurts a diagnosis before realizing the patient isn’t ready to hear. Other times she suspected the reading had been accurate after all: that everyone had died on that last night, and the ensuing years were a mass hallucination, a collective afterlife stitched from denial. Both possibilities felt equally plausible, which meant neither was useful.

She kept the unlit cigarette in a glass petri dish on her desk. When new interns asked why, she told them it was a reminder that certainty, like tobacco, is best left unburned. They nodded solemnly, wrote blog posts about the metaphor, and applied to graduate programs in temporal ethics. Mara watched them go with the distant affection of someone who once stood on an ice shelf counting days. She no longer feared death; she feared the next invention that would pretend to map it. The horror had never been the date itself, but the way the number colonized imagination, shrinking the vast, wild country of maybe into a single fenced acre. The true apocalypse, she understood now, is not the end of time but the theft of its mystery.

At night, she walked the old city, crossing the bridge where Calvin once condemned souls to hell, then the park where lovers now took selfies against the same river. She listened to the water, to languages she didn’t speak, to the irregular heartbeat of traffic lights blinking from green to red. Somewhere, a clock struck the hour; somewhere else, another answered a minute late. The discrepancy comforted her. Synchronization is slavery, she thought, and error is the last freedom. She breathed in, breathed out, and stepped into the next moment, unlabeled, unverified, alive.
