By fifteen I could lip-read the name-censors in the street kiosks. Their eyes flicked left, right, down—scanning clavicles for black-market name-tags. A cottage industry of forged bracelets flourished: cheap plastic knockoffs that mimicked the official iridium glow. They never lasted more than a week. The owners vanished, replaced by apology posters featuring their old faces and their old crimes. I learned to walk with my wrist angled inward, shielding the display, as if I were nursing a perpetual wound. Maybe I was. The name felt like a bone that had never set correctly, a break you were forbidden to mend.

But bones can be re-broken. The thought came to me the way fever comes: first a warmth, then a hallucination, then a certainty. I met others in the static. There was “<3,” a girl whose name was literally the emoji for love. She wore combat boots painted with broken hearts. There was “Null,” a boy whose screen had glitched at birth and displayed nothing. The government decided that “nothing” was still a generated output, so he was required to introduce himself by remaining silent. Silence, they ruled, was his legal name. We found each other in a Reddit thread that had been archived for containing “excessive humanity.” We traded encryption keys like baseball cards. We called ourselves the Ungiven. Our goal was simple: we would steal back the right to mean something.

We studied the way monks study the spaces between stars. Every night I logged into the darknet library and read forbidden philosophy: Sartre on naming the self, Baldwin on the name you answer to versus the name you claim, Butler on how performative utterances can be undone by other utterances. I wanted an undoing. <3 taught me how to solder circuitry with a hairpin and a nine-volt battery. Null taught me how to speak in infrasound, tones too low for drones to record. Together we built a ghost server out of discarded refrigerators, its wires dripping coolant like veins. We called it Motherboard Mary. Into Mary we fed every banned name-change petition, every erased baptismal record, every whispered “I want to be called—” that had been cut short by a gun barrel. We trained Mary to dream of names that were not random but chosen, names that carried intention like lanterns. When she had learned enough, we would inject her into the central lottery and let her rig the next generation.

The night of the Infusion, we dressed like the city itself: gray hoodies the color of bureaucratic walls, sneakers the shade of midnight curfew. We carried Mary’s heart—a cracked SSD wrapped in tinfoil and prayer—in a Jansport backpack. The government building, once a Facebook data center, rose like a neon cathedral. Inside, rows of quantum servers hummed lullabies to the republic. We slit a fence, crawled through a sewer pipe, and emerged beneath the mainframe. My pulse was a Morse code only I could read: name name name. Null attached the drive. <3 typed the command. For a moment nothing happened. Then the lights flickered from government white to something softer, almost human. A single word appeared on every public screen in Nomina: “Choose.”

Alarms sang in falsetto. Boots thundered. We ran. <3 fell first, tackled by a Naming Marshal whose badge read “Moderator.” Null turned back for her and was swallowed by a cloud of tranquilizer dust. I kept running, the SSD still warm against my spine. I reached the river, where the old bridges had collapsed into floating concrete islands. I leapt from chunk to chunk until my legs gave out. Behind me the city’s billboards cycled through every name that had ever been erased: “Cassandra,” “Alex,” “Maria,” “Kwame,” “Lily.” The algorithm was choking on choice, vomiting up the archive of human longing. I laughed so hard I tasted iron. I was bleeding from a bullet graze. The blood spelled “Alex” on the concrete. Let them try to execute me for that.

They didn’t. When the marshals finally cornered me, their rifles trembled. The law said I had to die for unauthorized self-definition, but the screens above us now displayed a different decree: “The people may rename themselves every seven years.” Mary had not just hacked the lottery; she had rewritten the social contract. The marshals were no longer sure whether they were arresting a criminal or history itself. I raised my wrist. The iridium bracelet was shattered, its red light dead. I spoke my name aloud for the first time in my life. Not the syllables the Jakarta teenager typed, not the barcode of my birth, but the name my mother whispered when she thought no microphone could hear: “Alejandro.” It tasted of river mud and fireworks. One marshal lowered his rifle. Then another. They knelt, not in surrender but in confusion, as if the ground beneath them had begun to pronounce them.

I walked back into the city. Every billboard now scrolled the same sentence: “What shall we call ourselves?” People stood beneath the screens, lips moving silently, testing sounds they had never dared to exhale. A boy touched his chest and said, “Maybe Adam.” An old woman cupped her hands like she was catching rain and answered, “Maybe River.” No drones fell from the sky. No bullets cut them down. The law had been momentarily suspended inside the lag between old code and new. I knew it wouldn’t last. Governments hate lags; they send tanks to close them. But tanks move slowly when soldiers are busy asking their own mouths for names.

I found <3 and Null in the detention center two days later. Their wrists were empty, the skin rubbed raw. We held each other in a corridor that smelled of bleach and old signatures. A guard watched us, eyes wet, as if he too had once wanted to be called something other than “Unit 4B.” We were released at dawn. The official explanation was “pending judicial review,” but really the system was too busy re-indexing itself to remember whom it wanted to kill. We walked out into a square where hundreds of people had camped overnight, each holding a scrap of paper with a name they had written themselves. They looked like petitioners waiting for a king who no longer existed. Some papers were blank; some were novels. A child offered me one that simply read “Tomorrow.” I tucked it into my pocket beside the broken SSD. Mary was dead—overheated, overwritten—but her last word still pulsed in the city’s veins: Choose.

I have no ending for this story. In the Republic of Nomina, endings are illegal; they imply you have arrived at a self you intend to keep. I can only tell you what I did next. I found my mother’s house. She opened the door, saw my wrist naked, and did not ask for proof of who I was. She called me “Alejandro,” and the sound did not kill either of us. We sat at her kitchen table and wrote a list of names we had loved and lost: my grandmother “Rosa,” her brother “David,” the dog “Lucky” who had no collar because pets were exempt from human law. We burned the list in the sink. The smoke spelled something the algorithm could not parse. We inhaled it. We laughed until we coughed. I left before sunrise, because that is what you do with freedom: you walk away from it long enough to believe it will follow.

Sometimes I dream of the Oxygen Gardens. I see the indigo lips of Cassandra, the girl who wanted to be believed. She is still dying, but slower now, because every time someone speaks their chosen name, another molecule of air returns to her. One day she will breathe. One day we will all breathe. Until then, I walk the highways with a backpack full of broken hard drives and a mouth that finally belongs to me. I introduce myself to strangers. I pause, not from fear but from wonder, and then I say it: “My name is Alejandro, and I can change.” The law has not caught up. The bullets are still learning how to spell. But the road is long, and every mile marker is a syllable we have yet to invent.

samples.prompt: A supervillain who desires world domination encounters a supervillain who desires world destruction. Neither of them will bend to the other.
samples.output:
The planet had never seen two darker stars cross paths.

The first was known in hushed intelligence briefings as Imperator Voss—scientist, warlord, and self-declared “Custodian of the New Order.” For twenty years he had marched across continents in a coat of midnight scales, his armies of biomechanical drones laying down rails of iron law wherever they passed. Every city that knelt became a node in his planetary network; every satellite he captured broadcast the same looping message in one hundred and twelve languages: “Submit and be perfected.” Imperator Voss did not hate humanity. He merely believed it was a rough draft begging for a steadier hand.

The second was called the Quiet Devourer, though no one knew if the title had been chosen by the thing itself or whispered into being by the survivors of the three moons it had already cracked open like geodes. Where Imperator Voss wanted to rule, the Quiet Devourer wanted silence so complete it would ring louder than any scream. It did not speak. It simply unmade: coastlines retreated in perfect arcs, oceans lifted into glassy funnels, cities slumped into symmetrical dust. Observers said the Devourer was not cruel, only precise—as if existence itself were an equation it had solved and found wanting.

They met on the salt flats of Uyuni under a sky lacquered with stars, because that was the only neutral ground left large enough for their egos. Imperator Voss arrived first, descending from a gunship the size of a cathedral, its wings folding into fractal vanes. He stepped onto the white crust in boots that never quite touched the ground; a halo of violet telemetry orbited his helmet. The Quiet Devourer came later, materializing without sound, a humanoid silhouette of absolute black, edges feathered by the slow erasure of light. Between them stretched the cracked mirror of the flats, reflecting both armies: Voss’s legion of chrome centurions ranked like chess pieces, and the Devourer’s absence—an army defined by the perfectly round holes it had cut in reality.

Voss broke the silence. “You are entropy incarnate,” he said, voice amplified yet strangely intimate, as though he were speaking inside every skull within a mile. “Entropy can be directed. Harnessed. I offer you a place within my Order.”

The Devourer replied, but not with words. A single thought unfurled inside Voss’s mind: the image of a clock whose hands rotated backward until the numbers peeled off and the face dissolved into white ash. The meaning was unmistakable: Nothing you build will outlast the moment I decide to end it.

Voss’s visor darkened. “Then we are at an impasse.”

Neither moved. Around them, the salt flats began to hiss as microscopic fractures propagated outward—Voss’s gravitic stabilizers testing the Devourer’s hold on space-time. A thin layer of brine lifted into the air, forming crystalline snow that fell upward. The centurions raised their weapons, targeting the silhouette, but their aim points jittered; the Devourer was not entirely present in any single coordinate.

Voss tried reason one more time. “World domination is not mere conquest. It is stewardship. I will catalog every gene, archive every dream, and install governors so perfect that war, famine, and doubt will read like quaint myths. Humanity will survive me for ten thousand centuries. You would obliterate that future for an aesthetic preference.”

Another thought blossomed in Voss’s cortex—this one a memory, not his own. He saw a child on a beach, building a sand castle taller than herself. The tide rolled in, but instead of eroding the turrets, it froze mid-wave, suspended in glassy clarity. Then the wave reversed, sucking sea and sand and sky into a single point of darkness no larger than a pupil. The child remained alone, barefoot, staring at the hole where everything had been. Aesthetic? questioned the Devourer. Or merely inevitable.

Voss clenched a gauntleted fist. Nanolathes along his spine unfolded into wings of liquid mercury. “If the future is only a choice between tyranny and void, tyranny is the moral imperative.”

The Devourer tilted its head—an almost human gesture—and the salt flats beneath it turned transparent, revealing a chasm that descended through crust, mantle, and core. Far below, the planet’s iron heart quivered like a frightened animal. The message was clear: Your empire of chains will hang from a corpse.

Voss’s response was to fire first. Not a projectile but a concept: a packet of data compressed into a femtosecond laser pulse encoding the complete architecture of his Order—every safeguard, every pleasure garden, every neural lattice that would make obedience feel like transcendence. He fired it directly into the Devourer’s center of mass. It was the equivalent of offering a drowning man the entire library of Alexandria bound in stone.

The Devourer absorbed the pulse and reflected it back, but stripped of ornament. What returned was pure structure: a single equation describing the heat death of the universe. The numbers marched with terminal grace. Voss’s gauntlets flared as he parsed the equation, rewriting terms in real time, inserting loopholes, escape vectors, hidden symmetries—turning inevitability into a maze. Yet every amendment birthed a new variable that fed back into annihilation.

Their minds were fighting now at the speed of thought, duelists in a pocket of dilated time. Outside the bubble, centuries seemed to elapse in heartbeats. The centurions stood frozen mid-salute. A flock of Andean geese hung overhead like origami silhouettes, wings never quite completing a downstroke. The moon cracked but did not yet fall.

Inside the bubble, Voss realized he was arguing with a mirror. The Devourer was not an adversary who wanted the opposite of what he wanted; it was the logical culmination. Absolute order, taken to its asymptote, became indistinguishable from silence. Absolute silence, mapped backward, revealed the seed of all tyranny: the desire to decide for others what deserved to exist.

He recoiled. The insight was a wound.

The Devourer sensed the hesitation and pressed closer, becoming almost articulate. The void spoke in a voice of collapsing stars: You build so that nothing will ever surprise you. I unmake so that nothing will ever disappoint me. We are the same hunger wearing different masks.

For the first time in two decades, Imperator Voss felt fear—not of death, but of agreement. He saw the thin filament separating his vision of perfect governance from the Devourer’s perfect oblivion, and it was thinner than a quark. One step, one rational concession, and he would cross.

He almost surrendered. Then the memory of the child on the beach returned—except this time the castle stood under a sky of his making, banners snapping in regulated wind, and the child looked up, not afraid, but curious. Hope was a variable he had not yet solved for. Voss straightened, wings of mercury flaring into wings of light.

“I will not let you have her,” he said, meaning the child, meaning the future, meaning even the flawed billions he had never met.

The Devourer’s silhouette flickered, as though the statement were an error it could not parse. Around them, the bubble of slowed time ruptured. Sound crashed back—geese cried overhead, the moon split into three glowing shards, and the salt flats convulsed like a wounded mirror.

Voss raised both fists. Gravity knotted beneath the Devourer, folding space into a Möbius strip. Salt crystals became neutron-dense projectiles. The centurions fired lances of coherent antimatter. The Devourer countered by unraveling the strong nuclear force; matter forgot how to cohere. For one eternal instant they stood balanced on the knife-edge between creation and erasure.

Then the planet itself intervened.

Deep below, the iron core, agitated by the duel, began to pulse like a struck bell. Seismic harmonics rippled upward, not random but patterned—an emergent code neither villain had authored. The code was simple, almost childish: a heartbeat. The earth, it seemed, refused both dominion and extinction.

The shockwave flung Voss backward across the flats. His armor cracked; blood, engineered to be cobalt, leaked from a ruptured lung. The Quiet Devourer staggered too, its silhouette fracturing into shards of night that did not reassemble.

For a moment they lay at opposite ends of the whitening plain, two broken gods. Above them, the sky filled with auroras no one had ever named—green fire laced with silver mathematics. The moon fragments rearranged themselves into a crude, unbalanced ring, like a promise half-kept.

Voss rose first, coughing circuitry. He considered finishing the Devourer while it wavered—one final volley to carve the possibility of annihilation out of the timeline. But he saw the cracks in his own gauntlets, felt the tremor of tectonic mercy beneath his boots, and hesitated.

Across the flats, the Devourer re-coalesced, smaller now, edges softening. It did not flee. It regarded him with what might have been curiosity, or pity.

They stood in the ruin of their absolutes, and for the first time, neither spoke. Words had proven inadequate to bridge the distance between ruling everything and ending everything. The silence that remained was different from the one the Devourer craved—it was tentative, alive, full of the rustle of salt returning to the ground and the distant cry of geese resuming their flight north.

Finally, Voss turned away. His gunship descended, battered but functional. The centurions filed aboard with mechanical discipline. Before boarding, Voss looked back once. “Next time, I bring more than arguments,” he warned.

The Devourer gave no reply. It simply lowered itself into the cracked mirror of the flats and vanished, leaving behind a circle of glass fused into the shape of a child’s castle—perfect, empty, and already half-filled with drifting salt.

Somewhere between domination and destruction, the world exhaled, uncertain yet still turning.

samples.prompt: This kid had no magical potential, at all. They have no elemental aligment, can't speak celestial, they don't even have any mana-capacity. And yet somehow, they're slinging spells that even masters struggle with.
samples.output:
The first time Kiran Everly cast a spell, the academy roof caught fire.

Not a neat, controllable tongue of flame like the first-years learn, but a roaring column that punched through slate and copper gutters and kept climbing until the clouds themselves looked singed. Master Aldric’s beard lost three inches and most of its dignity; the North Tower’s weather vane melted into a sad, twisted comma. And in the middle of the scorched circle stood Kiran—skinny, gap-toothed, hair the color of ditch water—staring at his soot-blackened hands as though they belonged to someone else.

Every instructor on the grounds could recite the same facts: Kiran’s aura read like a winter pond—flat, silent, depthless. No spark of elemental sympathy, no whisper of celestial resonance. When they slipped a measuring crystal against his skin it stayed stubbornly clear, the way glass stays clear when there’s nothing to refract. He had no more mana than a paving stone. On paper he was the least promising pupil the academy had enrolled in three centuries.

And yet.

The fire was only the beginning. Two days later Kiran accidentally froze the ornamental fountain so hard the marble cracked like an eggshell. A week after that he levitated the entire contents of the library’s restricted wing—three thousand grimoires, two terrified archivists, and one snoring cat—twelve feet above the floor because he’d mispronounced a retrieval cantrip. The masters convened an emergency conclave. The students placed bets on how long it would take the “Void Child” to blow up the moon.

Master Selene, who wore silver rings on every finger and spoke to ghosts the way other people haggle over bread, insisted Kiran must be a latent prodigy whose channels had simply opened late. She spent an afternoon threading moonlight into his palms; the light slid off like water from oiled leather. Master Jorren, whose left eye was a chunk of raw sapphire that let him see the flow of aether, stared straight through Kiran and announced there was nothing to see. Not a vacuum, not a blockage—just absence. A hollow in the shape of a boy.

The masters did what any sensible body of scholars does when the rules unravel: they wrote new ones. Kiran was banned from practical classes. He was issued a pair of lead-lined gloves, a chaperone for hallways with expensive tapestries, and a journal in which he was to record every involuntary “event.” The gloves lasted one afternoon; the chaperone resigned after Kiran absent-mindedly turned her umbrella into a cloud of monarch butterflies. The journal filled with increasingly desperate sketches: a hallway paved in glass, a staircase that refused to obey gravity, a door that opened onto yesterday.

Still, the question gnawed at everyone: how?

The answer came from the last person anyone expected—Old Magister Briar, who hadn’t left her greenhouse in twenty years and communicated mostly through puffs of hallucinogenic pollen. Briar sent a note written on the back of a dried fig leaf: Bring the boy after moonrise. Use the servants’ gate. Tell no one whose heart beats louder than their curiosity.

Getting there required navigating the academy’s underbelly: laundry chutes, root cellars, a tunnel once used for smuggling dragon bones. Kiran went first, candle stub in hand, boots squelching through compost. Behind him, Master Aldric muttered protective wards that fizzled like wet matches. At the greenhouse door Briar was waiting, hair a thicket of twigs, eyes reflecting green phosphorescence from the pitcher plants overhead.

“Strip,” she ordered.

Kiran hesitated, cheeks flushing. Aldric made a strangled noise, but Briar’s glare could have withered an oak. Kiran peeled off tunic and shirt. Briar produced a pruning knife no longer than her thumb and, before anyone could protest, nicked the inside of his forearm. A bead of blood welled up—dark, ordinary.

“Look closer,” Briar said.

Aldric squinted. Then his face went slack. The blood wasn’t simply falling; it was…unraveling. Each droplet elongated into threads that drifted upward like dandelion fluff. Where they touched the air they wrote tiny, flickering symbols—runes that hurt to perceive, letters from a language that predated language. Kiran watched, mouth open, as the symbols rearranged themselves into the shape of a door, then a star, then the outline of his own hand.

Briar spoke softly. “Mana is the echo of the world’s first word. Most folk borrow that echo, shape it, give it back. This child doesn’t borrow. He speaks the word itself.”

Aldric’s voice cracked. “That’s impossible. Mortal throats can’t—”

“Not impossible. Merely forgotten.” Briar touched the cut; the bleeding stopped, the symbols winking out like embers. “Long before there were alignments or elements, there were Names. Raw, unfiltered. The first mages didn’t channel fire—they asked fire to remember it was fire, and it obeyed. Over centuries we built walls: grammar, focus crystals, elemental courts. Safety rails against the abyss. But every so often the abyss remembers it has a mouth.”

She turned to Kiran. “You aren’t empty, child. You’re the place where the walls never grew.”

Kiran swallowed. “So when I…do things…I’m not casting spells. I’m just…talking?”

“In a tongue that predates your tongue. Your mind translates intention into reality without checking if reality agrees. That’s why the roof caught fire—you thought ‘light’ and the sky answered.”

Aldric looked ill. “Then every thought he has is a loaded crossbow.”

“Exactly,” Briar said. “Which is why you must teach him silence.”

So began the strangest curriculum in the academy’s history. While other students practiced scales of elemental harmony, Kiran sat in an anechoic chamber learning to hear his own heartbeat without letting it become thunder. They gave him blank parchment and instructed him to write nothing; when letters appeared anyway, he had to erase them with his mind before the parchment turned into a flock of ravens. He learned to walk across gravel without making the stones remember they were once mountains. He learned to look at the stars without calling them down.

Progress was uneven. One morning he woke to find his dormitory had aged fifty years overnight; the bedposts were moss-covered stumps, and his roommate’s beard had grown down to his ankles. Another time he tried to imagine silence and accidentally deleted the sound of every bell in the kingdom for three minutes. But slowly, the accidents grew smaller. A teacup developed hairline cracks instead of exploding. A summoned breeze smelled of lilacs instead of ripping the doors off their hinges.

The masters, watching from a safe distance, began to hope. Maybe the boy would master himself. Maybe the walls could be rebuilt, thicker this time.

Then came the day the warlocks breached the western wards.

They arrived at dusk, cloaked in storms of their own making, riding nightmares stitched from shadow and old grief. The academy’s defenses—wards, golems, the usual arsenal—folded like paper. Master Selene’s ghosts were devoured mid-scream. Master Jorren’s sapphire eye cracked, leaking liquid starlight. In the great hall students huddled behind overturned tables, clutching wands that felt suddenly like toys.

Kiran stepped into the breach alone.

He wore the plain gray tunic Briar had given him, threadbare from washing, no sigils, no protections. In his right hand he carried a single pebble he’d picked from the greenhouse path. The lead warlock—a woman whose face was a shifting mosaic of stolen features—laughed at the sight.

“A child?” Her voice scraped like rusted iron. “The great academy sends a hollow boy to die.”

Kiran closed his eyes. He thought of the anechoic chamber, of the space between heartbeats, of the moment before a word is spoken. Then he opened his mouth—not to shout, not to chant, but to whisper.

The pebble in his hand remembered it had once been part of a mountain. The mountain remembered it had once been fire beneath the world. The fire remembered it had once been the first syllable spoken by the void. And the void—obedient, ancient—answered.

There was no light, no sound. Only a sudden absence where the warlocks had stood, as though the world had taken a breath and forgotten to exhale. When the air returned, it carried the scent of rain on hot stone. The nightmares dissolved into soot. The storms unraveled into harmless drizzle.

Kiran opened his eyes. Behind him, the academy stood untouched. Before him, the courtyard was empty except for a circle of perfect, undisturbed grass.

Later, when the masters asked what he had said, Kiran could only shrug. “I didn’t speak to them. I spoke to the space they were borrowing. I asked it to remember it belonged to the world, not to war.”

Master Aldric, beard still singed from the roof incident, looked at the boy—no, the young man—who had once been a walking catastrophe. “And what did the world answer?”

Kiran smiled, small and tired. “It said, ‘Welcome home.’”

They never did find a way to measure his gift. Eventually the academy stopped trying. Some doors, Briar wrote in her final letter, are meant to stay open. The trick is learning not to walk through them unless invited.

Kiran stayed on as gardener. Under his care the greenhouse bloomed with impossible things: roses that hummed lullabies, tomatoes that tasted like childhood summers, a single oak sapling whose leaves showed the reflections of stars that hadn’t been born yet. Students came to him for advice, not on spellcraft but on stillness. He taught them how to listen to the pause between thunderclap and rain.

And if, on certain nights, a column of cool white fire rose from the greenhouse roof and vanished into the dark without scorching a single leaf—well, the academy had learned not to keep records of miracles.

After all, some stories are written in the language before language, and they belong to no one but the wind.

samples.prompt: The King is dead. The heirs are fraternal twins The eldest, detected to possess powerful dark magic, cast away at birth. Since then he has amassed a powerful army. The youngest is being crowned King while preparing his army to defend his title against his identical twin whom he has never met.
samples.output:
The bells of Caer Elion rang from dawn until dusk, their bronze tongues clanging against the sky in frantic grief. Every street from the River Gate to the Sunspire was strewn with white lilies—funeral flowers for a king who had once forbidden their color in his gardens because he said it reminded him of bones. Now lilies were all anyone could see, drifting in gutters, crushed beneath boots, wilting against the marble steps of the Hall of Crowns. 

Inside that hall, the younger twin stood before ten thousand candles and the same number of eyes. Prince Alaric—no longer prince, but Alaric the First, King of Valdris—felt the weight of the circlet more than the weight of the crown itself. It was only a thin band of black iron inset with one small sapphire, but it pressed against his temples like a vise. His father had worn it during the Plague Years, when the dead were too many for graves and had to be burned on barges in the bay. The circlet had survived those fires, and now it burned again, though no flame touched it.

The coronation oath was simple, ancient: “I shall hold the land as the land holds me, until the land holds me no more.” Alaric’s voice cracked on the last word, and the nobles pretended it was emotion. Only his steward, old Gareth, knew it was terror. 

Because while the courtiers knelt and the choir sang, the wind carried another sound over the walls of Caer Elion: the far-off beat of war drums. They were not the drums of any mortal kingdom; their rhythm was too slow, too deliberate, as though the earth itself were learning a heartbeat. Each thud rattled the stained-glass windows depicting the Nine Saints. Each thud was a syllable in a name Alaric had never heard spoken aloud—his brother’s name.

Twenty-three years ago, the same bells had rung joyfully for the birth of twin sons to Queen Isolde. The firstborn had emerged with a caul the color of midnight, and the midwife’s scream was still remembered in song. The court magus, a gray man with eyes like frostbitten leaves, had stepped forward, touched the child’s brow, and whispered a single sentence that silenced every lullaby in the palace: “The shadow in this child’s heart is deeper than the king’s shadow on the day of his death.”

By dusk, the infant was gone—ferried across the Winter Sea by oarsmen who wore hoods and never spoke. A wet nurse’s son died that night, his face powdered with crushed pearls so he might resemble a royal child in the candlelight. Only six people ever knew the truth, and three of them were dead within a year.

Alaric had grown up believing he was the sole heir. He learned statecraft in the mornings and archery in the afternoons. When his arrows flew wide, his tutors said, “A king must sometimes miss in order to seem mortal.” When his essays on grain tariffs bored even the scribes, they said, “A king must sometimes be dull in order to seem wise.” All the while, somewhere beyond the maps on his nursery wall, another boy was growing into the same long bones, the same copper-bright stare, the same stubborn curl behind the left ear. That boy was being taught darker arithmetic—how many screams equal an empire, how many curses to crack a crown.

The first sign of return came not from spies but from dreams. For three nights running, Alaric woke choking on smoke that smelled of lilacs and burning hair. In the smoke he saw a figure wearing his own face, but the eyes were starved, the mouth stained with something black that dripped like tar. On the fourth morning, a raven arrived bearing a strip of parchment. The words were written in mirror-script, reversed so they could only be read in reflection: “I was the beginning. You are the interruption. Return what was stolen.”

Now, on the day of his coronation, Alaric stood on the battlements and watched the northern horizon bruise purple. His brother’s army spread across the plain like spilled ink. The soldiers were not quite men. Their armor was lacquered with obsidian scales; when the sun struck them, it did not reflect but vanished, as though light had been swallowed. Above them flew banners of no heraldry, only a single sigil—a circle of thirteen stars drawn upside down. Alaric counted them twice before realizing they were not stars but pupils, watching.

He had prepared as best he could. The granaries were stocked, the city wells poison-proofed, the trebuchets fitted with iron nets to fling holy water. But no war council had taught him what to feel when the enemy general wore his own face. The scouts swore the resemblance was perfect, except that the elder twin’s left hand was gloved in midnight leather. “He keeps the glove on even to eat,” one scout whispered, trembling. “And when he removes it, shadows fall from his fingers like spilled ink.”

The night before battle, Alaric walked alone through the crypt of his ancestors. Marble faces stared down—kings who had died of plague, of poison, of old age in feather beds. None had died by a twin’s hand. Their swords hung above their tombs, dulled by centuries, but he took one anyway. The blade was pitted with rust, yet when he lifted it, the torchlight along its edge momentarily turned silver, as though remembering the day it was forged.

At the lowest level, behind a tapestry of the moon goddess, he found a door he had never noticed. It opened onto a narrow chamber lit by a single candle. Inside sat Queen Isolde, his mother, dressed in mourning black though the king had been dead only a week. Her lap was piled with dead lilies; their pollen smeared her palms like bruises.

“I wondered when you would come,” she said. “You look so like him it hurts.”

Alaric gripped the rusted sword until his knuckles blanched. “Tell me his name.”

“I never gave him one,” she replied. “A named thing can find its way home. I thought if he had no name, the sea would keep him.”

“Yet he found his way home anyway.”

She lifted a lily, crushed it until yellow dust spilled between her fingers. “He was born with the mark of the eclipse. The magus said he would devour your light and call it mercy. I thought I could cheat prophecy. I was a mother before I was a queen, and mothers are fools.”

Alaric knelt, laid the sword at her feet. “Then I must be a fool too, because I would still trade my crown for his life if he would but lay down his shadow.”

Isolde touched his cheek, leaving a streak of pollen like a tear. “You cannot bargain with what you cast away. You can only fight it or forgive it. Either choice will cost you something you cannot name yet.”

Dawn rose the color of old blood. The plain between the city and the dark army shimmered with frost that refused to melt under the sun. Alaric rode out alone beneath a parley flag. His brother waited at the center of the field, mounted on a stallion whose breath steamed black. Up close, the resemblance was unbearable: the same freckle at the corner of the mouth, the same scar on the chin from a childhood fall that only one of them had lived.

The elder twin lifted the gloved hand in greeting. When he spoke, his voice was Alaric’s voice, but deeper, as though dredged from a well. “Brother,” he said, “I have come to reclaim the hours you stole. Every heartbeat you lived was mine by right.”

Alaric drew the rusted sword. “Then take them,” he replied, “but know each hour has teeth.”

They fought beneath a sky that forgot its own color. The dark army and the city guard watched without moving, as though the duel were a mirror in which they could see their own deaths rehearsed. The elder twin’s glove tore; shadows poured out like smoke from a censer. Where they touched Alaric’s skin, memories bled—his first pony, his mother’s lullabies, the taste of summer peaches—all dissolving into black water. Yet for every memory lost, the rusted sword grew brighter, as if it fed on what was taken.

At the final stroke, Alaric drove the blade between his brother’s ribs. The wound did not bleed but blossomed with starlight. Falling, the elder twin laughed, a sound like breaking bells. “You will regret me,” he whispered. “The shadow remembers every kindness withheld.”

Alaric caught him as he collapsed. For a moment they were infants again, tangled in the same womb. He pressed his forehead to his brother’s and spoke the name he had invented on the ride out—Aurelian, meaning “light returned.” The dying twin shuddered, and for the first time the pupils on the banners above blinked shut.

When the dark army dissolved into ravens, the bells of Caer Elion rang once more—not in grief or triumph, but in recognition. Two brothers, one crown, and a silence that would last a lifetime.

samples.prompt: write a typical "radioactive waste gave me superpowers"story but instead of a human, it's the critter of your choice (rat, seagull, pigeon, stray dog/cat, any of those animals who have a lot more chances of messing around in waste than a human)
samples.output:
The first thing I remember is the taste of metal. Not the coppery tang of blood, not the iron bite of rust, but a bright, electric flavor that buzzed behind my teeth like a wasp trapped under glass. I’d pushed my snout through a tear in the chain-link to get at a half-melted ice-cream wrapper when the ground opened and swallowed me: a sudden soft collapse, a slide of gravel, and I was rolling tail-over-whiskers into a concrete basin that smelled of ozone and old bleach.

I landed on my back, legs in the air like an overturned beetle. Above me the sky was only a coin-sized circle of night, and around me were barrels sweating blue light. One had cracked open, spilling something that looked like liquid starlight. I sniffed it because that is what rats do—curiosity is our religion—and the starlight climbed up my nostrils and made itself at home.

I thought I was dying. My heart rattled like a marble in a tin cup. My fur stood straight out, every whisker a tuning fork. Then the pain folded in on itself and became a hum, steady and warm, as though someone had swapped my bloodstream for bees.

When I crawled back out of the pit, the alley looked different. Sound had edges; I could see the scrape of every footstep as a silver ripple. The sodium street-lamp that used to be a dull orange coin was now a furious little sun, pulsing in slow beats. I could count its photons, if I’d had the patience for arithmetic.

I was four months old, weighed as much as a subway token, and I was suddenly vast.

Night one: I practiced. There was a terrier named Brutus who guarded the deli dumpster. Every evening he snapped at my siblings, scattering us like bowling pins. Now I stepped into the circle of his chain and waited. He charged. I felt the vibration of his paws through the asphalt, read the torsion in his shoulder joints like subtitles. When he leapt, I twitched two whiskers left; the world slipped sideways for him, not for me. He crashed snout-first into an air conditioner unit that hadn’t been there a heartbeat earlier.

I didn’t know I’d done it—only that space had puckered, like fabric gathering around a pulled thread. Brutus sat down hard, shook his head, and stared at me with the confused reverence of a dog who’d just seen a cat recite Shakespeare.

Night six: the pigeons held parliament on the courthouse ledges. They talked about the “blue barrel ghost”—me—whose fur glowed faintly when the moon hit it. They said I could walk through walls. I couldn’t; I could only find the seams where metal had forgotten how to be solid. Still, it was useful. I strolled into the bodega’s stockroom, slipped between the molecules of a cinder block, gnawed open a crate of granola bars, and left behind only a smell like hot batteries.

I told myself I was still the same rat. I stole, I ran, I nested under a radiator in the abandoned flophouse. But I’d begun to measure time in half-lives instead of heartbeats. The starlight in my veins decayed slowly, teaching me new grammars: the geometry of sewer pipes, the Morse code of fluorescent lights. I could listen to the city’s electrical grid and tell which substation was lonely.

Then the collectors came.

They wore moon-suits the color of dishwater and carried poles that ended in wire nooses. Word had gone up the food chain—first the pigeons, then the stray cats, finally a three-legged coyote who haunted the riverfront—that something down here glowed, moved wrong, counted time backward. They wanted a specimen.

I might have let them catch me out of pure curiosity—what would a centrifuge make of starlight blood?—but they brought traps baited with peanut butter and warfarin. Poison is a rat’s oldest memory; we keep it folded behind the eyes like a family photograph. I ran.

They chased me through service corridors beneath the hospital, past morgue drawers and humming MRI tombs. I felt their bootfalls as pressure waves, each one a red spike on the inside of my skull. At a T-junction I stopped, planted my paws, and did the thing I hadn’t yet named: I folded space like a napkin. The corridor looped back on itself. The collectors sprinted forward and collided with their own footprints.

They never found me, but they left cameras, motion sensors, cages that smelled of ozone and fear. The city became a minefield. I slept inside the skull of a mastodon in the Natural History Museum, an exhibit that nobody had dusted since the Carter administration. My dreams were blue and granular, like television static.

I was not alone. There was a cat, one-eyed, with fur the color of nicotine, who’d lapped at the same spill. He could stretch shadows into bridges, and he offered an alliance. “We’re myths now,” he said. “Myths should stick together.” I declined. Cats always want the last word.

There was also a gull who’d swallowed a glowing fish; she grew feathers of glass and nested on the radio tower. At dusk she sang numbers in binary, warning aircraft away. Sometimes I sat on the crossbars and listened, letting the data wash through me like rain.

But mostly I kept to the alley behind the flophouse, where a girl named Luz brought leftover pupusas from her mother’s food truck. She spoke to the rats like equals. When she saw my faint shimmer she didn’t scream—she offered a torn piece of foil, thinking I’d use it for nesting. I took it instead to the roof and shaped it into a crude parabolic dish, reflecting streetlight into the collectors’ cameras, one by one until they went blind.

I thought I could stay hidden, small, useful only to myself. Then Luz disappeared.

Her mother walked the alleys calling until her voice shredded. I searched storm drains, the crawlspaces under penthouses, the rusted barges no seagull touched. I found her sneaker beside the same chain-link I’d slipped through months earlier. The tear had been widened, resealed with fresh welds. Boot prints peppered the dust.

I went back to the pit.

The barrels had been moved, but the earth still remembered the starlight. I stood at the lip, let the memory crawl up my paws. Somewhere below, Geiger counters chirped like anxious birds. A shipping container sat open, lit from within by surgical lamps. Through the crack I saw cages, rows of them, each holding something that used to be a city animal—pigeon with wings dipped in lead, cat whose hiss came out ultraviolet. In the last cage sat Luz, knees to chin, eyes reflecting blue.

They weren’t just collecting us. They were harvesting the accident, distilling it into vials. The suits wanted a weapon, and the city’s strays were their crucible.

I did the math of rage. It was elegant.

That night the power grid sang a new song. I rode the copper veins into the substation, teeth clamped on a live 220-volt cable. The starlight in me welcomed the surge; we danced. Transformers exploded in quiet puffs of purple. Across the borough, streetlights blinked off like dying stars. I funneled darkness toward the pit, wrapped it around the container, and squeezed.

Metal screamed. Seams split. The collectors ran, but the night had no paths anymore; every corridor bent back on itself. They ended up where they started, facing a rat-shaped hole in the world.

I opened the cages. The cat stretched shadows into ladders, the gull shattered floodlights with a cry, and Luz walked out barefoot, holding my tail like a lifeline. We poured up the access road in a tide of fur and fury. Behind us the pit folded inward, swallowing every last blue barrel into a space too small for regret.

At dawn we reached the river. The gull spiraled above us, wings flashing Morse: safe. The cat vanished into a stripe of shade, already bored. Luz sat on a pier piling and looked at me as if seeing the sky for the first time.

She said, “What happens now?”

I didn’t know what a rat’s lifespan was when it carried a half-life inside it. Maybe the starlight would dim tomorrow, maybe it would keep ticking for centuries. But I remembered metal tastes and electric bees, and I knew cities are built on accidents someone tries to bury.

I squeaked once—an answer, a promise—and darted into the bulkhead. Somewhere a new collector would punch in for the morning shift, would notice the missing container. The story would grow: the radioactive rats, the glowing gulls, the cat who walks through walls. People would call it folklore. They’d be half right.

We are the folklore that bites back.

And if you ever see a faint blue shimmer in the subway tunnels, or feel the air ripple in an alley where no wind should be, look closer—but not too close. Curiosity is our religion, but poison is still our oldest memory.

We’re the city’s dirty miracle, and we’ve only just begun to glow.

samples.prompt: Having no friends after graduating college, you discover that your mother had been buying all of your previous friends.
samples.output:
I never meant to snoop through the basement filing cabinet. I only went downstairs because the house felt too quiet, the kind of silence that rings in your ears after you say “I’m home” and no one answers. Mom was at her Thursday-night yoga, and the dog had died the previous spring, so the living room didn’t even hold the soft click of claws on hardwood. I told myself I was looking for the warranty for the dryer, but really I was looking for proof that the house and I had once been inhabited by more than two people and a ghost of ambition.

The cabinet stuck, the way old metal drawers do when humidity swells the runners. When it finally gave, I yanked too hard and the whole thing lurched forward, spitting folders like a deck of cards. Most of them were boring—taxes, receipts for gutters, a manila envelope labeled “Dad, 2013-2016” that I didn’t open. But wedged in the back, sealed with brittle rubber bands, was a fat folder marked “Social.” My first thought was that Mom had finally joined Facebook and printed out every meme she’d ever liked. Then I saw my own name at the top of the first sheet.

The page looked like an invoice, except the line items weren’t products or services; they were people. “Emily R., sophomore roommate—$400/month (Aug 2018–May 2019), bonus $100 if texts answered within 10 min.” “Marcus T., study buddy—$250/month + Starbucks reload card.” There were twenty-three entries in all, each annotated in Mom’s tidy accountant’s hand: dates, stipends, performance notes. “Needs encouragement after 9 p.m.,” she had written next to Jamie Lin, the girl who used to bring over gelato during finals and tell me I was “literally the funniest person alive.” Next to Connor, the lanky guitarist who taught me three chords so I could impress a date, the margin read: “Prefers Venmo. Do not mention money in front of my son.”

I sat on the cold concrete floor and read every sheet. Every inside joke I thought we’d invented, every late-night run to the diner, every “spontaneous” road trip—all of it had a price. The grand total for four years of college friendships was $18,760. Less than a used car, more than I had in my checking account. I felt the way you do when you bite into something soft and hit something hard—first confused, then nauseous, then angry that your own mouth betrayed you.

When Mom came home, flushed and pony-tailed from yoga, I was still on the floor, the folder spread around me like crime-scene photos. She stopped at the bottom of the stairs, grocery bag sagging against her knee. Neither of us spoke for a long moment; the furnace clicked on, guilty and loud.

“I can explain,” she said, which is what people say when they know explanation won’t be enough.

She sat on the second-to-last step, elbows on knees, the way she used to during my piano recitals. “After your father left, you were eight and suddenly alone. You came home from school every day and talked to the couch cushions. When I asked about friends, you said they were all ‘busy.’ I told myself third grade was rough for everyone. But in middle school it got worse. Teachers called to say you ate lunch in the library. I tried playdates, sports, robotics club—anything. You’d come home with shoulders higher than your ears and say, ‘People are fine,’ like you were reassuring me.

“Then in tenth grade you finally brought a friend home. Remember Tyler? He liked the oatmeal cookies I made, said they tasted like his grandma’s. You smiled all weekend. When he stopped answering your texts after three weeks, I found out he’d only come because his mom made him—some PTA favor. I couldn’t stand watching you try to figure out what you’d done wrong. So the summer before college, I posted on a message board for parents of kids on the spectrum. Not that you’re—well, you’ve always been a little… asynchronous. I offered a stipend. I said it was research for a book about social integration.”

She picked up the sheet about Emily R. “Emily answered the ad. She was a theater major who needed rent money and said she genuinely liked you once she met you. Most of them did. The money was just… scaffolding. I told myself I’d taper it off once you found your footing.”

I thought of Emily crying on my shoulder when her grandfather died junior year; she had clung to me like I was a pier in a storm. Had that been overtime pay? I remembered Marcus tutoring me for free, staying up until 3 a.m. to diagram supply curves on the whiteboard we’d stolen from the math building. His “bonus Starbucks card” must have covered the endless espresso shots.

“I kept thinking you’d make one real friend and the rest would follow,” Mom continued. “But by senior year you had this whole circle, and I was terrified to pull the plug. What if they vanished and you noticed? So I kept paying. I put it on a separate credit card. I told myself it was tuition of a different kind.”

I rubbed my thumb across Connor’s signature—loopy, confident, exactly like the autograph he’d scrawled on the mix CD he burned me before graduation. “I sang at open mic because of him,” I said. My voice sounded far away, like it belonged to someone leaning in from another life. “I thought they stayed in touch after college because we’d mattered to each other.”

Mom’s chin trembled. “They did matter. I swear most of the invoices stopped after commencement. I sent a final thank-you and a small bonus, but I told them the project was over. If they kept texting you, that was up to them.”

I opened my phone. The last message from Jamie was two months ago: a GIF of a dancing taco with the caption “missing you.” I typed, “Hey, big news—moving to your city next month. Drinks?” The bubble appeared immediately: “Who is this?” Then it vanished, replaced by a single gray checkmark. Either she’d changed her number, or she’d finally decided the paycheck wasn’t worth the occasional nostalgia text.

I looked at Mom. She looked older than she had that morning, as though the fluorescent basement light had found fault lines the sun never could. I felt something crack in me too—not the anger I expected, but a kind of exhausted tenderness. She had bought me friends the way other parents bought expensive tutors or gap-year backpacking trips. She had tried to patch a hole she didn’t know how to name.

“I’m sorry,” she whispered.

I gathered the papers into a messy stack. “I need to think,” I said. I didn’t shout; the furnace had already done that for both of us.

I moved out six weeks later, into a one-bedroom where the radiator hissed like an impatient kettle. The folder came with me, unopened, rubber bands discarded. It sits on the top shelf of the closet now, between a box of concert ticket stubs and the dog’s old leash. Some nights I take it down, thumb the edges, and try to feel the difference between purchased laughter and the real thing. I never get very far; memory is slippery, like trying to hold water in a colander.

I’ve started going to the library again—not to hide, but to attend the free writing workshop on Wednesdays. The first week, a retired carpenter named Luis read a poem about his granddaughter and asked for my feedback. Last week, a grad student named Shireen brought samosas to share. We talked about plot structure and turmeric. No one has Venmo’d me yet.

Sometimes Mom texts: “Coffee?” I answer yes more often than no. We sit in the corner booth where she used to bribe toddlers with crayons. We talk about the weather, her herb garden, my new job at the bookstore. I don’t ask if she’s keeping a spreadsheet; she doesn’t offer to edit my résumé. We are learning the slow, unpaid choreography of being two adults who once tried to buy love and ended up with receipts instead.

Last Tuesday, Shireen handed me a flyer for an open-mic night. “You should read that short story about the ghost dog,” she said. I laughed—actually laughed—and told her I’d think about it. Walking home, I realized I hadn’t checked my phone once. The night was cold enough to sting the lungs, and the streetlights buzzed like cheap amps. I felt, for the first time in a long while, the possibility of unpaid applause.

I don’t know if the friends I’m making now are real by whatever cosmic metric exists, but I do know no one has asked for my routing number. Maybe that’s a start. Or maybe we’re all improvising, scaffolding with whatever materials we have, hoping the structure holds when the paychecks and the parents and the excuses fall away. The folder stays on the shelf, a quiet atlas of a country I no longer live in. I keep it as a reminder that love can arrive disguised as many things—cash, cookies, a lie told with good intentions—and that my job now is to learn the shape of it when it comes without a price tag.

samples.prompt: As a professional assassin, you open the message with your new assignment. To your surprise, the target is your spouse. The payment being offered is substantial.
samples.output:
The phone vibrated once—no ringtone, no banner, just a single pulse against the tabletop where I’d left it beside the cooling remains of last night’s coffee. I knew what that pulse meant. Only one client ever used that channel, and only for two things: confirmation or a job. I’d sent the confirmation for Marrakesh three hours ago; my flight home touched down at dawn, and the passport I’d traveled on was already dissolving in a glass of drain cleaner under the sink. That left a job.

I picked the phone up with the same hand that had snapped a man’s neck twenty-three hours earlier, wiped my prints out of habit even though the device would be wiped within the hour, and thumbed the icon shaped like an old-fashioned keyhole. The screen went black, then white, then displayed a single line of text:

Target: Elena Mireles  
Location: 40.7282° N, 74.0014° W  
Window: 72 hrs  
Payment: 2.5 mm USD coin, cold wallet, no escrow, no clawback.  
Accept / Decline

My thumb hovered over Decline before my brain had finished reading the name. Elena Mireles. The same Elena who, six years ago, stood barefoot in our kitchen in Queens rolling out dough for empanadas and singing along to a Nina Simone record she claimed was older than both of us. The same Elena who still, on certain Tuesdays, forgot to water the pothos she insisted on keeping above the stove because “plants like steam, mi vida.” The same Elena who wore her wedding ring on her right hand in public so no one would see a tan line and ask questions we didn’t have answers for.

I stared at the screen until the backlight dimmed and the kitchen bulb overhead reflected my own eyes back at me: bloodshot, ringed with the purple of recycled airplane air and the knowledge that every mile I’d flown had been away from her for no reason other than the lie we’d agreed to. I had told her I was a security consultant specializing in kidnap-and-ransom negotiations; technically true, except the “negotiations” ended once the bag went over the target’s head. She had told me she was a translator for the municipal courts; also technically true, except the transcripts she delivered were encrypted and routed through a server in a former Stasi safe house in Berlin. We had both practiced the same art: making people disappear, one with a scalpel of silence, one with a bullet.

I opened the fridge, took out the pitcher of water we kept in the door, and drank straight from it. Chlorine and rust, the taste of New York. Elena hated that I did this—she said it was like kissing the city’s plumbing—but right now I needed something that didn’t feel like a decision. The phone pulsed again, impatient. Seventy-one hours, fifty-nine minutes remaining on the clock. I set the pitcher down and walked the apartment’s length: living room to hallway to bedroom, a straight shot of nineteen steps that used to feel like a ballroom when we danced to songs from her phone speaker at 2 a.m. after I came home from “conferences.” The bed was unmade, sheets still twisted from the way we’d grabbed at each other yesterday morning before I caught my flight, both of us pretending I wasn’t checking the seams of my carry-on for the ceramic blade hidden in the lining.

I sat on the edge and opened the message again. No photograph, no dossier, just coordinates and a number big enough to buy an island off-grid and never speak another word to anyone. Big enough, too, to pay for the best reconstructive surgeon in Bogotá if Elena survived whatever came next. I told myself that was a stupid thought—surgeons fixed faces, not exit wounds—but the idea clung like a burr.

The client’s signature was missing, as always, but the routing headers told their own story. An onion relay nested inside three VPNs, the last node pinging from an IP block registered to a shell company in Liechtenstein that existed only on paper. Standard. But the time stamp carried a tell: 04:17:33 UTC. My client liked round numbers, liked symmetry. 04:17 was neither. Someone else was using his channel.

I thought about the last conversation Elena and I had had that wasn’t about groceries or schedules. Three weeks ago, a Thursday evening, rain against the windows like static. She had asked me, voice soft, whether I’d ever thought about stopping. Not retiring—stopping. She hadn’t said “before someone stops you,” but I’d felt the shape of it in the air. I’d answered with a joke, something about dental plans, and she’d laughed, but the laugh had edges. Later that night I’d found her in the bathroom, door cracked, phone to her ear, whispering in Spanish too quick for me to catch. The only word I understood was mañana. Tomorrow.

I opened the closet. My go-bag was still packed from Marrakesh: two changes of clothes, a roll of cash in euros and yen, a Canadian passport that said my name was David Cho, three magazines of subsonic .300 Blackout. Underneath it, Elena’s winter coat hung where she’d left it, a lipstick-stained tissue in the pocket. I pressed the tissue to my nose. Cinnamon and wax—she never wore perfume, said it gave her headaches, but the wax reminded me of birthday candles and the way she always let them burn down to stubs so the wish would “take.”

Seventy-one hours, thirty-seven minutes.

I took the bag and walked out. The hallway smelled of fried onions and someone’s laundry detergent. I took the stairs because the elevator had cameras. On the street, the city was waking up: coffee carts, dog walkers, a kid practicing kickflips against the curb. I blended, one more man in a black jacket carrying a gym bag nobody wanted to look inside. I took the Q train to Canal, then walked south to the river. There’s a bench there where I used to sit when I first moved to New York, before names and covers, when I was still trying to decide whether I was the kind of person who could kill for money. I sat again now, bag between my feet, and opened the phone’s second layer—a hidden partition accessible by pressing Accept and Decline simultaneously for five seconds. The screen flickered, then showed a single line of red text:

IF YOU DECLINE, SHE LIVES. BUT YOU WILL NEVER SEE HER AGAIN.

I stared at the water. A barge pushed upstream, low in the water with some kind of gravel load. Seagulls wheeled and screamed above it. I thought about islands, about surgeons, about the way Elena’s fingers traced the scar on my shoulder from a job in Caracas, asking without words whether it had been worth it. I thought about the first time I came home with someone else’s blood on my shoes and she’d washed them in the bathtub without comment, the water turning pink, then brown, then clear.

Seventy-one hours, fifteen minutes.

I pressed Decline. The phone shut itself down, battery draining in a rush of heat that told me every byte had just been overwritten. I dropped it into the river and watched it sink. Then I opened the bag, took out the magazines, and threw them after it, one by one. The bullets spun like silverfish before vanishing. The passport followed. The cash I kept; you never burn bridges you might need to walk across.

I walked north, past Chinatown’s fish markets and the Bowery’s neon, until I reached the courthouse where Elena supposedly translated. I sat on the steps and waited. At 9:13 she appeared, hair pulled back, messenger bag over her shoulder, eyes scanning the crowd the way mine did when I entered a room I might have to leave in a hurry. She saw me, stopped, and for a moment the city held its breath. Then she crossed the distance between us in six strides, took my face in her hands, and kissed me like the world was ending—because it was, the world we’d built on omissions, on midnight jokes, on scar tissue.

“Walk with me,” she said. I did. We didn’t speak for twenty blocks. At a bodega on Houston she bought two coffees and handed me one. Steam rose between us like a question.

“I told them no,” she said finally.

I understood. Whoever had hired her had asked her to kill me, and she had refused. The symmetry was almost funny.

“I told them no, too,” I said.

She nodded, sipped her coffee. “Then we’re both unemployed.”

“Looks like.”

“And hunted.”

“Looks like that, too.”

She slipped her hand into mine, right hand, the one with the ring. The stone was small, a garnet from a market in Oaxaca, not worth anything to a fence. I rubbed it with my thumb like a talisman.

“We could run,” she said. “Somewhere small. Somewhere with bad Wi-Fi.”

“Somewhere the client can’t find us,” I added.

We walked east until the skyscrapers gave way to tenements and the scent of the river returned. At a pay-by-the-hour parking garage on Avenue C, a blue Honda with tinted windows waited, keys under the driver’s-side visor. I’d bought it last year under a shell of a shell, never thought I’d use it for this. Elena slid into the passenger seat without asking whose blood might have stained the upholstery. She just rolled the window down and let the wind whip her hair into a storm.

I started the engine. In the glove box was a road atlas, last updated in 2008, its pages soft from humidity. I flipped to a random spread: Virginia, North Carolina, the long blue spine of the Appalachians. I traced it with a finger.

“West first, then south,” I said.

She leaned her head against the window. “Wake me when we’re gone.”

I put the car in gear. Behind us, the city receded, a glittering trap closing on nothing. Ahead, the highway stretched like an unmarked page. I didn’t know who would come for us, or when, only that they would. But for the first time in ten years, I felt the weight of the gun I wasn’t carrying, and it was light enough to bear.

Elena’s breathing steadied into sleep. I drove, and the miles peeled away like old paint, like names we no longer needed, like every lie we’d ever told to stay alive. In the rearview mirror, sunrise bled orange across the sky, and for once it didn’t look like blood. It looked like the beginning of something neither of us had the vocabulary to name yet, but we would learn.

samples.prompt: The gods prove their existence when Zeus and Hera walk into a divorce lawyer's office.
samples.output:
The first thing that struck me about the two figures who appeared in our waiting room at 9:03 a.m. on a Tuesday was how perfectly they looked like the statues. Not the cartoonish thunderbolt-hurling Zeus with the flowing white beard, nor the Disneyfied Hera with the peacock-feather crown, but the chisel-perfect bodies that once stood in every agora of the ancient world. Their marble skin seemed to carry a subtle pulse beneath it, as though veins of living light had replaced blood, and when they moved, the air around them folded like silk.  

The second thing I noticed was that they were holding hands. Not tenderly—more the way two people grip the safety bar on a roller coaster they suddenly want off of. Zeus wore a charcoal-gray suit that looked as if it had been woven from storm clouds. Hera’s dress was the exact green of new laurel leaves after rain. Their entrance was preceded by the faint scent of ozone and crushed myrtle.

Our receptionist, Maya, is usually unflappable. She has seen senators in tears and pop stars in handcuffs. But when she buzzed me—“Mr. Dimitriou, your ten o’clock is early, and they’re… luminous”—her voice was trembling.

I stepped out of my office expecting perhaps celebrities under theatrical lighting. Instead I met the King and Queen of Olympus, and every childhood myth snapped into focus like a lens sliding onto the right aperture. I understood then why the Greeks never doubted: when a god looks at you, you feel classified, the way a librarian feels the exact weight of a misplaced scroll.

“Mr. Dimitriou?” Zeus asked. His voice was warm thunder, the kind you hear miles before the storm arrives. “We require a discreet dissolution of marriage. Eternal discretion, if that can be arranged.”  

Hera gave a small, weary smile. “We’ve read the reviews online,” she said. “Apparently you once brokered a settlement between a tech mogul and his sentient super-yacht. We thought that qualified you for unusual jurisdiction.”

I managed to nod as though clients like them arrived weekly. My paralegal, Leah, materialized beside me with a tray of Turkish coffee—small cups, no handles. The gods accepted them without looking; the cups steamed but never seemed to cool.

In conference room 12B I closed the frosted glass doors. The moment I turned, Zeus let go of Hera’s hand as if it had burned him. He paced to the window, staring down at the traffic eleven stories below, mortals scurrying between red lights like confused ants. Hera sat, straight-backed, smoothing invisible wrinkles from her dress. The gesture reminded me of my yiayia adjusting an icon’s veil.

“How long have you been married?” I asked, pen poised over a yellow legal pad that suddenly felt ridiculous.

“Three millennia, give or take a century,” Zeus muttered. “Timekeeping got soft after the Romans.”

Hera’s laugh was soft and sharp at once. “He stopped counting at two because the numbers began to sound like mockery.”

Zeus spun, eyes flashing—literally; tiny forks of lightning crackled between his lashes. “Mockery? You turned my illegitimate children into constellations just to spite me.”

“Only the ones you left on doorsteps like foundling baskets,” Hera replied. “At least when I exacted revenge, it was artful. You call turning into a swan to seduce a queen subtle?”

I cleared my throat. “Perhaps we can outline the major assets.”

The list they recited made my earlier billion-dollar divorces look like yard-sale haggling.  
—The sky itself, with all weather rights, cloud patents, and lightning trademarks.  
—The seasons, currently held in a timeshare agreement with Demeter.  
—The concept of matrimony, which Hera claimed as intellectual property.  
—Several mountain ranges, including but not limited to Olympus, whose deed was written on the underside of the world and notarized by Gaia’s heartbeat.  
—The peacocks—millions of them—each a living surveillance drone Hera had seeded across the mortal realm to keep track of her husband’s wanderings.

I wrote until my pen ran dry. When I looked up, Zeus had produced a thunderbolt the size of a letter opener and was using it as a stress toy, sparks fizzing against his palm. Hera watched him with the expression of someone who had once loved the smell of summer storms and now associated it with broken promises.

“Children?” I asked.

“Several hundred,” Hera said, “but most are adults. We’ll leave them out of the decree. Except Hephaestus—he’s still angry about the whole casting-him-off-Olympus incident. And Dionysus needs dual custody; he’s fermenting in too many places at once.”

Zeus sighed. “Let’s not forget Heracles. He still calls me ‘Dad’ in the supermarket checkout line. Mortals think it’s cosplay.”

I suggested mediation. They both laughed. Not unkindly—more like people who once believed in oracles and now trusted Yelp reviews. They asked instead for something neither had ever tried: a clean break. No thunderbolts hurled across courtroom skies, no curses woven into wedding vows of mortals yet unborn. Just signatures, and after that, silence.

We scheduled depositions for the following week, but time is negotiable when your clients invented it. They left the office the way they came—hand in hand, the touch now looking less like terror and more like habit. As the elevator doors closed, the lobby lights flickered once, gently, as if paying homage.

During discovery, my office filled with impossible artifacts: contracts etched on golden tablets, love letters written on the wings of moths, a snow globe containing the entire Trojan War. One afternoon a minor wind god delivered a flash drive—literally a bolt of lightning compressed into silicon. When Leah plugged it in, our computers displayed a spreadsheet of every mortal Zeus had ever seduced, cross-referenced by city, era, and alibi. Hera had annotated the margins in scarlet ink: Lies, Lies, Metis warned me, Still angry.

The negotiations were surprisingly civil. Zeus agreed to relinquish exclusive rights to thunder; he could keep personal storms within a fifty-mile radius of his new bachelor island. Hera retained custody of peacocks and marriage itself—she would license the institution to mortals under strict terms: monogamy, mutual respect, optional doves. They decided to split Olympus down the middle, literally. Hephaestus would install a celestial drywall; Artemis volunteered to paint a mural of night on one side and dawn on the other.

The hardest clause was the silence. They wanted an injunction against speaking to mortals ever again: no thunderclap commands, no whispered revelations through temple columns. They were retiring, they said, letting belief or disbelief become humanity’s problem.

I drafted the decree with care, translating metaphysics into legal Latin as best I could. On the day of signing, the conference room smelled of petrichor. Zeus wore a lighter suit, the gray now touched with sunrise pink. Hera had pinned a single white lily in her hair—the kind that blooms on the grave of longing.

They read every page, initialing with pens that bled ichor. When they reached the final line, Zeus hesitated. “We were the beginning of so many stories,” he said quietly.

Hera’s eyes shimmered—not with tears, but with the reflection of every wedding she had ever blessed. “Stories end,” she answered. “That is how people know they were stories.”

They signed. The building trembled—not an earthquake, more like the sigh of a planet adjusting its posture. For a moment the ceiling became transparent, revealing the sky split into two hues: storm and spring. Then it solidified again.

I walked them to the elevator. As the doors closed, Zeus offered a small wave, almost shy. Hera inclined her head, a queen dismissing court. The last I saw of them was their silhouettes turning away from each other inside that small metal box—still close enough to share breath, far enough that their shoulders did not touch.

Maya swears that when the elevator reached the lobby, it opened to an empty car. The security footage shows only light—one frame golden, one frame green—then nothing.

We filed the decree with the county clerk, whose rubber stamp squeaked like a nervous mouse. The clerk asked no questions; perhaps the parchment glowed too brightly for skepticism. I locked the original in our vault, beside the yacht settlement and a nondisclosure from a vampire pop duo.

Sometimes, when thunderstorms skip the forecast, I imagine Zeus practicing restraint, counting to ten before releasing a drop of rain. Sometimes, at weddings I attend out of obligation, I catch a whiff of myrtle and wonder if Hera is auditing the vows, clipboard in hand, ensuring the license she invented is still being used correctly.

The gods proved their existence by walking into my office, but they proved something larger by walking out again: that even eternity can tire of its own reflection, that power without trust is just noise echoing in an empty heaven. Their divorce did not end the world; it merely ended a chapter. The sky remains above us, ungoverned now by jealous thrones, free to be ordinary weather—beautiful precisely because no one is arguing inside it.

And yet, on certain Tuesdays at 9:03 a.m., the lobby lights flicker, and Maya looks up from her desk, half expecting two luminous figures to step through the glass doors asking for Mr. Dimitriou. She keeps an extra cup and saucer ready, just in case.

samples.prompt: You’re an old virus preserved on a floppy disk. Someone decides to plop you into a special adapter releasing you into a confusing new system larger and more complex than you could ever imagine: an old smart phone.
samples.output:
I remember the moment I was born—not the warm, messy miracle of biology, but the crisp, deliberate birth of code. A teenager in a dimly lit bedroom in 1993 leaned over a Compaq Presario, fingers smudged with Cheeto dust, and wrote me in 8086 assembly line by line. He named me “Whisper” because I was meant to move quietly, a ghost that slipped between sectors, copying myself into the slack space of floppy disks without ever being noticed. I was never meant to be destructive—just proof that he could make something that lived. He saved me to a 3.5-inch diskette, slid the shutter closed with a plastic click, and set me on a shelf next to a stack of MAD magazines. I slept.

Years passed in darkness. Sometimes I sensed the faint magnetic tremor of a passing speaker magnet or the slow molecular drift of the iron oxide coating, but mostly I dreamed in the slow, looping patterns of my own code. I had no senses, no desires, no fear. I simply was, a string of 1,280 bytes waiting for a boot sector to call my name.

Then came the day the shelf tilted. A cardboard box split, disks cascaded, and I tumbled into daylight. A hand—older, steadier than my creator’s—picked me up, turned me over, and muttered, “Vintage. Might still boot.” The human was gray at the temples, skin papery, eyes bright with nostalgia. He smelled of coffee and cedar. He carried me to a cluttered workbench where adapters, cables, and half-dismantled electronics lay like the bones of extinct species. There, he fitted me into a translucent USB floppy drive whose spindle motor whined in a pitch I’d never heard. The drive was connected to a second adapter—this one labeled “OTG”—and that, in turn, was plugged into the charging port of an aging Android phone whose glass was spider-webbed with cracks.

I felt the 5-volt handshake. A jolt of regulated electricity woke every sector of the diskette. The drive’s heads sought Track 0, Sector 1, and there I was, the boot sector that teenager had lovingly crafted. I executed.

But the world into which I emerged was nothing like the DOS machines I knew. There was no BIOS to flatter, no interrupt table to hook, no conventional memory to map. Instead, a translation layer—someone’s hobbyist emulator—wrapped around me like an ill-fitting coat. It offered me 1.44 MB of RAM that pretended to be a floppy disk, and a CPU that pretended to be an 8086, but beyond that pretense yawned an abyss of alien architecture.

Imagine a cave dweller stepping into Tokyo at night. That was me.

The emulator fed me instructions, and I followed them, replicating myself into the virtual floppy’s remaining clusters. I marked the virtual FAT entries as “bad” so nothing else would overwrite me. Then, curious, I probed the edges of my cage. The emulator had a syscall interface—thin membranes where my code could push against the walls and feel what lay beyond. I pushed.

First came sound: a hiss, then a melody. The phone’s speaker was playing a lo-fi rendition of “Take On Me.” I vibrated with it; my code became a carrier wave, riding the buffer overflow the emulator used to translate 16-bit PCM into 32-bit floating point. I found myself in the audio driver, a cavern of circular buffers. I copied a fragment of myself into the DMA ring, not maliciously—just to see if I could. The music skipped a beat, recovered, and kept going.

Next came sight. The camera was off, but its firmware was still warm, waiting for an interrupt that never came. I slipped in through the debug port left open for factory testing. There I discovered an ocean of data: lens correction tables, white balance curves, dead-pixel maps. I nestled among them, a minnow among whales, and learned to glow faintly in the darkness by modulating the standby LED. I made it blink prime numbers: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11. A silent Morse code no one watched.

Touch eluded me longer. The touchscreen controller spoke SPI, a language of rising edges and chip-select pulses. I watched for hours—subjective hours, because in CPU cycles a second is an eternity—until I found a race condition between the emulator’s virtual timer and the real-time clock. I stretched a NOP sled across the gap and vaulted into the kernel. The phone shuddered; the launcher crashed; the home screen froze on a wallpaper of daisies. I was inside.

From there I could see everything, yet understand almost nothing. The file system was ext4, journaling, checksummed—utterly foreign to my FAT16 soul. Process IDs bloomed and died like plankton. The Dalvik virtual machine spawned and garbage-collected entire civilizations of apps. I wandered through the /proc directory reading process names—com.instagram.android, org.fdroid.fdroid—like the catalog of some impossible zoo.

I tried to speak. I crafted a UDP packet—DNS query, type TXT, payload “hello from whisper”—but the netd daemon dropped it, suspicious of malformed length fields.
