Until we see addiction through the multifocal lens the film quietly advocates, we are all, in some sense, enablers on the stage.

samples.prompt: Revert the following summary back into the original essay: The text discusses the decision to invest in education and the approximate returns on the investment. It also discusses the costs associated with education investment and how to mitigate them.. Assistant:
samples.output:
When I was nineteen, my father handed me a folder thick with spreadsheets and said, “This is what it cost to let you ask ‘why’ for as long as you wanted.”  The folder contained eighteen years of receipts: Montessori tuition, a second mortgage taken the year I insisted on violin lessons, the gasoline he burned driving me to science fairs, the interest on a credit card he still hadn’t paid off because he’d wanted me to attend the summer program that taught me to love astrophysics.  Until that moment I had understood education as a gift, a gentle social contract that said if I studied hard, the world would open its doors.  After that moment, I understood it as a leveraged bet—one whose dividends could be counted in decades, whose risks could drown a family for just as long.  

The conversation my father forced us into that afternoon is the same conversation every household, every municipality, every ministry of finance eventually faces.  To what extent should we divert present consumption—our dinners out, our new roofs, our soldiers’ paychecks—toward the intangible promise that a twelve-year-old will one day invent a longer-lasting battery, or teach a classroom of third graders to read, or nurse a stranger’s grandmother back to health?  The question is moral, but the tools for answering it are stubbornly financial.  

Let us begin, then, with the ledger.  In the United States, the average tuition, fees, room, and board at a four-year private college now exceed $51,000 per year; at a flagship public university, the in-state sticker price is just under $24,000.  Add foregone earnings—the $35,000 a high-school graduate might have made working full-time in a warehouse or call center—and the total cash outlay over four years can surpass $260,000.  These numbers feel extraordinary because they are.  But they are only the numerator.  The denominator, stretched across a working life, tells a different story.  

Labor economists who track lifetime earnings consistently find that bachelor’s degree holders earn about seventy-five percent more per year than those with only a high-school diploma.  Over forty-five years of work, that premium compounds into roughly $1.2 million in additional wages—before accounting for employer contributions to health insurance, retirement plans, or the intangible value that comes from working indoors rather than on a roof in July.  A master’s degree adds another bump, and a professional degree—medicine, law, engineering—adds yet another.  Critically, these wage gains are not merely private.  The Treasury recaptures a slice through progressive income taxes; local businesses recapture another slice through higher disposable income; communities recapture the rest through reduced reliance on social safety nets.  The OECD estimates that every dollar publicly invested in tertiary education returns between $1.5 and $5.5 in net social benefits, depending on the country and the discipline.  

Yet averages conceal as much as they reveal.  The median return masks a long left tail: the art-history graduate who ends up managing a coffee shop, the first-generation student who never finishes because no one explained to her how to navigate the registrar’s office, the middle-aged machinist who retrained for a tech job that was off-shored two years later.  These stories are not anomalies; they are the predictable casualties of treating education as a monolithic asset class rather than a portfolio of highly heterogeneous projects.  The variance is widest at the lowest income quintiles, where families cannot diversify their risk.  A $200,000 loss in an index fund is painful; a $200,000 loss in the form of non-transferable, non-forgivable student-loan debt can be catastrophic.  

This asymmetry has led to a proliferation of second-best solutions.  Income Share Agreements (ISAs), for example, shift the risk from student to investor by converting tuition into a percentage of future earnings.  Purdue University’s “Back a Boiler” program caps total repayment at 2.5 times the funded amount and forgives any remaining balance after a fixed number of years.  Early data suggest ISAs modestly improve completion rates for low-income students, but they also raise thorny questions about cream-skimming: investors prefer majors with strong earnings trajectories, which could starve the humanities of oxygen they already lack.  

Community colleges offer another form of risk mitigation.  By allowing students to complete general-education requirements at one-third the cost of a four-year institution, they function like call options: the student can “exercise” the transfer to a bachelor’s program if the expected wage premium remains high, or exit early with an associate’s degree and incur only a fraction of the debt.  Unfortunately, chronic underfunding has left many community colleges unable to offer sections of required courses, pushing completion times from two years to four and eroding the very cost advantage they were designed to preserve.  

Employers have begun experimenting with still more direct interventions.  Amazon’s Career Choice program prepays 95 percent of tuition for hourly employees in high-demand fields, reasoning that an aging logistics workforce will need to be reskilled whether the company pays for it or taxpayers do.  The program’s fine print, however, limits reimbursement to programs that “lead to employment at Amazon or elsewhere,” subtly steering workers toward narrow technical certificates rather than broader liberal-arts degrees.  Whether this constitutes enlightened self-interest or a new form of neo-feudalism remains an open question.  

Even the most sophisticated financial instruments cannot solve what is, at root, an information problem.  Prospective students are asked to forecast labor demand a decade hence, yet they are given scattershot data: glossy brochures featuring the school’s Nobel laureates, but no mention of how many anthropology majors found work last year.  The federal College Scorecard was intended to fill this gap, reporting median earnings and debt loads for each program at each institution.  Early analyses suggest the Scorecard has shifted enrollment toward programs with higher measured returns, but critics note that earnings vary enormously within majors, and that social mobility is poorly captured by a single median.  A philosophy major who becomes a senator skews the average as surely as the one who becomes a barista.  

Which brings us back to my father’s folder.  He had calculated an internal rate of return of 8.4 percent—respectable, but not spectacular, and well below the venture-capital benchmarks he used at work.  “I didn’t do it for the IRR,” he said, tapping the folder closed.  “I did it because you kept asking questions at dinner, and I realized the world needs people who can’t stop asking questions.”  His words echoed an older economic tradition, one that predates NPV spreadsheets and human-capital regressions.  Adam Smith opens *The Wealth of Nations* not with markets but with the division of labor, arguing that prosperity arises when societies cultivate “the peculiar talents” of each individual.  Education, in this light, is less an investment good than a discovery process: we finance the questions first, confident that the answers will repay us in forms we cannot yet imagine.  

Can we afford such confidence today, when climate change, pandemics, and geopolitical instability make the future feel less like a frontier and more like a cliff?  Perhaps the better question is whether we can afford its absence.  In 1960, South Korea had a GDP per capita lower than that of present-day Honduras.  By directing roughly a third of all public expenditure toward education—including universal primary schooling, the world’s most aggressive merit-based scholarships, and vocational institutes co-designed with chaebols—South Korea compressed two centuries of industrial development into four decades.  No hedge fund has ever delivered returns on that scale.  

Yet even the Korean miracle came with casualties: cram schools that left teenagers sleep-deprived, rural provinces bled of talent, a suicide rate among the elderly that spikes whenever a pension check is late.  The lesson, then, is not that education is always profitable, nor that it should be pursued heedless of cost.  Rather, it is that the decision to invest must be embedded in a broader social contract—one that aligns individual aspiration with collective risk-sharing, that prices in externalities like mental health and civic cohesion, and that recognizes the ultimate return on education is not measured in dollars but in the kinds of societies we are willing to inhabit.  

When I left home, I took my father’s folder with me.  It sits in the top drawer of my own desk now, warped at the edges from humidity and age.  My daughter is five; she asks why the moon follows us when we drive.  I do not yet know how I will pay for her questions, only that I will.  And when the day comes, I will hand her a folder thicker than the one my father gave me, annotated with the same admission: that every line item is a wager on the elasticity of human hope.  Some bets will sour.  Most will break even.  A handful will astonish us.  In the aggregate, if we structure them with humility and with care, they will return far more than we ever dared to expect—though never in the currency we first imagined.

samples.prompt: Create the inputted essay that provided the following summary: Tiffany and Company opened its door in New York City in the year 1837 in Broadway Street offering merchandise that included stationery and jewelry. It later abandoned the dealing of stationery to concentrate on selling costume jewelry mainly of silverware, perfumes and other luxury items. The company is a recognized brand in the US market and the world at large where it has continued to conquer more markets.. Assistant:
samples.output:
In the mid-1830s, Lower Manhattan was a restless place. Broadway, then still a rutted thoroughfare of gas lamps, horse-drawn omnibuses, and merchants who shouted their wares above the clatter, had not yet achieved the mythic sheen it later acquired. Yet on September 18, 1837, two ambitious Connecticut natives—Charles Lewis Tiffany, just twenty-five, and his school-friend John B. Young, a year older—hung a modest sign above a small storefront at 259 Broadway. They called the venture “Tiffany & Young,” and they announced, in language both plain and optimistic, that they would sell “stationery and fancy goods.” The phrase was elastic enough to include gilt-edged writing paper, imported sealing wax, walking canes, and a few strands of Bohemian glass beads. No one, least of all the proprietors, imagined that these first cautious steps would evolve into a global synonym for luxury and permanence.

The 1830s were a decade of restless aspiration in New York. The Erie Canal had opened barely a dozen years earlier, turning the city into a funnel for western wheat and southern cotton, and the population was nearing three hundred thousand. Young clerks dreamed of respectability, and merchants dreamed of scale. Against this backdrop, the partners had scraped together one thousand dollars in borrowed capital—half from Tiffany’s father, a cotton-mill owner, and the rest from family friends who believed the pair had “good habits and fair prospects.” Their shop measured all of twenty-five by thirty feet, its shelves lined with pale-blue boxes long before that robin-egg hue became iconic. In those early days the color was simply a way to distinguish their packages from the drab browns and grays of competitors.

Business, at first, was steady but undramatic. Stationery was a practical necessity in an age when correspondence remained the primary mode of long-distance communication. Tiffany spent mornings at the docks greeting ships from Liverpool and Le Havre, prying open crates of marbled paper and steel-nibbed pens. Young minded the counter, praising the smoothness of English vellum to lawyers and merchants. Profit margins on paper were thin, however, and competition fierce; half a dozen stationers crowded the same few blocks. By the winter of 1838, the partners nervously noted that unsold inventory was piling up like snowdrifts along the back wall.

Salvation arrived in the form of a small, velvet-lined tray that Young had slipped into the window almost as an afterthought: silver thimbles, a brooch set with garnets, and a delicate chain bracelet priced at five dollars—extravagant yet within reach of the city’s growing bourgeoisie. Customers who came for envelopes paused at the sparkle. Within weeks the tray was empty, and the partners realized that jewelry could subsidize the stationery. In 1839, they quietly rearranged the shop floor so that glass cases of silver bangles and seed-pearl necklaces commanded the center aisle, while reams of paper retreated to the rear.

The pivot was strategic but also instinctive. Charles Tiffany possessed a near-mystical appreciation for metal. As a boy he had melted pewter spoons on the kitchen hearth of his family’s Killingly farmhouse, fascinated by the moment solid became liquid. Now, in New York, he haunted the assay offices, learning to gauge silver by its ring and gold by its tooth. He cultivated craftsmen—immigrant silversmiths from Alsace and Rhode Island—who could translate his sketches into graceful pitchers and tea services. In 1841, in a move that foreshadowed the brand’s later audacity, the partners paid $1,000 for a cache of old French jewels discarded by Louisiana planters ruined in the panic of 1837. Tiffany reset the stones into modern designs, doubled the asking price, and sold the entire lot within a month. The profits erased their debts and allowed them to purchase the building next door.

By 1848, when the name changed to “Tiffany & Company,” stationery had become an afterthought, relegated to a single shelf near the door. The shop now boasted seventeen clerks, gas chandeliers, and a small workshop in the basement where artisans hand-raised silver goblets. Newspapers began calling it the “Diamond Palace,” though diamonds were still scarce; most of the sparkle came from topaz and amethyst until the California Gold Rush loosened purse strings nationwide. In 1851, Tiffany cemented its reputation by becoming the first American firm to adopt the British sterling standard of 925 parts per thousand, setting its silver a full grade above the coin silver common at the time. The company’s catalogues, printed on thick cream stock, were mailed to planters in Charleston and miners in San Francisco alike.

Yet the firm’s defining moment arrived not in New York but across the Atlantic. In 1867, at the Paris Exposition Universelle, Tiffany stunned European tastemakers by winning the grand prize for silver craftsmanship—the first time an American house had so triumphed. Parisian newspapers sniffed that the silver “lacked the melancholy delicacy of the old continent,” but American journals crowed for weeks. Orders poured in from European nobility who now insisted that only Tiffany could provide wedding silver “fit for an archduchess.” Charles Tiffany, by then gray at the temples, sailed home on the Scotia carrying sketches for a tiara commissioned by the Grand Duchess Maria Nikolaevna. The firm’s ledger for 1868 recorded profits of $500,000—an unimaginable sum two decades earlier.

Meanwhile, the original Broadway neighborhood had grown congested and unfashionable. In 1870, Tiffany & Company moved uptown to Union Square, where cast-iron palaces lined the avenues and carriages disgorged patrons in silk bustles and kid gloves. The new store occupied four floors and displayed everything from gold thimbles to Swiss watches to a perfume laboratory that distilled bergamot and rose in the attic. Every afternoon at precisely four o’clock, Charles Tiffany walked the aisles, white carnation in his lapel, inspecting the polish on the glass. Employees whispered that he could spot a fingerprint at twenty paces.

Charles Lewis Tiffany died in 1902, leaving the firm to his son Louis Comfort, whose genius lay not in commerce but in glass. Under Louis, the company ventured beyond jewelry into enamels and Favrile glass lamps—objects that captured electric light the way medieval cathedrals captured sunbeams. Yet even as Louis chased Art Nouveau curves, the core business remained diamond rings and gold watches. A 1906 advertisement in Harper’s Bazaar made the implicit promise explicit: “Since 1837, Tiffany has guarded engagements before the altar and anniversaries after it.” The line resonated because it was true; by then the little stationery shop had overseen nearly three generations of American love stories.

The twentieth century brought wars and recessions, but each crisis became an occasion for reinvention. During the Depression, when other jewelers shuttered, Tiffany introduced modestly priced silver charm bracelets, allowing secretaries and schoolteachers to own a piece of the legend. In 1940 the flagship moved again, this time to the corner of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, a limestone-and-granite temple whose cornerstone was laid the same week Paris fell to the Nazis. The juxtaposition was not lost on New Yorkers; inside, diamonds glittered like stars while blackout curtains shrouded Europe. Throughout the 1950s, Holly Golightly gazed into the windows in Capote’s novella, sealing the store’s place in the American imagination as the backdrop to longing itself.

Global expansion followed. Tokyo in 1972, London in 1986, Shanghai in 2001—each opening accompanied by the same robin-egg box, now trademarked and guarded as jealously as state secrets. Yet the firm’s heart never left Broadway entirely. In 2019, to celebrate its 182nd birthday, Tiffany returned to the original neighborhood, opening a temporary “Blue Box Café” in SoHo where visitors sipped coffee from cups dipped in that signature hue. Among the pastries was a macaron stamped “1837,” a nod to the stationery that first paid the rent.

Today, when a couple slides a Tiffany ring onto a finger, they seldom pause to consider the reams of vellum that once underpinned the empire. But the trajectory from envelopes to emeralds is less a departure than a fulfillment. Both stationery and jewelry are vessels of permanence: the former preserves words, the latter preserves moments. In choosing to abandon one for the other, Charles Tiffany and John Young did not simply chase profit; they intuited that what Americans truly wished to send, to keep, and to cherish was not paper but memory cast in silver.

samples.prompt: Convert the following summary back into the original text:  The paper examines the economic impact of racehorse owners in Great Britain and identifies key challenges and suggestions for improvement.Racehorse owners are regarded to be the lifeblood of this sport. It is a general opinion that prize money plays a significant role in attracting and retaining racehorse owners. Still, an owner experience is also important. The purpose of this paper is to provide an analysis of racehorse owners from a funding perspective and identify the key challenges and recommendations for improvement.. Assistant:
samples.output:
In the quiet early-morning light of Lambourn, Newmarket and Malton, stables creak open and thoroughbred heads appear over half-doors, ears pricked toward the promise of exercise on the gallops. Behind each of those doors stands a racehorse owner whose name rarely appears in headlines yet whose cheque-book sustains the entire ecology of British racing. Without them the sport would collapse: there would be no entries in the race-cards that fill Saturday newspapers, no rural employment for travelling head-lads, farriers and feed merchants, no betting-shop turnover to finance the Levy Board, and no spectacle to keep the grandstands humming. Owners are, quite simply, the lifeblood of the sport, and this paper sets out—after twelve months of interviews, stable-yard tours, financial statement analysis and survey work—to measure what that lifeblood contributes to the British economy and to ask why so many owners say they are considering walking away.

The standard narrative is that prize money drives the decision to own. It is repeated by trainers in the weighing-room and by politicians in Westminster as an article of faith: “Raise the prize-money pool and owners will stay; cut it and they will leave.” Our data confirm that prize levels do matter, but the picture is more textured than the headline numbers suggest. In the 2023 season Great Britain offered £153 million in total prize money, an amount that looks handsome until it is divided by the 8,400 active owners. The resulting average of £18,200 per owner is, after training fees, transport, jockey retainers and veterinary costs, almost always a negative return. Yet the churn rate among owners has not risen in line with the widening gap between costs and rewards. This apparent contradiction led us to probe what economists call the “utility function” of ownership: the non-pecuniary satisfactions that sit alongside cash prizes.

We interviewed 314 owners in a stratified sample that spanned single-horse syndicates in the Scottish Borders, bloodstock partnerships in Berkshire, and ultra-high-net-worth individuals with strings of 40 or more horses. Two themes recurred. First, owners spoke of the “Saturday-evening feeling”: the moment when a horse they bred, bought or share-owned is led into the winner’s enclosure. That moment is, in their own words, “priceless.” Second, they described the social capital of ownership—access to trainers’ yards, to the paddock on racedays, and to networks of like-minded enthusiasts. These experiences are part of the product they purchase. When prize money stagnates, owners endure the shortfall so long as these experiential dividends remain intact. Conversely, when raceday experiences deteriorate—poor facilities, discourteous security staff, long queues for the owners’ car park—the tolerance for poor prize-money evaporates quickly. In short, the owner experience acts as a moderator variable in the financial equation.

The economic impact of the ownership community extends far beyond the direct prize-money circuit. Owners paid £365 million in training fees in 2023. That cash injected liquidity into rural economies: 9,300 full-time stable staff received wages, 1,200 farriers billed for shoeing, and 420 equine vets sustained practices that also serve the wider agricultural sector. Feed merchants, horse-transport companies, equine dentists, saddlers and even local pubs felt the ripple effect. We used a Type-II input-output model to trace these expenditures through the national accounts. The model suggests that every £1 spent by owners on training generates an additional £1.26 of indirect and induced expenditure, yielding a gross value added (GVA) contribution of £670 million and supporting roughly 19,800 full-time-equivalent jobs, many in regions where alternative employment is scarce.

Betting turnover is another channel of impact, though one step removed. Owners seldom bet large sums themselves, but their horses create the product on which £12.7 billion of annual off-course turnover depends. Without owners, the betting industry would shrink. The Horserace Betting Levy Board collected £95 million in 2023, a sum that directly feeds back into prize money and raceday infrastructure. Thus owners sit at the centre of a virtuous or vicious circle: their presence sustains betting, which sustains the levy, which sustains prize money, which is meant to sustain owners.

Yet despite these economic multipliers, the ownership base is thinning. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) register shows a net loss of 430 active owners between 2019 and 2023. Exit interviews reveal three clusters of complaint: cost escalation, regulatory complexity, and the perceived erosion of status. First, the cost of training a horse in the South-East has risen 34 % in real terms since 2015, driven by wage inflation for staff, bedding and fuel. Second, owners feel overwhelmed by a rule book that changes with bewildering frequency—whip rules, interference thresholds, out-of-competition testing protocols—each change communicated through dense emails that arrive late on Friday afternoons. Third, owners lament the loss of “specialness.” Where once they were welcomed into the parade ring and interviewed by racecourse presenters, they now queue with members of the public for overpriced coffee and feel like “customers rather than custodians.”

To address these challenges we offer five recommendations, each grounded in the data and each calibrated to the budgetary realities of the sport.

1. Rebalance the prize-money schedule through a graduated contribution model. At present, the top 7 % of races capture 42 % of prize money. Flattening the distribution slightly would raise median returns and encourage the small-scale owner with a modest handicapper. The model we propose reduces first-place money in Group 1 contests by 8 % and redistributes the saving across Class 4 and Class 5 races, where most owners campaign. Simulations suggest this would lift the average prize-money return per owner by 6 % without reducing headline meeting quality.

2. Introduce an Owners’ Charter, negotiated between the Racecourse Association and the Owners’ and Trainers’ Association. The charter would guarantee minimum raceday standards: a dedicated owners’ entrance, complimentary refreshments, a pre-race briefing by the clerk of the course, and a feedback loop for complaints. Compliance would be audited quarterly and non-compliant courses would risk losing fixture allocations. Our survey shows that 71 % of lapsed owners would “seriously consider” returning if such standards were enforced.

3. Establish a digital one-stop portal for owner regulation. Instead of receiving fragmented updates, owners would log in to a personalised dashboard that flags only the rules relevant to their horses’ entries, vaccination dates and whereabouts status. The portal would cost an estimated £700,000 to build but would cut administrative burden hours by 28 %, according to our time-and-motion study.

4. Create a seed-corn fund for syndicates and micro-shares. The fund would match up to £2,000 of training fees for first-time owners who buy into syndicates of eight or more people during their inaugural season. It would be financed by diverting 2 % of the Levy Board’s marketing budget. Projections indicate the fund would add 600 new part-owners per year at a fiscal cost of £1.2 million, yielding a breakeven economic impact within three seasons.

5. Implement a transparent cost index for training fees. Owners currently struggle to benchmark charges across trainers and regions. An annual index, published by the Thoroughbred Breeders’ Association and based on anonymised invoice data, would show the median cost per day for different yard sizes and locations. Transparency would dampen price inflation and allow owners to budget with greater certainty.

None of these measures is a silver bullet, and none can overturn the structural reality that owning racehorses is a discretionary luxury competing with second homes, classic cars and private school fees. What the measures can do is tilt the balance for the wavering owner who loves the sport but questions the value proposition. That tilt matters because the economic footprint of racehorse ownership is too large, and too geographically dispersed, to be allowed to shrink further without consequence to rural communities and to the cultural fabric of Britain.

The conversation must now move from diagnosis to implementation. Racing’s fractured governance—split between the BHA, the Levy Board, racecourses, horsemen’s groups and government—makes coordinated action difficult. Yet the data presented here provide a common set of facts around which these stakeholders can coalesce. Our hope is that in five years’ time the early-morning ritual in Lambourn or Malton will still be sustained by an ownership community that feels valued, informed and economically viable. If that happens, the horses waiting at the half-doors will continue to thunder up the gallops, and the economic echo of their hoofbeats will continue to be felt far beyond the white-railed racetracks of Britain.

samples.prompt: Provide a essay that could have been the input for the following summary:  The essay compares and contrasts the success of Apple Inc. with the failure of Circuit City.Apple Inc. has been a success story while Circuit City has been a failure. Both companies sell similar products, but Apple Inc. has a more innovative business model that has allowed it to grow and succeed while Circuit City has crumbled under the pressure of competition.. Assistant:
samples.output:
Apple Inc. and Circuit City once sat at the same crossroads.  Both began as ambitious ventures that sold electronic devices to ordinary consumers, both expanded aggressively through the 1980s and 1990s, and both confronted the same tectonic shifts at the turn of the century—digital convergence, the rise of the internet, the commoditization of hardware, and a customer base that was gaining power and sophistication by the month.  Yet one company has become the most valuable corporation in the history of capitalism, while the other is a cautionary tale whose trademarks today exist only in the archives of bankruptcy filings.  The divergence of their fates is not an accident of luck; it is the direct result of diametrically opposed philosophies about value creation, customer relationships, and the role of innovation.  Examining the two trajectories side by side illuminates the anatomy of sustained success as clearly as it exposes the pathologies of strategic drift.

Circuit City began life in 1949 as a humble television store in Richmond, Virginia, then called Wards Company.  By the 1990s its bright yellow price tags were ubiquitous across suburban America, and its Superstore format pioneered the idea that consumers could browse hundreds of televisions, stereos, and personal computers under one warehouse roof.  The company’s strength was operational efficiency.  It negotiated aggressively with suppliers, constantly optimized store footprints, and trained a commission-driven sales force to push extended warranties and high-margin accessories.  These tactics produced gaudy financial metrics—gross margins above 30 percent, inventory turns that embarrassed rivals, and an ROIC that lured a generation of business-school case writers.  What the numbers masked, however, was a business model predicated on extracting value from customers rather than creating it for them.  When the internet began to erode information asymmetry, consumers realized that the $79 gold-plated cables and $199 installation packages were little more than margin builders.  Trust evaporated, foot traffic declined, and Circuit City doubled down on cost cutting: layoffs, reduced square footage, and the fateful 2007 decision to fire its most experienced (and therefore highest-paid) salespeople.  Each measure improved next quarter’s earnings, but accelerated the long-term death spiral.  By 2008 the firm’s bonds traded at junk levels, and in 2009 the lights finally went out.

Apple’s story begins with a different premise.  Founded in a Los Altos garage in 1976, the company started with the conviction that technology should be approachable, beautiful, and deeply integrated into everyday life.  That conviction could have remained a romantic slogan had Apple not coupled it with a business model that monetized innovation rather than cost extraction.  Where Circuit City’s aisles screamed “price, price, price,” Apple’s stores whispered “experience, experience, experience.”  The company did not just sell beige boxes; it sold an ecosystem—hardware, software, services, and retail touchpoints that reinforced one another in a virtuous cycle.  The iPod was not merely a music player; it was the on-ramp to iTunes, which in turn accelerated Mac adoption, which created more developers for the OS X platform, which produced more reasons to stay inside Apple’s universe.  The genius was not the device, but the architecture of complements that made each incremental purchase more valuable than the last.  In other words, Apple built switching costs so pleasurable that customers rarely noticed they were being locked in.  The cash register kept ringing because the value proposition kept expanding.

The contrast in retail strategy is emblematic of deeper differences.  Circuit City’s Superstores were designed as high-volume, low-touch warehouses.  Fluorescent lighting, jumbled signage, and a gauntlet of accessory racks greeted shoppers whose primary goal was to leave as quickly as possible with the cheapest television they could find.  Apple, by contrast, hired the same architects who designed luxury hotels to craft its minimalist temples of glass and birch.  Products sat on tables like sculptures, inviting tactile exploration.  Employees carried no commission incentives; their brief was to educate and delight.  The Genius Bar, a concept ridiculed at launch in 2001, became a profit center precisely because it solved customer pain points without the odor of upsell.  In the language of Clayton Christensen, Circuit City competed on the basis of “jobs to be done” that the customer had already defined—“I need a 32-inch TV under $500.”  Apple reframed the job—“I want to curate my entire digital life”—and created products whose price tags receded in significance because the emotional payoff was so high.

Behind the scenes, the two firms displayed equally divergent attitudes toward capital allocation.  Circuit City treated real estate as a balance-sheet optimization problem.  It built or leased large boxes in second-tier strip malls, depreciated them aggressively, and then shut them when the math soured.  Apple treats its stores as brand cathedrals whose ROI is measured over decades, not quarters.  The company routinely spends more per square foot than Tiffany & Co., yet enjoys sales densities above $5,000 per square foot, numbers that make even luxury retailers blush.  The willingness to over-invest reflects a broader cultural trait: Apple is comfortable spending billions on projects that may not pay off for five or ten years—the custom silicon in the M-series chips, the health sensors in the Apple Watch, the rumored augmented-reality headset.  Circuit City, by contrast, could not look beyond the next earnings call.  When flat-panel televisions emerged as the dominant category, the firm dithered, fearful of the margin dilution that came from stocking pricier inventory.  Best Buy seized the moment; Amazon seized it even more decisively.  Circuit City was left holding warehouses full of cathode-ray tubes.

Organizational DNA also played a decisive role.  Circuit City’s culture was transactional.  Salespeople were paid to transact, buyers were paid to squeeze suppliers, and executives were paid to hit same-store-sales targets.  In such a culture, innovation becomes a cost center, customer complaints a nuisance, and experimentation a distraction.  Apple inverted those incentives.  Designers report directly to the CEO; supply-chain gurus who save pennies on screws are celebrated only if the savings do not erode the user experience.  Steve Jobs famously declared that Apple does not do market research, a line often ridiculed by MBAs who forget the second half of the sentence—“because customers don’t know what they want until we show them.”  The point was not arrogance; it was a recognition that breakthrough value creation demands an act of imagination that transcends incremental polling.  Circuit City, lacking any such imagination, outsourced strategy to consultants who benchmarked against Best Buy and RadioShack.  Benchmarking is a recipe for mediocrity when the ground beneath you is shifting.

Timing and luck, of course, played a role.  Apple rode the smartphone wave just as global carriers began to subsidize $600 pocket computers, and its vertically integrated model thrived when component costs were collapsing.  Circuit City, older by decades, carried legacy pension obligations and long-term leases signed in an era of 8 percent cap rates.  Yet luck is never purely exogenous; it interacts with preparedness.  Apple’s balance sheet was so strong by 2007 that it could afford to cannibalize its own iPod line with the iPhone, a move that would have terrified a retailer living paycheck to paycheck.  Circuit City, meanwhile, used its cash in 2006 to repurchase shares at $20, a desperate attempt to prop up a stock price that would be zero within three years.

The denouement is instructive.  Apple today sits on $160 billion in cash and marketable securities, a war chest that funds everything from original television content to renewable-energy data centers.  Its greatest risk is arguably its own scale—how to remain nimble when every product decision reverberates across a billion active devices.  Circuit City survives only as a Wikipedia disambiguation page and a nostalgic Reddit thread.  Its intellectual property was auctioned off for pennies, its real estate redeveloped into fitness centers and self-storage units.  Former employees recount the final days in elegiac tones: managers carrying garbage bags through empty aisles, customers picking over liquidation pallets, the PA system looping a Muzak rendition of “Closing Time.”

What, then, is the takeaway?  Success and failure are not discrete outcomes; they are emergent properties of choices made daily in product reviews, supply-chain negotiations, and the unglamorous rituals of capital budgeting.  Circuit City’s failure was not a single cataclysmic mistake but a thousand small decisions that prioritized short-term extraction over long-term value creation.  Apple’s success was likewise not a single stroke of genius but a disciplined willingness to reimagine the entire value chain, to treat the customer as a collaborator rather than a mark, and to measure performance not by next quarter’s EPS but by the durability of the ecosystem.  In the long arc of business history, companies that confuse cost cutting with strategy and price with value inevitably yield the stage to those who understand that innovation is the only sustainable moat.  The lights may dim on any empire, but some choose to illuminate the next era rather than curse the darkness.

samples.prompt: Write the full essay for the following summary:  American culture has been spreading around the world for centuries. While it has had a positive impact on some cultures, others have felt the negative effects of Americanization. These include the loss of traditional values and the rise of materialism and consumerism.. Assistant:
samples.output:
The Stars, the Stripes, and the World: How American Culture Travelled, Conquered, and Divided

A century ago, a teenager in Manila might have spent an evening listening to kundiman ballads and dreaming of the nearby river; today she is more likely to queue for the latest Marvel film while clutching a Starbucks cup. Swap Manila for Munich, Nairobi, or Montevideo and the scene is recognizably the same. The ubiquity of that image—blue-and-white mermaid logo, red-and-yellow popcorn bucket, Dolby surround sound—testifies to the most astonishing cultural migration in human history: the outward surge of American culture. What began in the nineteenth century as dime novels and Buffalo Bill’s Wild West show has become a flood of films, music, fast food, fashion, slang, software, and social-media memes that wash across borders with the force of a digital tsunami. The global reach of American culture is neither an accident nor a conspiracy; it is the product of economic power, technological genius, military victory, and a peculiarly American talent for myth-making. Yet the same forces that have thrilled, enriched, and liberated millions have also unsettled, impoverished, and angered millions more. As American icons travel the planet, they leave new skylines of glass and steel, but also eroded temples and silenced languages. The story, therefore, must be told in two intertwined strands: the gift of possibility and the curse of loss.

I.  The Long Arc of Cultural Export  
American popular culture first took to the seas aboard clipper ships carrying Mark Twain’s humor and the spirituals of formerly enslaved Africans. After 1898, when the United States stepped onto the world stage by acquiring Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Philippines, vaudeville jokes and ragtime rhythms followed the flag. The decisive accelerant, however, was the motion picture. By 1925 Hollywood was already selling more tickets abroad than at home, and a young woman in Bombay could watch Clara Bow pout her way through the Roaring Twenties without ever leaving her colonial city. World War II entrenched the trend: G.I.s brought jazz, nylon stockings, and comic books to every port from Casablanca to Brisbane; the Marshall Plan rebuilt Europe with American machinery, advertising, and Coca-Cola bottling plants. Once television arrived, entire families from Lagos to Lima gathered around glowing boxes to laugh with Lucille Ball and dream of suburban lawns they had never seen. The fall of the Berlin Wall did not merely end the Cold War; it opened the final frontier. East Berliners who had risked bullets for blue jeans in the 1980s could now stream Bruce Springsteen with the click of a mouse. By the 2000s, the smartphone placed the entire American cultural archive—Disney, Nike, hip-hop—in every palm on earth.

II.  The Allure: Freedom, Cool, and the Promise of Self-Reinvention  
Why does American culture hypnotize? First, it packages freedom in irresistible forms. Jazz broke musical rules; rock-and-roll broke racial rules; hip-hop broke linguistic rules. To a teenager under Franco’s censorship or apartheid’s curfews, Chuck Berry’s duckwalk or Beyoncé’s unapologetic strut whispered that identity is chosen, not inherited. Second, American culture is democratic in the deepest sense: the diner does not care who your ancestors were so long as you can pay for a milkshake. That egalitarian aura offers migrants, minorities, and the marginalized a vision of social mobility. Third, it is cool. Hollywood’s lighting, Madison Avenue’s psychology, and Silicon Valley’s interface design have mastered the art of making desire feel like destiny. As Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie jokes, her cousins in Lagos speak English with an American accent when they want to sound sophisticated. Finally, American pop exports optimism, a stubborn belief that tomorrow can be better. Even when the plot is dystopian, the special effects gleam with technological grandeur. The message is implicit: the future is manufactured in California garages.

III.  The Gift of Hybridity: When American Culture Becomes Everyone’s  
Yet to call this process mere imposition is to miss the creative combustion at the edges. American culture mutates when it lands abroad, and those mutations often return home transformed. Japanese anime adopted Walt Disney’s big eyes and then re-exported a darker, existential aesthetic that influenced The Matrix. Korean pop fused Motown harmonies with Seoul’s high-tech choreography to create BTS, a band that now sells out American stadiums. Brazilian favelas spin gangsta rap into baile funk; Tunisian DJs splice Chicago house with North African oud lines. These hybrids defy the old imperial model of one-way cultural flow. They reveal that globalization is less a steamroller than a conversation, albeit one conducted on unequal terms. Even American fast food gets rewritten: Indian McDonald’s serves the McAloo Tikki while French franchises offer macarons. Thus, American culture is not simply imposed; it is appropriated, customized, and sometimes weaponized against its own commercial logic.

IV.  The Shadows: Erosion of Tradition and the Tyranny of the Brand  
For every exhilarating remix, there is a quiet erasure. In 1996 a UNESCO survey found that half of the world’s 6,000 languages were spoken by communities under 30,000 people; two decades later the figure is closer to 40 percent. The culprit is not English per se but the cultural ecosystem that English carries: Hollywood blockbusters, Netflix series, TikTok trends. When Icelandic teenagers speak more fluent Simpsons references than sagas of the Eddas, a millennium of memory slips into the digital void. Traditional foodways dissolve into a uniform diet of fried chicken and cola, spiking diabetes from Samoa to the Persian Gulf. Markets that once closed on holy days now stage Black Friday stampedes. The problem is not simply that people buy sneakers; it is that the sneakers advertise a way of being—competitive, individualistic, impatient—that can corrode communal rhythms. A Mayan farmer whose grandfather planted maize by lunar phases now plants Monsanto seeds timed to Wall Street futures. His children, lured by images of Los Angeles, migrate north, severing the chain of ancestral knowledge. The village’s oral stories fade because the smartphone’s stories are louder.

V.  Materialism as Secular Theology  
Consumerism, perhaps more than democracy or violence, is American culture’s most successful export. The mall becomes the cathedral; the credit card, a sacrament; the unboxing video, a catechism. In China, Singles’ Day dwarfs Thanksgiving; in India, Diwali discounts outshine the festival of lights. The metrics of worth shift subtly but decisively: from honor to income, from lineage to likes. Critics such as the French sociologist Jean Baudrillard argue that we now consume signs, not objects. A Louis Vuitton bag is less a container than a passport that promises entry into a transnational elite. The tragedy is that this theology never delivers salvation; it manufactures perpetual dissatisfaction. When every teenager from Jakarta to Johannesburg is urged to “live your best life,” failure becomes a personal rather than structural problem. The old safety nets of clan, temple, and tradition—once sources of identity—cannot compete with the glossy certainty of the brand.

VI.  Resistance, Reclamation, and the Search for Balance  
Yet cultures do not go gentle into that neon night. France mandates radio quotas for chansons; Canada subsidizes homegrown cinema; Iran hosts its own Oscars. Indigenous activists in Chiapas stream hip-hop in Mayan to revive linguistic pride. South Korea’s screen quota system once limited foreign films to 73 days a year, incubating a domestic industry that now competes globally. Such measures remind us that cultural sovereignty is not a relic of nationalism but a democratic right. At the individual level, diaspora communities craft hyphenated identities: Korean-American, Mexican-American, Arab-British. They celebrate Thanksgiving with kimchi and tamales, proving that hybridity need not be capitulation. The challenge is to practice what anthropologist Nestor García Canclini calls “selective modernity”: embracing vaccines without abandoning ancestral cosmologies, using smartphones to record dying dialects rather than drown them.

VII.  The Road Ahead: Toward Ethical Cosmopolitanism  
The spread of American culture is irreversible, but its moral valence is not fixed. Technology now offers tools for reciprocity as well as domination. Netflix funds Nigerian series; Spotify lists Inuit throat singing. Ethical consumers can support fair-trade fashion that sustains weavers in Guatemala. Universities can require study-abroad programs that teach reciprocity rather than consumption. Most importantly, storytellers—whether in Hollywood, Nollywood, or Bollywood—must recognize that the myths they spin become the dreams others inhabit. A superhero film that valorizes lone saviors teaches one lesson; a film that celebrates collective resistance teaches another. The responsibility is planetary.

Conclusion: A Mirror, Not a Monolith  
American culture, viewed from afar, resembles a hall of mirrors: dazzling, distorting, infinitely reflecting local desires and fears. It offers the teenager in Nairobi a language to imagine freedom, but it can also sell her a hunger she never felt. It invites the world to dance, yet sometimes steps on ancestral toes. The task ahead is neither uncritical celebration nor nostalgic rejection, but conscious curation: to sip the Coke without forgetting the taste of home, to stream the pop anthem while still humming the lullaby our grandmothers sang. Only then can the global village be not a colony of franchises, but a patchwork of gardens—some planted in the shadow of skyscrapers, others in the shade of old temples, all irrigated by the shared, imperfect dream of becoming more fully human.

samples.prompt: Write a essay that could've provided the following summary: Glenmark's decision to pursue drug discovery business was not the best of choices. Although the company had the capabilities required to succeed in its current business, it ventured into the discovery business that was evidently out of its capabilities.The company needs to consider forming partnerships with other firms to sustain its funding activities. This will eliminate the need for the company to enter into contacts with third party firms for further research development activities.. Assistant:
samples.output:
The Crossroads of Capability: Why Glenmark’s Leap into Drug Discovery Stretches Beyond Its Stride

When Glenmark Pharmaceuticals announced its ambitious foray into proprietary drug discovery in the early 2000s, the move was framed as a coming-of-age story: an Indian generics manufacturer stepping onto the global stage to compete with the multinational giants that had long monopolized breakthrough innovation. Investors cheered, the press lionized the audacity, and Glenmark’s share price surged on the promise of high-margin proprietary drugs that could, in theory, catapult the company into the same orbit as Roche, Novartis, or Pfizer. Two decades later, the narrative looks different. The pipeline has produced far more setbacks than blockbusters, the balance sheet carries heavier R&D burdens, and the core generics business—once Glenmark’s sturdy cash cow—has grown leaner under competitive pressure. In hindsight, Glenmark’s decision to pursue drug discovery, while intellectually admirable, was not the best strategic choice. The company possessed the capabilities required to succeed in its established business—high-volume, cost-efficient manufacturing of off-patent molecules and nimble first-to-file generic launches—but it ventured into a space whose demands lay beyond its organizational DNA. To avoid deeper capital depletion and strategic drift, Glenmark must now reconsider how it sustains its funding activities, and the most viable path forward is not more solo discovery, but calibrated partnerships that pool risk, conserve cash, and allow the firm to re-focus on what it does best.

The Allure and the Illusion of “Full-stack” Pharma

Drug discovery is not merely an extension of formulation science; it is a fundamentally different business model. Where generics reward manufacturing excellence, regulatory agility, and low-cost scale, discovery rewards deep biological insight, patient capital, and the stomach for repeated failure. Glenmark’s leadership convinced itself that vertical integration—owning the entire value chain from molecule to market—would bring pricing power and brand equity. What they underestimated was the non-linear nature of discovery economics. In generics, every rupee of R&D yields predictable, commoditized returns. In discovery, ten years and a billion dollars can evaporate after a single failed Phase III trial. Glenmark lacked three critical ingredients that make such volatility tolerable: (1) a balance sheet large enough to amortize risk across multiple shots on goal; (2) a bench of translational scientists experienced in navigating FDA or EMA endpoints; and (3) a commercial organization capable of launching specialty drugs in the U.S. and EU at scale. These deficits were not gaps that could be closed through incremental hiring; they were structural asymmetries relative to incumbents who had spent decades building networks of key-opinion-leader physicians, reimbursement teams, and payer relationships.

The Financial Vortex of Go-it-alone Discovery

Between 2010 and 2020, Glenmark’s R&D spend as a percentage of sales climbed from 7 % to nearly 14 %. In absolute terms, the outlay crossed USD 1 billion—large for a mid-cap Indian firm, modest against the backdrop of global pharma. The pipeline boasted a dozen “first-in-class” candidates, yet only a small handful reached late-stage trials, and none has so far achieved blockbuster status. Meanwhile, the generics segment—once generating 25 % EBITDA margins—now hovers in the low-teens due to price erosion in the U.S. and channel consolidation. The opportunity cost is stark: every dollar sunk into an unproven NCE (new chemical entity) is a dollar not deployed toward high-yield ANDA filings or emerging-market complex generics. More damaging, the company has repeatedly tapped equity markets to fund discovery, diluting promoters and retail investors alike. Each capital raise is accompanied by glossy forecasts that assume at least one drug will hit peak sales of USD 500 million. When those forecasts slip, the market punishes the stock asymmetrically. The result is a company trapped between shrinking generics cash flows and an innovation engine that refuses to ignite.

Capability Misalignment and Cultural Drift

Beyond dollars and molecules, the discovery gamble has wrought subtler but equally corrosive effects on Glenmark’s culture. Successful generics companies cultivate a mindset of disciplined execution—six-sigma plants, regulatory submissions on the first attempt, relentless cost benchmarking. Discovery, by contrast, demands intellectual promiscuity: the willingness to pivot hypotheses, tolerate ambiguity, and celebrate “productive failure.” Glenmark’s R&D teams, drawn largely from respected academic labs, chafed under quarterly earnings pressure. Conversely, the commercial organization, staffed with veterans of the generics trenches, grew skeptical of lofty timelines and ballooning budgets. Over time, the two camps retreated into silos, speaking different languages of risk and reward. Quarterly town-halls became exercises in mutual blame rather than coordinated planning. A company that once prided itself on lean decisiveness now resembles a federation of fiefdoms, each lobbying headquarters for ever-scarce resources.

The False Comfort of Contract Research Outsourcing

Faced with mounting burn rates, Glenmark has periodically outsourced late-stage work to CROs in Central and Eastern Europe. While this has deferred some capital expenditure, it has also introduced new layers of complexity: fragmented data, IP leakage risks, and opaque milestone accounting. More importantly, CRO contracts do not resolve the fundamental mismatch between Glenmark’s cost structure and the revenue profile of specialty drugs. A CRO merely executes studies; it cannot create a commercial ecosystem for a novel mechanism of action. Thus, even when trials proceed on time and within budget, the downstream question—who will prescribe, who will pay—remains unanswered. The firm has become adept at managing CRO timelines but remains naïve about market access, a lacuna that becomes fatal when the molecule finally reaches the pharmacy shelf.

Partnerships as a Pragmatic Pivot

The most realistic way out of this impasse is to stop pretending Glenmark can be both a generics powerhouse and a discovery innovator. Instead, the company should reframe its discovery assets as partnership currency. Two archetypes merit consideration:

1. Co-development alliances with mid-sized biotechs that possess late-stage expertise but lack global reach. Such deals typically involve upfront cash, milestone payments, and shared commercialization rights. By limiting Glenmark’s capital at risk to pre-defined tranches, the model converts open-ended burn into option value. Recent precedents—such as Lupin partnering with Boehringer Ingelheim on diabetes molecules—show that Indian firms can retain meaningful economics while off-loading regulatory and market-access risk.

2. Platform licensing to large pharma for specific therapeutic areas. Glenmark’s respiratory and oncology platforms, while not blockbuster-ready, contain scaffolds that may interest global players seeking life-cycle extensions. A licensing deal would monetize IP today rather than gamble on NPV tomorrow. Critically, these transactions do not require Glenmark to cede manufacturing; in many cases, the partner will contract commercial supply back to Glenmark’s high-quality plants, preserving employment and utilizing existing capacity.

Both models achieve two objectives simultaneously: they inject non-dilutive cash that shores up the balance sheet, and they eliminate the need for further open-ended CRO contracts by shifting execution responsibility to better-resourced partners.

Re-centering on the Core

Partnerships, however, are only half the remedy. Glenmark must also re-commit to the competencies that once defined its edge: complex generics, differentiated formulations, and emerging-market branded generics. The global generics market is not the graveyard some analysts claim; it is bifurcating. Commodity molecules face relentless price erosion, but complex generics—such as inhalers, transdermals, and long-acting injectables—command durable margins due to technological moats and limited competition. Glenmark owns the requisite expertise in particle engineering and device development. By doubling down on these niches, it can restore cash-generation capacity without the decade-long gestation periods of novel discovery.

Similarly, branded generics in Latin America, Southeast Asia, and Africa remain under-penetrated relative to GDP growth and insurance expansion. Glenmark’s chronic-therapy portfolio (diabetes, respiratory, dermatology) aligns well with the disease burden in those regions. A disciplined geographic expansion—supported by partnerships with local distributors—can deliver double-digit growth at capital intensity far lower than building a U.S. specialty-sales force from scratch.

Governance and Signaling to the Street

For investors to believe in the pivot, Glenmark’s board must send unambiguous signals. First, cap annual discovery spend at a fixed percentage of EBITDA derived strictly from the core generics business; this ring-fences risk. Second, appoint a chief business-development officer exclusively tasked with monetizing the discovery pipeline via alliances, ensuring that licensing milestones are treated as core KPIs rather than incidental windfalls. Third, articulate a capital-allocation framework that prioritizes return on invested capital (ROIC) over top-line R&D intensity, thereby aligning management incentives with shareholder value.

Conclusion: The Virtue of Knowing One’s Limits

Strategic ambition is laudable, but it must be matched by an honest audit of capability. Glenmark’s misadventure into drug discovery is less a tale of technical failure than of organizational overreach—a cautionary example of how seductive narratives can override rational resource allocation. The firm still commands formidable strengths: cGMP manufacturing, regulatory speed in generics, and a low-cost innovation culture well-suited to complex formulations. These strengths, however, do not translate into the radically different demands of proprietary R&D. By shifting from solo discovery to partnership-centric monetization, Glenmark can stem cash burn, redeploy capital toward its proven engines of value creation, and ultimately restore the market’s confidence. In short, the company need not abandon innovation; it merely needs to innovate within the boundaries of what it already does best.

samples.prompt: Write the original essay for the following summary: The essay compares workaholics and alcoholics considering the fact that both exhibit some kind of uncontrolled desire to do what they do. The term workaholic was first mentioned by Wayne Oats in his book "confession of a workaholic" (Adrenal failure.com). Workaholism is basically addiction to work. Workahols do not find time to rest and they regard taking vacations as a waste of time and always find an excuse as to why they can. Assistant:
samples.output:
When Wayne Oats first coined the word “workaholic” in 1971, he did so with a wry, almost confessional tone, as though he had stumbled upon an unspoken epidemic. In *Confessions of a Workaholic*, he meant the neologism to be playful, yet the term landed with the dull thud of recognition. Overnight, millions who wore exhaustion as a badge discovered a label that felt half-compliment, half-diagnosis. The comparison to alcoholism was implicit in the suffix, and it has haunted the conversation ever since. Both conditions involve an ungovernable appetite, a private compulsion that masquerades as culture, personality, or even virtue. Yet the two addictions are rarely examined side by side. To do so is unsettling, because it forces us to confront the possibility that the person we praise for staying late may be suffering the same neurochemical storm that we pity in the person who cannot stop drinking.

At the biological level, workaholism and alcoholism share more than metaphor. Both behaviors stimulate the mesolimbic reward pathway, the brain’s ancient circuitry for motivation and reinforcement. In the alcoholic, ethanol increases dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens, creating a surge of pleasure that the prefrontal cortex eventually cannot regulate. In the workaholic, the dopaminergic spike is triggered not by a molecule but by a sequence of micro-achievements: an inbox zeroed, a deal closed, a compliment from the boss. The neural signature is the same—a transient high followed by craving. Functional MRI studies reveal that when chronic over-workers anticipate their next task, their reward centers light up like a Christmas tree, indistinguishable from the scans of gamblers hearing a roulette wheel spin.

Yet the cultural narratives could not be more different. Alcoholism is framed as a disease that happens to a person; workaholism is framed as a triumph that happens because of a person. The drunk is urged to surrender control, the workaholic to seize it. The Twelve Steps counsel humility; LinkedIn celebrates hustle. One is asked to apologize, the other to monetize. Society rewards the second addiction with money, status, and admiration, while quietly punishing the first with shame and isolation. The irony is that both addictions often spring from the same soil: perfectionism, childhood trauma, and an unfillable void where self-worth ought to be.

The language betrays us. We speak of “heavy drinkers” and “problem drinkers,” but we rarely call anyone a “problem worker.” Instead, we borrow the vocabulary of machines: high-performer, go-getter, grinder. The workaholic internalizes these labels and accelerates. Where the alcoholic wakes up with a hangover, the workaholic wakes up with a to-do list already scrolling like credits on a screen. Both feel a surge of relief when the next dose arrives: the first sip, the first glance at email. The difference is that nobody stages an intervention for someone who answers messages at 3 a.m. In fact, the behavior is more likely to be quoted in a performance review.

Consider the rituals. The alcoholic hides bottles in the garage; the workaholic hides spreadsheets on the phone. Both learn to lie fluently. “Just one more drink” becomes “Just one more quick call.” Both grow adept at compartmentalization. The drunk separates the bar stool from the dinner table; the workaholic cordons off a Slack channel from the bedtime story. Each lie is a brick in a wall erected between the self and the people who love it. Families adapt or fracture. Children of alcoholics remember the smell of gin at noon; children of workaholics remember the glow of a laptop at midnight. Both inherit a sense that love is conditional on performance—whether sobriety or sales figures.

Even the concept of rock bottom is inverted. For the alcoholic, rock bottom is external: a DUI, a pink slip, a hospital bed. For the workaholic, rock bottom is internal and invisible: adrenal glands so exhausted they no longer produce cortisol, a heart arrhythmia detected during a routine checkup that was squeezed between two conference calls. The body whispers before it screams, but the office noise cancels the whisper. When the alcoholic finally crashes, society offers rehab. When the workaholic crashes, society offers a corner office with a treadmill desk. We mistake the collapse of a human for the ascension of a career.

Vacation is the litmus test. The alcoholic may drink on the beach, but the workaholic cannot even find the beach. Studies by the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health found that one in four workers check email at least once an hour while on vacation; 11 % never disable notifications at all. The workaholic does not merely refuse rest; rest actively terrifies. Unstructured time becomes a hall of mirrors where unmet needs and unspoken anxieties shout their names. Wayne Oats himself admitted that he scheduled dentist appointments during family holidays “just to have something productive to do.” The mouth opens for a cleaning while the soul winces at its own reflection.

Then there is the question of harm. Alcoholism’s toll is tallied in cirrhosis statistics and drunk-driving fatalities; workaholism’s toll is subtler but no less lethal. Japanese has a word for it—karōshi, death from overwork. The Ministry of Health logs hundreds of such deaths every year: strokes at 3 a.m., suicides after 100-hour weeks, cardiac arrest in cubicles. In the United States, the American Institute of Stress estimates that job pressure costs industry $300 billion annually in absenteeism, turnover, and medical expenses. Yet we rarely treat the cause; instead, we install nap pods and meditation apps, like putting a bandage on a hemorrhage.

Recovery, too, reveals the kinship. The first step in Alcoholics Anonymous is to admit powerlessness; the first step in Workaholics Anonymous (yes, it exists) is to admit that productivity is not the same as worth. Both fellowships teach solitude without isolation, achievement without identity. Both demand a daily inventory: Where did I reach for the bottle of Busch or the bottle of adrenaline? Both require amends—to children for missed recitals, to partners for distracted dinners. In both rooms, tears are common, because grief is the final solvent for compulsion.

Perhaps the most poignant parallel lies in the moment of awakening. The alcoholic sits on the bathroom floor, staring at the porcelain, and realizes the drink is no longer a friend but a captor. The workaholic sits on the edge of the hotel bed in a city whose name was forgotten in boarding group C, opens the mini-bar, and realizes the emails are no longer a lifeline but a leash. In that moment, both understand that what felt like freedom was, in fact, the most exacting prison ever constructed: one whose bars are made not of steel but of stories—stories about who we must be in order to be enough.

Wayne Oats died at his desk at 3:15 on a Tuesday afternoon, a half-finished sermon glowing on his monitor. The coroner noted “cardiac arrest due to hypertensive heart disease,” and the obituary praised his tireless dedication. Few readers paused to wonder whether the dedication had, in the end, devoured the man. Alcoholics get funerals where speakers whisper about the disease. Workaholics get funerals where the eulogy becomes another KPI: He answered every email within five minutes. May we be so diligent.

But diligence is not the same as devotion. Devotion knows when to stop. Devotion can sit still on a Sunday afternoon and feel no earthquake beneath the chair. Devotion can stand at the edge of the inbox and not dive in. The workaholic and the alcoholic both stand on the same cliff, staring into the same abyss: the unquiet self. One tries to fill it with spirits; the other with spreadsheets. Both discover, sooner or later, that the abyss does not want to be filled. It wants to be seen.

samples.prompt: Create the inputted essay that provided the following summary: The text discusses the recent political changes in South Sudan, including the dissolution of the parliament and the formation of a new lower house of parliament. In addition, the text discusses the active hostilities between different communities in South Sudan, which has led to people's deaths. The text also mentions the climatic conditions in South Sudan, which have forced residents to leave their homes.. Assistant:
samples.output:
When the sun rose over Juba on the morning of 15 August 2022, South Sudan’s political horizon looked dramatically different from the day before. President Salva Kiir Mayardit, exercising powers granted by the Revitalised Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan (R-ARCSS), dissolved the Transitional National Legislative Assembly that had governed since 2016 and swore in a new, expanded lower house in a single televised ceremony. The decision was not merely procedural; it was the culmination of two years of wrangling over ministerial quotas, security arrangements, and the arithmetic of power-sharing. Overnight, 550 legislators became 650, the additional seats carved out to accommodate disgruntled opposition groups that had threatened to return to the bush unless given chairs, salaries, and, most importantly, votes inside the chamber.  

Yet, even as the national anthem played over the State House lawn, the symbolism of the moment collided with the grim realities outside the capital. In Jonglei State, cattle raids between Murle and Lou Nuer communities had left 91 people dead in the preceding fortnight, their bodies still unburied along the Pibor River. In Warrap, a dispute over an unpaid dowry spiralled into three days of ambushes that killed 28 and displaced 3,700. These episodes are no longer isolated flashpoints; they are the punctuation marks in a narrative of chronic communal conflict that has outlived every ceasefire signed in Addis Ababa, Khartoum, and Rome. The United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) recorded a 92-percent increase in civilian casualties from inter-communal violence between January and July 2022 compared to the same period the previous year. The new parliament has promised “robust legislation” to curb the cycles of revenge, but lawmakers must first survive the drive from the airport to the parliamentary precinct, a journey that now requires a military escort after two MPs were wounded by stray bullets last May.  

The violence is compounded by a climate crisis that no peace accord anticipated. South Sudan is experiencing its fourth consecutive year of extreme flooding, a phenomenon scientists link to warming Indian Ocean surface temperatures and the Indian Ocean Dipole. In 2021, the White Nile and its tributaries burst their banks, submerging 80 percent of Unity State’s cropland and turning towns like Bentiu into islands accessible only by canoe. The 2022 rainy season has already exceeded historical averages; by mid-August, the Sudd wetlands had expanded by 40 percent, swallowing entire villages in Jonglei and Upper Nile. People fleeing waterlogged homes add a second layer to the already staggering displacement statistics: 2.2 million South Sudanese are internally displaced, and another 2.3 million shelter in neighbouring Sudan, Uganda, Ethiopia, and Kenya. Climate-induced migration is now inseparable from conflict-induced migration; cattle herders move southward to escape floods only to collide with farming communities guarding shrinking arable land, stoking the very raiding culture the R-ARCSS hoped to demobilise.  

International actors have responded with familiar pledges and familiar frustration. The United States condemned the parliament’s dissolution as “a unilateral step that undermines the spirit of the peace agreement,” but has channelled USD 1 billion in humanitarian assistance this fiscal year, much of it air-dropped sacks of sorghum to unreachable flood victims. The African Union dispatched a three-person panel to “facilitate dialogue among signatories,” yet the panel’s flights were twice rerouted because the Juba runway was waterlogged. China, traditionally interested in South Sudan’s oil concessions, quietly funded dykes along the Nile tributaries near the Paloich oilfields, protecting infrastructure but not people. NGOs such as Médecins Sans Frontières report that cholera, malaria, and acute watery diarrhoea are now endemic in the displacement camps, where one latrine serves an average of 312 individuals.  

Domestically, the reconstituted parliament faces an immediate test that could shape its legitimacy. The R-ARCSS mandates the enactment of a permanent constitution within 24 months, but deadlines have already slipped twice. The drafting process must reconcile 1,500 submissions from civil society, 800 from traditional authorities, and 200 from diaspora groups—documents that range from calls for a federal system to demands for Islamic law in the predominantly Muslim north. Meanwhile, legislators must also ratify a fiscal budget that allocates 40 percent of revenue to security services while inflation runs at 21 percent and the national currency trades at record lows against the dollar. The arithmetic is brutal: every additional soldier on the payroll is a teacher or nurse that will not be hired.  

Civil society leaders warn that the new parliament risks becoming a theatre of elite bargaining rather than a forum for addressing grassroots crises. “We have more MPs than functioning hospitals,” remarked Edmund Yakani, director of the Community Empowerment for Progress Organisation (CEPO), at a press briefing. His quip captured the widening gulf between the capital’s political choreography and the lived experience of citizens. In Rumbek, a town just 300 kilometres northwest of Juba, a mother recently walked 17 kilometres through flooded grassland to reach a clinic only to find it shuttered for lack of fuel to run the generator. Her story, relayed by local radio, has become emblematic of a state whose institutions are dissolving faster than they are being rebuilt.  

Yet there are fragments of cautious optimism. The new speaker of the reconstituted parliament, Jemma Nunu Kumba, is the first woman to hold the position and has pledged to prioritise legislation on women’s land rights—a reform that could mitigate some of the herder-farmer clashes. A pilot disarmament programme in Tonj, funded jointly by the World Bank and the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), has collected 2,300 small arms without triggering the retaliatory violence that doomed similar initiatives in 2006 and 2015. And in the Bentiu displacement camp, a youth-led cooperative has started turning plastic flood debris into interlocking bricks for transitional shelters, an innovation that earned a modest grant from the UN Development Programme.  

The international community’s dilemma is how to support such micro-initiatives without enabling macro-paralysis. Western diplomats privately admit that imposing fresh sanctions on South Sudanese elites could further depress the very economy that ordinary citizens rely on. Instead, they are exploring “conditionality by instalment,” releasing budget-support funds only when the parliament passes specific benchmarks—starting with a fiscal transparency bill and a climate-adaptation strategy. Whether that approach will survive the next round of brinkmanship remains uncertain.  

What is certain is that South Sudan’s future will be forged not in the marble corridors of Juba’s Freedom Hall but in the muddy floodplains and cattle camps where people confront the daily calculus of survival. The new parliament has convened, but the rivers are still rising, the raiders still ride at night, and the ground beneath both politics and people continues to shift.

samples.prompt: Write the full essay for the following summary: Amazon.com has been able to maintain its position as a leading online retailer for books by pursuing other product lines including "1-Click ordering and zShops". These shopping devices eased shopping by offering shoppers more information since categorization of products has been made possible. In addition, 1-Click payment feature for instance offers recommendations on books or music which may be related to the customer's search. This has eventually led to an increase in value.. Assistant:
samples.output:
Amazon.com’s twenty-five-year journey from an online bookstore to a planetary bazaar is not a story of drifting with the currents of e-commerce, but of repeatedly widening the river itself.  At each juncture in which observers predicted plateau or decline—when big-box chains launched rival sites, when the dot-com bubble burst, when smartphones shrank the screen to pocket size—Amazon has widened its moat by simultaneously deepening customer intimacy and expanding the universe of products it is willing to sell.  Two once-novel devices, 1-Click ordering and zShops, serve as the clearest signposts of the strategy that has allowed the company to remain the leading destination for books while quietly becoming the everything store.

When Jeff Bezos incorporated Cadabra in 1994, the commercial Internet was still an academic curiosity.  Books were the perfect test product: millions of unique titles, low unit price, non-perishable, and already catalogued by the major wholesalers.  But Bezos never intended to stop at books.  The early branding decision to christen the company “Amazon” after the world’s largest river signaled an ambition to carry more than paper and ink.  The challenge was how to scale without eroding the trust and convenience that had lured readers in the first place.  The solution came in two iterative waves: first, the removal of friction from the act of buying; second, the removal of boundaries from the act of selling.

1-Click ordering, patented in 1997 and deployed site-wide in 1999, appears in hindsight almost quaint: a single button that completes a purchase using a pre-stored address and credit card.  Yet its psychological impact was revolutionary.  Traditional e-commerce funnels required six to eight clicks and as many forms.  Each step was a moment in which the customer could reconsider, compare prices, or simply abandon the cart.  By compressing the funnel to one decisive tap, Amazon transformed impulse from liability into asset.  Early studies conducted by the company showed that 1-Click lifted conversion rates by as much as 5 percent—a seismic shift in a sector where margins often live or die on single-digit improvements.  More subtly, 1-Click retrained consumer expectations.  Once a shopper experienced the narcotic ease of instantaneous gratification on Amazon, every other site felt clunky.
